DOC.HEAD: Richards Blasts Uattributed Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards on Thursday denounced an unattributed allegation that she was in a restroom where several women appeared to be smoking marijuana almost 11 years ago. ``Do you think this country has reached the point now ... that unsubstantiated people can say what they want to and suddenly it takes on the vein of truth by appearing on television and in the newspapers?'' Ms. Richards said at a campaign stop in Dallas. The state treasurer blamed her runoff opponent in Tuesday's primary election, Attorney General Jim Mattox, for spreading rumors about drug use. Mattox has said he possesses sworn statements from people who say they know Ms. Richards used illegal drugs in the past. But Mattox repeatedly has refused to reveal the names of those people or offer any other evidence to back up his accusations. The Houston Post on Thursday quoted a woman it didn't identify as saying she had seen Ms. Richards with a group of women in the restroom of an Austin hotel during the National Association of Women in Construction convention in 1979. The woman, who refused to tell her story unless guaranteed her name not be used, told the Post, ``When you walked in the door you could smell the definite aroma of marijuana. ``When I walked in (Ms. Richards) put her hand behind her and held it. The girl on the end, who I did not know, had a roach or a joint that had been smoked down in her hand,'' the woman told the newspaper. The Post report said the woman felt compelled to recount the incident after watching Ms. Richards refuse during televised debates to answer yes or no to the question of whether she had ever used illegal drugs. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, has said she has not had an alcoholic drink nor a mood-altering chemical in 10 years. Asked about the alleged 1979 incident, the state treasurer said, ``I have no idea what they're talking about.'' Ms. Richards said Thursday she was shocked the allegations had been reported. ``The surprising part is that now people are willing to put it in print, with no substantiation at all. That's not what this country is all about,'' she said. At a Thursday campaign stop in Lubbock, Mattox said he promised confidentiality to people who alleged Ms. Richards has used drugs. He also refused again to release his income tax records, as Ms. Richards has requested, unless she releases her medical records. When asked why, he said, ``Because I intend to win this campaign, and I choose the playing fields and I choose the methods by which we are going to play this game. That just happens to be the way politics work.'' Mattox has repeatedly said he expects to win the runoff and face Republican Clayton Williams in November. Releasing his income taxes when Williams hasn't done so would give Williams a signficant advantage, Mattox said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Proposes Unusual Plan To Repair Eastern Europe's Environment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: An unusual financial arrangement devised to promote conservation in the Third World could help Eastern Europe begin to repair its badly damaged environment, a U.S. lawmaker says. Rep. John LaFalce, D-N.Y., has proposed in a letter to President Bush that the United States initiate so-called debt-for-nature swaps with Eastern Europe to clean up what LaFalce said could be ``the final and longest lasting legacy of the Stalinist period.'' Under his proposal, the Eastern European countries' debts to the United States would be forgiven in exchange for their commitment to redirect the savings to cleaning up their environment. LaFalce also proposed that a multinational environmental trust fund be set up for Eastern Europe. ``The problems seem to be very severe,'' said Peter Preuss, a toxicologist at the Environmental Protection Agency who recently visited Poland and Hungary. Preuss explained, for example, that the water in the Vistula River at Krakow, Poland is not only undrinkable, it's too dirty for industrial use. ``It is so salty and acid that the industries along the river can't even use it for cooling water,'' Preuss said. Levels of air pollutants are ``many times higher, tens of times higher'' than anything found in the United States, he said. In the small blackened town of Copsa Mica, Romania, every building, tree and patch of ground is covered with soot and dust from factories that dye rubber and produce nonferrous metals. In January, LaFalce, a senior member of the House Banking Committee and chairman of the House Committee on Small Business, led a congressional delegation to Yugoslavia, Poland, East Germany, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. The plan was to discuss trade, investment and business with Eastern European officials, but ``intruding into our discussions of all these issues was the problem of environmental degradation,'' LaFalce said. ``On our trip to central Europe we saw great hope and great expectations,'' he said in his letter to the president. ``But we also saw polluted rivers and the dull, gray, hazy hues of polluted skies ... ``Indeed, the problems are daunting and can barely be exaggerated,'' he wrote. In the Upper Silesia region of Poland, researchers have observed an increase in mental retardation because of metal particulates in the air. Life expectancy is decreasing in Hungary, and mothers are protesting about the respiratory problems that polluted air is causing their children, LaFalce said. LaFalce's staff said legislation to provide for the debt swaps and the trust fund, to be administered by the new Central European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, will be introduced in April. Debt swaps for conservation have been used to encourage Third World countries to establish nature preserves and to devote resources to conservation. The first such swap was executed in July 1987 by a Washington environmental organization called Conservation International, which purchased and forgave $650,000 of Bolivia's foreign debt in exchange for the establishment of a wildlife preserve. The arrangement has been widely imitated by other environmental groups. Poland's foreign debt is about $40 billion, of which $3 billion is owed to the United States. Poland has not made any payments on the debt in recent years, LaFalce said. Hungary, on the other hand, owes most of its outside debt to commercial banks, not governments, LaFalce said. If governments forgive debt to finance environmental clean-up projects, banks might do the same, he said. He has proposed that up to $20 billion be put into an environmental trust fund under the auspices of the Central European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. About 10 percent of that, or $2 billion, would come from the United States. The encouragement of environmental clean-up projects in Eastern Europe could benefit American business, LaFalce said. ``Businesses in the United States have the experience and technology needed to deal with these problems,'' he said. ``Therefore, they could expect to play a leading role in establishing the necessary water and sewage treatment and other facilities required to solve the problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Plane Down in Western Louisiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT to `Bexar County,' sted `Bexar.'
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force A-10A Thunderbolt II attack plane crashed in woods in western Louisiana durinng a combat training mission Thursday, killing the pilot, England Air Force Base officials said. The plane went down around 1:30 p.m. in rural Sabine Parish between the towns of Negreet and Florien, state police said. The pilot was identified as 1st Lt. Michael N. Ayotte, 24, of Bexar County, Texas. Ayotte was attached to the 75th Tactical Fighter Squadron of the 23rd Tactical Fighter Wing at the central Louisiana air base, an Air Force news release said. The cause of the crash was not immediately known. The Air Force said the crash would be investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Episcopal School Found Negligent in Mount Hood Tragedy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Sixteen-year-old Richie ...,' with 5 grafs to CORRECT victim's name to `Richard Jr.,' sted `Richie,' UPDATE with comment by father, no-comment from school Summers; picks up 4th graf, `The lawsuit ...'
DOC.TEXT: A private school as negligent in the death of a teen-age student during a school-sponsored climb of Mount Hood in 1986 that claimed nine lives, and should pay the boy's father $500,000, a jury decided Thursday. But the Multonomah County Circuit Court jury cleared mountain guide Ralph Summers of negligence for his part in helping lead the 13-member Oregon Episcopal School party up the mountain. Sixteen-year-old Richard Haeder Jr. was one of the nine who died after the group became lost in a blizzard during the May 1986 climb. Summers was among the four who survived. The verdict on the lawsuit by Haeder's father, Richard, came after about five hours of deliberations. ``I'm happy to have justice done,'' the elder Haeder said after the verdict. ``If nothing else comes out of this, it is that my son did not die in vain.'' Haeder said much of the $500,000 award would go toward creating scholarships or other funds to honor his son. ``It isn't the money,'' he said ``I wanted everyone to know those deaths were needless.'' Neither Summers nor representatives of the school would comment. The lawsuit accused the school and Summers of negligence in planning and carrying out the trip. The climbers tried to reach the top of the 11,235-foot mountain in deteriorating weather, got lost in the blizzard as they retreated and had to build a snow cave for shelter as the sun set. The next morning, Summers and a student hiked to safety and notified authorities. The snow cave wasn't marked, however, and authorities searched for two days before they found it. Of the nine students and two faculty members inside, only two teen-agers survived. The jury began deliberating about 2 p.m. after closing arguments in the case. Haeder's attorney, Paul Luvera, told jurors, ``They were leading a group of schoolchildren up a mountain for no good reason. This wasn't a group of mountain climbers; they were schoolchildren. ``Richie was crying; he wanted to go back and they kept going,'' Luvera said. ``And then he died a horrible painful death with people dying all around him in a tomb made of ice.'' Calling the lawsuit Richard and Judith Haeder's ``final eulogy'' to their son, Luvera asked that jurors award them $2.76 million. Luvera said evidence and testimony in the case showed Summers didn't follow a correct compass bearing or use a map while descending the mountain through a snowstorm. ``They were lost coming down, lost when they dug the snow cave, and lost the next day when they went for help,'' he said. He also said Summers told inconsistent stories about who was leading the climb, he or the Rev. Thomas Goman. Both men failed to adequately respect the weather, and went too far up the mountain, he said. Attorney Mark Wagner, representing Summers and the school, told the jury to remember the storm that struck the mountain was three times stronger than had been predicted. ``People died because a storm came in before our people got off the mountain,'' he said. ``In the real world, accidents do happen and it doesn't mean people are negligent or at fault.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Issue Surfaces With a Twist in Pennsylvania Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: The Pennsylvania governor's race is tipping conventional political wisdom on its ear when it comes to the issue of abortion. Democratic Gov. Robert P. Casey is an unyielding foe of abortion, contrary to his national party platform. Casey's chief Republican challenger, state Auditor General Barbara Hafer, is firmly pro-choice, a position that puts her at odds with the GOP national platform. While leaders of both parties say they can accommodate people on both sides of the issue, a Casey-Hafer contest could test the loyalties of many rank-and-file members in both parties. ``It's a difficult one for me,'' said Natalie Schmoyer, a marketing consultant and pro-choice Democrat from suburban Philadelphia. ``I feel very strongly about the choice issue, but I'm also a Democrat who votes for Democrats. ... It's a hard choice.'' Casey's and Hafer's views on abortion have attracted two more candidates to the gubernatorial race, an anti-abortion Republican and a pro-choice Democrat campaigning almost exclusively on the abortion issue. The Republican, 34-year-old Marguerite Luksik, has done little campaigning but said she felt compelled to run because no one else came forward to challenge Hafer's pro-choice stand. ``Sometimes I think that not defending your principles is the worst thing you can do,'' said Mrs. Luksik, who runs a home day care program for single parents. ``Then it looks like you really don't believe in them.'' Pro-choice Democrat Phil Berg, a 45-year-old lawyer, said Casey's opposition to abortion is the only reason he decided to challenge the governor. Berg, who calls himself ``the conscience of our party,'' thinks Hafer will have a good shot at becoming governor if she and Casey face off in November. ``We're in uncharted territory,'' said G. Terry Madonna, director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville University of Pennsylvania. Madonna expects Casey, 58, and Hafer, 46, to win their respective primaries on May 15, but he said the contests could become a barometer of public sentiment on abortion. ``The test will be whether the pro-life supporters can energize their forces for Luksik,'' Madonna said. ``There's no doubt that the pro-choice people have galvanized and energized their forces.'' While Casey signed into law one of the nation's most restrictive abortion laws last year, and the state Legislature is overwhelmingly anti-abortion, surveys show many voters lean the other way. A recent poll commissioned by Hafer found 50 percent of those surveyed felt a woman should have the right to have an abortion, while 9 percent said abortion should be illegal in all cases. About 14 percent of the respondents favored abortion only if the mother's life was in danger and another 26 percent said abortion should be allowed if the mother was in danger and in cases of rape or incest. The telephone survey of 800 registered voters was done in mid-March by Michigan-based Market Opinion Research and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. Patrick Killian, Hafer's campaign manager, said the results were encouraging because they indicate abortion will be ``the wild card in the race.'' Killian's counterpart in the Casey camp, James Carville, said the results could not be interpreted as support for Hafer because not all pro-choice voters would support her. Carville said the same caveat applied to the pro-choice candidacy of Berg in the Democratic primary. ``I believe in Pennsylvania the vast majority of Democrats and the vast majority of Republicans see abortion as only one issue,'' Carville said. ``It isn't going to be just an election on abortion.'' The abortion issue aside, Casey is a popular first-term incumbent who is credited with keeping his state's finances stable while many neighboring states run deficits. Hafer's campaign has gone through a rough stretch in which she was criticized for calling Casey a ``redneck Irishman from Scranton,'' antagonizing blacks with her comments about a black state prisons chief and charging personal and political expenses to the state.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Strike Not Grabbing Much Attention in Congress
DOC.TEXT: Labor's traditional allies in Congress are steering clear of the Greyhound strike because bus passengers don't carry political clout and lawmakers are skittish about taking sides in the violent dispute, legislators and others say. ``Members of Congress fly in airplanes _ they don't ride buses. These passengers tend to be poor folks who are not active politically,'' said Rep. Tom Downey, D-N.Y. Democrats who sometimes take the lead on labor issues also said President Bush's hands-off approach to such disputes _ he vetoed a union-backed plan to help settle the Eastern Airlines strike _ has inhibited lawmakers from jumping into the fray. Congress historically has sat on the sidelines for months before injecting itself in labor-management disputes, and neither Greyhound nor striking drivers who walked out five weeks ago has asked Congress to intervene. Still, there has been no flurry of floor speeches on the strike, which has been marked by shootings and bomb threats and has choked transportation in small communities around the country. One House member's call for hearings has gone unheeded. Several lawmakers have written to Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner asking for help. Last year, Mrs. Dole intervened in the Pittston coal strike by appointing a ``supermediator'' who helped reach a settlement for Appalachian miners. Mrs. Dole believes her involvement in the Greyhound walkout would be premature because federal mediators are working on the matter, said spokeswoman Dale Tate. Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 of its office and maintenance workers walked out March 2 over wages and job security. The company, which operates the only nationwide bus system, has been running on a reduced schedule since then, using replacements and union members who cross picket lines. Officials of both Greyhound and the striking Amalgamated Transit Union say Congress might be paying closer attention if middle- or high-income Americans used buses. ``If this were happening to airplanes, it would be in every politician's speech, in every headline,'' said Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey. Added union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson: ``These people aren't spending their spare time writing letters to the editor; they're not making long distance phone calls to Congress demanding action.'' Nelson said that although the strike isn't on the top of Congress' agenda, lawmakers helped persuade the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Bernard E. DeLury, to personally involve himself in negotiations. ``This is the best we can expect from the government at this point,'' Nelson said, adding that ``arm waving and standing on desktops'' wouldn't accomplish a resumption of talks. The company has refused to return to the bargaining table until a week goes by without any acts of violence. Rep. Nick Rahall, D-W.Va., has called for the House Public Works and Transportation Committee to hold hearings on the strike, but without success. ``There should be a higher level of consciousness about it,'' Rahall complained. Hearings would ``put pressure on both sides to sit down and engage in collective bargaining and work toward an agreement ... I think we should discuss overall safety concerns and say, `Hey, we are in an emergency here.''' Downey said the violent nature of the strike also has kept lawmakers quiet. Along with sniper attacks, bomb threats and brick-throwing incidents, one striker was crushed to death by a bus driven by a replacement driver. On Wednesday night in Boston, a suspicious fire destroyed a bus, and later its doors were found to have been welded shut. ``There's a level of violence out there no one wants to be associated with,'' Downey said. Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., blamed Congress' reluctance on the tone Bush set with his Eastern veto. An override attempt in the House last month failed. ``I would be willing to have Congress enter tomorrow, but our entry would only create thunder'' and accomplish nothing, given the administration's stand, Williams said. ``As with Eastern, the delay by the White House and the Labor Department benefits management and not the workers. Workers are going bankrupt daily, unions are being broken and management'' seems to be surviving, Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Hubbles to Hobnob at Cape Canaveral for Telescope Launch
With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: A horde of Hubbles, Hubbells and possibly even a couple of Hubbels will descend on Kennedy Space Center next week, drawn by the shuttle launch of a space telescope that's named for one of their own. They are all relatives of the late astronomer Edwin Powell Hubble, whose discovery in the 1920s that the universe is expanding gave rise to the big-bang theory of creation. The $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, due to lift off Tuesday aboard Discovery, is a tribute and memorial to Hubble. ``Edwin's being honored by NASA, and it gives us an excuse to get together and learn a little more about things and to pass the heritage on to the next generations,'' said Harvey Hubbell IV, 60, a distant relative and retired businessman from North Palm Beach who is organizing the affair. Nearly 200 descendants of Richard Hubball, a 17th-century immigrant from England, are expected to begin to arrive this weekend. The Hubball name has changed over the generations. It doesn't matter whether someone is a cousin once, twice or even thrice removed from the astronomer; everyone is welcome, said Robert L. Hubbell, 71, president of the Hubbell Family Historical Society. The retired foreign service officer from Falls Church, Va., is bringing two grandchildren. The family reunions, held every two years (this is an off year), have tended to attract only the older generations, Hubbell said, but ``this is catching the interest in the younger generation.'' Edwin Hubble, who died at age 63 in 1953, studied the stars and galaxies during the 1920s from Mount Wilson Observatory in the San Gabriel Mountains above Pasadena, Calif. His survey revealed a much larger universe than anyone imagined. He concluded galaxies were moving away from Earth at velocities proportional to their distances, supporting the concept that the universe originated 15 billion or so years ago in a cosmic explosion known as the big bang. There were other noted family members. Harvey Hubbell's grandfather, Harvey Hubbell, invented the pull-chain electric socket and the conventional duplex wall socket. The factory he started in 1888 in Connecticut has grown into Hubbell Inc., a Fortune 500 company. There was Carl Owen Hubbell, the Hall of Fame pitcher who played for the New York Giants from 1928 through 1943. John Lorenzo Hubbell established his first trading post on the Navajo reservation in northeastern Arizona in 1876. The nearly 400 members of the Hubbell Family Historical Society aren't the only ones with reason to be proud. Relatives from Edwin Hubble's mother's side also plan to attend the reunion and launch. Lena James Jump, 75, a third cousin on his mother's side, will be there with her three sisters. National Aeronautics and Space Administration representatives will meet with the family Monday. The next morning, chartered buses will take the group to a special viewing area at Kennedy Space Center, provided the launch is on time. A pool party is planned for Tuesday afternoon, followed by a tour of the space center on Wednesday and a luncheon at nearby Patrick Air Force Base on Thursday. The astronomer's closest living relatives _ two sisters _ aren't coming. Helen Hubble Lane, 91, and Betsy Hubble, 85, are in ill health and will be watching televised coverage from their homes in El Paso, Texas. The astronomer's wife, Grace, died in 1974, and the couple had no children. Three other sisters and two brothers are dead.

DOC.HEAD: Tiananmen Square Reopens Under Heavy Guard
DOC.TEXT: Tiananmen Square reopened to the public today, but police remained on guard to stop any attempt to mourn protesters killed last year when soldiers stormed the square to crush the pro-democracy movement. The vast plaza was cordoned off on Thursday for the Qingming festival, an annual holiday when Chinese honor their dead. Overseas dissidents, through facsimile transmissions and mailed leaflets, had urged Beijing residents to stroll through Tiananmen on Qingming in memory of those killed in the military crackdown last June. But officials cordoned off the square and held ceremonies in which 13,000 young people paid homage to China's revolutionary heritage and pledged allegiance to its socialist system. Officials also closed the square for official ceremonies on April 1, another day targeted by overseas activists for silent protest marches through the symbolic center of last spring's democracy movement. Schools and factories have warned young people to stay away from Tiananmen and told them they face punishment if caught involved in any kind of protest. Police continued to maintain a heavy presence around the 100-acre square today. Police vehicles were parked at strategic points, and dozens of officers were on patrol. The monument to revolutionary martyrs in the center of the square, normally open to the public, was closed. About a dozen police officers stood around the monument's perimeter and on its steps, and another 10 officers sat nearby. The next key anniversary will be April 15, the day former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang, a popular reformist, died. His death touched off the demonstrations for democratic reform that continued until the June 3-4 military attack on the city that left hundreds, and perhaps thousands, dead.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Lawyers Head Home After Observing US Legal System
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen Soviet lawyers who have watched the upheaval in their country from afar for the past seven months are heading home today with plenty of ideas for more changes. Some want to help handicapped children and improve Soviet justice. Another hopes his Soviet rock star client will make American audiences forget Madonna. The 17 are the first to participate in an American Bar Association program that placed them as interns in U.S. law firms, law schools and government offices. ``We believe these 17, each selected for having a spark of idealism, will be among the leading players in the continuing debate on Soviet reforms,'' said Steven Raikin, the program's director. The Soviet visitors, in their early 30s, said there is a lot to like here but found flaws in the American system they do not want to duplicate back in the Soviet Union. After declaring that the adoption of children in the United States ``works 10 times better than in the Soviet Union,'' Olga Djujeva frowned while assessing the American juvenile court system. ``It works badly because it is structurally and financially weak,'' she said. ``This is not how we are going to do it in the USSR.'' Ms. Djujeva, a Moscow State University teacher who specializes in family law and children's rights, said her experiences at the law schools of Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., and Valparaiso University in Indiana have given her ``a renewed commitment to change things.'' ``We have no foster parenting in the Soviet Union. We someday will. And handicapped children _ we do not see them because they are in special institutions. In this country, handicapped children are part of your open society.'' The ABA program, funded by the New York-based Soros Foundation and other private donors, was created in anticipation of the growing opportunities for joint Soviet-American business and to foster mutual understanding between lawyers in both countries. ``We learned as much about the Soviet system as these 17 kids learned about ours,'' Raikin said. ``Historically, Soviet lawyers have not occupied a major role in their society. In the last couple of years, however, there's been an explosion of interest among Soviet lawyers to play a larger role.'' Raikin added: ``The next couple of years will be crucial. Everything's up for grabs right now, the whole legal reform agenda.'' Up for grabs also are potentially lucrative business contacts between East and West, a fact not lost on Valentin Blueger, who has tried to steer his practice in Latvia to entertainment and international law. Blueger spent his time with the Nashville law firm that represents the Grand Ole Opry, an experience he says will help him better represent Soviet rock star Laima Vaikule. ``She's like your Madonna,'' Blueger said of the singer who has sold 20 million records in the Soviet Union and is trying to make her mark in the U.S. market. ``The potential is great,'' says Blueger with a laugh at the mention of several Soviet athletes now playing in the National Basketball Association. Raikin said the Soviet economy ``is in desperate need of foreign investment, but not many Soviets know how to facilitate such deals. Valentin is a natural deal-maker.'' Irene Mashlenko, an employee of the Soviet Ministry of Justice in Moscow, split her time in the United States between the staffs of a state attorney in Montgomery County, Md., and a defense lawyer. ``After seeing both sides, I now think that your system of punishment is very severe, the terms of imprisonment for non-violent crimes are too long.'' But one of the most recent criminal trials Mashlenko sat through ended in acquittal, giving her ``the best evidence that the U.S. system of justice is really a just system.'' Nearly 200 Soviet lawyers applied for the program, and more than 100 U.S. law firms and law schools applied to become hosts. A new competition will begin in June, ending with the selection next fall of 30 new interns.

DOC.HEAD: New Amazon Nature Reserve Expected To Draw `Ecotourists'
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: An Amazonian nature reserve the size of Connecticut could become an important tourist attraction, helping to show Third World countries they can make more money saving forests than logging them, conservationists say. The Tambo Pata-Candamo Reserve in a remote, nearly uninhabited Amazon valley has among the highest numbers of rare and exotic birds and animals of any area in the world, said Charles Munn, an ornithologist with Wildlife Conservation International in New York. Set aside as a reserve, the park could help promote ``ecotourism'' as a means for Third World nations to profit from their wilderness areas without destroying them, Munn said. Before being declared a park Feb. 17, the area covered by the 3.7-million-acre reserve had been drawing about 9,000 tourists a year, generating $2 million annually for Peru. ``This area can be self-sustaining immediately if they enact a gate fee of even $5 a day per visitor,'' Munn said. ``This is unusual. It could simply live off of gate receipts.'' About one out of every eight species of birds in the world is found in Tambo Pata, Munn said in an interview Tuesday. ``In three square miles of southeastern Peru, you can see 560 species, which is a world record,'' he said. ``You can see 330 in one day. Which is not bad.'' All of Canada and the United States have only about 830 species. Among the Peruvian birds are eight species of brightly colored macaws, the world's largest and most endangered parrots. They congregate in great wildlife spectacles around ``macaw licks,'' where they eat clay to help digest their food. The reserve is also home to the endangered, 6-foot-long giant otter, which travels in family packs and eats anacondas, among other delicacies. The park has ``white-water rafting that will knock your socks off,'' Munn said. Peru announced last month the establishment of a 1-million-acre reserve, Kugapakori-Nahua Indian Reserve, to protect the Kugapakori and Nahua Indians, who remain out of contact with civilization, Munn said. ``If you go in there, they kill you,'' said Munn. ``So you don't go in there.'' The two new reserves are near the Manu Biosphere Reserve, an even larger park roughly the size of Massachusetts. This area of Peru is not among those affected by guerrilla and cocaine trafficking violence, Munn said. ``I take my family down with me, including two young children,'' he said. ``Peru has a fantastic system of parks and reserves on paper,'' said Adrian Forsyth, a tropical ecologist with Conservation International in Washington, D.C. ``If they can just get the support needed to have them operate, I think conservation in Peru will be in pretty good shape.'' The Tambo Pata-Candamo Reserve, located north of the city of Puerto Maldonado, about 500 miles southeast of Lima, covers a varied landscape in the Andes foothills ranging from lowland tropical rain forest to mist-shrouded cloud forest at elevations up to 10,000 feet. Besides its spectacular bird population, it contains half again as many trees as any other region in the Amazon, Munn said. And it is virtually untouched. ``The important thing here is there are basically no people living in this entire area,'' said Munn. ``It is the last big valley in entire western Amazon that has no people living in it.'' Peru is also considering setting aside several million additional acres of rubber and brazil-nut forest in the area adjacent to the part of Brazil where Francisco ``Chico'' Mendes, an environmental activist and rubber tapper, was murdered in December 1988, Munn said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Delegations Off to Soviet Union, Middle East
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, and six Democratic colleagues are off to the Soviet Union today for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Lithuania is sure to be on the agenda when the senators see Gorbachev and other Soviet officials. While the group intends to talk with leaders of the Baltic republics in Leningrad before they head to Moscow, Mitchell said they won't try to cross into Lithuania, which is trying to secede from the Soviet Union. Mitchell said Thursday that he and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., had been assured by visiting Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze that the Soviets want to solve the Lithuanian situation by negotiation and dialogue. ``They have concluded as a matter of policy that a process that does not involve the use of force is in their best interest,'' Mitchell said. Dole said the senators warned Shevardnadze that Congress might retaliate against Moscow with trade sanctions and other economic pressures if Gorbachev uses further military force in seeking to quell the Lithuanian independence movement. ``I've got to believe they clearly understand there's going to be a big gap here in our relationship if something happens in Lithuania or Estonia or any other republic,'' Dole said. ``Congress, if anything happens, is going to go off on its own.'' And Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., urged President Bush to take action in support of the Lithuanians and to ``make the U.S. position clear'' to Shevardnadze. Mitchell said the congressional delegation will travel to Berlin before going to the Soviet Union. The group returns April 14. Traveling with Mitchell are Democratic Sens. Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, Wyche Fowler of Georgia, John Glenn of Ohio, Jim Sasser of Tennessee and Paul Sarbanes of Maryland. Meantime, Dole is taking four Republican senators and a lone Democrat _ Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, on a swing through the Middle East. The contingent intends to visit Syria, Egypt, Jordan and Israel during the congressional Easter recess that ends April 18. Dole, who recently angered the Israelis with calls to reduce the amount of money they receive in aid from the United States, said his message will be ``Let's get some peace in the Middle East.'' ``Everywhere else in the world, peace is breaking out except in this troubled region,'' he said. ``We want to see more progress and we want to see more talking and negotiations.'' Meetings are planned with President Hafez Assad of Syria, top Israeli leaders Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Shamir, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan. Others on the trip are Sens. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo.; James McClure, R-Idaho; Charles Grassley, R-Iowa; and Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Propose $3 Tax Checkoff for Federal Campaigns
LaserPhoto W7
DOC.TEXT: Taxpayers could elect to check off $3 instead of the current $1 on their income tax returns to finance federal election campaigns under a new public funding proposal by three Democratic senators. Sens. John Kerry of Massachusetts, Joseph Biden of Delaware and Bill Bradley of New Jersey, all seeking re-election this year, introduced a bill Thursday to expand public financing of presidential campaigns to congressional races as well. Kerry acknowledged that the proposal, to be offered as an amendment to a campaign reform bill already approved by the Senate Rules Committee, faces ``an uphill fight'' when the legislation is considered by the full Senate, most likely next month. Democratic leaders in both the House and Senate and public interest groups such as Common Cause have all but abandoned hopes of winning passage of public campaign financing in the face of intense opposition from President Bush and other Republicans. But Kerry, Bradley and Biden said taxpayer financing is the only way to fully reform a system discredited by politicians raising campaign dollars from individuals and groups who then expect special treatment from the government. ``We are engaged in what I fear is moderate reform,'' said Biden. ``I fear that moderate reform is somewhat like moderate chastity. The mere existence of money means to some that the entire process is tainted.'' If advertised and promoted by the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Election Commission, Kerry said, the checkoff could raise an estimated $60 million for every two-year election cycle despite a recent decline in its use by taxpayers for presidential campaigns. ``The tail-off has been a reflection of the fact there has been no push to get people to do it ... and the increased cynicism of the public _ they don't want to contribute their dollars to a system they don't think is sensitive to them,'' he said. When Senate Democrats last tried to pass a public campaign financing law two years ago, they were unable in eight attempts to break a Republican filibuster. Since then, many Democrats, after reaping large contributions from labor and corporate political action committees in recent years, also have become wary of public financing. ``If we need to have another filibuster, then let's have another filibuster,'' Kerry said. ``Just because you fail once doesn't mean you shouldn't come back and test whether there's a change in consciousness.'' On a strict party-line vote, the Senate Rules Committee last month approved a bill by Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., that would impose voluntary spending caps ranging from $1.6 million to $9.2 million on individual Senate candidates. But Democrats acknowledged that was just a starting shot to force the start of serious negotiations. Both Mitchell and Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas have somewhat embraced the recommendations of a bipartisan task force they appointed calling for ``flexible'' spending ceilings, no public financing and a diminished role for PACs and out-of-state contributors. In the House, there has been little progress in narrowing disagreements between the two parties and within each party. Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and Republican leader Robert H. Michel of Illinois met for 40 minutes on the issue Wednesday but agreed only to meet again when Congress returns April 18 from a spring recess.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Official With Controversial Kin May Get Judgeship
DOC.TEXT: Justice Department official Michael Boudin, the son of noted civil liberties lawyer Leonard B. Boudin, is under consideration for a federal judgeship by the Bush administration, according to sources familiar with the selection procedure. Boudin, 50, a deputy assistant attorney general for antitrust, is being considered for a vacancy on the U.S. District Court here, said the sources, who spoke Thursday on condition of anonymity. The FBI is conducting a background check and the American Bar Association's judicial screening committee is interviewing lawyers to assess Boudin's qualifications. The possible nomination by a Republican president is interesting because Boudin's father was long associated with left-wing causes and his sister, Kathy Boudin, is an imprisoned radical. But Michael Boudin is a quintessential member of the legal establishment who has a reputation as an outstanding appellate lawyer. He was graduated first in his class from Harvard Law School in 1964, clerked for Supreme Court Justice John Marshall Harlan II and became a partner at the prestigious Washington law firm of Covington & Burling. An administration official said Boudin's name has been cleared with conservatives who might be expected to raise opposition because of the notoriety of his family. Boudin is highly regarded by conservatives, the official said. The nomination, if made by Bush, would be subject to Senate confirmation. Leonard Boudin, who died last fall, was a respected civil liberties attorney who represented actor-singer Paul Robeson as well as anti-war activists Daniel Ellsberg and Benjamin Spock. He also represented Cuban government interests in this country. The elder Boudin's most famous legal victory was a 1958 Supreme Court decision that held the State Department could not revoke passports for political reasons. Michael Boudin's sister, Kathy, is serving a 20-year prison term for murder arising from her involvement in a 1981 armored truck robbery in Rockland County, N.Y., in which a guard and two police officers were killed. Previously, Ms. Boudin, 46, had been a fugitive wanted for questioning about a 1970 explosion in a Greenwich Village townhouse in New York City that killed three members of the Weather Underground.

DOC.HEAD: Parent Groups Endorse Voluntary Record Labeling Plan
DOC.TEXT: Parent groups leery of rock song lyrics about sex and violence are pinning their hopes on a new music industry labeling plan and are asking state lawmakers to end their drives to require warning stickers. ``We are asking state lawmakers to give the voluntary system a chance to work,'' Tipper Gore, president of the Parents' Music Resource Center, said Thursday at a news conference. She and Ann Lynch, president of the National PTA, said an industry-wide voluntary system is a better answer to parents' needs than mandatory labeling. ``We can accommodate the rights of artists to express themselves freely with the rights of parents, of consumers, to know, for example, if the music their kids want to buy says suicide is a good idea,'' Gore said. She said legislators in 13 states have agreed to abandon attempts to pass or revive bills to require warning labels on recordings. She urged a similar course in the six states where such measures are still pending. Six major record companies _ Warner Brothers, MCA, CBS, Capitol-EMI, RCA and Polygram _ said last week that they plan to create an industry-wide standard for warning labels. Gore's group and the PTA, among others, have expressed concern about music they believe encourages violence, suicide, drug use, sexual promiscuity, bigotry and Satan worship. Gore and Lynch said they were confident the uniform standard would result in better compliance than a 1985 agreement that called for voluntary warnings or printed lyrics on albums the companies determined to be violent or explicit. ``We take the industry on good faith that they really do mean to seriously address the problem. We take them at their word and we believe they will do the job correctly this time,'' Gore said. It still will be up to recording companies to decide which music merits a warning label, she said. But she said the commitment to create a standardized label shows the industry ``is willing to provide the tools to make a voluntary system work. Now it is up to parents to use that tool wisely.'' Tom Susman, a member of the West Virginia House of Delegates, said he had withdrawn a mandatory labeling bill inspired by a local disk jockey's concern. ``We hope for a positive outcome,'' Susman said of the latest music industry scheme. ``If not ... then it will be up to the legislators to look at this issue again.'' Record merchandising industry executives indicated last week that pressure from state legislatures was at least partly responsible for their decision to standardize and try to broaden the labeling system. The music industry has been lobbying hard in state capitols to kill legislation to require warning labels. States where lawmakers have promised not to pursue or revive mandatory labeling bills include Arizona, Iowa, Maryland, Oklahoma, West Virginia, Alaska, Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York, Tennessee and Rhode Island, Gore's group said. Measures sponsored by others are still alive in New York and Rhode Island, according to the National Association of Recording Merchandisers. Bills also are pending in Missouri, Florida, Delaware and Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: USA in Middle of Developed Nations in Life Expectancy, Death Rates
DOC.TEXT: The United States lands in the middle of the pack in rankings of life expectancy and death rates in 33 developed nations, according to new figures from U.S. health officials. Atop the list: Japan. In the United States, the average life expectancy is 75 years, trailing Japan by 4.1 years, but beating the lowest of the 33, Hungary, by more than five years, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. The average Hungarian lives 69.7 years, the CDC said. The United States also ranked near the middle of the 33 nations in death rates from all causes: 828.4 deaths are reported for each 100,000 people each year. Japan was best at 628.8; Romania worst at 1,242. The leading cause of death in the United States, heart disease, hits harder here than in other countries. The U.S. mortality rate from heart disease was 382 per 100,000 per year for men and 214 for women, compared with 339 and 206 in the other 32 developed countries. Throughout the 33 countries, heart disease accounted for 30 percent of deaths, with cancer causing 21 percent and stroke causing 14 percent. Fourteen percent of deaths in the 33 countries _ about 1.5 million a year _ are attributed to smoking, the CDC said. Fewer Americans smoke, compared with the other countries; 31 percent of U.S. males and 26 percent of American females smoke, compared with 41 percent of men and 29 percent of women in the other countries. ``The large number of deaths attributable to cigarette smoking indicates that reduction of this risk factor would substantially increase life expectancy in the developed world,'' the Atlanta-based CDC said. The CDC study included countries defined as developed according to a 1963 U.N. standard pegged to reproductive rates: countries where the average woman has fewer than two daughters who, themselves, survive their childbearing years. Such areas include the United States and Canada, the Soviet Union, most of Europe, some Latin American nations, Japan and Australia. The CDC study cited life expectancies and death rates in the latest available statistics for each country, from 1984 to 1987. Life expectancies for the 33 countries: Australia 76.3 years, Austria 75.1, Belgium 74.3, Bulgaria 71.5, Canada 76.5, Czechoslovakia 71.0, Denmark 74.9, East Germany 73.2, Finland 74.8, France 75.9, Greece 76.5, Hungary 69.7, Iceland 77.4, Ireland 73.5, Israel 75.2, Italy 75.5, Japan 79.1, Luxembourg 74.1, Malta 74.8, Netherlands 76.5, New Zealand 74.2, Norway 76.3, Poland 71.0, Portugal 74.1, Romania 69.9, Spain 76.6, Sweden 77.1, Switzerland 77.6, United Kingdom 75.3, United States 75.0, U.S.S.R. 69.8, West Germany 75.8, Yugoslavia 71.0.

DOC.HEAD: Polio & Guinea Worm Could Be Wiped Out; Others Not So Easy, Report Says
With PM-CDC-Death Rates, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Just as smallpox was wiped out in the 1970s, two other debilitating diseases, polio and guinea worm, could be wiped out in the near future, global health advocates say. The International Task Force for Disease Eradication said Thursday, in a report published by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, that eradication of guinea worm disease, which strikes 10 million people a year, largely in the Third World, ``is feasible, if the necessary commitment and resources can be mobilized.'' And worldwide polio eradication ``is technically possible'' by 2000, the task force said. But three other global maladies _ measles, tuberculosis and leprosy _ are ``not now eradicable,'' the task force said, citing the need for better measles vaccine, improved tests for TB and leprosy and the ``social stigma'' surrounding the latter. The benchmark in disease eradication came in 1977, when smallpox was eliminated from the planet, with efforts spurred largely by the United States. People around the world continue to be plagued by guinea worm and polio, and ``public and political awareness'' along with ``increased national and international commitment'' will be needed to eradicate them, the task force reported. ``Whatever priority countries might give to these diseases, the matter of resources, to the countries concerned, is often very great,'' said Dr. Donald Hopkins, project director for the task force. ``The ideal situation,'' he said, is one in which ``the more affluent countries have a direct national stake in seeing that a disease is eradicated, and are helping less affluent countries to get rid of it.'' The task force, launched at the Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta, includes representatives from the World Health Organization; the United Nations Children's Fund, or UNICEF; the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and other agencies. The task force's assessment on eight worldwide diseases: _Guinea worm disease: Infects 10 million a year. Eradication is feasible with commitment and resources. The Carter Center last week announced that American Cyanimid Co. donated enough of a guinea-worm fighting chemical to make eradication possible within five years. _Polio: Kills 25,000 a year. Eradication is technically possible, improved vaccine would help. Goal: to eliminate in western hemisphere by year's end. _Onchocerciasis: Blinds 340,000 a year. Eradication of disease not now feasible, but associated blindness could be eliminated through control of carrier worms. _Yaws-endemic syphilis: Strikes 2.5 million a year. With ``political and financial inertia,'' eradication not feasible now. _Rabies: Kills 52,000 a year, albeit virtually none in the United States. Eradication not feasible; no vaccine for wild-animal populations. _Measles: Kills 2 million a year. Not now eradicable; virus very infectious, and vaccine not effective in youngest infants. Hopkins said he remains somewhat optimistic for the eradication of measles, which was believed almost wiped out in this country before a comeback in the last few years. ``Sooner or later, an improved vaccine is going to be developed,'' he said. _Tuberculosis: Kills 2 million to 3 million a year. Eradication not feasible; need improved tests, chemotherapy and vaccine. _Leprosy: Strikes more than 11 million a year. Eradication not now feasible; need for improved tests and chemotherapy and overcoming of ``social stigma'' surrounding the disfiguring disease.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Lithuania Issue is Time Bomb in US-Soviet Summit
DOC.TEXT: There is a ticking time bomb in the upcoming superpower summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev: the status of Lithuania. While U.S. officials say they hope the May 30-June 3 summit will produce major arms agreements, a deterioration of the situation in the secessionist Baltic republic could have explosive impact on the summit _ and on future U.S.-Soviet relations. Secretary of State James A. Baker III spelled this out clearly in a three-hour private session with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Wednesday night, according to both U.S. and Soviet officials. Gennadi Gerasimov, the glib Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, had no trouble slipping into American slang when characterizing the tone of Baker's message. ``There was a serious, hardball, exchange of opinions on this subject, yes sir,'' Gerasimov told a reporter. Bush has come under considerable pressure from Congress for not speaking out more assertively in behalf of Lithuanian independence. Some lawmakers have threatened the Soviet Union with sanctions if force is used to thwart Lithuanian freedom. ``We are obligated to do whatever we can to encourage the Soviets to grant the Baltic nations their freedom. What does America stand for if we don't stand for freedom?'' asked Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. Pro-independence Lithuanian activists have been demonstrating in front of the White House daily. If the summit is held in Washington, these demonstrators are likely to provide a noisy and constant backdrop to any Bush-Gorbachev talks. Just hours after the superpower summit was announced on Thursday, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., suggested that the current level of tension in Lithuania makes holding the summit ``a little more difficult.'' If Moscow escalates its crackdown in Lithuania or moves with force in the other Baltic republics of Estonia or Latvia, Congress could react angrily ``about trade or anything else dealing with the Soviet Union,'' Dole said. He said he was less certain whether ``it would spill over into arms control agreements.'' To date, Bush's approach has been cautious and nonjudgmental _ voicing general support for the self-determination rights of Lithuanian citizens but declining to criticize Gorbachev for the steps he has taken so far. Bush has urged restraint on both sides and a peaceful resolution of the crisis that began March 11 when the Lithuanian parliament declared independence from Moscow. ``Lithuania makes the summit all the more important,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. He suggested ``tough love'' tactics would be in order for dealing with the Soviet leadership. Bush no doubt had Lithuania on his mind when he commented on the first superpower summit of his presidency on U.S. soil: ``This is time for a lot of dialogue and a lot of discussion.'' At this point, no one knows just how the Lithuania wild card will be played. U.S. officials say the existing situation in Lithuania is not such that it would interfere with summit planning. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, who begins a five-day visit of the Soviet Union today as part of a six-member Democratic Senate delegation, applauded Bush for deciding to go ahead with the superpower meeting. After he met with Bush on Thursday, Mitchell was asked if Lithuania was casting a cloud of uncertainty over the summit. ``The answer to that requires the development of further events,'' Mitchell said. ``We don't know what events may occur in Lithuania,'' Mitchell added. ``It is my hope that there will be a peaceful resolution of the situation in Lithuania and that the United States and the Soviet Union will reach meaningful, fair, balanced and verifiable agreement on arms.'' The United States has never recognized the 1940 forced incorporation of the three Baltic republics into the Soviet Union. But neither has it extended diplomatic recognition to the new government of Lithuania formed March 11. Moscow has repeatedly said force won't be used against Lithuania _ and Shevardnadze reiterated that view in his meetings with Baker this week. Furthermore, in recent days both sides have shown they may be willing to negotiate a compromise. Even so, any change for the worse could threaten to make the upcoming summit even more turbulent than the storm-tossed session Bush and Gorbachev experienced at their shipboard Mediterranean summit in December at Malta.

DOC.HEAD: King Restored to Throne After Refusing To Sign Abortion Law
DOC.TEXT: The government said it will seek a change in the constitution after King Baudouin was restored to power following a two-day suspension that allowed him to avoid signing an abortion bill into law. At the request of Baudouin, a devout Catholic long opposed to abortion, the government suspended him Wednesday, then passed the abortion bill itself and asked the legislature to restore the king. Parliament, by a 245-to-0 vote, restored the king as head of state Thursday. However, 93 lawmakers abstained and 58 were absent. Prime Minister Wilfried Martens told lawmakers that ``to prevent a recurrence of similar problems in the future, the government ... intends to propose a structural change'' in the constitution. He did not elaborate. But his center-left government will likely seek to curtail the king's already largley ceremonial powers even further, possibly by removing the need for the king's signature before a bill can become law. The suspension set off a debate about the role of the king and his already largely ceremonial powers. Legal experts say the king cannot cast aside his constitutional role on moral grounds, only if he is physically or mentally unable to rule. Vatican Radio in Rome praised the king, calling his stand a ``noble and courageous choice'' that was dictated by his ``very strong moral conscience and his undisputible sense of statehood.'' Parliament adopted the abortion bill March 29. It allows abortion in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy if a doctor deems his patient to be ``in a state of distress.'' Until now, abortion was a criminal offense.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Most Women Don't Suffer Post-Abortion Mental Health Problems
DOC.TEXT: Some women may feel regret, sadness or guilt, but most do not develop mental health problems from legal, voluntary abortion in the first trimester of pregnancy, according to a study published today. The study in Science magazine said some women may experience emotional distress, but for the vast majority, ``legal abortion of an unwanted pregnancy in the first trimester does not pose a psychological hazard.'' Olivia Gans, director of American Victims of Abortion, called the study ``a manipulation'' and a ``rehash'' of data from earlier studies. ``When you look at these studies, you can twist them any way you need to to get whatever conclusion you want,'' she said. The new study was commissioned by the American Psychological Association, which asked six experts to examine all current research and determine if a valid conclusion could be drawn about post-abortion psychological effects. Nancy E. Adler, a University of California-San Francisco professor of psychiatry and lead author of the report, said the panel surveyed more than 200 studies and found only ``about 19 or 20'' that met solid scientific standards. Once those studies were examined, she said, the conclusion ``was really quite clear.'' The APA convened the panel in 1988 after then-Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said studies were inadequate to draw final conclusions about the effects of abortion on women's mental health. In the Science report, the authors said case studies have shown that some women do experience ``severe distress ... after abortion and require sympathetic care.'' But for most women who have voluntary abortions, ``severe negative reactions are infrequent in the immediate and short-term aftermath,'' the study said, while the greatest distress ``is likely to be before the abortion.'' ``Severe negative reactions after abortions are rare and can best be understood in the framework of coping with a normal life stress,'' the study said. ``I feel comfortable about the conclusion that there is little psychological hazard for women,'' Adler said in a telephone interview. But she noted that there is a need for scientific studies that would compare the effects of abortion with that of other stressful events in life, such as divorce or death of a family member. Adler said studies of the psychological effects of a death have shown that if there is no negative mental health response within a few months, there is little likelihood that one will develop later. As a result, she said, ``there is reason to believe that there will be very little long-term effect'' from abortion. But she added: ``As a scientist, I really can't say anything beyond two years.'' ``Two years is not enough,'' said Gans, who said she had an abortion in 1981. ``I know many years later you still have to deal with emotional debris of that experience.'' She said the effects can show up five to 10 years later and she described them as similar to the post-traumatic stress disorder experienced by combat veterans. Gans' organization, American Victims of Abortion, is associated with the National Right to Life Committee. Other findings of the Science report include: _Most women report feelings of relief and happiness after a first trimester abortion. One study showed that 76 percent of women reported feeling relief two weeks after an abortion and only 17 percent reported guilt. _A study of 360 adolescents seeking pregnancy tests compared those who were not pregnant, those who were pregnant and sought abortion and those who carried their babies to term. After two years, the study said, ``the abortion group showed, if anything, a more positive psychological profile than either of the other two groups.'' _Women obtaining second trimester abortions, according to one study, experienced more distress than those getting abortions in the first three months of the pregnancy. Those having difficulty deciding on abortion are also more apt to experience negative effects afterward, the study said. In addition to Adler, the coauthors of the Science study were: Henry P. David of the Transitional Family Research Institute in Bethesda, Md.; Brenda N. Major of the State University of New York, Buffalo; Susan H. Roth of Duke University, Durham, N.C.; Nancy F. Russo of Arizona State University, Tempe; and Gail E. Wyatt, University of California, Los Angeles. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Four Humans Infected From Lab Monkeys' Virus, But None Are Sick
With PM-CDC-Death Rates, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A deadly Ebola virus outbreak among imported laboratory monkeys apparently isn't harming people, as evidenced by four animal handlers who have become infected, but not sick. The virus, related to the deadly Ebola virus of Africa, has turned up in monkeys from three Philippine importers since fall. The licenses of three of the nation's largest monkey importers have been revoked amid concerns about the virus's spread. Researchers with the national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday that four workers at Hazleton Research Products of Reston, Va. _ the first laboratory where the virus appeared _ have now been infected. But unlike African Ebola virus, which attacks suddenly and produces serious and often fatal illness, the virus from the Philippines isn't making humans sick. ``In nobody's book can this virus be considered the same,'' said Dr. Susan Fisher-Hoch, a CDC specialist in Ebola virus. ``It's not as pathogenic, that's for sure. ``You would expect them to be ill within a few days of exposure.'' She said researchers have no idea why this latest virus, which has killed numbers of monkeys, is not affecting the humans it infects. ``We don't know,'' Ms. Fisher-Hoch said, adding that the virus does have ``a high rate of transmission.'' The four infected workers were among five animal handlers at Hazleton who had what the CDC termed ``a high level of daily exposure'' to the infected animals. In a 1976 epidemic of Ebola virus in Zaire, it is believed that 98 percent of the people infected became ill and the fatality rate among patients was 88 percent. Inspectors from the CDC are continuing to check the three large primate importers who were shut down last month, as well as other importers. No decision has yet been made regarding when the three might resume business, Ms. Fisher-Hoch said. CDC researchers suspect that the Philippine virus _ which is closely related to African Ebola, but not identical _ does not reproduce itself well once it infects a person. One of the animal handlers who became infected showed high levels of antibodies to the virus, but tests to detect the actual virus in his blood were unsuccessful, Ms. Fisher-Hoch said. ``He had cut himself, so we knew he was most definitely inoculated with the virus,'' she said. ``But he never developed a high load of virus in the blood. ``That's an indication _ in one case _ that the virus does not replicate very well.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Seek Motive in Crack House Massacre
DOC.TEXT: The assailants who massacred six men and boys in a reputed crack house may have been stoned on drugs or seeking revenge for a deal gone bad, officials said. City Councilman Gilbert Hill, former head of the police department's homicide division, said he saw little difference. ``Most of the time it's not a turf battle, just thugs robbing each other,'' Hill said. ``Some of these guys walking around with Uzis and .44 Magnums, they have the brain of an ant. I don't think it's part of any organized conspiracy.'' The Wednesday night attack was the worst multiple murder in Detroit since June 1971, when seven members of a heroin ring were found shot to death in a west side apartment. No arrests had been made by Thursday night, Officer Thomas Martinelli said. The victims ranged in age from 15 to 32. According to accounts from witnesses, a woman and two men burst into the house, forced the victims to lie on the floor and started shooting them. Four of the dead were found on the second floor of the bungalow. Each had been shot in the head, Buck said. The two other victims, one of whom died shortly after arriving at a hospital, were shot trying to run downstairs and were found in the basement. Buck declined to discuss a possible motive, and calls to the department's homicide, narcotics and special crimes units weren't returned. A neighbor said the bungalow where the shootings occurred was one of a number of crack houses in the area. ``It's a drug deal gone bad,'' said Alonzo Johnson, 26. ``They are dealing drugs on every other house on every other street in this neighborhood. It's bad.''

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Bill Heading to House Floor
DOC.TEXT: A far-reaching clean air bill goes to the House floor after clearing a committee by a lopsided 42-1 vote, moving Congress a step closer to enacting tougher air pollution controls. The Energy and Commerce Committee approved the complex and costly clean air package late Thursday after resolving the thorny issue of helping Midwest utilities cope with tougher acid rain controls. The acid rain compromise, approved 39-4, aims to help Midwest states pay for cleaning up pollution caused by utility plants by providing a ``pollution allowance'' system and a one-year extension for initial compliance in some cases. Critics of the measure have said it would cause electric rates to jump. Legislation passed by the Senate earlier this week includes a similar provision. Pleas from some Midwest congressmen for a nationwide energy fee or tax were rejected. The compromise ``allows us to recoup some costs,'' said Rep. Michael Oxley, R-Ohio, although indicating he would like to have seen more aid for the region. ``This is a tough, tough bill for my part of the country and we're going to feel it for a long time.'' ``A lot of blood was spilled in these debates,'' said Rep. Jim Cooper, D-Tenn., who vigorously opposed proposals such as a tax or energy fee to help the Midwest. Only Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., voted against the House measure. Like the Senate bill approved 89-11 on Tuesday, the House legislation calls for sweeping emission controls on automobiles and industry, including a requirement that electric utilities cut annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons, or roughly in half. Sulfur dioxide, especially from Midwest electric power plants that use high sulfur coal, is the source of the acid rain that has caused problems with lakes and streams in much of the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states. The Bush administration has estimated the Senate legislation would cost the economy $21.5 billion a year when all provisions go into effect. The House bill has been said to be slightly cheaper. Environmentalists say much of that cost will be offset by lower health costs. House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., has indicated he wants to begin floor action on the clean air bill by early May. The House and Senate versions then would have to be worked out in a conference committee. Several congressmen have indicated they intend to pursue additional amendments on the House floor. But congressional sources suggested Thursday that it is unlikely that major changes will be made in light of the one-sided committee vote. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the panel chairman, said the legislation was ``significantly better'' in protecting the environment than the Senate version. Dingell's committee tackled the most controversial aspects of the legislation _ including the acid rain issue _ behind closed doors. Private committee negotiations last week produced compromises on controlling urban smog and releasing toxic industrial chemicals. More than 150 lobbyists, representing everything from environmental groups to oil and chemical companies, gathered outside the closed committee hearing room Wednesday and Thursday as committee members and their staffs worked out the acid rain agreement. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., for years a leading advocate in Congress for tougher air pollution controls, noted it had been eight years since the full committee tackled clean air legislation. ``This legislation is long overdue,'' agreed Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn. ``It's a real victory for our lakes, lungs and resources.'' Meanwhile, the latest survey by the Environmental Protection Agency released Thursday showed that, using 1988 figures, smog continues to plague more than 100 cities and affect about 121 million people.

DOC.HEAD: With US-Japan Trade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the highlights of the promises made by U.S. and Japanese negotiators to address broad-ranging structural barriers to trade:

_Stiffen penalties for antitrust violations by Japanese companies, including bid-rigging and other collusive practices. _Deregulate the nation's complex distribution system, including relaxation of restrictions on opening large retail stores. _Increase government spending to build and expand airports and harbors to increase the flow of imports. _Study the feasibility of shortening the work week for Japanese government and private-sector employees to 40 hours and five days. _Support legislation to change tax laws to increase the amount of land available for residential construction.

_Strengthen procedures to meet targets of a balanced budget by 1993. _Support legislation to provide for Family Savings Accounts allowing couples to reap tax-free earnings on contributions of up to $5,000 a year. _Seek legislation to reduce the tax rate on capital gains, profits from the sale of stocks, real estate and other investments, as a way of boosting investment. _Study ways to lower the cost to U.S. corporations of raising capital. _Boost federal spending for basic research and development. _Set national goals for improving the educational system to provide students with necessary job skills.

DOC.HEAD: Measure Would Make Ag Secretary King of Compost
DOC.TEXT: Some in Congress want to create the job of compost czar and think Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter should wear the title. A House Agriculture subcommittee headed by Rep. George E. Brown Jr., D-Calif., approved by voice vote Thursday an amendment to the 1990 farm bill that would require Yeutter to designate a 15-member Compost Task Force, which he would head. The measure, if it became law, would require a study of methods used to make compost out of agricultural waste. Evaluations would include wastes from ``the production, processing and distribution of food, fiber, forestry, livestock and fish products.'' Compost is a mixture of decomposing vegetable refuse used for soil fertilization. Officials at the Agriculture Department were apparently caught off-guard by the compost amendment. Kelly Shipp, Yeutter's press secretary, said she had not been aware of a move to create a compost bureaucracy. Until there was an opportunity to study the proposal, Ms. Shipp said, there would be no Yeutter position on the matter. But surely, she joked, this wouldn't mean that everybody would have to bring their grass clippings to USDA just because Yeutter was the nation's compost czar. ``What are we, up to about $30 billion by now for what everybody wants in the farm bill?,'' she said. ``If we put together all the task forces and special offices they want us to have, we'd probably have to go out and buy another building as big as the two we have now.'' The Brown amendment, which now goes before the full House Agriculture Committee, said that the composting of agricultural wastes can help prevent contamination of water supplies and alleviate waste removal burdens on farmers. Further, it said, compost can be ``a safe and useful soil additive which can help to stabilize and enrich the soil'' and reduce the use of chemical fertilizers. ``The Department of Agriculture is uniquely qualified to research appropriate uses and markets for compost,'' the proposal said. Among its provisions, the amendment would require Yeutter to establish standards for compost quality, and come up with definitions for processing, handling and using compost. Further, it would require USDA to ``initiate extension efforts, including seminars, demonstration projects and dissemination of materials, to inform the agricultural community'' about the benefits of compost.

Low-income families on food stamps will come out substantially ahead under the new federal minimum wage law, according to a senior Agriculture Department official. ``Every case is different, but most food stamp recipients will keep at least 64 cents in benefits for each dollar they gain in wages,'' said Assistant Secretary Catherine Bertini, who oversees USDA food and consumer services. ``The food stamp program is not an alternative to work,'' she said Thursday in a statement. ``We want to encourage people to work, earn money and support themselves and their families.'' The federal minimum wage rose to $3.80 an hour on April 1 from $3.35 and will rise again next April 1 to $4.25 an hour. Food stamp benefits are allocated on the basis of several factors, including household size and net income as determined by deducting expenses for such items as housing, utilities and day care. Bertini cited an example of a family of three claiming the maximum deduction for housing, earning $580 per month in wages and receiving $207 in food stamps. Under the new minimum wage law, the family's earnings would increase by $78 to $658 per month, while food stamp benefits would be reduced by $19 per month. That would total $787 per month under the old minimum wage and $846 under the new law, a net gain of $67 per month, she said. ``The gain in wages more than makes up for the loss in food stamps,'' Bertini said. ``In fact, for each new dollar earned with the new minimum wage, this household would keep 76 cents in food stamp benefits.'' More than 19 million people get benefits under the food stamp program, which is estimated to cost $14.8 billion this year.

Be polite, prompt and keep promises if doing business internationally, says an Agriculture Department report. It also helps when traveling to a prospective new market to learn in advance as much about the country's culture. ``For example, when in Mexico, it is customary to inquire about a colleague's wife and family, whereas in many Middle Eastern countries it is taboo,'' the report said. ``Patting a U.S. colleague on the back for congratulations is a common practice. In Japan, however, this behavior would be discourteous.'' The suggestions were include in the April issue of AgExporter magazine by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service. ``Keep promises,'' the report said. ``A good way to lose customers is to break promises. The biggest complaint from foreign importers about U.S. suppliers is a failure to ship as promised.'' Other important consideration involve religious and national holidays. Trying to conduct business in the United States on the Fourth of July would be difficult, if not impossible. Likewise, different dates have special meaning in various countries. ``A little research and observance in cultural behavior can go a long way in international commerce,'' the report said. ``Likewise, a lack of sensitivity to another's customs can stop a deal in its tracks.''

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Make Rape Victim's Style of Dress Inadmissible Evidence
DOC.TEXT: A House bill, created in response to an alleged rapist's acquittal by jurors who said the woman ``asked for it,'' would bar evidence from court concerning the rape victim's clothing. A Fort Lauderdale jury last year acquitted Steven Lamar Lord, 26, of Lawrenceville, Ga., after his attorneys introduced as evidence the victim's miniskirt and testimony that she wasn't wearing underwear. The defense used the clothing to challenge the woman's character and attempt to show she was looking for trouble. ``It was not relevant at all to whether the person on trial actually committed the crime,'' the bill's sponsor, Rep. Elaine Gordon, said Thursday. ``It only had to do with an attack on the character of the victim.'' The bill passed a subcommittee of the Criminal Justice Committee 6-0. It will be considered next by the full committee.

DOC.HEAD: Director Says Social Security Not Reaching Enough Needy People
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Social Security Administration says the agency has erected mind-boggling obstacles to poor, homeless and disabled people who need its help. Far too many people aren't receiving Supplemental Security Income benefits because they don't know about them, don't understand them or can't figure out how to apply, Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn S. King told the House Select Committee on Aging on Thursday. ``It's more than a little hard,'' she said of the 15-page application form. ``It boggles the mind.'' The Supplemental Security Income program provides monthly cash benefits to poor, aged, blind and disabled people. It provides up to $386 a month per individual or $579 a month per couple for those who meet strict and complex rules that take into account ordinary Social Security payments and other income. About 4.6 million people receive the benefits, but studies have concluded that as many as 50 percent of those eligible for SSI are not participating. A 1988 survey conducted for the American Association of Retired People found that nearly one-fourth of those over 65 living near or below the poverty line had never heard of it, and only 22 percent received its benefits. King said that when she took the job last year she found the program of SSI benefits ``an absolute maze, a patchwork of information and instructions that confused me.'' The agency has a moral obligation to find eligible people and help them apply and will increase its outreach efforts, but no large new appropriation is needed, she said. Maria Foscarinis, director of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, a private advocacy group, criticized the Social Security Administration, saying the government failed to get benefits to homeless people ``suffering the most extreme deprivation imaginable.'' Bills in the House and Senate would require the Social Security Administration to regularly visit shelters to explain benefits, help homeless people apply and provide other assistance. Congress authorized the agency to conduct outreach demonstration projects in 1987 but the agency never conducted them, arguing no money was appropriated. Congress provided $3.5 million for research into outreach programs and demonstration projects in the current budget.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Navy Biplane Recovered from Pacific
