DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Rebounds, Dollar Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to wrap up with comments, closing bond price; CORRECTS that Nikkei gain was fourth-largest. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded sharply today as the dollar declined against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed the week at 29,278.78 points, up 1,029.72 points, or 3.65 percent. It was the index's fourth-largest single-day advance. Its largest gain was on Oct. 21, 1987, after the worldwide Black Monday stock market crash, when it surged 2,037.32 points. Securities dealers said today's gain followed an improvement in market mood Thursday afternoon when major institutional investors began actively buying shares to support the falling market. The move helped the Nikkei index wipe out most of a 1,088.94-point morning loss to close the day Thursday down only 193.88 points. ``The market has entered on a rebounding phase as domestic demand-related issues and large-capital stocks, including steel issues, were bought briskly,'' said Masaya Hashizume, an analyst with Nikko Securities. ``The relatively large trading volume of 800 million shares signals the beginning of a market turnaround,'' he said. On Thursday, 650 million shares changed hands on the market's first section, following weeks of sessions in which typical trading volume was less than 500 million shares. Other dealers said many participants, including institutional investors, believed the index has reached its bottom. In currency dealings, the dollar closed the week at 157.47 yen, down 0.43 yen from Thursday's close. After opening at 156.90 yen, it ranged between 156.55 yen and 157.65 yen. Many market players were reducing long, or overbought, dollar positions against the yen prior to a weekend meeting of finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Paris, said Takeo Suzuki, a dealer with Yasuda Trust and Banking Co. Suzuki said the yen ``now is under less selling pressure against European currencies, including the West German mark, because their value (against the yen) have risen enough.'' Other exchange dealers said they expect some policy initiatives to defend the yen against the dollar in Saturday's meeting of monetary authorities from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. Yasuda's Suzuki said the yen's relative stability also was partly due to ``progress to some extent'' in Thursday's agreement in trade talks between the United States and Japan in which both pledged to make structural reforms in their economies. The preliminary agreement in the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative, reached after several months of discussions between U.S. and Japanese negotiators, is intended to remove structural causes of their $49 billion trade imbalance. In the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.38 points, down from Thursday's finish of 86.55. Their yield was 7.275 percent, up from the previous day's 7.240 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Prime Minister Says Economic Reforms in National Interest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD Japanese reaction; no Pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Japan Trade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today the broad trade reforms approved by the United States and Japan could be painful but will improve living standards. Consumer groups said the changes could hurt community development and go against with cultural values, however. Speaking at a news conference, Kaifu said Japan must carry out its end of the accord, announced Thursday in Washington, ``as a responsible member of the international community.'' The agreement, reached after four days of discussions, sets forth complex proposals aimed at lowering America's huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. ``I ask for the understanding and cooperation of the people of my country,'' Kaifu said. In the end, he said, the reforms will improve the lives of the Japanese. The talks were unprecedented because they aimed not at boosting sales of specific foreign products but at easing barriers to trade in both countries. But the Federation of Specialty Stores Associations said in a statement it would do its best ``to prevent the decisions from being enforced by keeping close ties with other groups and promoting consumer awareness and cooperation.'' It focused its attack on the most controversial of the proposed Japanese reforms _ revision of a law that protects small retailers by restricting the opening of large department stores, a process that takes about 10 years. The United States sought abolition of the law, contending larger stores are more likely to sell foreign products. Kaifu said effects of the revision would be ``severe.'' But, he added: ``I believe it is important for me and all of you to think of the viewpoint of consumers' interests.'' The association's statement said, however, ``the decision will do nothing but weaken minor retailers, devastate shopping districts and slow economic and cultural development of the community.'' The association claims a membership of 50,000 small retailers nationwide. The trade ministry says Japan has 1.6 million retail shops with fewer than 50 employees, and 800,000 tiny ``mom-and-pop'' stores. The talks on barriers to trade, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, began last July. Until this week, they had made little headway. Japan said the United States contributed to the trade imbalance with its large budget deficit, low savings rate, short-term corporate planning and weak education system. U.S. negotiators promised to remedy these problems. U.S. officials have argued the changes sought in Japan would benefit Japanese consumers, who pay some of the world's highest prices as a result of a complex distribution system and numerous government restrictions. Japanese consumers, however, have not formed strong organizations to press for change, and many Japanese identify their own interests with those of their companies. Larger is not necessarily better, said Naokazu Takeuchi, head of the Japan Consumers Union, one of the nation's largest consumer groups. ``It is not cheap pricing that we consumers want,'' he said. ``We have to take many elements _ cultural aspects, community relationship _ into consideration before making decisions.'' Kaifu said the promised package of reforms would benefit not only the United States and Japan, ``but also the whole world, serve to prevent the rise of protectionism and thus contribute to the steady development of the world economy.'' ``The Japanese measures included in the interim report have been attained after undergoing a difficult domestic process, and their implementation may, in some cases, be painful,'' Kaifu said. ``It is my conviction, however, that they are essential in furthering Japan's own national interest.'' Among Japan's pledges was one to spend more on public works such as housing, sewers, parks, airports and port facilities. The United States, believing such spending will boost Japan's demand for foreign goods and services, sought a spending target, but Japan said it will decide expenditures annually to avoid overheating the economy. On the retail store law, which the United States wanted abolished, Japan said it will improve how the law works, revise it next year and then review it again in another two years. If by then it still takes 10 years to open large stores, specific areas of the country would be exempted from the law, Japanese officials said. ``Because the agreement said `specific areas,' the law will not be abolished,'' an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: De Maiziere Asked to Form New Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Social Democrats, German Social Union overcoming differences; Kohl saying no tax hike for unification. no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An East German leftist party and a conservative alliance cleared away some ideological differences in efforts to build a broad coalition government, the ADN news agency said today. Christian Democratic leader Lothar de Maiziere, whose party holds the most seats in Parliament, was asked to try to form a government during Thursday's inaugural session of the new legislature. De Maiziere is trying to resolve differences over reunification and build a broad coalition from the 11 parties represented. His success would speed the merger of the German states, the principal issue in the country's first free elections on March 18. The Christian Democrats are part of a conservative alliance that also includes Democratic Awakening and the German Social Union. The alliance has tried to ally with the left-leaning Social Democrats, despite serious ideological differences between that party and the Social Union. Those two parties were able to put aside some differences in a late-night meeting, according to East Germany's ADN news agency. ADN quoted Social Democrat chief Markus Meckel as saying there are still ``differing views'' between the two parties, but ``no obstacles that can't be overcome.'' De Maiziere needs a broad coalition to ensure the two-thirds vote needed to enact constitutional changes required for unification. Members of the conservative alliance follow the policies espoused by their like-minded colleagues in Bonn, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Kohl said again today his countrymen will not face a tax increase to finance the heavy costs of German unification. ``A tax increase would unnecessarily brake the economic upswing and have a counterproductive effect,'' Kohl said in the West German city of Ludwigshafen. Unification was a prominent theme of Thursday's inaugural session of the 400-member Parliament, and the lawmakers formally dismantled the Communist system that ruled for four decades. Despite differences over how to proceed with unification, East German political parties together oppose a proposal by the West German Central Bank to trade East marks for West marks at a 2-1 exchange. Thousands of East Germans rallied nationwide Thursday to demand a 1-1 rate, which would offset unemployment and inflation in East Germany once the countries unite. However, West Germany said Thursday it was moving ahead with plans to replace the nearly worthless East German currency with the mighty Western mark by summer. The East German lawmakers chose Christian Democrat Sabine Bergmann-Pohl to serve as Parliament president. He said he hoped the legislators do ``justice to our responsibilities and that we soon sit in a common German Parliament.'' The Parliament also created the office of president, a ceremonial head of state, and abolished the Communist collective body, the Council of State. Dr. Bergmann-Pohl will serve as head of state until the lawmakers elect a president. De Maiziere will likely be chosen premier. Running the country now is the Communist-led caretaker government headed by Premier Hans Modrow, who took over after hard-liner Erich Honecker was ousted in October. The Alliance for Germany favors rapid reunification while the left-leaning Social Democrats favor a gradual merger. Hundreds of thousands rallied nationwide Thursday to protest the proposed 2-1 exchange rate and demand West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl live up to his promises of prosperity for East Germans. Kohl campaigned hard for de Maiziere. About 50,000 people rallied in East Berlin and another 50,000 marched in Leipzig, the state news service ADN said. Rallies also were reported in the cities of Halle, Neubrandenburg, Magdeburg, Dresden, Gera, Potsdam and Cottbus, the government news agency ADN reported. Despite the uproar, West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel confirmed newspaper reports that under the proposed currency union, East Germany would relinquish control of monetary policy to the West German central bank, Bundesbank. Waigel said government ministers were studying a 50-page draft proposal for replacing the East German mark. He said West Germany would like basic agreement by next month and establishment of the common currency sometime this summer. ADN also said 40,000 East Germans lost their jobs in March. East Germany's many inefficient and obsolete industries are having difficulty competing with the flood of Western products now available to East Germans.

DOC.HEAD: Islanders Sentenced in Religious Witch-Hunt Murders
DOC.TEXT: A jury convicted and sentenced to prison 23 islanders for torturing and burning to death six people in a frenzied witch hunt that terrorized their tiny atoll in the South Pacific. The seven-man, two-woman jury at the Tribunal of Papeete handed down the penalties late Thursday. They ranged from three to 14 years imprisonment for those who particiapted in the 1987 slayings. Prosecutor Raymond Morey had recommended penalties ranging from five to 20 years. The defendants, mostly fishermen and farmers from the atoll of Faaite, showed no reaction when the sentences were read. Another suspect, a minor, will be judged in a separate proceeding. ``I find these penalties very heavy,'' said Roman Catholic Archbishop Michel Coppenrath, the highest-ranking church official in French Polynesia. ``The repentance of the accused is sincere.'' The heaviest sentence, 14 years, went to farmer Francois Mauti, 25, on convictions of murder, complicity in murder and inflicting mortal blows. He led a band of disciples that organized the violence in Sept. 2-4, 1987. ``I had a spirit under the spell of the devil,'' Mauti told Judge Marcel Bihl. ``I lost my head, but I believed I was on the holy path, shunning the evil fighting within me.'' During the nine-day trial, the court heard defendants speak of being swept away by demons or religious frenzy as they hunted down and killed neighbors they thought were possessed. The terror had roots in August 1987 visit by three women who arrived from Tahiti, 300 miles to the west. The women claimed to represent the Roman Catholic-affiliated movement Christian Renewal, but church authorities deny they had any official role in the movement. The group already had a strong following on Faaite, a sunny atoll of white sand that is home to about 180 people. The women, regarded as ``priestesses'' by the islanders, took over the community's whitewashed church and replaced the lay preacher as the religious authority. The trio's leader, Alexandra Silvia, conducted services in a trance and told frightened islanders of her visions that God would abandon Faaite, the defendants said. Miss Silvia suggested demons were in their midst, defendants said, and the population began viewing with suspicion fellow islanders who failed to attend her daily services. ``My words were misinterpreted,'' testified Silvia, a 55-year-old dental secretary who was not charged. ``I only gave prayers that cured those who were sick.'' But the defendants said the mood of the once-placid atoll swung between ecstasy and dread inspired by Silvia and her assistants. The trio left Faaite in late August and anointed seven disciples to continue their work. A few days later, a 14-year-old boy reported a vision that the devil had possessed his aunt. The islanders gathered in nightlong prayer and finally pronounced the demon exorcised. They repeated the ritual with two other people. But Ioane Harris, the assistant mayor, publicly denounced the women on Sept. 2. Maddened villagers twisted a cord around his neck, beat and drowned him, and threw his body on a bonfire built before the church. ``It was necessary to purify him,'' one defendant said. ``It was necessary to purify the village.'' Five more people were killed over the next two days. Most islanders took no part in the carnage, but it was Sept. 4 before anyone established contact with Papeete, the capital of French Polynesia, and reported trouble on the atoll. The mayor, who had been on vacation, and a Roman Catholic priest arrived the next day with police, in time to prevent four more executions. Psychiatric experts testified the emotional charismatic Christianity, mixed with ancient Polynesian beliefs in the supernatural, produced a dangerous mass hysteria on an isolated island lacking institutional authority. The three women were not put on trial since they had left Faaite before the murders.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Ryan White, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0478, a0480,0495
DOC.HEAD: Ryan White Brings Hope to Other Patients with Gifts from Elton John
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Dr. Martin...', to UPDATE with condition unchanged this morning. SUBS 9th graf, `The callers..', to CORRECT spelling of Richie.
DOC.TEXT: Celebrity visits have boosted the spirits of Ryan White's family while the teen-age AIDS victim remains unconscious and in critical condition with a lung infection. ``Jeanne (White's mother) had wondered whether their travels and all they've done to educate people about AIDS had had any effect,'' said Carrie Van Dyke, family spokeswoman and director of health promotions for the state Health Board. ``She feels now they did have an impact. The visits helped the family tremendously,'' Van Dyke said Thursday. White, 18, has been in the intensive care unit at Riley Hospital for Children for a week. Dr. Martin B. Kleiman said during a daily briefing Thursday there had been no perceptible change in White's condition and he remained on life-support systems. This morning, the hospital said his condition was unchanged. Kleiman said he had been impressed by pop singer Elton John and other celebrities, who have called and visited White's family at the hospital. ``I've seen nobody trying to advance their personal careers. They've come as private individuals, and they've been very honest and very sincere in their concern for Ryan and the family,'' Kleiman said. Hospital switchboard operators said about 1,000 calls a day have come in from celebrities and others expressing hope and concern for White. A record of each call has been passed to the family. The callers have included Vice President Dan Quayle, Sen. Edward Kennedy, and entertainers Michael Jackson, Carol Burnett, Lionel Richie and Phil Donahue. One of the visitors was John, a long-time friend of White's who passed out $500 worth of toys to other patients at the hospital Thursday. John, who has been at the hospital since Monday night, went to a toy store to buy gifts for White and other young patients. ``He bought stuffed animals, pretty much _ Minnie Mouse, Mickey Mouse, lions and tigers,'' Eddie Birchel, a toy store spokesman said. ``He signed a few autographs, and he joked around with some people.'' John has spent many hours with White's mother and sister, 16-year-old Andrea. He has declined requests for interviews. Clayton Archer, 18, a patient at Riley Hospital and a former classmate of White's, said John's visit Wednesday made his day. ``I was always a pretty good fan of his,'' said Archer, who's being treated for pneumonia. ``I never got to see him in concert; so I'm really glad he came up, and I'm glad I got to see him. ``He gave me some tapes, his whole collection plus some other stuff. I think he gave the toys to the kids in ICU who couldn't get a lot of things.''

DOC.HEAD: Small Core of Prisoners Still on Loose in Sixth Day of Defiance
DOC.TEXT: A small core of inmates at riot-torn Strangeways Prison, including the self-professed leader of this week's disturbance, remained on the loose inside the jail today in a sixth day of defiance. News reports said the rebellious prisoners have been repeatedly changing clothes with each other in a bid to confuse authorities about the exact number involved. Some are masked, adding to the uncertainty. Ivor Serle, chairman of the local chapter of the Prison Officers Association, said those still refusing to surrender included 13 who have been identified by authorities. He said 10 other inmates remained unaccounted for in the riot that began Sunday at the overcrowded, Victorian prison. Officials say a prisoner was fatally injured and 49 other people were hurt. Prison governor Brendan O'Friel told reporters on Thursday that a search of most areas of the prison had found no bodies. But he said he ``could not rule out the possibility of fatalities.'' Some prisoners from Strangeways who have been transferred to other prisons reported seeing bodies inside the prison, and reports persisted Thursday of prisoners being hanged and tortured by fellow inmates after the riot broke out. Prisoner Derek White, 46, died in North Manchester Hospital on Tuesday of injuries he received at the hands of other inmates when the riot began. He was in the prison in the northern city of Manchester awaiting trial on charges of indecently assaulting three children. Child molesters, together with convicted policemen and some other groups, are regarded with particular loathing by other inmates in English prisons. A prison guard, Walter Scott, 46, died in a hospital Thursday, apparently after suffering a heart attack on Monday, the Home Office reported. The Home Office _ which is responsible for prisons, among other things _ said Scott was on duty when the riot began but was not involved in combating it. Paul Taylor, self-professed leader of the disturbance, in a speech which he shouted to reporters Thursday from the roof of the prison, said the inmates had not intended to cause the riot. Shouting to be heard over the din of a police helicopter which hovered overhead trying to drown him out, Taylor said a sit-in at the jail's chapel was the plan Sunday when he grabbed the chaplain's microphone and urged others to take action. ``At no time did anyone have any willful intention that we would develop into a riot situation,'' Thomas, 28, shouted through a makeshift bullhorn. At the height of the riot, rampaging inmates started fires in various parts of the prison, smashed fittings and hurled down slates from the roof. The government said Thursday it has ordered a major inquiry headed by a senior judge, Sir Harry Woolf, into the violence. Inmates' relatives say tension at the facility was increased by overcrowding, with up to three prisoners sharing cells designed for one when the prison was built in 1868, unsanitary conditions, and rules that allowed inmates to be locked in cells for up to 23 hours. Strangeways was built to hold 970 men. It had 1,648 prisoners on Sunday. It contains inmates of all categories, from extremely dangerous to low risk.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney for Missing Moscow Circus Clown Says His Client Wants to Defect
DOC.TEXT: A Moscow Circus clown who disappeared after the troupe ended a two-month engagement here wants to defect, his attorney said. ``He's applying for political asylum because he fears reprisals from expressing his political views,'' attorney Michael Ross said Thursday by telephone from Southern California. Ross wouldn't discuss the specific political views Sergei Uhanov advocates that could get him into trouble, but intimated that many Soviets still don't feel free to express their views despite President Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness. ``Have you talked to many Soviets lately?'' Ross asked. ``It's not that good over there.'' Uhanov's last performance with the Moscow Circus at Bally's Resort Casino-Reno was Sunday night. When he didn't show up for a bus to the airport Monday, his friends checked his hotel room and found that all of his possessions were gone, Bally's publicist Brian Lawson said. A missing persons report was filed with Reno police on Wednesday. Ross said he notified police Thursday that his client was well. David Ilchert, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service office in San Francisco, said it is the agency's policy to neither confirm nor deny if his office had been contacted by Uhanov. ``It's up to the person to make it public if they're seeking asylum,'' Ilchert said. Uhanov, 28, is being sequestered pending approval of his application for political asylum, Ross said. The attorney would not reveal where the application would be filed or his client's current location. However, Uhanov was spotted in a San Francisco restaurant this week. ``He's been in here two of the last three nights with a couple of attorneys, but he doesn't want much publicity because he's trying to defect,'' said Lloyd Wiborg, owner of Scott's Restaurant. ``He's terrified that somebody is going to catch him and send him back to Russia.'' Ross said Uhanov wouldn't make any public statements until after his asylum application is processed, possibly by next week. The rest of the Soviet troupe flew to New York City, where the more than 100 circus performers are staying for a few days before flying back to the Soviet Union, Lawson said.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez's Sister Tanker Runs Aground in Harbor; Nothing Spills
DOC.TEXT: A sister ship to the tanker Exxon Valdez, carrying more than 1.2 million barrels of crude, ran aground in Long Beach Harbor but no oil was spilled, authorities said. The 950-foot Exxon Long Beach scraped an ocean ridge as it was leaving a harbor anchorage Thursday, said Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Jim Milbury. The vessel was refloated in about 30 minutes and taken to a harbor anchorage where a diver found no damage to its hull, a Coast Guard statement said. Coast Guard Cmdr. Chris Desmond said the ship was traveling slowly when it struck the ridge. ``It's not a terribly unusual occurrence,'' he said. The Long Beach was carrying Alaskan North Slope crude for off-loading at a harbor terminal. The 211,000-ton tanker is a sister ship to the Exxon Valdez, which spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound in March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Receives Arafat and Urges Israeli-Palestinian Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II met with PLO leader Yasser Arafat today and urged Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate a settlement allowing them both to live in peace. The pope reaffirmed that Palestinians, as well as Jews, have a right to a homeland. The two men met for 20 minutes in the papal library in an audience described by the Vatican as ``private.'' It was their third meeting in eight years. John Paul had previously received the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman at the Vatican in 1982 and 1988, drawing protests from Israel and Jewish groups. During this visit, the Israeli Embassy said it was ``mystified'' that Arafat was being treated by Italy and the Vatican as a ``man of peace.'' The papal meeting came on the second day of Arafat's two-day visit to Italy. He has met with Italian government and political leaders, seeking European support to force Israel to the bargaining table. Israel's coalition government collapsed March 15 in a dispute over a peace plan that called for preliminary meetings between Israeli officials and Palestinians to discuss proposed elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where the Palestinian uprising began 27 months ago. Arafat's PLO helps direct the uprising, and Israel's government has banned talks with Palestinians loyal to the PLO. In a statement after the talks, Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the pope had agreed to meet Arafat to encourage ``any positive attitude in the search for peace and especially to strengthen the will for dialogue as the only valid way to find adequate solutions for conflicts.'' The statement noted that John Paul had often spoken out against the recourse to arms and ``especially violence carried out by terroristic means and by reprisal.'' Navarro said the pope noted that this is the season of important religious holidays: the Christian Easter, the Jewish Passover and the Moslem Ramadan. ``The pope expressed the strong hope that Almighty God wishes to listen to the pleas of so many faithful, and in particular of those people of the Middle East, and grants them the so-desired peace in justice and security,'' Navarro said. The pope, according to his spokesman, stressed that Israelis and Palestinians must show a willingness for mutual understanding and the respect for the rights and fears of each other in order to open the way to negotiations. He said this would lead to a ``path which brings an end to the sufferings and which allows each to live in peace, freedom, dignity and calm in a homeland of one's own, open to collaboration with all peoples of the region.'' Navarro said the two also discussed the crisis in Lebanon, with the pope stressing that the use of arms would not succeed in bringing dignity and sovereignty to that country. The Vatican sought to emphasize that the Arafat visit did not have an official status. The PLO leader was identified simply as ``Mr. Yasser Arafat,'' and a pool of journalists organized to witness the pope greeting Arafat was canceled. The Vatican has no formal diplomatic ties with Israel. It has cited Israel's unsettled boundaries, the contested status of Jerusalem and the Palestinian question as the reasons for the absence of relations.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS CAMBRIDGE-dated 2nd item in rdp, subbing penultimate graf with 2 grafs to add background on actress, add time element.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actors Judd Nelson, Howard Hesseman and Elizabeth Pena canvassed passers-by at a subway stop as part of a nationwide campaign by Hollywood stars to register voters who favor abortion rights. ``I walked right by Judd Nelson,'' said Joyce Cunha, associate director of MassChoice, an affiliate of the National Abortion Rights Action League. She described him as ``a typical brat packer ... wearing dark glasses and a suit jacket. I just sort of stopped and said `Hey, that's great.''' Nelson, who has starred in several of the films for Hollywood's younger set, including ``The Breakfast Club'' and ``St. Elmo's Fire,'' passed out pamphlets that read ``Join The Breakfast Club. Register to vote pro-choice.'' Hesseman stars in the TV sitcom ``Head Of The Class.'' His leaflet urged: ``Go to the head of the class. Register to vote.'' Ms. Pena appeared in the TV miniseries ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story'' and the short-lived series ``I Married Dora.'' Between 40 and 50 people registered during the Thursday morning effort, Cunha said. The actors were emissaries from the Hollywood Policy Foundation Center, the non-profit arm of the Hollywood Women's Political Action Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Government Regains Control Of Michoacan City Halls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to RECAST the lede and MOVE UP claim that opposition won elections. Pickup 6th graf, `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers and police cleared city halls in Michoacan state of leftist opposition supporters who staged a four-month sit-in to protest elections they said the governing party stole from them. The security forces, backed by armored vehicles on Thursday retook the 21 buildings closed since the disputed municipal elections held Dec. 3 in the region, a stronghold of the opposition Democratic Revolutionary Party. ``We won't allow any political force in the state to put itself above the law,'' Interior Secretary Fernando Gutierrez Barrios said of the crackdown. Wilbert Rosas, spokesman for the opposition party, said authorities used tear gas and water hoses to disperse protesters in this western state and that more than 100 people were detained. Police said at least 17 people were arrested, most for illegal possession of firearms, but that no injuries were reported. ``There hasn't been even one blow nor one drop of blood,'' Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo told the private Televisa TV network. The government news agency Notimex reported late Thursday that army troops and police were sent to oust the activists. Sixty police officers were sent to Michoacan ``to guarantee peace,'' said Fernando Arias, spokesman for the attorney general's office. He said the local government requested the forces. It was not clear how many soldiers were dispatched. The activists warned there could be a ``bloodbath'' in the state. At least seven people died in February and in March in neighboring Guerrero state during protests of alleged election fraud. The Revolutionary Democratic Party says the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has been in power for 61 years, cheated it out of victory in the Dec. 3 elections in both states. Television news showed armored vehicles patrolling the streets of Michoacan. Witnesses said the vehicles began arriving Wednesday. The fraud protests have brought Michoacan to the edge of ``anarchy,'' Gov. Jaime Genovevo Figueroa Zamudio said in a letter published in Mexico City newspapers Thursday. ``The city halls have been taken over by armed people who have intimidated the population, who have created illegal police forces and tried to collect for public services,'' a high government source said on condition of anonymity. Michoacan has been a thorn for the governing party since the 1988 presidential race, when founder Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, a former Michoacan governor, ran second to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in an election still clouded by allegations of vote fraud. Cardenas, in a speech Thursday, urged his supporters to avoid violence. Nearly half of Michoacan's city halls were occupied by Cardenas' supporters after the national elections. There were more occupations after the July 2 state elections in which the governing party claimed a majority in the state legislative races. Official results from the December balloting show the governing party won local elections in 56 municipalities, the Democratic Revolutionary Party in 52, the conservative National Action Party in three and the leftist Authentic Party of the Mexican Revolution in one. The Democratic Revolutionary Party alleges it won at least 20 more elections.

DOC.HEAD: Orthodox Jew Stabbed in Old City of Jerusalem
LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: An Orthodox Jew was stabbed in the back today as he wheeled his 1-year-old son in a carriage through the Moslem Quarter of Jerusalem's walled Old City, police said. The baby carriage overturned, but the child was not injured. The victim, Danny Robbins, pulled out a pistol and fired three times in the air to summon police help, said police inspector Rahamim Comfort. Robbins, 35, was reported in satisfactory condition at Hadassah Ein Kerem Hospital. Police closed off all gates to the Old City and rounded up about 100 Palestinian suspects after the stabbing, Comfort said on Israel radio. Police at the scene said the attacker apparently was a Palestinian with a political motive. The bespectacled Robbins was wearing the skullcap of a religious Jew at the time of the attack. The stabbing occurred mid-morning on a dark, narrow street covered with a vaulted ceiling. The street is like many in the Old City, a busy area often crowded with shoppers and tourists. Robbins said on the radio that he lives in the Moslem Quarter and was on his way to the grocery store when he was attacked. He complained that no one tried to stop his assailant. ``Nobody chased after him. They saw him, they saw him very well, but nobody tried to chase him,'' Robbins said. ``He was not armed except for the knife that remained in my back.'' Robbins is only one of a handful of Jews living among the 20,000 Arabs of the Moslem Quarter. In August, the Jerusalem Post quoted a spokesman for Atara Leyoshna, a Jewish organization dedicated to buying houses from Arabs in the Moslem Quarter, as saying 25 Jewish families have moved into the area. There have been several stabbings of Jews in the Old City during the 27-month Palestinian uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 672 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis during the uprising in the occupied territories. Another 202 Palestinians have been killed by their fellow Arabs, accused of cooperating with Israel and 43 Israelis have died in the violence. The most recent attack in Jerusalem was the January stabbing of a woman soldier in the Moslem Quarter. In September, a Jewish seminary student was stabbed with a screwdriver and moderately injured in the Moslem Quarter. Most of the city's major tourist attractions are amid the narrow stone streets within the walled city, which is part of the area annexed by Israel after its capture from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. These include the Western Wall, the last remnant of the ancient Jewish Temple, the Al Aqsa and Dome of the Rock mosques, and the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

DOC.HEAD: China and U.S. Agree to Resume Fulbright Program
DOC.TEXT: China has agreed to resume the Fulbright scholar exchange program with the United States, but on a smaller scale, a U.S. Embassy official said today. China abruptly canceled the 1989-90 program in August in anger over U.S. criticism of the military suppression of the student-led movement for democratic reform. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a formal agreement was reached Wednesday with the State Education Commission for the 1990-91 academic year starting in the fall. Sixteen American professors will come to China, and 16 Chinese scholars will do advanced research at U.S. universities, he said. The 1989-90 program had called for an exchange of 24 scholars from each side, with 12 graduate students and 12 research fellows representing China. It had been one of the largest Fulbright programs, which exchange American and foreign scholars around the world. The Chinese government has sharply curtailed approval of overseas studies for undergraduates and most graduate students since its crackdown on political dissent last spring. The government, while insisting it will continue overseas study programs, is now limiting scholarships mainly to older scholars in technical fields for short-term programs. The reasoning is that such scholars will be less likely to become involved in politics while abroad and will be less tempted to join the thousands of Chinese students who have failed to return home after completing their programs. The U.S. Embassy, in a statement, said the Fulbright program ``fills a need not addressed in other exchange programs'' and the agreement was ``a positive step toward the resumption of this important program.'' It added: ``We hope the Chinese will resume the participation of Chinese graduate students in the near future, and will take steps in other areas that will be conducive to reform and to China's opening to the outside world.'' The exchange of 16 scholars on each side roughly returns the program to its size during the 1984-85 academic year. Discussion on resuming the exchanges began after President Bush dispatched National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft to Beijing in December for talks aimed at easing bilateral tensions. No progress has been made in other areas deemed crucial to improved relations. China is believed to still be holding without trial thousands of people who participated in last year's democracy movement, and it has taken a hard-line position on the release of astrophysicist and political dissident Fang Lizhi. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, took refuge in the U.S. Embassy after the military crackdown in June and have since been charged as counterrevolutionaries. Negotiations on their safe passage out of the country have apparently stalled, with China continuing to insist the two give themselves up to Chinese authorities and ``admit their guilt.'' The Fulbright program was established in 1946 under legislation by former Sen. J. William Fulbright, D-Ark. More than 167,000 people, including 58,000 from the United States and 109,000 from abroad, have participated.

DOC.HEAD: Separated from Her Dogs, Accused Bomber Refuses Plea Bargain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT charge to attempted murder sted murder.
DOC.TEXT: An animal rights activist turned down a plea bargain that would have allowed her to serve only one year in prison on an attempted murder charge because the agreement did not include visits with her dogs. Fran Trutt, who is charged with attempted murder, possession of explosives and bomb manufacturing, will go to trial for planting a bomb at a company that demonstrates surgical staples on dogs in 1988. She faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted. Plea negotiations in which Trutt would have pleaded no contest to at least one of the three charges broke down Thursday when prison officials refused to grant her permission to see her pets, said John Williams, Trutt's lawyer. ``She was willing to allow herself to be incarcerated for a crime she did not commit in order to see her dogs immediately,'' Williams said. ``She would do anything to see her dogs. The only thing you could compare it with is a mother seeing a child.'' Michael Donahue, a spokesman for the state Department of Correction, said: ``Our policy has been and remains that for safety, health and security reasons, canines are not allowed to the facilities to visit those who are incarcerated.'' Trutt is being held at Connecticut Correctional Institution in Niantic on $500,000 bond and has not seen her dogs since her arrest in November 1988. Williams said Trutt was distraught because she will have to wait months with no possibility of seeing the dogs. Her trial is expected to last into the fall. Trutt was arrested for allegedly planting a remote-controlled pipe bomb near the corporate parking space of Leon Hirsch, president of U.S. Surgical in Norwalk. Trutt has said she planted the bomb to scare Hirsch and protest the company's use of about 1,000 anesthetized dogs annually in training physicians to use surgical staples in place of stitches. The dogs are then destroyed. Williams last month filed a civil lawsuit against the state in U.S. District Court in New Haven charging that Trutt's constitutional rights are being violated because she is not permitted to see her dogs. The state has until Monday to respond. In January, Trutt was sentenced to 14 months in prison after pleading guilty to charges of illegally possessing two bombs in her New York City apartment. She already has served that time.

DOC.HEAD: Seventh Woman Found Strangled in Kansas City
DOC.TEXT: A young woman has been found strangled in the same area where six other bodies have been discovered since September, fueling fears that the deaths are the work of a serial killer. It was the seventh time in as many months that a black woman in her 20s or 30s has been found dead in or around Gillham Park, said Sgt. Greg Mills of the Kansas City Police Department. All the women had been strangled, Mills said, and none of the killings has been solved. He would say only that police are investigating the possibility of a serial killer. The latest victim was discovered Thursday morning by a woman walking her dog, Mills said. The victim was identified as Michelle Mitchell, 22, of Kansas City. The Jackson County medical examiner's office determined she had been strangled, and police said she had been dead four to six hours before her body was discovered. The unexplained killings began in September when the bodies of three women were found over 10 days. Two more women were found dead the next month. The latest victim before Thursday was that of a 23-year-old woman found in Gillham Park on Jan. 18. Police began considering the possibility of a serial killer after the October deaths. ``We are not in a position to say it is, but the similarities have not escaped us,'' Mill said. ``We don't have one definite thing that ties all of them together conclusively, and until then, it would be irresponsible to say they were all committed by one person,'' he said. Gillham Park is located in a residential neighborhood in the city's Midtown area, south of downtown.

DOC.HEAD: Last Of Original Preservation Hall Jazz Musicians Dead At 87
DOC.TEXT: Funeral services will be Monday for jazz trombonist Louis Nelson, the last surviving musician from the original Preservation Hall bands. Nelson, 87, died Thursday from injuries suffered in a car accident 10 days earlier. ``He was someone who played with the musicians of the last century and played almost into the next one,'' said jazz historian Dick Allen. Nelson's last performance was two weeks ago at the Palm Court cafe in the French Quarter with his Louis Nelson All Stars. He had been scheduled to perform this weekend at the French Quarter Festival but complained he had not felt well since another driver had collided with his vehicle after running a red light. Although he did not appear seriously injured from the accident, he collapsed Wednesday night and was rushed to a hospital, where he never recovered. A funeral will be held Monday. ``He was the last personal link to the original tailgate style,'' Allen said. ``That's the way trombonists used to play in New Orleans _ sitting on the tailgate of the wagon as they advertised dances.'' Nelson was playing with the Kid Thomas band in 1961, when private jam sessions at a French Quarter art gallery became so popular that the place was opened as Preservation Hall, dedicated to keeping the old-time music alive. Nelson became an indefatigable international star, touring South America, Australia and Europe. He was booked for a tour of Japan in August. At the time of his death he was still playing Preservation Hall twice a week with the Kid Sheik band, as well as leading his own band on Saturdays. His style ranged from the unbridled energy of traditional New Orleans jazz to the sweet, lyrical sliding melodies of the swing era. Nelson was born in New Orleans on Sept. 17, 1902, but grew up in Napoleonville. His mother was a mathematician and a graduate of the Boston Conservatory of Music; his father was a physician. In the 1920s he played with the Kid Harris Dixieland Band and Kid Rena. He was a member of the famed Sidney Desvigne's band for 15 years, including five years playing on a Mississippi riverboat. During the Depression, he was in the Works Progress Administration's big band and during World War II he was in the Naval Band. After the war, he joined Kid Thomas at Specks' Moulin Rouge in Marrero, where their hard-driving band acheived instant fame. Since then he has played with numerous bands, including George Lewis, Kid Howard and Billie and DeDe Pierce, and made records all over the world. Nelson is survived by his daughter, Anna Tircuit of New Orleans; seven grandchildren; 14 great-grandchildren; and three great-great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: African Updates Raise Reported Global AIDS Total 6.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: AIDS cases reported worldwide increased 6.5 percent last month to more than 237,000, with Zaire and the Ivory Coast more than doubling their figures, the U.N. World Health Organization said today. As of the end of March, 237,140 cases of the immune-stripping disease were reported, the organization said, up from 222,740 the month before. Zaire last month listed 11,732 cases as of Jan. 31, up from 4,636 reported at the end of 1988. Ivory Coast listed 3,647 cases, against 1,010 reported last October. Most other African countries did not file new reports during the month and 11 have not sent in updates for more than a year. Congo's latest report dates Dec. 9, 1987, when it listed 1,250 cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. With the new figures, Zaire replaced Brazil as the country with the second highest total, trailing only the United States, which still accounts for slightly more than half the global total. It reported 124,182 cases on March 31, up from 121,645 reported at the end of January. Brazil listed 10,058 cases in February, compared with 9,555 reported by the end of last year. The statistics, including 153 countries, were included in the latest issue of WHO's Weekly Epidemiological Record. Dr. Jonathan Mann, who resigned last month as director of WHO's AIDS program, has said the real number of AIDS victims may have already been as high as 600,000 by the end of last year, including an estimated 300,000 fatalities. Dr. Mann predicts that 6 million AIDS cases may occur by the year 2000 and has warned that if HIV infection accelerates, especially in Asia, even this estimate will be too low.

DOC.HEAD: Two Public Figures Kidnapped in Kashmir, Threatened With Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with threat to kill hostages. Pickup 10th graf `Kashmiri militants...' ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Moslem separatists today kidnapped a leading industrialist and a university official and threatened to kill them unless three jailed militants were freed, police and a telephone caller said. Soldiers tightened security throughout the troubled Kashmir Valley and blocked off roads in and out of Srinagar, where the kidnappings took place. Police, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said soldiers killed six separatists who tried to cross into neighboring Pakistan on Thursday to seek training and weapons. The telephone caller told a local reporter the abductors were holding a third hostage and all three men would be killed within 24 hours after a Monday afternoon deadline for the release of three jailed militants. The telephone caller claimed to speak for the Students Liberation Front, a branch of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front fighting for autonomy in the predominantly Moslem state in mainly Hindu India. Both the caller and police sources said the vice chancellor of Kashmir University, Mushir ul-Haq, and the general manager of Hindustan Machine Tools Co., L.M. Khela, had been abducted. The telephone caller, who didn't give his name, claimed Mushir's private secretary also was being held hostage, but that could not be independently confirmed. Moslem separatists had warned officials in the Indian government to leave Jammu-Kashmir state by the end of March or ``face the consequences.'' The border incident took place Thursday in the Kupwara district, where at least 20 separatists were trying to sneak into Pakistan to receive military training and buy weapons, police said. No further details were immediately available. India claims Pakistan trains and arms the militants, but Pakistan has denied the claim. The two countries have fought two wars over the region since 1947 when both nations won independence from British colonial rule. At least 255 people have died in Jammu-Kashmir since Jan. 20, when the Indian government launched a crackdown on the separatist movement. Most of the victims have been Moslem protesters defying curfew or militants killed in gunbattles with security forces. Kashmiri militants had earlier demanded union with Islamic Pakistan but now seek independence and the status of a neutral country. India's Jammu-Kashmir state, which includes the scenic Kashmir valley in the north and the plains of Jammu in the south, is India's only state with a majority of Moslems. About 64 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of india's 880 million people. Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Many Greeks Trek to Their Hometowns for Election Vote
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Athenians left today for their voting districts in the provinces and on Aegean islands to cast ballots in the country's third national elections in 10 months. Police reported traffic delays at toll booths on the national highway leading out of the capital. Olympic Airways, the national carrier, offered extra domestic flights and chartered planes from Balkan-Bulgarian airlines to accommodate the expected travel overflow. State-run buses and railways offered discounts on fares as an incentive to Greeks to return to their hometowns to vote in Sunday's election. Many Greeks who moved to big cities from the provinces over the years have never changed their voting districts in order to avoid the bureaucracy of re-registering and to maintain ties with their hometowns. Greece has 8,050,658 registered voters among its 10 million population. Over one-third of the population leaves in or near the capital; about 600,000 live in Salonica, the nation's second largest city. Voting is compulsory for people between 18 and 70. Sunday's general election is the third in 10 months. Two earlier polls ended inconclusively with no one party winning an absolute majority in the 300-member, single-chamber Parliament. Two coalitions failed to resolve the country's pressing social problems, prompting another vote. Opinion polls forecast another political deadlock when the ballots are counted after polls close Sunday night. The exodus to the provinces was expected to peak later today when shops and private businesses closed for the weekend. Most government agencies closed at noon today. Civil services were not expected to return to normal until Tuesday because the law provides for three days' travel time for voters who are registered out of town.

DOC.HEAD: Deliberations Now In Fifth Day
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 3 grafs new with jury resuming activity; pick up 5th graf, ``The next.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial resumed deliberations today for a fifth day with no indication they were approaching a verdict soon. On Thursday, jurors sent out a note asking for a dictionary, triggering a brief flurry of activity as U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene and lawyers in the case debated whether they should fill the request. The judge and lawyers for both sides were against providing a dictionary, and the jurors subsequently said they didn't need one, anyway. ``The next thing you know they will look up `conspiracy' and then they will know more about it than we do,'' Greene quipped. Poindexter, former White House national security adviser, is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. Prosecutor Dan Webb said he has experience with dictionary requests from other trials. He suggested the judge find out what word the jurors wanted to look up, and then possibly send the definition to them. If it's a legal term, it wouldn't be appropriate to give the definition, since the judge already had instructed the jurors on the law, Webb suggested. If it's not a legal term, it would be proper to illuminate the jurors, he added. Greene agreed that a response of some kind should be sent the jurors, saying ``I hate to ... tell them, `No, go away, don't bother me'.'' Defense attorney Richard Beckler had no objection to the plan. Greene sent a note to the jurors asking them about the word. Ten minutes later, laughter erupted in the courtroom as Greene climbed to the bench and read the note from jurors, which said, ``Thank you. The definition we requested before is no longer needed.'' Poindexter, who was national security adviser to former President Reagan, is accused of covering up Oliver North's military assistance to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua and the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran. The jurors were sequestered Tuesday after news reporters contacted two jurors. The eight women and four men are in the care of U.S. marshals. Under a court order, the marshals transport them between the federal courthouse and a hotel and provide them with meals and up to two alcoholic beverages a day.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Deliberating College Student's Fate in Baby Drowning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The 12-member...' , to UPDATE with deliberations resuming.
DOC.TEXT: A college student was either out of her mind or lying, attorneys told jurors who began deciding whether she should be imprisoned for life in the drowning of her newborn in a dormitory toilet. If convicted of first-degree murder, 18-year-old freshman Claire Moritt would be ineligible for parole until she's 43 under mandatory sentencing guidelines. ``Be certain you can live with it the rest of your life, because Claire Moritt will,'' defense attorney B. Anderson Mitcham warned the jury before it began considering its The 12 jurors met for about three hours Thursday and were sequestered for the night before resuming deliberations this morning. A full day of closing arguments Thursday focused on the defense argument that Ms. Moritt was temporarily insane and had no memory of being pregnant or giving birth. ``The excuse `I don't remember' may just be the biggest lie of all,'' said Assistant State Attorney Stephen Crawford. ``It keeps you from having to explain all the other inconsistencies in your story.'' Crawford recounted in detail the morning of Oct. 23, 1989, when the Hillsborough Community College student from Hollywood gave birth in her dorm room. He claimed she made a conscious decision to kill her baby son. Using a chalkboard, diagrams and a photograph of the dead 6-pound, 9-ounce infant, Crawford began by describing how a roommate awoke to the sounds of a baby crying. ``It's nothing. I'm having my period. Go to bed,'' was Ms. Moritt's explanation, according to court testimony. When Ms. Moritt went into the bathroom and her roommate noticed blood on the floor and more crying sounds, other friends gathered outside her door for nearly an hour asking her what was wrong. ``Her roommates were going to come in and find her. She had to do something,'' Crawford told the jury. When roommates finally did get inside, the found Ms. Moritt kneeling next to the toilet, where later in the day they discovered the baby stuffed headfirst, wrapped in bloody towels and sheets. Mitcham emphasized during his final arguments that nine psychiatrists and psychologists had testified Ms. Moritt suffered from a dissociative disorder in which she mentally denied the existence of the pregnancy and the events surrounding it. ``Claire fits the dissociative disorder perfectly,'' Mitcham said, noting that one expert even planned to use the case as an example in his medical school classes. ``You're going to have to decide whether she knew what she was doing or not.'' But prosecutor Crawford blasted the defense psychiatrist and psychologist testimony as ``psychobabble,'' saying that nobody can tell what was in a person's mind five or six months ago. ``There's a difference between denying something and flat-out lying,'' Crawford said, adding that Ms. Moritt variously explained her apparent pregnancy to her friends an ulcer, tumor and ovarian cyst. ``Down through the ages criminals have tried to flee,'' Crawford said. ``She attempted to flee _ not physically but mentally _ from the scene of the crime. Don't let her do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Vandal Sprays Unknown Chemical on Rembrandt's ``Night Watch''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with museum officials saying damage minimal, information on attacker, plans for restoring painting, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed man, described by police as confused, sprayed Rembrandt's famous painting ``The Night Watch'' with an unidentified chemical today, but museum officials said damage was minimal. It was the second attack on the priceless art work in nearly 15 years, and the third this century. Dutch Television said the spray was concentrated sulfuric acid, but museum officials would not confirm the report. Immediately after the attack, a museum guard applied a neutralizing agent, and the damage to the 1642 masterpiece appeared limited to surface veneer, Rijksmuseum spokesman Piet van Thiel said. Museum guards seized the attacker and handed him over to police, according to another museum spokesman, Frans van der Avert. The painting is guarded around-the-clock by an unarmed security company worker. Police said they did not know what prompted the attack. Spokesman Klaas Wilting said the 31-year-old suspect was a Dutch national from The Hague, the capital of the Netherlands. The man was not identified by name in line with police policy and was being held on suspicion of vandalism. ``He is confused and not telling us anything at the moment,'' Wilting said shortly after the attack. Barry Olshen of Toronto, Canada, said he was standing among a group of museum visitors and right next to the man, who was wearing a long, hooded tan coat. The vandal pushed his way through the crowd to a steel barrier about two yards in front of the painting. Suddenly he took a ``little spray pump he had been concealing in his hand'' and sprayed the painting, Olshen told The Associated Press. The chemical dripped over an area of almost a square yard, covering it in white splotches. The damage ``doesn't seem to be too bad,'' Van Thiel told reporters at the national museum. He said the chemical failed to eat its way through the painting's veneer to the delicate paint layer. ``Immediately after the attack, the guard slapped the bottle out of his hand (and) sprayed the painting with a benign chemical substance that is always there,'' Van Thiel said. He said the painting would be taken to a secret location for restoration but would probably be on display again in about two weeks. Van Thiel said a new veneer layer would take several months to dry, during which the painting would be kept behind glass to protect it from dust. He said there were no plans to put the painting, which yearly attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors from around the world, behind a protective shield. The painting has been under permanent guard since 1979, when it was put back on diplay after a four-year restoration period that followed a knife attack on Sept. 14, 1975. A Dutch schoolmaster claiming to be on a divine mission made several deep slashes in ``The Night Watch.'' He was never tried but committed to a mental asylum, where he later committed suicide. During World War I, an unemployed shoemaker made several knife slashes in the art work to protest his inability to find work. ``The Night Watch'' measures 12 feet by 14.5 feet and shows a gathering of 17th-century militiamen. It is believed to commemorate celebrations surrounding the 1638 visit to the Dutch capital by French Queen Maria de Medici. It is considered a prime example of Rembrandt's skilled handling of light and dark. Its most noteworthy artistic element is a beam of light which illuminates a richly dressed woman in the foreground. The museum has never valued ``The Night Watch,'' which is not insured, in line with Culture Ministry policy.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Neil Sedaka Hospitalized in Danbury
DOC.TEXT: Singer-songwriter Neil Sedaka has been admitted to Danbury Hospital for treatment of diverticulitis, a hospital spokesman said today. Sedaka, 51, was admitted to the hospital Tuesday, spokesman John Morgan said. The singer was listed in good condition today. Morgan said Sedaka is considering surgery to alleviate the intestinal inflammation. Sedaka, a singer-composer who first reached fame in the 1950s, has written and recorded dozens of popular songs including ``Breaking Up is Hard to Do,'' ``Calendar Girl'' and ``Stupid Cupid.'' Sedaka has a weekend home in Fairfield County.

DOC.HEAD: Takeover Maneuvering For UAL Stretched Over Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of Checchi.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-UAL
DOC.TEXT: Here are the major developments in the UAL Corp. buyout story:

_June 1989: NWA Inc. accepts a $3.65 billion bid for Northwest Airlines from an investor group led by Alfred Checchi, stirring takeover interest in airline companies. _August: Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis offers $5.4 billion, or $240 a share, for UAL Corp., the parent of United Airlines. He later sweetens the bid to $6.19 billion, or $275 a share. _Sept. 14: UAL directors accept a $6.75 billion offer, or $300 a share, from United's pilots, management and British Airways PLC. The offer includes labor and wage concessions. _Sept. 15: Davis says he will match the offer and demand no labor concessions. _Oct. 13: The $6.75 billion takeover by pilots, management and British Airways collapses when financing fails. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials falls 190 points. _Oct. 17: Davis withdraws his matching bid for UAL. _Oct. 20: British Airways says it will no longer participate in takeover talks. _Oct. 30: United pilots, without a contract since April 1988, resume talks with the company. _Oct. 31: Machinists union says it won't join Davis in making a new offer for UAL. _Nov. 1: Investor Saul Steinberg tells the government he wants to buy 15 percent to 25 percent of UAL stock. _Nov. 3: The investment group Coniston Partners says it has a 9.7 percent stake in UAL and wants to reduce the size of the board of directors. _Jan. 8, 1990: UAL directors tell financial advisers to consider a recapitalization of the company. _Jan. 24: United's three labor unions say they are willing to buy 75 percent of the stock. Directors say it is not a formal acquisition bid and tell their advisers to try to come up with a firm proposal. _March 19: UAL unions announce a new $3.8 billion offer. Coniston, now holding an 11.8 percent stake, says that unless the board agrees to an employee buyout, it will attempt to oust UAL's board in a proxy contest. _March 22: UAL board says the union offer has ``serious deficiencies'' but agrees to negotiate. It also directs its financial advisers to develop plan to sell company assets and consider buyout bids from other suitors. _March 23: UAL's board announces it will let former suitor Marvin Davis again buy company stock, stirring speculation of a new Davis bid. _March 30: UAL's non-union workers hire a lawyer to help them muscle into employee buyout talks after being rebuffed by unions leading the effort. _April 5: UAL board meets to consider sweetened buyout offer from unions. _April 6: After all-night session, UAL board announces they have agreed to sell the parent of the nation's second largest-airline to its employees for $201 a share or $4.38 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Says Husband Committed Suicide Over Fight With IRS
DOC.TEXT: A North Carolina woman told a Senate panel today that her husband was so distraught from a lingering fight with the Internal Revenue Service that he killed himself so she could use his insurance money to continue the battle. The courts eventually ruled that Kay Council of High Point, N.C., owed nothing and ordered the IRS to cancel a lien on her property. However, she told the Senate Finance oversight subcommittee, she has spent $70,000 in legal fees, she had to sell her home, her credit rating is stained and ``I was cheated of growing old with the man I love.'' ``We just got caught up in the middle of a big IRS screw-up,'' Mrs. Council said, ``and we couldn't get out of it.'' Mrs. Council's story highlighted a subcommittee hearing into how the IRS is implementing the so-called Taxpayer Bill of Rights, a 1988 law designed to protect taxpayers in disputes with the agency. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr., who preceded Mrs. Council to the witness stand, was not asked about her story. She has refused to sign a waiver of her privacy rights and the IRS is thus prohibited from discussing the case. On the whole, Goldberg said, ``we are indeed making a great deal of progress'' in seeing that taxpayer rights are respected. He acknowledged that mistakes are made, and pleaded for tax simplification and a budget big enough to train the IRS's 120,000 employees. ``What the American public resents is complexity, uncertainty ... hassles with the IRS that take month after month after month to resolve,'' Goldberg said. Questioned by Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., the subcommittee chairman, Goldberg denied the IRS has a quota system for rewarding collections officers or a bounty system for businesses that snitch on cheating competitors. ``I think that is reprehensible,'' Goldberg said after Pryor read a second-hand account from a businessman who reported attending a meeting in which an IRS agent implied a lower tax bill for those who turned in cheats. ``We're not going to let it happen,'' the commissioner said. The Councils' problems with the IRS began after their attempt to write off a $70,000 tax-shelter loss on their 1979 tax return was rejected. Mrs. Council said she and her husband had been prepared to pay the tax shortage resulting from that denial, but that the IRS never informed them of the deficiency. In 1983, she said, the IRS sent a bill for $183,021 taxes and interest, but it was not until two years later that the notice of deficiency arrived _ four years late. The agency was slow in admitting the mistake, although it turned out that the original notice had been mailed to the wrong address. After years of fighting in the courts, Mrs. Council said, she came home one evening in June 1988 and found a note from her husband. ``I have taken my life in order to provide capital for you. ... It's purely a business decision,'' the note read. ``You will find my body on the lot on the north side of the house.'' Mrs. Council pleaded with Congress to ``control the IRS, to keep it from destroying people's lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Episcopal School Found Negligent in Mount Hood Tragedy
DOC.TEXT: The father of a 16-year-old boy who died climbing Mount Hood says he'll use part of a half-million-dollar jury award to create a memorial fund for his son. ``It isn't the money. I wanted everyone to know those deaths were needless,'' Richard Haeder said after a jury ruled the Oregon Episcopal School was negligent in his son's death. But the same jury found no negligence by Ralph Summers, the guide hired by the private school to help lead the ill-fated climb up Oregon's highest peak in May 1986. Haeder's son, Richard, was among nine who died on the climb, including its leader, the Rev. Thomas Goman. Summers was the only adult to survive, along with three students. Neither Summers nor Oregon Episcopal School officials would comment. It was the first suit stemming from the tragedy to come to trial. Parents of at least five of the victims settled with the school out of court. The Multnomah County Circuit Court jury delivered the verdict shortly before 8 p.m. Thursday following about 5{ hours of deliberation. Haeder said that he and his wife, Judith, hope the verdict will encourage safer climbing and prevent other parents from having to ``endure the anguish we've had to.'' He declined to comment on the jury's decision not to find Summers negligent. His attorneys claimed during the trial that Goman and Summers forced the students up to near the summit of the 11,235-foot mountain despite bad weather and signs of hypothermia. The party got lost in a blizzard as they retreated from the summit and were forced to dig a snow cave for shelter as the sun set. The next morning, Summers and a student hiked to safety and notified authorities. The snow cave wasn't marked, however, and it took two days of intensive searching to find the bodies of Goman, another adult and seven students. Two other students were found alive. In closing arguments, Haeder's attorney, Paul Luvera, reminded the jury that Haeder's son pleaded to return. ``Richie was crying; he wanted to go back and they kept going,'' Luvera said. ``And then he died a horrible, painful death with people dying all around him in a tomb made of ice.'' Attorney Mark Wagner, representing Summers and the school, said the storm that struck the mountain was three times stronger than had been predicted. ``People died because a storm came in before our people got off the mountain,'' he said. ``In the real world, accidents do happen and it doesn't mean people are negligent or at fault.''

DOC.HEAD: Caucasus Republic's Party Chief Replaced
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party officials meeting in the troubled Caucasus republic of Armenia today replaced their party leader Suren Arutyunyan, the Tass news agency said. Arutyunyan was appointed in May 1988 after the first wave of ethnic violence between Armenia and neighboring Azerbaijan over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region. But the violence only has gotten worse. Hundreds of people have been killed in the past two years and hundreds of thousands more have been forced to flee their homes. Tass said the Central Committee of the Amenian Communist Party replaced Arutyunyan at his own request so he could be transferred to other work. It did not say what new job the former party leader would take up. He was replaced by V.M. Movsisyan, a first deputy premier and head of the republic's agricultural-industrial complex. Arutyunyan was replaced a couple of months after the Azerbaijan Communist Party chief, Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov, lost his job and was expelled from the party. He was blamed for serious mistakes that led to bloodshed in the Azerbaijan capital, Baku. Anti-Armenian riots broke out in Baku on Jan. 13 and Soviet troops stormed into the city a week later. By official count about 200 people were killed. Vezirov and Arutyunyan were picked to run their republics on the same day, May 21, 1988. But the party organizations in both republics have been criticized for failing to control the unrest and increasing calls for the two republics to gain more freedom or even leave the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter's Notebook: Readers' Changing Habits; a Plagarizing Kemp
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 of the nation's newspaper editors met here this week to talk shop and look over some political leaders. Footnotes from the meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors:
DOC.HEAD: ``Catching the News''
DOC.TEXT: At a time of stagnant newspaper circulation, editors worried about the challenge of producing a newspaper that simultaneously appeals to two groups: loyal readers, who like to read and are deeply interested in the world; and the often-younger readers _ or non-readers _ who grew up on television, have little love of reading and chiefly want news that will affect their lives. Researcher Kris McGrath, who helped write a report on ``How Readers Look at Newspapers,'' put the distinction this way: ``In this nation of specialists, the daily newspaper habit appears to be declining. People speak of `catching' the news rather than keeping up with it. The preferred way to `catch' the news often is while doing something else _ listening to the radio while driving or watching TV while exercising. It's hard to do something else while reading a newspaper other than drink a cup of coffee _ and coffee consumption is down, too.''
DOC.HEAD: Stealing from the Communists
DOC.TEXT: Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, former player for the professional Buffalo Bills football team, former congressman and former candidate for the 1988 Republican presidential nomination, gave the editors a speech full of the usual Kemp evangelism. He was introduced as a ``bleeding-heart conservative'' and in his speech used the term ``capitalism with a human face.'' An editor accused Kemp of benign plagiarism, swiping the catchword of Czechoslvakian communist reformers who were suppresed by Soviet tanks in 1968. Said the editor: ``You speak of `capitalism with a human face.' That actually is a paraphrase of Euro-communism, which was `communism with a human face.''' Replied Kemp: ``I'm not troubled at all by phrases. I can defend liberal democratic values in a Republican convention. ... So phrases don't bother me at all, whether I'm a bleeding-heart conservative or a progressive conservative or a Jeffersonian democratic Republican. ... So I'm not afraid at all to say that I would support the idea of capitalism with a human face or a socially responsible capitalist economy.''
DOC.HEAD: Coming Out Before One's Peers
DOC.TEXT: One of the meeting's most dramatic moments occurred when Leroy Aarons, senior vice president for news at the Oakland (Calif.) Tribune, ended a report to the editors on the views of homosexual journalists by publicly revealing his own sexual orientation. In a paragraph scribbled at the end of his typewritten text and read hurriedly in a choked voice, Aarons said: ``I want you to know that the doing of this report has had tremendous impact on gay and lesbian journalists across the nation. It has given them hope and new optimism. It has enhanced their respect for this organization. I, as an editor and a gay man, am proud of ASNE.''
DOC.HEAD: Using Homosexuals' Expertise
DOC.TEXT: Aarons reported that the 205 gay journalists who took part in a survey felt that ``coverage of gay and lesbian issues _ other than AIDS _ is at best mediocre.'' He said newspapers failed to take advantage of the expertise that their homosexual staff members could provide. ``We don't have to prime the supply pump to get gay and lesbian expertise on our staffs _ it is already there,'' he said. ``They may be hiding, but they are there, eager to be heard. ``The point to emphasize here is the link between workplace issues and coverage. A newsroom in which gay and lesbian staff people feel safe and accepted is one in which they will come forward and make their case on coverage. A workplace is which gays and lesbians know they can aspire to management roles, even though it is known they are gay, will be one with enhanced sensitivity to these issues in our communities. A newsroom where insulting remarks are forbidden also becomes a newsroom in which sensitive terminology is encoded and enforced.''
DOC.HEAD: Feeding the Habit
DOC.TEXT: David Halberstam, former Pulitzer prize-winning newspaper reporter, told the editors the way to retain readers is to improve their papers. He lectured on the danger of paying more attention to the bottom line than the printed word. ``A newspaper is like an addiction,'' Halberstam said. ``You have to have it. You have to read the sports, this section, that section. If you start shrinking it, you cut down the addiction.''

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Police Chief Fires Gun Accidentally
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the city Housing Department police admits he committed a .38-caliber boo-boo in his office and now, as judge, jury and executioner, will punish himself. Chief Louis Raiford Jr. said he inadvertently fired one of his two handguns as he sat at his desk Thursday. The bullet went through a wall to the adjoining office, where it lodged in the coat of Assistant Chief Peter Cummings, who luckily was in shirtsleeves at the time. Raiford's offense is formally called failure to safeguard his weapon, which calls for disciplinary action _ by the chief. ``I'm fully qualified to make the decision,'' Raiford said. He said he was considering options ranging from forfeiting five days pay, nearly $2,000 at his $100,000-a-year salary, to scolding himself. Raiford said the accidental firing occurred after he cleaned his two guns in preparation for later target practice.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Additive Spill Causes Waterway Closing
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 gallons of a lightweight petroleum distillate spilled into a busy waterway between New York and New Jersey this morning, closing it to traffic, officials said. The liquid, naphtha, has the consistency of lighter fluid and was expected to evaporate rapidly, said Lt. Cmdr. Paul Milligan at Coast Guard headquarters on Governor's Island, N.Y. ``It will probably dissipate quicker than we can get equipment to clean it up,'' Milligan said. ``We may just let the environment handle itself, just let it evaporate.'' A three-mile section of the Arthur Kill waterway was closed at 6:45 a.m. but reopened before noon. Reports indicated the spill was not harming two bird sanctuaries in the area, Milligan said. The additive, called naphtha, spewed into the waterway when a gasket blew out as workers at the General American Tank Storage Terminal in Carteret pressurized pipelines in preparing to load a vessel. ``Apparently they had a bad seal and it blew out,'' Milligan said. The waterway was hit Jan. 1-2 by a spill from a break in an Exxon pipeline that leaked 567,000 gallons of heating oil.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Battles Kill 11
DOC.TEXT: The once glittering hilltop of Ashrafiyeh, home to some of the oldest and richest Christian families, smoldered Friday as rival Christian forces battled for control of the district. Fighting in various sectors of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave killed 11 people and wounded 29 on Friday, police said.
