The battle over the enclave, a mere 10th of Lebanon, has killed 866 people and wounded 2,354 since it broke out Jan. 30 between army units under Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces militia run by Samir Geagea. Shells opened gaping holes in the residential buildings of Ashrafiyeh, a militia stronghold. Smoke billowed from apartments as explosions echoed across the city. A 130mm howitzer shell fired by Aoun's gunners scored a direct hit on a militia ammunition depot in the Karantina port district, police said. The area at the base of Ashrafiyah's hills is near Geagea's shell-shattered war council headquarters. The hit ignited a huge fire and a chain of powerful explosions. A cloud of smoke hung over the district. Thick smoke also billowed from the district's coastal strip, controlled by Geagea's militiamen, as well as from the wooded slopes of the Aoun-held Metn province northeast of the capital. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said the two sides hammered each other at the rate of 10 shells a minute at times. Firefighters ventured out despite the intensity of the shelling to combat the blazes in Ashrafiyeh and other areas. Sixteen cease-fires have been called since Jan. 30, when Aoun made his first move against Geagea. The truces have been worked out by a three-man Christian mediation committee and Maronite Catholic clergymen headed by Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. Geagea has proposed handing his garrisons over to the 22,000 predominantly Moslem troops loyal to President Elias Hrawi. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi's authority. The president was elected in November under terms of an Arab League-brokered accord intended to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun refuses to accept the accord because it does not include a timetable for the withdrawal from Lebanon of Syrian troops. A government source, speaking on condition of anonymity, stressed that ``the government will not send its troops into the enclave to become a party to the present conflict.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Stabbed While Walking With Baby; Palestinian Shot to Death
DOC.TEXT: A Jewish man wheeling his son in a baby carriage was stabbed in the back Friday by an Arab in Jerusalem's Old City, police said. In the Gaza Strip, soldiers shot to death a Palestinian teen-ager, hospital officials said. The stabbing victim was identified as Danny Robbins, 35. He was hospitalized in fair condition. Robbins told police he was walking to the grocery store when he was attacked. The bearded Robbins was wearing a Jewish skullcap when attacked. Police Inspector Rahamim Comfort said Robbins pulled out a pistol and fired three times in the air to summon police. Robbins was pushing his 1-year-old son in a carriage when he was assaulted, police said. The stroller overturned but the child was unhurt. Robbins is a seminary student who lives with a small community of Jews in the Moslem Quarter. Jewish efforts to buy property and move into the quarter have created tensions in the area. Police at the scene said the attacker was a Palestinian and the assault apparently was politically motivated. Police briefly closed the gates to the Old City, and Israel army radio said more than 170 Palestinians were detained for questioning. Robbins complained on Israel radio that no one tried to stop the assailant. ``They saw him, they saw him very well, but nobody tried to chase him,'' Robbins said. ``He was not armed except for the knife that remained in my back,'' Robbins added. Radio reports said an Arab doctor gave Robbins first aid, but Robbins said he received no care until an ambulance arrived. There have been several stabbings of Jews in the Old City during the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation. Another Jewish seminary student was stabbed in the Moslem Quarter last September. He recovered from his wounds. The clash in the Gaza Strip occurred outside the Great Mosque in Khan Yunis. Soldiers said it was a hotbed of uprising activity and welded it shut Wednesday. Arab reporters said Palestinian youths gathered outside the closed building to pray Friday, the Islamic holy day, and a stone-throwing confrontation with troops broke out. The victim was identified as Ali Suleiman Urbiya, 17, of the Khan Yunis refugee camp. Officials at Nasser Hospital in Khan Yunis said he was hit with a single bullet in the chest. Hospital officials said six other Palestinians were treated for wounds from rubber-coated steel balls. An army spokesman confirmed there was an incident in Khan Yunis but had no details. The death raised to 673 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the revolt against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. An additional 202 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have been slain in the uprising violence.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Fort Worth Museum to Sell Eakins Painting
DOC.TEXT: The Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth is planning to sell ``The Swimming Hole,'' a painting by 19th century American artist Thomas Eakins, a newspaper reported. The painting, which was purchased for $700 in 1925, could bring millions of dollars at auction. Owned by the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, the painting of six nude men and a dog has been on loan to the nearby Amon Carter Museum since January 1988. Carter Museum director Jan Keene Muhlert said Wednesday the painting was removed from display on Monday for shipment to New York. An auction date of May 24 has been set at Sotheby's in New York, sources told The Dallas Morning News. Modern Art Museum director E.A. Carmean Jr. would not comment on the reported sale. Eakins is regarded as one of the most important 19th century American painters.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senator Criticizes Gorbachev After Being Refused Entry into Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead, subs grafs 10-12, ``Through an...'' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY border guard said he called Moscow. Pickup 13th graf, ``Saudragis then...
DOC.TEXT: Soviet border guards today refused Sen. Alfonse D'Amato entry into Lithuania, which has been locked in a war of wills with the Kremlin since the Baltic republic declared independence. After being turned away at the small border crossing in northeast Poland, D'Amato denounced what he called the Soviet Union's ``psychological warfare'' on Lithuania, whose Parliament approved the independence declaration March 11. D'Amato wanted to enter Lithuania on a Lithuanian visa to demonstrate what he called Congress's solidarity with the republic. Instead, the New York Republican, who was invited to the capital of Vilnius by Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, was instructed to apply for a Soviet visa at a consulate. ``The sooner the United States wakes up to what is taking place and becomes realistic, the better,'' D'Amato told reporters at the border crossing. ``Mr. Gorbachev says one thing and does another. He talks about freedom and yet denies access to a free country. That is wrong.'' D'Amato flew to Poland on Thursday, planning to challenge the Soviet land blockade of Lithuania. Accompanied by Lithuania's foreign minister, Algrinas Saudragis, D'Amato and a half dozen aides traveled by chartered bus the 200 miles from Warsaw to Ogrodniki, Lithuania's only direct border opening to the outside world. They arrived at the crossing on a country road around 2 p.m. today, and Polish soldiers let them pass the first barrier on the Polish side. But another 100 yards down the road they came to a red-and-white barrier marking the Lithuanian frontier and guarded by Soviet KGB troops. Through an interpreter speaking Lithuanian, D'Amato asked Soviet Maj. Vitas Buchis for permission to enter the country. Buchis, a native Lithuanian serving in the Soviet border force, said he had to check by telephone with Moscow. After returning, Buchis told D'Amato that passage was forbidden. ``I am sorry but rules are rules. I am just following orders,'' he said. Saudragis then crossed into Lithuania alone. Extending his arm to D'Amato's across the frontier, Saudragis said: ``We shake hands over this border that divides us. But your support is strengthening our spirit.'' He also thanked the United States for never recognizing the forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union in 1940. The Soviet government since Tuesday has closed the Ogrodniki crossing to most traffic, permitting only Polish and Soviet citizens to use it to return home. Even in normal times, citizens of other countries are not allowed to pass the pair of wooden gates on the narrow rural road. The main international crossing between Poland and the Soviet Union is about 95 miles to the south, at Brest in the Soviet Byelorussian Republic. On Thursday, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of D'Amato's trip: ``We're always concerned about members of Congress and others getting too involved in foreign policy. But on the other hand, he is a senator who has an important message to deliver. He represents a broad constituency and has every right to make that trip and deliver his message.'' Congressmen, including D'Amato, have been urging President Bush to give Lithuania more support. Some U.S. politicians have suggested sanctions if force is used against the republic. D'Amato is the junior Republican on the Senate Intelligence Committee and also serves on the Appropriations Subcomittee on foreign operations. He is not considered one of the Senate's leading voices on foreign relations. Before he left Wednesday, D'Amato tried to deflect suggestions that the trip was designed to counteract problems at home. D'Amato's public opinion ratings have slipped dramatically since the Senate Ethics Committee began looking into allegations he used his influence to steer federal Housing and Urban Development money to friends and political supporters. ``Now, if every time I do something that's not associated with HUD, you're going to say `Oh, you're doing that because it's not associated with HUD,' that's silly,'' he told reporters Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Three Dead, 18 Injured in Miami Beach Hotel Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE number of unaccounted-for to 15 sted 16; move up quote from resident who escaped; give detail on search through building for victims; CORRECT manager's first name to Olimpia sted Olivia in 11th graf pvs; CORRECT attribution of quote in 12th graf to Marcello sted Jackson. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `He said another...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MH2,4,6; LaserColor MH3
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a residential hotel this morning, killing at least three people, injuring 18 and sending scores of mostly elderly residents running into the street, officials said. Fifteen people were unaccounted-for after the 3 a.m. fire at the Fontana Hotel was brought under control in about five hours, said Assistant Fire Chief John Reed. The hotel is on famed Collins Avenue north of the beach's trendy art deco district. ``It was incredible,'' said one resident, Joe Marcello, who jumped to safety from a second-floor window. ``Flames were shooting 40 feet in the air.'' Mayor Alex Daoud said the intensity of the three-alarm fire led investigators to suspect arson, but fire officials said the report was speculative. ``We have all the fire units of the city of Miami Beach working on the fire, attempting to get it under control,'' police Detective Jim Hyde said earlier. ``This is definitely the worst I've seen.'' Up to 200 residents of the three-story Fontana Hotel and 175 to 200 in the adjacent Prince Michael Hotel, which was threatened for a time, were evacuated, police said. By early afternoon, authorities were conducting a room-to-room search of the burned building and checking crowds outside the hotel, hospitals and a community center to narrow the list of missing tenants. Residents said the fire broke out near the elevator shaft in the front of the Fontana, and Hyde said the two bodies were found in the lobby area. He put the number of people injured at 18. ``They're not able to get inside yet _ it'll be all gone,'' police Sgt. Jim Scarberry said three hours into the fire. Many of the residents were elderly and infirm, according to Myrtle Jackson, 35, a yearly tenant on the second floor of the Fontana. She said she escaped out the back door after the building's managers ran through the hallways knocking on doors. Ms. Jackson said the smoke was too thick and there was no chance to help anyone else _ ``no time to be a hero tonight.'' Marcello, her roommate, said he heard his smoke alarm, which was installed to comply with a city ordinance requiring an electronic alarm in every hotel room. But he said he didn't realize the situation was serious until Olimpia Mihai, one of the owner-managers, started knocking on doors. By the time he gathered his passport and other papers, he said the hallway was too smoky to risk escape down the stairs. ``I started panicking. I ran back to my room and knocked the window out and just jumped down,'' said Marcello, 32. ``When I dove out the building, there were four cars engulfed in flames.'' He said another second-floor resident broke her window, dropped her baby to a man on the ground and jumped out herself. About five hours after the blaze began, the building's roof had collapsed and burning cinders showered down from the remnants of the roof. Smoke arched hundreds of feet in the early morning sky, partially obscuring oceanfront condominiums. Long-time residents said the hotel housed between 100 and 200 residents, most of whom rented by the week, month or year. A few vacationers also were believed in the building when the fire broke out. The American Red Cross was busing scores of residents to a nearby shelter. Spokeswomen at St. Francis, Mount Sinai and South Shore hospitals said 18 people were taken to their emergency rooms, and four were expected to be admitted. Many were suffering from burns and smoke inhalation. ``I have all people who have lost everything in the fire, including their medication, so we're treating them for whatever there individual needs are,'' said South Shore emergency room supervisor Carol Perlaza.

DOC.HEAD: Tables Turned on Texas Candidate Who Accused Opponent of Drug Use
Precede DALLAS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Mattox denials at news conference, picking up at the 7th graf pvs, `The drug use...'. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Jim Mattox, who has been harassing his Democratic runoff opponent with claims she used drugs, today flatly denied claims by two men that they saw him smoking marijuana in the 1970s. Mattox, the attorney general, vigorously denied reports today in Dallas and Houston newspapers. ``I'll tell them that they are liars to their faces,'' he said at a news conference. Mattox has criticized election opponent Ann Richards for refusing to answer yes or no when asked if she ever used an illegal drug, and has accused her of smoking marijuana in the 1970s. He said he was willing to take a lie detector test to dispute the allegations about him. ``I will,'' he said. ``And I want you to get Ms. Richards strapped in beside me when we do it.'' Houston lawyer Jim Sharp and former Dallas police officer Edward H. Lowe signed affidavits that they saw Mattox smoke marijuana on separate occasions. Lowe said he saw Mattox smoke marijuana in a Dallas apartment during an undercover investigation in the early 1970s, when Mattox was a Dallas lawyer. He said he didn't arrest Mattox because he was investigating a separate matter. Sharp said Mattox and he shared a marijuana cigarette in 1974 while in a car after the Democratic state convention in Austin. ``I've never used any marijuana or dangerous drugs, period,'' Mattox said about the accusations, which Sharp and Lowe made in the Houston Chronicle and The Dallas Morning News. The incidents the two men described ``absolutely did not take place,'' Mattox said today. ``I've never been in a car where there has ever been any marijuana smoked, by me or anybody else,'' Mattox said. The drug use issue first was presented at a debate before the March 13 primary. Mattox and former Gov. Mark White denied ever using illegal drugs, but Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, refused to answer the question. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, later said she has not had an alcoholic drink or a mood-altering chemical since leaving an alcohol recovery program in 1980. The issue has dominated the Democratic campaign, particularly since the primary that vaulted Mattox and Ms. Richards into the runoff. Mattox has said a former drug user could not effectively lead the state's efforts to end illegal drug use. Ms. Richards has not accused Mattox of drug use. Earlier this week, Mattox said he had affidavits signed by people who saw Ms. Richards use drugs in the 1970s. But he has refused to release the documents, citing the confidentiality of the people who made the allegations. On Thursday, The Houston Post quoted a woman it didn't identify as saying she had seen Ms. Richards in a restroom with other women who appeared to be smoking marijuana at an Austin convention in 1979. The Dallas Morning News, in today's editions, said the same woman confirmed her allegation in a polygraph examination paid for by the paper. ``I have no idea what they're talking about,'' Ms. Richards said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Search for Stolen Item: One House
DOC.TEXT: Thieves made off with an entire house, right down to the kitchen sink, and police are red-faced because they provided an escort. Murray D. Ladner, owner of Young's House Movers of Pass Christian, owns the 14-by-20-foot cottage and had planned to move it Thursday. ``The cottage had been jacked up on blocks and was ready to go,'' said Ladner, who is in the hospital recovering from back surgery. ``But when my brother-in-law took the equipment there to haul it away, it was gone.'' Ladner said it was taken late last week. ``I bought three of the cottages and had already sold two and moved them to new locations,'' Ladner said. ``This was the last and the lady who bought it was expecting it to be delivered Thursday afternoon. She was really surprised when I called and told her what had happened. ``She said, `You mean, it's been stolen?''' Ladner said he was surprised the theft went so smoothly. ``They had to have a permit for the police to escort them,'' he said. ``So apparently, they used an old moving permit, whited out the old stuff and put in new.'' Police Chief George Payne confirmed that officers had escorted the house out of town, and said the case was under investigation. Ladner said he suspects who the culprits are and has given their names to the police. ``People are really going to be surprised when they find out who took it,'' he said. ``They must be crazy because they know I know. They're already in enough trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Group Says Three Europeans Will be Freed
DOC.TEXT: A radical Palestinian group led by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal said today that preparations were under way to free at least three French and Belgian hostages it holds. The group said in a statement that the action was in response to an appeal by Libya's leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi. ``I am pleased to announce the acceptance of our movement in response to (Gadhafi's) appeal,'' Walid Khaled, Beirut spokesman for Fatah-Revolutionary Council, said in a statement issued in Beirut. ``I am also pleased to declare that the contacts and arrangements under way now include Mrs. Jacqueline Valente, her boyfriend, Fernand Houtekins, and their baby, Sony Houtekins.'' The statement, delivered to the offices of a Western news agency, added that the group ``hopes that this will draw the attention of the Belgian government that it should fulfill its pledges ... and curb Zionist activities against the revolution of our people.'' On Thursday, Abu Nidal's group said an effort was under way to free at least one of the hostages it holds. The group has acknowledged holding Valente, a 32-year-old French woman; her two daughters born in captivity; and five Belgians. The previously reported names of the two girls were Liberte and Palestine. On Wednesday, Gadhafi called for the release of Ms. Valente as a compassionate measure on the occasion of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan, which ends in late April. Gadhafi's call was carried by the official Libyan news agency JANA. Abu Nidal is backed by Libya and believed to be living in Tripoli, the Libyan capital. Fatah-Revolutionary Council said on Nov. 8, 1987, that it had seized the hostages aboard the French yacht Silco off the Gaza Strip. It claimed they were collaborating with Israel's Mossad secret service. But friends denied the charge and said the hostages were Roman Catholics on a holiday cruise. Because the boat hostages are believed to be in Libya they are not listed among the 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon, including eight Americans. Most of them are believed to be held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions. American journalist Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held Western hostage. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Two other daughters of Ms. Valente were freed after Libyan intervention on Dec. 29, 1988. Daughter Marie-Laure was 6 at the time, and Virginie, 5. They were returned to their father, Pascal Betille, who had divorced Ms. Valente. The Belgians are Emmanuel Houtekins, in his 40s; his wife, Godlieve Kets, age unknown; his son, Laurent, in his late teens; his daughter, Valerie, a teen-ager; and his brother Fernand, in his 40s.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Fishermen Kill and Kidnap Vietnamese Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Thai fishermen armed with knives and iron rods attacked a boat carrying 191 refugees from Vietnam, stabbing to death three refugees and kidnapping six of the women, U.N. officials said Friday. Eleven other refugees were missing and presumed drowned, said the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. It was the first known case this year of piracy against boat people off Malaysia's coast. The U.N. statement faxed to The Associated Press said that of the 191 boat people, only 171 escaped. They had left Camau, in the southern tip of Vietnam, on April 1 and were attacked the following day, the statement said. Those who escaped reached an American Exxon oil rig off the Trengganu coast in the South China Sea on April 3, the U.N. agency said. They were in a refugee camp awaiting resettlement. The statement did not identify the pirates, but officials said information given by the refugees identified the attackers as Thai fishermen. The incident ``underlines once again the importance of granting safe haven as soon as possible to Vietnamese asylum seekers in accord with all humanitarian and maritime obligations,'' the U.N. High Commissioner said in its statement. According to the account provided by the U.N. group, the pirates were in four boats. One pulled up alongside the Vietnamese vessel and offered the refugees ice and water. The other boats then approached from different directions and surrounded the targeted vessel. Three men armed with knives boarded and took watches, jewelry, money and the boat's compass. They attempted to abduct a 20-year-old female. When she resisted, one of them stabbed her to death and threw her body into the sea. At that point, six or seven men with knives, iron rods and hacksaws boarded the Vietnamese boat and began looting it. They threw all the food overboard, took the battery and most of the fuel, then abducted six women and left. One boat later returned and rammed the Vietnamese boat at full speed, causing 20 to 30 people to fall overboard. At least two Vietnamese were stabbed to death when they attempted to grab on the ropes hanging down from the pirate's boat. The survivors managed to start up their battered boat again and steered it in the direction of the oil platform, which could be seen in the distance. The last major piracy attack on the boat people off the Malaysian coast occured in August 1989. Seventy-one people drowned when pirates looted and sank their boat. Thirteen survivors were picked up by Exxon boats.

DOC.HEAD: Margaret Polk, The Memphis Belle, Dies From Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Polk, the ``Memphis Belle'' whose romance with a B-17 bomber pilot became a celebrated World War II love story, has died of cancer. She was 67. Ms. Polk died Thursday at her home. Robert K. Morgan, who was widely credited with being the first B-17 pilot complete 25 missions over Nazi-occupied Europe, named the plane ``Memphis Belle'' in honor of Ms. Polk. The romance generated international headlines and helped the War Department when Morgan began a war-bonds tour in 1943. He said his long separation from Ms. Polk during the tour cooled the relationship. ``She was a courageous lady, and I'd like for her to be remembered as an upbeat person who never had a bad word for anybody,'' said Morgan, now 69, of Asheville, N.C. After the romance ended, Ms. Polk returned to college and later became an airline flight attendant. A 1946 inheritance from her father left Ms. Polk independently wealthy and she devoted much of her time to working with alcoholics and raising funds for the preservation and restoration of the plane, which is now a Mud Island tourist attraction. A memorial service will be held Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: 44 People Reported Killed as Police Fire on Protesters in Nepal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf `At sundown...' with graf to CORRECT that blackout opposition-organized. Pickup 8th graf `Soldiers holding...'; INSERTS 2 grafs after 16th graf `A doctor...' to UPDATE with doctor saying government hauling away bodies. Pickup 17th graf `Another witness...'
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire on 200,000 pro-democracy demonstrators marching toward the royal palace today, and at least 35 people were killed, witnesses said. At least nine more people were killed in clashes with police during similar demonstrations in other parts of the country, witnesses said. The violence occurred immediately after King Birendra dismissed the government and promised talks with pro-democracy activists. Opposition leaders rejected the offer and vowed to continue their nearly 2-month-old struggle for a multiparty political system. In Katmandu, the capital, bands of angry protesters calling for greater democracy in this Himalayan monarchy tried to set fire to government buildings and the houses of politicians loyal to King Birendra. Gunshots and automatic weapons fire echoed throughout the city. At sundown, the city was plunged into darkness as an opposition-planned blackout took effect. Clouds of tear gas fogged the streets. Soldiers holding automatic weapons were seen patrolling in trucks and on foot. The mostly deserted streets were littered with bricks, shoes and slipper, and there were piles of burning tires. In Washington, the State Department urged Nepal to restore calm without further violence. ``The U.S. government deplores the deaths which have occurred and the violence which has taken place,'' said spokesman Mark Dillon. ``The United States urgently calls on the government of Nepal to exercise restraint in restoring order,'' Dillon said. ``As a step toward this goal we urge that a dialogue with opposition leaders begin immediately.'' Witnesses said police first shot tear gas and beat demonstrators with sticks when they came within 500 yards of the royal palace. The protesters were waving flags and chanting anti-government slogans. When that failed to turn back the protesters, police opened fire. One witness said he saw at least 200 demonstrators fall to the ground, but accounts of the number of casualties varied. Another witness, speaking from a hotel in the city's center, said he saw 35 corpses at Bir Hospital, the city's largest. ``There are hundreds more wounded. It's a bloody mess,'' said the witness, speaking on condition of anonymity. A doctor at Bir Hospital, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said a British man was among the dead. He also said another British man and a Dutch man were among the wounded. Their identities were not released pending notification of relatives. There was no immediate word on American casualties. Doctors at Bir Hospital and at the Teaching Hospital said they had a total of 9 bodies and 150 wounded people. But they charged that soldiers had been carting away corpses from the city. ``Bodies were in taken trucks for disposal by the army,'' said the doctor at Bir Hospital. ``At least 200 to 300 people must have died.'' Another witness contacted by telephone said that he saw 30 young men gunned down as he watched the demonstration from a hotel window. ``The people were unarmed and the government just started shooting,'' he said. ``A whole line of demonstrators fell.'' He said security forces carried away some of the wounded but others were left lying in the street. A Western diplomat, contacted by phone from New Delhi, said exact casualty figures were difficult to confirm, ``but there's been lots of bloodshed,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. In the town of Butwal, 120 miles west of Katmandu, witnesses said security forces killed seven people and wounded scores. Two others were killed in clashes in Pokhara, 160 miles northwest of the capital, other witnesses said. Witnesses speaking from Janakpur said police fired on crowds in that city, but there were no reports of casualties. King Birendra said on state-run radio today that a new government will be formed by Lokendra Bahadur Chand, a former prime minister regarded as more moderate toward political opposition than former Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha. Prior to today's violence at least 16 people had been killed in clashes between demonstrators and the police since the banned Nepali Congress party and a coalition of left-wing groups began the protests on Feb. 18. Hundreds of people have been arrested, and human rights activists have charged that many detainees have been tortured. Birenda said Shrestha's government had failed to maintain law and order during the 47-day-old campaign for multiparty democracy and he promised that the new government would ``consult people holding different political views.'' The king also said committees would be formed to make recommendations on constitutional reforms and investigate accusations of police abuses against the demonstrators. Major opposition leaders rejected the offer and vowed to intensify protests by the pro-democracy movement. ``The royal proclamation has given a slap in the face to the countrywide call for democracy,'' the leader of the Nepali Congress party, Ganesh Man Singh, said in a statement from his hospital bed. ``The people's demands can only be reflected in a multiparty system,'' Singh said. ``Hollow consolations of reforms made in the royal proclamation can not deter the people's aspirations. Therefore, the people's movement will be carried on with even greater intensity and even more extensively.'' Singh has been under house arrest since the pro-democracy campaign was launched by his Nepali Congress and a coalition of left-wing groups. Radha Krishna Mainali, a leader of the United Left Front, also said the king's response was inadequate. `The royal proclamation has not fulfilled the demands of the people,'' Mainali said in a written statement. ``Instead of preparing a new constitution to pave the way for a multiparty system, there is talk, including reforms, within the previous constitution, which is unacceptable.'' The protesters are demanding the withdrawal of a 1961 royal decree banning political parties and separate platforms in the Rashtriya Panchayat, or national assembly. Power in Nepal is technically shared between the assembly and the king, but the monarch nominates one-fifth of the assembly's 140 members and, according to political observers, approves the nominations of others standing for election. Nepal's two-year experiment with a Western-style democracy ended in 1961 when King Mahendra, Birendra's father, dismissed the government of the Nepali Congress party, accusing it of corruption and inept administration.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Launch Counteroffensive, Claim to Seize One Town
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Cambodian guerrillas launched major attacks Friday in a bid to recapture territory seized by government forces in recent weeks, senior guerrilla officials said. A spokesman for the Khmer People's National Liberation Front said the guerrillas seized Don Noi late Friday as the counteroffensive got under way. ``We have launched a large scale counteroffensive involving all our forces,'' said Ok Serei Sopheak, a senior official of the National Liberation Front. He said the objective was not only to recapture lost territory but to take Sisophon, a major town in western Cambodia. The front is one of three guerrilla groups allied in a loose coalition to fight the Vietnam-backed government in Cambodia. Others in the coalition are the communist Khmer Rouge, and followers of the former Cambodian head of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The non-communist National Liberation Front is reeling from government attacks in which it lost much of 2,000 square miles of territory it had held since last fall. The embattled territory is in western Cambodia near the Thai frontier, where the guerrilla coalition has most of its bases. The latest blow to the guerrillas occurred Tuesday when government troops retook the district capital of Thmar Puok. This town, along with Kok Mon, Sisophon and Don Noi, appear to be the prime targets of the guerrilla counteroffensive. ``We will show the world that we are still strong,'' Ok Serei Sopheak said. He said new shipments of ammunition from China in recent days had given the guerrillas the means to retake the lost ground. Thousands of civilians have fled into forests and other areas in recent days to avoid the fighting. The 11-year-long Cambodian war has taken the lives of thousands of civilians. Western analysts at Aranyaprathet, a key Thai border town, said it appeared the guerrillas had ``bounced back'' from recent defeats, but it remained to be seen whether they were disciplined and strong enough to hold territory. The guerrillas claim Vietnam has sent back several thousand troops to bolster the Phnom Penh side and that this had largely accounted for the guerrillas' recent defeats. Vietnam claimed all its forces had withdrawn from Cambodia in September, and it denys any soldiers have returned. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978 to oust the Khmer Rouge and set up a pro-Hanoi government in Phnom Penh. The guerrillas and independent analysts say the monsoon season, which gets under way at the end of April, will probably give the guerrillas a major advantage. The government employs tanks and large artillery pieces, which will be difficult to move over rain-soaked areas.

DOC.HEAD: Polls Indicate Crucial Election To End Inconclusively
DOC.TEXT: For the third time in less than a year, Greece is holding an election aimed at breaking a deadlock that left temporary coalitions running the country since the scandal-ridden Socialists were thrown out. Opinion polls indicate Sunday's parliamentary election will fail to produce a one-party government, resulting in another coalition administration with small parties in a powerbroker's role. Frustration has led to violence. Leftist terrorists calling for an election boycott have set off scores of bombs, and clashes have erupted between conservatives and Socialists. The leading conservative New Democracy party led by Constantine Mitsotakis is hoping that this time around, it will win an absolute majority in the 300-member unicameral Parliament. It came close in June and November elections. The conservatives won 146 seats in June and improved to 148 places in November, three short of a majority. The Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was a close second. The conservatives and the small Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress teamed up after the June vote, which ousted Papandreou after eight years in office. The short-lived alliance, with Mitsotakis as prime minister, presided over the indictment of Papandreou and some of his ministers for alleged involvement in financial scandals and illegal wiretapping of political opponents. No trial date has been set. In November, another alliance comprised of the conservatives, Socialists and Communist-dominated Coalition collapsed in February after it was unable to confront growing economic problems or stem a resurgence of urban terrorism. Prime Minister Xenophon Zolotas, 86, a former governor of the Bank of Greece, remains caretaker until a new government is chosen. The country faces 17 percent inflation and a $15 billion budget deficit. The European Community has said Greece is in danger of bankruptcy and the EC will not bail it out because Greece violated austerity requirements of a 1985 loan. Papandreou, 71, has failed to clarify his party's platform, promising only stability and progress. Mitsotakis, also 71, pledges private investment in the ailing economy which would create 100,000 new jobs. Conservatives and Socialists disagree over U.S. bases. New Democracy says the bases and NATO membership are essential for defense, while the Socialists say any future bases agreement should be put to a referendum. Coalition leaders offered nothing new in their party platform, renewing their often repeated pledge to protect workers' rights. In November's election the conservatives got 46.19 percent of the vote, the Socialists received 40.68 percent for 128 seats and the Coalition dropped to 10.97 percent and 21 seats. The Environmentalist-Alternative party and two independents took the other three seats. Respected pollster Panayote Dimitras expects Sunday's results will ``more or less'' be the same as in the previous vote. ``I see all parties falling slightly. But the Coalition could fall a little more because of protest votes that may go to the Environmentalist-Alternative party or blank ballots,'' said Dimitras. He said that if the Environmentalist-Alternative party, which won one seat in the last election, gains one or two more seats, ``they could also become the key to power.'' The collapse of communist regimes in Eastern Europe and social reforms in the Soviet Union could also have a negative effect on the left. Campaigning was low-key with more debates and interviews on nationwide television than in past elections. Gone were the many colorful fiestas and fireworks where each major party drew tens of thousands of supporters at outdoor rallies. Urban terrorist groups claimed responsibility for scores of bombings in an attempt to intimidate the country's 8 million voters. The Revolutionary Popular Struggle underground guerrilla organization called on voters to boycott the election _ describing it as a ``political farce.'' Some minor clashes occurred between conservative and socialist supporters in various parts of the country. One clash in Iraklion, Crete, resulted in the shooting death of a socialist follower and the wounding of four other people, including a journalist and member of the conservative party.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Fast-Food Eatery On U.S. Waterfront Lures the Curious
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Janae in 20th graf is cq
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: You may not be able to get borscht as fast as you could a Big Mac at Red Square. But some customers at the first Soviet-American fast-food eatery in this country just love the piroshkis. Others are wondering ``Where's the beef?'' ``I had to come and try it,'' said Robert Foxhall of Chesapeake. ``I always try to eat a different variety of food. This is wonderful ethnic fare.'' Foxhall left the stand at the Waterside Festival Marketplace with a dozen piroshkis _ which look like elongated egg rolls _ for co-workers at his office. Danny Crocker of Norfolk found the piroshkis a bit greasy, but ``so are french fries and I love french fries.'' In January, McDonald's opened its first franchise in the Soviet Union and is serving up to 50,000 people a day. The restaurant here, named Piroshkis, a joint venture between Soviet and American investors, opened this week on the Norfolk waterfront. The Soviet partner is Tomak-Kiev. Mark Aynbinder, a Soviet emigre and president of the American partners, described the company as the largest Soviet manufacturer of food processing equipment. Local officials and Aynbinder say the joint-venture is the first of its kind in the United States between investors from the two countries in recent memory. The U.S. Department of Commerce said they had no records to indicate otherwise. The eatery was established in Norfolk partly because sailors from Soviet navy ships that visited last summer got a warm welcome from the community. Also, Aynbinder initiated contacts with friends in the Ukrainian city of Kiev that got the venture off the ground. Piroshkis takes its name from the staple finger food of the Soviet Union. It is a pastry stuffed with potatoes and mushrooms, or beef and rice, or jam, or beef and fish, and deep fried. The restaurant also offers Russian pancakes, Russian donuts, Russian coffee and Russian tea. Ellen Landrum of Norfolk said she came to try the fare out of curiosity. ``Well, there wasn't enough beef in the piroshki. But the pancakes are good and the tea is wonderful,'' she said. She said the service tended to follow a Russian stereotype. ``It was a little bit slow and I thought I had to wait longer than I ought,'' she said. The 600-square-foot stall is on one end of a food court where vendors also sell seafood, gourmet coffee, ice cream, barbecue, hamburgers, and Chinese, Filipino, Mexican and Italian dishes. Piroshkis had more than its share of customers. E.W. Michaels of Norfolk polished off four piroshkis and announced himself satisfied. ``One of the nice things about this country is that we have a touch of everything,'' he said. ``I'll never get to Russia. It's nice to know about other things, other people.'' The Russian accents behind the counter piqued the curiosity of many customers. Several Russian technicians minded the piroshki-, pancake- and donut-making equipment. The Soviet investors provided the equipment; the Americans market the franchise and the equipment. The technicians are here to train American employees. Luba and Igor Stefnek waited on customers and fielded as many questions about Russian lifestyle as they did orders. Not all the customers gave glowing reviews. Four-year-old Janae Smith of Portsmouth made a sour face after she ate a beef and rice piroshki. Her mother, Della Smith, said Janae was not big on anything new. Asked to compare Russian fast food to American, customers at the new restaurant were divided. Ms. Landrum and Foxhall said they stay away from American fast food, but would return to Piroshkis. But Janae was adamantly a McDonald's fan. Crocker said he, too, would return, but ``hamburgers are still Number One. When I visited friends in Germany, I had to go looking for a hamburger after three weeks. A man has to have his hamburger.''

DOC.HEAD: West German Calls on Western Democracies to Form `New Partnership'
With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher called Friday for a ``new Atlantic partnership'' of North American and European democracies to forge ``one Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals.'' ``It would involve the United States in the building of the common European house,'' Genscher said in a speech to the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Speaking in English, Genscher said, ``We don't want Germany to pursue unity alone. We don't want the country to be neutralized but to be tied to Europe's fate.'' In an interview conducted in German after the speech, the foreign minister was asked about Secretary of State James A. Baker III's announcement that the Soviet Union is dropping its demand that a reunified Germany be neutralized. Baker, who has been meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze, said the Soviets continue to resist the inclusion of a united Germany in the North Atlantic alliance. Genscher was asked whether Baker's statement enhanced the likelihood of a single Germany becoming a member of NATO. He said he thought it was premature to assess the U.S.-Soviet talks but that what he had heard so far ``confirms the impression'' he received last month when he met with Shevardnadze in Windhoek, Namibia. He said his impression was ``that the Soviet Union is taking a constructive position or attitude both toward the building of a future Europe ... and also to German reunificiation, which they view as a law-abiding procedure.'' In his speech, Genscher said, ``I call upon the North American democracies and the members of the European Community to issue a joint declaration heralding a new Atlantic partnership, a declaration encompassing all the political, economic, technological and cultural aspects of our relationship and capable of meeting the challenges confronting mankind. ``That would not only be beneficial to the members of the European Community and the North Atlantic democracies. It would also enhance world stability and be an asset to all nations in Europe, for such a future-oriented transatlantic partnership would help to overcome the division of Europe and to create one Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals,'' he said. Genscher said, ``it makes a lot of sense'' for President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to meet, even if that happens before an arms control agreement is reached. ``In a very rapidly changing world, direct talks between the two superpowers are of decisive importance,'' said Genscher. Bush on Thursday scheduled his second summit with Gorbachev for May 30 to June 3. Genscher said the Bush-Gorbachev summit in Malta last year ``has greatly contributed to the improvement of East-West relations'' and ``I am assuming that this will also be the case for the next summit conference.'' He said such a meeting could help pave the way for a meeting of the 35 signatories of the Helsinki Pact, which he hopes will be held in November and approve German reunification.

DOC.HEAD: Statue of General to Get Another Sword
DOC.TEXT: Defenseless for almost 18 months, Gen. James E. Oglethorpe will soon get another sword. This time, city leaders want one that can't be easily stolen from the statue of Georgia's founding father. Vandals are believed responsible for the disappearance of the original sword from the statue in 1988. The city's purchasing department is about to begin legal advertising for bids to cast a 3-foot-10-inch replacement. Nearly $6,000 has been set aside for the project. ``It will probably take 90 days to get the bid awarded,'' said Billy Jones, streets and drainage director for the city and supervisor of the replacement project. To prevent another theft, the bid specifications say, the material attaching the sword to the statue should be stronger than the blade material, meaning a vandal would have to break the sword to remove it. The statue at Chippewa Square was sculpted in 1910 by Daniel Chester French, who also did the Lincoln statue in the Lincoln Memorial. Park and Tree Director Don Gardner said the city is looking at world-class bronze casters, including Moreland Studios of New Jersey, which handled the renovation of the Statue of Liberty. ``If it's good enough for the Statue of Liberty, it's good enough for us,'' Gardner said.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Members Considering Alternatives to Philippine Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed for release at 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Seven members of a House Armed Services subcommittee will travel to East Asia to consider alternatives to U.S. military bases in the Philippines, the panel said Friday. The delegation from the subcommittee on military installations and facilities leaves Saturday for Hawaii, Guam, Thailand and Indonesia for a 10-day trip. The trip also includes an examination of U.S. security responsibilities in the region and the lawmakers plan to visit Vietnam and Cambodia to assess the extent to the which the Soviet Union has reduced its forces at Cam Rahn Bay. The United States and the Philippines are scheduled to begin negotiations on two U.S. facilities in the Philippines _ Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Base. Philippine officials have criticized the current arrangement and urged President Corazon Aquino to end the U.S. rights. Earlier this year, Mrs. Aquino refused to meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney who visited the Philippines as part of an Asian trip. ``With reduced East-West tensions and an increased American debt, it may be time to pack up and leave the Philippines,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., chairwoman of the subcommittee. ``On this mission, we hope to find out whether the impact of such a departure can be minimized.'' Schroeder said that some in the Philippines are demanding that the United States pay $2 billion a year in rent for the bases, ``nearly the amount that the citizens of Colorado pay in state taxes.'' In addition to Schroeder, the delegation includes Reps. David O'B. Martin, R-N.Y., the ranking GOP member on the subcommittee; Norman Sisisky, D-Va.; Jim Courter, R-N.J.; James Hansen, R-Utah; Larry Hopkins, R-Ky.; and congressional delegate Ben Blaz, R-Guam.

DOC.HEAD: City Planners Envision Aerial Tram to Canada, Skywalks
DOC.TEXT: In one vision of 21st-century Detroit, people would be able to ride cable cars across the Detroit River to Windsor, Ontario, or stroll to work through enclosed skywalks. The plan, unveiled Wednesday, would turn empty shops to fancy apartments, extend an elevated rail system and reclaim blighted neighborhoods. ``We've got a lot of lofty ideas in there, but how you carry them out is another question,'' said City Planner Harold Smith. Mayor Coleman A. Young's planning department and the city planning commission have traded drafts on a master plan since 1973, only agreeing on the latest. The plan would relocate residents of largely abandoned neighborhoods and raze buildings so the land could be offered to developers. It also calls for creating jobs by helping steel industries, and re-establishing Detroit as a recording industry center. Planners also envision a fashion district much like New York's Seventh Avenue along Detroit's Seven Mile Road, reviving of a former ``Avenue of Fashion.'' Smith said most of the ideas depend on finding developers and money.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Drop Demand that Reunified Germany Be Neutral
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs, with editing.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union today withdrew its demand that a reunified Germany be neutral and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze predicted ``very important documents will be signed'' at next month's superpower summit. But Shevardnadze and the White House acknowledged it may not be possible to resolve all major provisions of a new treaty to reduce long-range nuclear weapons before the arrival of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on May 30. ``There are very technical issues that need to be resolved,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty that would cut the most dangerous U.S. and Soviet nuclear arms. Shevardnadze predicted a wide range of agreements at Bush's Washington summit with Gorbachev. But he, too, cautioned that ``it will take an additional effort'' to settle on ways to cut long-range nuclear missiles in time to be initialed by the two leaders at the summit. Also, Soviet actions in breakaway Lithuania continued to mar the U.S.-Soviet relationship. Fitzwater said the superpower relationship is ``at stake in this matter.'' Shevardnadze took a conciliatory stance on issues surrounding the unification of East Germany, a Soviet ally, with West Germany, the linchpin in Europe of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``We have to look for a solution, a solution that would be acceptable'' to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, Shevardnadze said. He could not provide a specific blueprint, he said, but added: ``It is possible we will be able to find a mutally acceptable'' solution. Earlier, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the Soviets had eased off their demand that the merged Germany be neutral but continued to object to its membership in NATO. ``This summit certainly will become a major event in world affairs,'' Shevardnadze told reporters. ``The two presidents will sign very important documents.'' Fitzwater said Bush had underscored to Shevardnadze that the United States did not recognize the Soviets' incorporation of Lithuania in 1940 and that the Kremlin should not take actions to block the Baltic republic's assertion of independence. The foreign minister delivered a letter to Bush from Gorbachev that dealt with arms control, Fitzwater said, declining to provide any details. He called the two-hour session ``cordial and productive.'' Shevardnadze, standing under an umbrella in a rain-swept driveway, told reporters agreements in preparation deal with arms control, trade relations, cooperation in science and space. Shevardnadze said ``we have a clear conscience'' on Lithuania. Defending Moscow's tactics in dealing with the independence movement, he said it was important to maintain order in the midst of possible ``inter-ethnic clashes.''. Shevardnadze said the Soviets were willing to implement an agreement for direct flights of Jewish refugees to Israel provided Israel gave assurances they would not be settled ``in the occupied territories.'' On Thursday night a Soviet official specified that means East Jerusalem as well as the West Bank and Gaza. Shevardnadze also held out the prospect of resuming normal diplomatic ties with Israel after a 23-year lapse _ depending on ``the overall Middle East situation.'' The Soviets have consistently demanded that Israel hold negotiations to create a Palestinian state and relinquish all the land the Arabs lost in the 1967 six-day war. That would include the West Bank, Gaza, East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights. Shevardnadze's White House session with Bush ran twice as long as initially planned. ``This talk was not only rather lengthy but also rather substantive,'' Shevardnadze said. Baker said earlier that Shevardnadze had not agreed to the proposal for direct emigre flights to Israel. But the Soviet official did say ``that they would be willing to give it some consideration,'' Baker said. On the subject of German reunification, Baker said he believes the Soviets have concluded that a neutral country is ``not the best route to go.'' ``A unified Germany as part of NATO presented a problem to them,'' said Baker, who has been meeting with his Soviet counterpart since Wednesday. ``We were equally firm in our view that the unified Germany must remain a member of NATO and that that would indeed provide stability, which is, after all, one of the major results that we all seek from the unification of Germany,'' Baker said. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has proposed keeping NATO troops from entering what is now East Germany even though the merged country is part of the Western alliance. Genscher told reporters after an address to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, ``what I have heard so far confirms the impression of my talks with Foreign Minister Shevardnadze in Windhoek, namely that the Soviet Union is taking a constructive position or attitude both toward the building of a future Europe ... and also to German unification, which they view as a law-abiding process.'' Genscher and Sheverdnadaze met in Windhoek, Namibia, last month. Despite some tough Soviet actions in the Baltics, Bush on Thursday scheduled his second summit with Gorbachev for May 30 to June 3. Fitzwater said the president would express his concerns ``forcefully and directly'' to the Soviet leader. Baker said Shevardnadze has been consistent throughout the talks in declaring that the preferred Soviet approach to the independence crisis in Lithuania is dialogue, ``and that they would like to see this resolved through peaceful means and that they rejected the concept of use of force.'' Bush said Thursday that the summit would provide ``time for a lot of dialogue and a lot of discussion.'' Officials acknowledged that in the weeks remaining until May 30 it will be difficult to forge agreements across the board of U.S.-Soviet relations. The Bush-Gorbachev meeting had been expected to be held in late June. The earlier date shortened the time left to find ways to assist the sluggish Soviet economy. The Soviets must enact a law guaranteeing a right to emigrate and negotiators must complete a new trade agreement for Moscow to qualify for U.S. trade concessions. U.S. officials said this still could be done by the time Gorbachev comes to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Health Insurance Commission Did Set Financing Guidelines Says Chairman
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Pepper Commisssion defended on Friday its refusal to include recommendations on how to pay the estimated $23 billion cost to provide health insurance for all Americans. ``We did not name taxes,'' Sen. John D. Rockefeller IV told a hearing of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. ``I think had we named taxes we would have come into the same criticism.'' He said the commission had, in fact, accomplished a great deal by putting a total price tag on its proposals _ $66.6 billion. Rockefeller said the group had narrowed the range of taxes that could be used by establishing the financing would have to be progressive, meaning the payment would grow with income and that all age groups would have to pay. ``We think we bit the bullet,'' said the West Virginia Democrat, adding that Congress and the White House can easily raise the taxes for the plan ``when they decide what they want to do.'' Committee chairman Edward M. Kennedy said that the bipartisan commission, formed in 1988, was only supposed to ``outline health policy'' and not substitute itself for the Finance and Ways and Means committees. Rockefeller had said last month when the commission's report was released that the tax-writing committees would have to come up with the financing. Criticism of a lack of a financing plan came from within the commission as well as outside it. Friday's hearing, held in cooperation with the Senate Finance Committee, dwelled on the health insurance component. The other major component deals with long-term care for all Americans. Rockefeller said the commission found that 32 million Americans lack health insurance and that one-quarter of the uninsured are children. Three-quarters of the uninsured are workers and their families, with the majority working in small firms, Rockefeller said. The commission, named after the late Rep. Claude Pepper of Florida, recommended a jobs-based universal health insurance plan because most insurance coverage already is provided through employers. The plan calls for full coverage for everyone within five years. Employers would either have to provide insurance or contribute to a public plan. Friday's hearing was the first in a series of hearings on how to develop and speed up passage of legislation to provide comprehensive health care.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives, Social Democrats Remain Apart Over Forming Government
DOC.TEXT: The head of East Germany's second-largest party on Friday said the dominant party has remained vague on policy, jeopardizing hopes of forming the country's first non-Communist government before Easter. Markus Meckel, acting chairman of the Social Democratic Party, said the Christian Democratic Union still had not presented a single ``position paper'' on unification with West Germany. The Christian Democratic Union, which heads the Alliance for Germany, has been trying to form a government since elections March 18. The alliance favors speedy unification, while the Social Democrats want a more gradual process to ease the country out of 40 years of Communist rule. Meckel said the country needs a government ``as soon as possible, but I doubt that it can really happen before Easter.'' When he agreed to formal talks Tuesday, he said a government could be formed before the April 15 holiday. The top Christian Democrat responded by saying his party would be able to form a coalition government even without the Social Democrats. ``We can also govern without the SPD,'' said party general-secretary Martin Kirchner. Lothar de Maiziere, head of the Christian Democratic Union, was asked Thursday during the inaugural session of the new Parliament to try to form a government by next week. The 400-member Parliament convenes again Thursday. If de Maiziere is successful in his efforts by then, the legislature will vote in the new government. The alliance, which also includes Democratic Awakening and the German Social Union, needs the support of the Social Democrats for a two-thirds parliamentary majority required to push through laws that would speed unification. The alliance, however, can also form a government with the help of a liberal alliance, which has given its tentative agreement to join in a broad coalition. The Social Democrats have had serious ideological differences with the alliance's German Social Union. According to East Germany's ADN news agency, those two parties were able to clear away some of their differences in a late-night meeting. ADN quoted Meckel as saying there are still ``differing views'' between the two parties, but ``no obstacles that can't be overcome.'' In West Germany on Friday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl promised that his countrymen will not face a tax increase to finance the heavy costs of German unification. ``A tax increase would unnecessarily brake the economic upswing and have a counter-productive effect,'' Kohl said in a speech in the West German city of Ludwigshafen.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment in 11 Major States
With AM-Unemployment
DOC.TEXT: Here are the March unemployment rates for 11 large states as reported Friday by the Labor Department: California, 5.2 percent, up from 4.9 percent in February. Florida, 5.2 percent, down from 6.0 percent. Illinois, 5.5 percent, down from 5.9 percent. Massachusetts, 5.4 percent, up from 5.3 percent. Michigan, 7.2 percent, down from 7.7 percent. New Jersey, 4.7 percent, up from 4.5 percent. New York, 5.0 percent, unchanged. North Carolina, 3.4 percent, down from 3.6 percent. Ohio, 5.5 percent, down from 5.8 percent. Pennsylvania, 5.2 percent, down from 5.7 percent. Texas, 5.6 percent, down from 6.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Unhappy Over Promised Reforms, Kaifu Asks Understanding
With US-Japan Trade
DOC.TEXT: A retailers' group said Friday it will fight key business reforms Japan promised the United States to alter the nations' trade imbalance, and a consumer group disputed claims the changes would help them. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, in a televised appearance, asked Japanese for ``understanding and cooperation.'' He said the economic changes could ``in some cases be painful,'' but he promised they would lead to a better quality of life for the Japanese people. Under an agreement reached Thursday in Washington, Japan promised to address wide-ranging structural barriers to trade. The most controversial point of the package would revise a Japanese law that protects small retailers by restricting the opening of larger stores. The Federation of Specialty Stores Associations reacted with anger this point. ``The decision will do nothing but weaken minor retailers, devastate shopping districts, and slow down economic and cultural development of the community,'' it said. Under current Japanese law, consent of small neighboring shops is needed before a big store can open. The process can take 10 years. U.S. officials say the law impedes entry of foreign stores. They also note that larger Japanese stores are more likely to sell imported products than small shops. Easing such barriers would help cut the United States' $49 billion trade deficit with Japan, they say. The federation vowed to ``do our best to prevent the decisions from being enforced by keeping close ties with other groups and promoting consumer awareness and cooperation.'' The association claims a membership of 50,000 small retailers nationwide. The trade ministry says Japan has 1.6 million retail shops with fewer than 50 employees, and 800,000 tiny ``mom-and-pop'' stores. U.S. officials also have argued that changes sought in Japan would benefit Japanese consumers, who pay some of the world's highest prices because of a complex distribution system and a web of government restrictions. But some see advantages to the small stores. ``It is not cheap pricing that we consumers want,'' said Naokazu Takeuchi, head of the Japan Consumers Union, one of the nation's largest consumer groups. He said large supermarkets charge relatively high prices for produce that is not necessarily fresh. A mushrooming of large stores could destroy local shopping communities, he added. ``We have to take many elements _ cultural aspects, community relationship _ into consideration before making decisions,'' Takeuchi said. Kabun Muto, minister of international trade and industry, said, ``It is necessary for us to create an environment that promotes sales of imported foreign goods in Japan. Because we are living in the era of speed, it is only natural to shorten the (new store approval) process.'' For small retailers, Muto said, ``we will never give them 100 percent protection under our free economy system. It is their own responsibility to make efforts to make their own business go well.'' Kaifu called the reforms a duty that ``Japan must discharge as a responsible member of the international community.'' Kaiful said the implementation of the changes may be painful. ``It is my conviction, however, that they are essential in furthering Japan's own national interest,'' he said. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said, ``Against the background of the serious large-scale trade imbalance, the present Japan-U.S. economic relations, unless managed properly, is in the danger of suffering grave damage, posing a threat of undermining the mutual trust which lies at the foundation of the overall relationship between the two nations.'' Japan argued in the talks that the United States contributed to the trade imbalance with its large budget deficit, low savings rate, short-term corporate planning and relatively weak education system. U.S. negotiators promised efforts to remedy these problems.

DOC.HEAD: Battle Plan Formed to Kill Millions of Crickets in Rural Nevada
DOC.TEXT: The state of Nevada is going to war. The enemy: millions of crickets that will eat almost anything, can grow as big as a mouse and have invaded Nevada in the worst infestation since the 1930s. ``They're in the canyons right now and our goal is to kill them before they reach the valleys and the towns where they can do some real damage,'' Robert Gronowski, director of the Nevada Department of Agriculture's plant industry program, said Friday. ``If we stop them in the mountains I think we've got the problem licked. But we couldn't wipe out the entire population no matter what we did.'' The insects, known as Mormon crickets, are hatching across 700,000 acres in five rural counties. The worst infestation of the brown juice-spitting pests is near Winnemucca, 150 miles northeast of Reno, where 100 crickets have been counted per square foot. Once on the march, the crickets will leave barren land in their wake, even eating the bark off trees and devouring each other if food is scarce. They can reach the size of a small mouse, some 2 inches long, and will bite people if disturbed. ``Once they start marching it becomes much tougher to stop them,'' Gronowski said. ``But right now they're still young and aren't really on the move so we've got an opportunity to do something to control them.'' Mormon crickets got their name from an infestation in Utah in the 1800s that ended when sea gulls from Salt Lake City reportedly flew over the land and ate the insects. The battle plan worked out by state and U.S. agriculture officials includes spreading a poison-laced bran and oil mixture on egg beds at the mouths of canyons where the insects are hatching. A two-man crew is scheduled to begin the baiting program Tuesday in the Winnemucca area. They'll continue through May 1 when surviving crickets are expected to begin their hungry march across the sagebrush and cheat grass desert lands toward crops and home gardens. Beginning May 1, an additional two-man crew will apply patches of the poisonous bait across areas where the crickets are traveling. ``We'll apply an 8-foot-wide band then go about 10 feet down the road and apply a second band; if the first band doesn't kill them, hopefully the second one will,'' Gronowski said. The insecticide isn't harmful to larger animals or people, according to Gronowski. ``Someone would have to eat a lot of it to even get sick.'' Aerial spraying will begin April 23 in Lander County and other infested rural areas where there aren't any rivers to get polluted by the insecticide. The spraying will be concentrated in the dry Middle Reese River area and the Reno Gund Ranch which, despite its name, is halfway across the state from Reno. The program is expected to cost $25,000 to $80,000, which will be picked up by the federal government because the infestation is on Bureau of Land Management property, Gronowski said. ``We'll keep the baiting and spraying programs going until the crickets start laying eggs about July 15,'' he explained. The insects die after laying their eggs. ``That should be the end of the problem but there's no way to tell if they'll come back like this next year or in 10 years. We'll just have to wait and see,'' he said. If the program doesn't keep the insects out of crops and towns, Gronowski said authorities might have to get private ranchers and farmers involved in killing them. Agricultural officials say they believe this year's large infestation occurred because three years of drought allowed large egg beds to accumulate and there were no extremes of heat or cold to kill them.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Try as she may, actress Beverly Garland seems destined to be remembered for playing Fred MacMurray's wife in the waning days of ``My Three Sons.'' ``It really wasn't the highlight of my career. But I must say, everybody seems to remember ``My Three Sons.'' No matter what I do, no matter what I've done in my life, it's ``My Three Sons,'' Garland said Thursday on WNYW-TV's ``Good Day New York.'' ``People say, `Did you ever do anything after ``My Three Sons?'' ' They forget that I was Kate Jackson's mother for four years on `Scarecrow and Mrs. King.' Nobody ever remembers that I was the first policewoman on TV, before Angie Dickinson.'' ``My Three Sons'' has been in reruns since it stopped production some 20 years ago.

``Jake's Women,'' a new Neil Simon comedy starring Peter Coyote and Stockard Channing, will close in San Diego before it reaches New York, a spokesman said. It is the first time a Simon play scheduled for Broadway production has closed out-of-town, said spokesman Bill Evans on Thursday. ``The show may very well arrive to New York in another version, but this production won't,'' Evans said. ``Jake's Women'' was to have opened at the Neil Simon Theater in New York on April 30. It will close April 15 at San Diego's Old Globe Theater. The comedy, which Simon has called semiautobiographical, concerns a writer who is still coming to terms with the death of his first wife while his second marriage falls apart. Simon, whose Broadway hits include ``Barefoot in the Park,'' ``The Odd Couple'' and ``Biloxi Blues,'' has had his share of flops on the Great White Way, including ``Fools,'' ``God's Favorite'' and the revival of ``Little Me.''

British ethnologist Jane Goodall says her work to save chimpanzees from extinction makes it easier for her to put up with the state of the world's environment. ``If I look at the whole world picture, overpopulation, pollution, the destruction of forests and so on, it's hard to be happy,'' Goodall said in a recent interview with The Oregonian. ``It's better to concentrate on the things I'm actually involved with. That makes it a bit easier.'' Goodall was in Oregon to give lectures on chimpanzees, which now number between 100,000 to 200,000 in the wild. ``If we lost the chimps from the wild, that would also mean all the forest would be gone,'' she said. ``And where would we all be?'' Goodall, 56, went to Tanzania in 1960 to study with paleontologist Louis Leakey, who sent her to study the behavior of chimpanzees at Gombe, Tanzania. She has devouted nearly 30 years to the study of the primate.

Ask rock singer Laura Branigan about ``sex on the beach'' and she'll tell you it's a new drink. At least that's what she says she would pass along to rock lyric critics such as Tipper Gore. Branigan said Friday that she would tell the wife of U.S. Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., that ``sex on the beach'' is a drink if she had to explain the lyrics of the title track from her new album ``Moonlight on Water.'' The song includes these lyrics: ``Instead of dreamin' about all the money we got much simpler things to do. Moonlight on water. Sex on the beach.'' She said the lyrics represent more than sex. ``Sex on the beach is really, I think, more than the actual physical act. It's the feeling of being with someone you care about or a friend, or just alone on the beach stripping off your clothes at night and going skinny dipping and, you know, just living for the moment.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Romanian defector Nadia Comaneci has given her first gymnastics performance in six years. Comaneci performed Thursday night before a near-capacity crowd at the 1,800-seat Ziegfeld Theater inside Bally's Reno hotel-casino. It was her first U.S. exhibition in nine years and her first public performance since 1984. Fighting off tears, Comaneci told the crowd, ``I'm glad to be in my new homeland. This is very emotional for me. ... I love America. I love you all.'' A cast of 16 younger gymnasts was in the performance, which was taped by ABC Sports for broadcast April 21. The show's producer, Paul Ziert, said he's thinking of touring with Comaneci. ``Nadia again is excited and motivated,'' Ziert said. ``She sees that she can still do what she loves, that she can still be a part of gymnastics.'' Comaneci also was reunited with former coach Bela Karolyi, who guided her to a series of perfect 10s and three gold medals in the 1976 Olympics in Montreal when she was 14. Karolyi defended the 28-year-old star from publicity over her alleged tryst with a married man who helped her defect in December. Karolyi, who defected 10 years ago, said she must have felt as he did on his arrival in the United States. ``Ten years ago, I was standing in the streets of Los Angeles a desperate man,'' he said. ``Ten years later, I believe Nadia was just as desperate as me.''

DOC.HEAD: Jobless Man Attacks Netherlands' Most Famous Painting
LaserPhoto AM52
DOC.TEXT: A distraught and unemployed man walked into a museum Friday and sprayed a chemical on Rembrandt's ``The Night Watch,'' but museum officials said damage to the nation's most famous painting was slight. It was the third attack this century on the huge Rembrandt, which hangs in the Rijksmuseum. The painting was slashed in the two other incidents. A museum guard immediately sprayed a neutralizing agent, saving the artwork's delicate paint layer before the chemical could eat through the veneer, said museum keeper Piet van Thiel. By late Friday afternoon, most of the chemical had been removed from the 12-by-14{ foot painting. Like all government-owned artworks, it is not insured. Its value has never been made public. The attacker wore a hooded raincoat and was about six feet from the painting when he produced ``a little spray pump he had been concealing in his hand,'' said witness Barry Olshen, a professor from Toronto. Dutch Television described the chemical as concentrated sulfuric acid. Only a knee-high steel barrier keeps visitors away from the work Rembrandt painted in 1642. Unarmed guards are near it at all times. Museum guards overpowered the suspect and handed him over to police, who said they were unable to determine the man's motives. The 31-year-old man was not identified, in line with Dutch police practice. He was held on suspicion of vandalism. ``He's confused and not telling us anything at the moment,'' police spokesman Klaas Wilting said. Restoration experts took the painting out of its plain wooden frame and stood it against the wall on the museum's second floor, where it shares a spacious gallery with three other 17th-century paintings. Using delicate brushes, they applied an agent that dried out the white blobs covering about a square yard of the work, then wiped it clean. Van Thiel told reporters the painting needs new veneer but will go on display in two weeks, protected by a glass shield until the veneer is dry. The attack was a reminder how vulnerable the Netherlands' artworks are, said Rob Mulders of the Sotheby's auction firm. In 1975, a Dutch schoolteacher claiming to be on a divine mission slashed ``The Night Watch'' several times with a knife stolen from the restaurant where he had just eaten lunch. He later committed suicide in a mental asylum. During World War I, a jobless shoemaker slashed the painting to protest his inability to find work. ``The Night Watch'' portrays a group of 17th-century militiamen characteristic of the period when such fraternal organizations patrolled Dutch cities by night. It is best known for Rembrandt's skillful handling of light and darkness and the beam of light that illuminates a richly dressed woman in the foreground. The painting was believed to have been made on the occasion of a 1638 visit to Amsterdam by Maria de Medici, Queen of France.

DOC.HEAD: Cargo Plane Crashes Into Sea; Pilot Killed
LaserPhotos SJ1,SJ3
DOC.TEXT: A cargo plane apparently lost an engine and crashed into the sea, killing its American pilot, police said Friday. The two other people on the plane were rescued. The accident occurred Thursday evening shortly after the Super Constellation LD-49 left San Juan's international airport for the Dominican Republic, police said. Witnesses told local radio station Radio Reloj they saw one of the engines fall. The other burst into flames, and there was an explosion seconds later, the witnesses said. The plane then plunged into the sea near Levittown, a suburb about 10 miles west of San Juan. Three police helicopters hovered over the crash scene as police marine units and U.S. Coast Guard and Civil Defense personnel worked to recover the pilot's body. The pilot, identified as William Bailes, apparently drowned after being knocked unconscious in the crash, police said. Police spokesman Baltasar Vazquez said Bailes was an American citizen who lived in the Dominican Republic. The two crewmembers aboard the aircraft were identified by police as Ramon Castro Lara, the flight engineer, and Miguel de los Santos. Both are from the Dominican Republic, police said. The two jumped out of the plane before it hit the water, according to the English-language newspaper The San Juan Star, which quoted eyewitnesses. Castro Lara and De los Santos were treated for minor injuries, police said. The cause of the accident was not known. The National Transportation Safety Board was investigating. Local newspapers reported that Bailes was co-owner of AMSA Airlines, the air freight company for which he was flying. The Star quoted AMSA cargo supervisor Hector Rivera as saying the airplane ``was a pretty old one'' but that it had been repaired recently.
