DOC.HEAD: Supporters, Opponents Rally Before Opening of Mapplethorpe Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be topped after court hearing, which began 1:45 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Supporters and opponents of an exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually graphic photographs rallied Friday outside a courthourse where a judge heard pleas to protect the show from censorship. Five hundred supporters marched about 10 blocks through downtown, ending at the steps of the Hamilton County Courthouse. They were met by about 100 people protesting Friday night's scheduled opening of the exhibit. Police kept the two sides apart. The supporters chanted for freedom of expression and carried a banner that read: ``If you give artists freedom of expression, soon every American will want it.'' Opponents carried signs that read ``We want decency in Cincinnati,'' and ``Calling pornography art does not make it so.'' The Contemporary Arts Center asked a Hamilton County Municipal Court judge to prevent local authorities from filing criminal charges or taking any other action involving photographs showing sexual or sadomasochistic acts. More than 3,000 museum members were expected to attend a special preview Friday night. The exhibit is scheduled to open to the public Saturday. City and county officials asked Judge Edward Donnellon to dismiss a lawsuit by the museum, which wanted a jury to decide whether the photographs violated local obscenity laws. Dismissal of the lawsuit would allow authorities to intervene. Police Chief Lawrence Whalen has called some of the photos criminally obscene but said authorities hadn't decided whether to file charges. A group called Citizens for Community Values contended that nine of the 175 photographs are unacceptable for public viewing. The Contemporary Arts Center issued a statement saying it would not be be deterred from opening the show. ``The CAC has supported the right of these individuals to express their opinion, while maintaining its own right to present the exhibition under the constitutional guarantee of freedom of expression,'' it said. ``CAC has taken precautionary measures to inform visitors of the exhibition's content. ``Regardless of the judge's decision, the CAC is committed to opening the exhibition, `Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment,' to the public April 7.'' Warning signs were posted at the center for the exhibit's Cincinnati run. The museum said it would not admit anyone under age 18. The show was scheduled to run through May 26. Last June, the Mapplethorpe exhibit was canceled at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. The exhibit of the work by Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in March 1989, prompted Congress to limit funding to the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared the photographs obscene. It has been shown in Philadelphia, Chicago, Hartford, Conn., Berkeley, Calif., and Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Latvia's Communist Party Debates Split With Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Latvia's Communist Party met Friday to discuss whether to follow its Baltic neighbors and declare itself independent from the Soviet Communist Party, news reports said. About 800 delegates representing Latvia's 177,000 Communists began a two-day meeting in the capital, Riga. The Communist parties of neighboring Lithuania and Estonia have already split with Moscow and declared their support for independence in those republics. The three Balitc republics were forceably annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Lithuania's legislature declared the republic independent March 11. The Kremlin responded by saying the move was illegal and invalid and launched a show of force that included sending troops to occupy party and government buildings. The official Soviet news agency Tass said some Latvian Communists believe they should split with the Moscow-based Communist Party and crusade for Latvian independence. Alex Grigoriev, an editor of the Latvian People's Front newspaper, said the party debate, which was televised live in Latvia, was inconclusive. In another development, unarmed volunteers backed by Lithuania's legislature entered the main printing plant in Vilnius early Friday to reoccupy the building, legislative spokeswoman Rita Dapkus said. The plant, where Lithuania's main daily newspapers are printed, was occupied by soldiers as part of the Soviet crackdown. Dapkus said in a phone interview that after several hours of tense discussions, the soldiers and volunteers agreed to a joint occupation of the building. Also Friday, Lithuania's military commissar told reporters he plans to proceed with a spring draft in the breakaway republic. Maj. Gen. A. Vysotskis told a news conference that nearly 6,000 young men will be recruited starting April 15. His remarks were reported by Tass. Since March 11, dozens of Lithuanians have deserted the Soviet army. Soviet troops have used force to arrest some of them.

DOC.HEAD: Man Indicted in Assassination Plot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Andri is cq
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury on Friday accused a former member of Iraq's mission to the United Nations of plotting to assassinate two opponents of the Iraqi government, authorities said. Andri Khoshaba, 47, was accused of two counts of interstate travel to further a murder-for-hire plot against the two unidentified opponents of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, authorities said. A warrant was issued for the arrest of Khoshaba, a former driver at the Iraq's U.N. mission. Khoshaba traveled to New York City in February to meet with an Iraqi government agent to discuss the plot, said U.S. Attorney David Levi. Details of the alleged assassination attempt and the role of the Iraqi agent were not released. Levi said Khashoba is a resident of Modesto, about 80 miles east of San Francisco. If convicted, Khoshaba could be sentence to a maximum 20 years in prison of and fined $500,000, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Jobless Rate Declines Though Few Jobs Created
DOC.TEXT: Civilian unemployment dipped to 5.2 percent in March, a slight improvement from February and the lowest rate in a year, the government said Friday. But analysts attributed the good news more to a statistical quirk than to an economic upswing. Indeed, the Labor Department report said the number of new jobs last month hit a four-year low. ``The economy is muddling along, but it's muddling along at a full-employment level,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``It's a, `Stay as you are, Sir,' economy, continuing along its path of steady but sluggish growth.'' Last month's 5.2 percent jobless rate, down from February's 5.3 percent, was the lowest since March 1989, when the rate was at a 15-year low of 5.0 percent. The next month, joblessness hit 5.3 percent, then eased down to 5.2 percent in May but rose again in June to 5.3 percent, where it held through February. Even with Friday's report, most analysts remained concerned that the slowdown in the economy's overall growth would translate into higher jobless rates by year's end. ``The low unemployment rate is a surprise in an economy that's growing below its potential, ... if we continue to have anemic growth, it's going up,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. By the end of the year, some analysts predicted, unemployment could reach 5.7 percent. Taking a more optimistic view, Michael Boskin, chairman of the presidential Council of Economic Advisers, said administration officials believe ``there's room for the economy to expand and for employment growth to continue and the economy to grow more strongly than it's growing today.'' As for last month, most economists said the 0.1 percentage point drop in unemployment probably stemmed from a continued tight labor market and from the fact that the government's figures, based on a survey of 60,000 households conducted early in March, reflected job activity in February more than in March. Over the first two months of the year, economic growth created about 700,000 jobs. Last month, based on a separate survey of employers, just 26,000 jobs were added to non-farm payrolls. ``Basically, 1990 started off to a bang and it seems to have come to a screeching halt in March. It is troubling, but given the strength of the first two months, I'm not inclined to panic,'' said David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill. Janet Norwood, the commissioner of labor statistics, said the unseasonably warm weather in January and February kept construction activity unusually high. That resulted in ``fewer opportunities for additional hiring in March,'' she said in explaining a 60,000-job loss in construction. Surging employment prospects in January and February helped reduce the number of ``discouraged workers'' to 747,000 for the first three months of the year. That's a level not seen since early 1979. For all of 1989, the number of discouraged workers had averaged 840,000. Dederick saw this decline as ``another sign that we're operating with an economy than can utilize nearly all of its workers.'' Discouraged workers are unemployed people who have given up looking for a job in the belief that the search will be fruitless, At the same time, the nation's manufacturing slump continued, with a loss of 30,000 factory jobs in March. That brought manufacturing job losses to 100,000 since November and 250,000 over the last year, the department said. ``There's no indication that manufacturing is going to turn around any time soon. That sector of the economy is bleeding, not profusely, but it's in a recession,'' Dederick said. Economists were concerned that average hourly earnings rose from $9.88 to $9.92, a 0.4 percent change that would translate into a 5.0 percent growth over a full year. ``It's a signal that inflation is not going to quickly fade,'' Sinai said. The government's household survey said that total employment rose slightly in March to 118.3 million and that the labor force _ those employed or actively looking for work _ edged up to about 124.8 million, a growth of about 200,000. The losses in factory payrolls were more than offset by gains in the service industries, which added 125,000 jobs, and the federal government, which added 75,000 Census Bureau workers and other employees. Since November, the number of service jobs has grown by more than 400,000. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the March jobless rate was 5.1 percent, down from February's 5.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Suspended Sentences Ordered in Pentagon Document Case
DOC.TEXT: Two RCA Corp. employees who pleaded guilty to obtaining and transporting classified Pentagon budget documents were sentenced Friday to two years imprisonment, with all but a few months suspended. In sentencing Ronald B. Stevens and Leonard C. Kampf, U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris in Alexandria, Va., said he wanted the sentences to have a deterrent effect on those who would consider similar activity in the future. Stevens and Kampf had pleaded guilty Feb. 5, the same day that RCA Corp. pleaded guilty and paid $2.5 million to cover criminal and civil liabilities. The cases stemmed from Operation Uncover that investigated the trafficking in classified documents by major Defense Department contractors. The documents involved summarize the Pentagon's plan for future spending, said Michael J. Costello, head of the Defense Criminal Investigative Service's Washington field office. Stevens, a manager of marketing services at RCA's Aerospace and Defense Division in Cherry Hill, N.J., was sentenced to two years imprisonment, with all but two months suspended, and 100 hours of community service. He also was placed on one year of supervised probation and fined $3,000. Stevens still works for RCA Corp., a subsidiary of General Electric Co., Costello said. Kampf, who was employed as manager of marketing information and communications in RCA's Government Systems Division in Cherry Hill until his retirement in 1984, was sentenced to two years imprisonment, with all but four months suspended, and 100 hours of community service. In addition, he was placed on one year of supervised probation and fined $5,000. The two had faced a maximum possible sentence of 10 years in prison. ``The sentencing of corporate employees to jail is a sanction which must occur if corporate America is to re-think its marketing philosophy,'' Costello said. ``Corporations can't go to jail, and they have to consider the traumatic effect on their employees who may have to do hard time.'' Since November, guilty pleas stemming from charges in Operation Uncover have been entered by RCA Corp., Stevens, Kampf, four other contractors and one individual. Additionally, one individual was convicted. The others were: _Boeing Co. Boeing paid fines and penalties of $5.2 million following its Nov. 13 guilty plea. Former Boeing employee Richard Lee Fowler was convicted Dec. 7 of 39 counts of conspiracy, conveyance without authority, mail fraud and conversion of government property. He received a two-year prison sentence and is currently in jail on contempt charges for refusing to answer questions posed by a federal grand jury, Costello said. _Hughes Aircraft Co., a subsidiary of General Motors Corp. Hughes entered a guilty plea March 9 and was ordered to pay $3.67 milion in fines and penalties. _Grumman Corp. Grumman pleaded guilty March 16 and was ordered to pay $2.5 million in fines and penalties. Grumman executive Harry Kotellos, a West Point graduate and retired Air Force lieutenant colonel, pleaded guilty March 12. Kotellos faces a maximum penalty of $250,000 in fines and five years imprisonment when he is sentenced May 18. _Raytheon Co. Raytheon pleaded guilty March 20 and agreed to pay a total of $1 million in fines and penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Iditarod Winner Susan Butcher Meets with Bush
LaserPhoto WX21
DOC.TEXT: Champion dog-sledder Susan Butcher told President Bush on Friday that she has plans for her own brand of U.S.-Soviet detent. If all goes well, Butcher said, there will be a 1,000-mile dog sled race between Alaska and Siberia. Bush welcomed Butcher and her prize sled dog, Granite, to the White House to congratulate her on her fourth win of the annual Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race across Alaska. Butcher and her team of dogs made the 1,158-mile Anchorage to Nome run in a record 11 days, 1 hour and 53 minutes last month. She broke her 1987 record by more than 10 minutes after braving temperatures that dropped to 40 below zero and 100 mph winds that ripped across the Bering Sea. Arriving at the White House in a shortsleeve spring dress while others were bundled up in winter garb against a cold rain, Butcher professed not to be cold, even when waiting outside while Bush's meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze ran long. ``I just finished a 440-mile race the day before yesterday in the Arctic. It was 20 below,'' she laughingly told Bush as they posed for photos with Granite in the Rose Garden. She gave Bush a photograph of the Iditarod race signed by the top 20 finishers after the president emerged from his Oval Office meetings to make superpower summit preparations. She also told him about plans for the Alaska-to-Siberia race. The Soviets already have agreed, and the race will go 800 miles into the Soviet Union. Butcher, 35, who is generally recognized as the greatest sled dog racer in the world, told Bush she started her mushing career in Maine, the president's vacation home since his boyhood. She is a native of Massachusetts. Butcher and her husband live in a wilderness cabin, 140 miles northwest of Fairbanks, Alaska, with a brood of dogs that numbers as many of 150. She breeds the dogs for other dog sled racers. Only one other musher, Rick Swenson, has won the Iditarod four times.

DOC.HEAD: Schweitzer Plus Arsenio Hall Equals Mr. Rogers?
DOC.TEXT: How would ``Mister Rogers'' describe himself? Fred Rogers, familiar to millions of viewers of his long-running public TV program, ``Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,'' knew the question was coming Friday at a National Press Club lunch. ``It's a tough question, and I've thought a lot about it,'' he replied with a grin. ``I think maybe it might be Albert Schweitzer and Arsenio Hall.'' In his speech, Rogers urged people to be better listeners, to ``try to understand what they've heard and then respond with all the creativity and care that their life has allowed them to develop.'' In reply to questions from the audience of journalists and their small children, Rogers said he is concerned that much of what children see on television is ``very scary.'' He said parents should always sit with their children to interpret ``the horrendous stuff'' they see on TV news programs. In his 35 years in children's television, Rogers said the ``outsides of children's lives have changed a lot'' but he said they are the same inside. Like adults, he said, children need to be assured that they are lovable, capable of loving others and respected for who they are.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Fire on Crowd, Scores Killed and Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Security forces using automatic weapons, tear gas and truncheons attacked about 200,000 pro-democracy demonstrators near the royal palace Friday, killing and wounding scores of people. One doctor said he saw soldiers carting 200 corpses from the center of the city. A high-ranking Western diplomat said witnesses provided him with a ``wild range'' of the number of dead, from nine to 300. State-run Radio Nepal reported Friday night that only one person had been killed and eight injured. One witness said he saw 35 bodies at a hospital, but doctors contradicted his report. During almost five hours of protests, mobs of angry demonstrators set fire to several government buildings, including the city hall and Ministry of Commerce. Bands attacked houses of politicians loyal to King Birendra, who dominates the government and has rejected calls for a multiparty system. Late Friday, the army moved in, cordoning off the palace with metal barricades and heavily armed squads. Soldiers clutching automatic weapons patrolled the deserted streets of the capital in trucks. Piles of tires smoldered at intersections littered with bricks, shoes and slippers left behind by fleeing protesters. Tear gas fogged the air, and gunshots echoed in the distance. Demonstrations also erupted in three other towns, including the tourist haven of Pokhara. At least nine people died in clashes with police outside Katmandu, witnesses reported by telephone. A doctor at Bir Hospital, Katmandu's biggest, said a British journalist was among the dead. A British man and a Dutchman also suffered bullet wounds, the doctor said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Their identities were not released pending notification of relatives. The Nepali Congress Party and a coalition of left-wing groups _ all banned by Nepalese law _ have been fighting since Feb. 18 for democratic reforms in this Himalayan nation wedged between China and India. Before Friday, at least 16 people had died in the protests, which struck a popular chord among the country's 17 million people. A series of strikes in support of the movement had grounded airplanes, closed shops, shut off electricity and slowed work at hospitals. On Friday morning, in his most conciliatory move yet, the king dissolved the Cabinet and replaced hard-line Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha with a political moderate, Lokendra Bahadur Chand. The king also established a committee to study changing the constitution, which since 1961 has banned political parties. And he set up a committee to access the damage and loss of life caused by the last seven weeks of protest. ``The royal proclamation has given a slap in the face to the countrywide call for democracy,'' Nepali Congress leader Ganesh Man Singh said in a message from his hospital bed. ``The people's demands can only be reflected in a multiparty system.'' Singh was placed under house arrest shortly after the movement began and subsequently hospitalized for arthritis and a urinary infection. He said the ``people's movement will be carried on with even greater intensity.'' Protests began in at least four cities soon after the king's proclamation was broadcast on Radio Nepal. In Katmandu, about 200,000 people marched on the royal palace, waving flags and chanting anti-government slogans. In midafternoon, police attacked with sticks and tear gas when the crowd came within 500 yards of the palace, witnesses said. Police then opened fire. One witness said he saw at least 200 demonstrators fall to the ground. ``It was practically a massacre. They fired into the crowd. We saw it in front of the hospital,'' said a doctor at Bir Hospital. As he spoke, a line of bleeding and bandaged demonstrators were rushed past on stretchers. ``I lost consciousness during a baton charge,'' said an 18-year-old man, his head wrapped in a blood-soaked bandage. ``I fell to the ground. Then they started firing. People were falling all around me.'' Another witness said he saw 30 young men gunned down as he watched the demonstration from a hotel window. ``The people were unarmed and the government just started shooting,'' he said. He said security forces carried away some of the wounded but others were left lying in the street. At sundown, the city was blanketed in darkness as a blackout, called by the opposition, took effect. Doctors at Bir Hospital and at Tribhuvan University Teaching Hospital said they had nine bodies and 150 wounded people, including 30 in critical condition. But they charged that soldiers were carting away corpses from the city. ``Bodies were taken in trucks for disposal by the army,'' said one doctor at Bir Hospital, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``At least 200 to 300 people must have died.'' A lawyer said 40 people were killed. In the state-run news report, Radio Nepal said police were forced to shoot. Nepal's only experiment with Western-style democracy lasted two years and was halted in 1961 by King Mahendra, father of the present monarchy. Mahendra accused the Nepali Congress of corrupt and inefficient government. Today, the king rules in conjunction with the Rashtriya Panchayat, or National Assembly. The king selects one-fifth of the assembly's 120 members. The rest are elected on a nonparty basis, but political observers say their candidacies must be approved by the palace. Most of the protests have focused on the ban on political parties, rather than on the monarchy. King Birendra has been accorded god-like status by many of his subjects in this landlocked nation, where the literacy rate is 25 percent and the per capita annual income is $150.

DOC.HEAD: Athiests Want Christ Statue Off Federally Protected Reef
DOC.TEXT: An atheist group is demanding that an underwater statue of Jesus be removed from a federally protected coral reef, angering those who say the bronze monument should stay. ``Can't these people find anything better to do with their time?'' asked diver Robert Segueira of Miami Beach. ``That Christ is beautiful, and it's not like it's in anybody's way, except maybe for the fish.'' Brian Gorman of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Washington, D.C., said the agency would decide whether the Christ of the Deep statue would remain in 25 feet of water in Key Largo National Marine Sanctuary. ``Although we view the statue as a historic artifact rather than a religious icon, we do take the issue bought up by the atheists seriously,'' Gorman said. ``We are researching whether or not it is proper for the statue to be in a federal park.'' The statue is a duplicate of the Christ of the Abyss, which stands in 50 feet of water off Genoa, Italy. The Florida statue, cast in Italy and donated to the Underwater Society of America by Italian industrialist Egidi Cressi, was placed in a state park in 1965. A boundary change later included the statute in the federal sanctuary. American Atheists says the statue violates the constitutional requirement for separation of church and state. ``I find it incredible that someone had the brazen gall to install such a shrine on public property,'' said American Atheists member Romulus Roberts of Wilton Manors. ``This is a public park, funded by the public's money, and there are other people in this world besides those who believe in Christ. I definitely want that statue removed,'' he said. The 2-ton statue stands on a 7{-foot pedestal on a white-sand bottom in an amphitheater of corals and has served as the backdrop for underwater weddings. Like the Christ of the Abyss, the Christ of the Deep statue was designed as a symbol of peace and as a memorial to people who have lost their lives at sea, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Frees IRA Supporter Wanted in Britain on Weapons Charge
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected a British request to extradite an IRA supporter and former legislator on a firearms charge, ruling he must be freed because the offense was politically inspired. Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke, who was in Dublin for unrelated talks, told reporters: ``We are greatly disturbed.'' The decision cast a new shadow over Anglo-Irish relations, exacerbating a long dispute about extradition of Irish Republican Army suspects. Owen Carron, 37, a former member of the British Parliament for the outlawed IRA's political front, Sinn Fein, left the court surrounded by cheering supporters. ``I'm delighted,'' the former schoolteacher declared before being driven away in brilliant spring sunshine. In Belfast, capital of Northern Ireland, the British authorities said the unanimous ruling by the five-judge court was ``most worrying.'' ``We cannot accept that acts of terrorism which put people's lives at risk ... are in any way political,'' the Northern Ireland Office added in a statement. Three weeks ago, the Irish Supreme Court freed two IRA men who had escaped from jail in Northern Ireland, saying there was a risk they would be beaten up by prison guards if they were extradited. Both men were serving 18-year terms on terrorism convictions. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the reason given by the court was ``grossly offensive.'' She said the refusal to extradite the men, Dermot Finucane and James Pius Clark, would encourage terrorists to believe they would probably find a safe haven in the republic. Carron jumped bail in Northern Ireland in January 1986 while awaiting trial on charges of possessing an assault rifle. He fled to the republic, was arrested in 1988 and has since fought rulings by two lower courts ordering his extradition. He was elected as a Northern Ireland member of the British Parliament in 1981 on a wave of sympathy for Bobby Sands, the first of 10 hunger strikers who died in jail during a political protest. Carron lost his seat two years later. The British Broadcasting Corp., in a report from Belfast, said the freeing of Carron probably means Britain will be unable to get any IRA members extradited for offenses committed before 1987. That was when Ireland signed the European Convention of Terrorism, which undermines the ability of terrorist suspects to avoid extradition by pleading political motivation. The Irish government counters British protests by pointing out that courts are independent of government control. However, the extradition dispute is straining the 1985 Anglo-Irish accord, which was intended to improve cooperation against the IRA. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA, banned on both sides of the border, is fighting a guerrilla campaign to unite Northern reland with the republic under a leftist administration. The Anglo-Irish accord angered leaders of Northern Ireland's Protestant majority because it gave the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland a consultative role in the running of the British administration of the province. The Northern Ireland Office says there have been a total of 154 warrants since 1971 for extraditions from the republic and seven suspected terrorists have been returned.

DOC.HEAD: Mobile Home Park Challenging Law
DOC.TEXT: A mobile-home park for retirees is the unlikely setting for a case that could yield a landmark decision on the privileges of unmarried couples who live together. The park's owner is asking the courts if an 1868 state law against ``lewd and lascivious'' cohabitation is grounds to evict unmarried elderly couples who stay in the same trailer. William Watson II, owner of Romany Mobile Home Park, also wants a Pinellas County circuit judge to decide if that law renders unconstitutional local fair-housing laws that prohibit discrimination based on marital status. In a lawsuit filed last month, Watson asked the court to allow him to bar unmarried couples from his 91-site park, where homeowners say the minimum age of residents is 55 years. ``Depending on how far it gets, it will probably have a bearing on all the (fair-housing) laws in Florida,'' said Gloria Williams, president of the Florida Association of Community Relations Professionals. Watson refused comment, but his attorney, Peter Hooper of St. Petersburg, said ``lewd and lascivious'' is a general legal term that does not necessarily mean depravity and could apply to common sexual activity. ``What's driving Mr. Watson is personal conviction. He's trying to do what's right,'' he said. Hooper said the lawsuit is not against a specific individual, and he does not want the issue to go to trial. He would like a court decision by April 20. ``The perception is it's common'' for unmarried couples to live together. he said. ``Most people don't realize, it's probably illegal.'' Robert Herman, a 65-year-old retiree who shared a mobile home with his wife until she died three years ago, is among residents bothered by Watson's lawsuit. ``He is passing moral judgment on me,'' Herman said. ``It's caused me a lot of heartaches.'' Herman, who lives in New Jersey and spends part of the year at the park, said he has had a conflict with management because a woman he is dating has stayed in his mobile home. Herman said he was told by Watson's son, who helps manage the park, that he must sell his home, lease it or marry his girlfriend. ``She started to cry. She broke down. He's assuming that things are happening here,'' said Herman, who said another couple was staying with them in his home. ``I figured I was doing nothing wrong.'' Assistant Pinellas County Attorney Bill Falkner said it's unclear if unmarried men and women who live together are protected under the county's ordinance. He said it wouldn't ``protect anyone who conducts lewd and lascivious behavior.'' But he said, Watson ``assumes that people who are unrelated and living together are committing lewd and lascivious acts. I don't know if we can make that assumption; it certainly doesn't seem so to me.'' According to the Florida State Archives, the 122-year-old law states that ``if any man and woman, not being married to each other, lewdly and lasciviously associate and cohabit together ... they shall be guilty.'' The Legislature amended the law in 1971 and changed the maximum penalty from up to three years in prison to one year in prison and a $500 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Mattox Denies Drug Use Report, Challenges Richards to Debate
DOC.TEXT: State Attorney General Jim Mattox denied allegations Friday that he was seen using marijuana, and challenged Democratic gubernatorial rival Ann Richards to take a lie detector test with him. ``I've not had an illegal drug, period. Ever,'' Mattox said after The Dallas Morning News and Houston Chronicle reported accusations by a lawyer and a former policeman that they saw Mattox smoke marijuana on separate occasions in the 1970s. ``Get those two folks, sit them right here with me. I'll tell them they are liars to their faces,'' Mattox said. He said the incidents they allege ``absolutely did not take place.'' He said he'd take a lie detector test, ``and I want you to get Ms. Richards strapped in beside me when we do it.'' Mattox and Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, survived last month's Democratic primary to meet in Tuesday's runoff. The winner will take on Republican oilman Clayton Williams, a political newcomer who swept away his opponents in the primary. Drug questions have dominated the Democratic race since Ms. Richards refused to answer yes or no when asked during the primary if she'd ever used illegal drugs. Mattox, citing witnesses he won't identify, accused her of drug use 10 years ago. Mattox said Friday there was a ``real difference'' between the drug allegations. ``In my case, they are untrue. In her case, they are true,'' he said. At a campaign stop in Denton, Ms. Richards had little to say about the allegations against Mattox. ``I really thought when Mattox began all this (drug) stuff, for the provocation of it, the sort of witch hunt that he was on, I just thought the whole thing was sick,'' she said. ``I still do, regardless of who they're talking about. I feel badly for the electorate, really, that this campaign has taken this tone,'' Ms. Richards said. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, says she hasn't taken a ``mood-altering chemical'' in 10 years but refuses to answer other questions. She says that could discourage others from seeking treatment. She also refused to debate Mattox before Tuesday's runoff vote. Mattox said drug use isn't as big an issue as Ms. Richards' refusal to discuss it. ``I told you exactly what took place in my circumstances. You asked me questions and I gave you answers,'' he told reporters Friday. ``I'm standing here. The one that I'm running against is not here. ``I notice that with the other campaign, you only have an opportunity to visit with that individual when you kind of catch her on the run. And she's bobbing and weaving and dodging.'' The allegations against Mattox were made in affidavits obtained by The Morning News from Houston lawyer Jim Sharp and former Dallas policeman Edward H. Lowe. Lowe said he saw Mattox smoke marijuana in a Dallas apartment during an undercover investigation. Lowe, then a vice officer, said he did not arrest Mattox or others in the room because his assignment was to confirm a tip about a prostitution ring. Mattox said he had enemies in the Dallas police department at the time and couldn't imagine that the officer wouldn't have jumped at the chance to arrest him on a drug charge. Sharp said Mattox and he shared a marijuana cigarette in 1974 in a car after the Democratic state convention in Austin. Mattox said Sharp had unsuccessfully sought a job from him in the past, adding: ``I have never been in any car, anyplace, anytime where marijuana has been smoked.''

DOC.HEAD: Besieged Khost: Symbolic Importance But Little Strategic Value
DOC.TEXT: Fierce fighting has flared anew in this shell-shocked border town, which has little strategic significance but is symbolically important in the war between the government and Moslem guerrillas. There is normally little fighting in Afghanistan during Ramadan, the Moslem month of fasting that began March 27. Khost, near Pakistan's western border, is the exception this year. The Pakistan-based mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors, are firing artillery from key captured military outposts and pummeling the town and adjacent airport. Government forces respond with heavy aerial bombardment to try to suppress rebel fire and dislodge the mujahedeen from their positions around the mine-laden perimeter. The Afghan government in Kabul, 100 miles to the northwest, at one time landed three supply flights a night in Khost. But the airstrip is badly cratered and littered with damaged planes, and supplies are now dropped by parachute. ``We are closing in on the Communists. We have taken the war into the city and now we are tightening the circle,'' said Jalaludin Haqqani, the most powerful commander in the area. ``On the ground we are in complete control. In the air, the communists can still fight and still deliver supplies,'' Haqqani said in an interview during a three-day trip to guerrilla positions. Both sides have suffered casualties since fighting erupted anew last month, but exact figures are difficult to determine. The government rarely releases the number of its dead and wounded, while guerrilla groups have been feuding for years and don't talk to each other. Khost lies at the center of a high plateau in the Safed Kho or ``white mountains,'' 18 miles from the Pakistan border. Its strategic significance is limited, but the guerrillas and the Afghan government have placed enormous importance on the city in Paktia province. Afghan President Najib is from the province. Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai, the former defense minister and leader of last month's coup attempt, maintained a home in Khost until he defected to the mujahedeen. The town has been on the brink of falling to the mujahedeen several times in the past two years. But troops loyal to Najib have always managed to push back the guerrillas. A week after the failed mutiny, Tanai boasted to reporters that government troops manning the Khost garrison would surrender to the mujahedeen when he gave the order. Across the border in Pakistan, the headquarters of the U.S.-supported resistance, the Hezb-i-Islami group led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, claimed the garrison wanted to surrender but was awaiting assurances of safety. ``The only major obstacle standing in the way of a surrender is Jalaludin Haqqani,'' said a spokesman for Hekmatyar. Haqqani, a traditionally proud Pathan warrior with a flowing red beard, is commander of rival Hezb-i-Islami faction led by Yunis Khalis. Haqqani has been fighting to take Khost since the 1978 coup that installed a Communist government in Afghanistan. He is considered the most powerful guerrilla commander in the area, largely because of his well-supplied fighters and close tribal ties rather than his fighting ability. Khalis' guerrillas have been blamed for the massacre of some 70 government soldiers who wanted to surrender to the mujahedeen in November 1988 near the eastern city of Jalalabad. Their bodies were cut up and put on display, and other guerrilla groups said that prevented soldiers from defecting once the Soviet army ended direct military involvement in Afghanistan in February 1989. On Friday, Moslem guerrillas opened fire as more than 10,000 insurgents surrendered in northwestern Afghanistan's Herat province. Radio Kabul said an Afghan general, a deputy security minister and several civilians died in the battle that broke out during the surrender ceremony. Haqqani's fighters contend Hekmatyar's faction has no right to negotiate a surrender and say they want revenge for the thousands of guerrillas who have been killed during the war. Their stand has enabled Hekmatyar's guerrillas _ who have a reputation for ruthlessness _ to promote themselves as humanitarians. ``The killing of prisoners is un-Islamic and the Koran explicitly states that once your enemy lays down his weapons you are under obligation to protect him,'' said the Hekmatyar spokesman. Before the war, Khost's population was about 15,000. Now after nearly 12 years of fighting, Western diplomats in Pakistan and mujahedeen leaders say that number has been drastically reduced. They say the only residents are the 5,000 to 8,000 militia and government troops manning the garrison. Most belong to a civilian militia formed by local tribesmen that had supported Gen. Tanai throughout the war. The mud villages between Khost and the Pakistani border are free-fire zones, and anyone traveling in the area is subject to attack _ by bombing and strafing of Afghan warplanes or mujahedeen firepower. The guerrillas fire into the town with mortars, recoilless rifles and howitzers. The bodies of dead are left to rot. Government troops answer with frequent air raids, forcing the mujahedeen to seek cover in underground bunkers. Once the planes are gone, the guerrillas emerge and resume firing.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Indicted in Connection With Bus Accident Solicitations
DOC.TEXT: Three lawyers and a law firm ``runner'' accused of illegally promoting lawsuits after the state's worst school bus accident were indicted Friday by a Hidalgo County grand jury. District Attorney Rene Guerra said he could not release the names of those indicted until they are formally summoned to appear before a judge. They are accused of ``barratry,'' a misdemeanor on the first offense punishable by up to a year in jail and a $2,000 fine. Officials began investigating alleged lawyer misconduct after the Sept. 21 accident in which 21 students died in the southern Texas town of Alton. Guerra has said authorities received reports of lawyers soliciting business at funeral homes, hospitals and wakes, and engaging in other improper activity, but he would not reveal the allegations in the sealed indictments. A runner is someone who works as an agent for a lawyer to promote a lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Gun-Toting Elderly Woman Halts Burglar
LaserPhoto DN3
DOC.TEXT: Ninety-year-old Gena Scarbrough said she learned how to shoot while growing up on a farm but never pointed a weapon at anyone until she stopped a burglar with a borrowed pistol this week. Police say Ms. Scarbrough stood in her carport Tuesday night waiting for an intruder to leave the house. When the burglar climbed out a window carrying a stereo and speakers, Ms. Scarbrough aimed the .22-caliber pistol at him. ``I told him, `Put it down right there and don't move! Don't move or I'll shoot!'' she said. Ms. Scarbrough said she wasn't the least bit flustered and would have shot the burglar if he hadn't cooperated. She held the intruder at gunpoint until the police arrived several minutes later. ``I'd determined he wasn't going to get away,'' she said. ``He'd broken into my property.'' A tenant at the duplex owned by Ms. Scarbrough had called her to say that someone was breaking in to the other apartment. After phoning the police, Ms. Scarbrough rushed to the property. In her haste, she said, she forgot her shotgun. But Tommie Barnes, 72, the woman who notified her of the break-in, handed her a handgun and was by her side when Ms. Scarbrough confronted the burglar. Police arrested Manfredo Barrios, 33, in connection with the break-in. A Dallas police spokesman criticized Ms. Scarbrough's action. ``This is what we get paid to do,'' said Cpl. Ray Bilbrey. But Ms. Scarbrough, who sometimes listens to police scanners for entertainment, said she thinks homeowners should know how to defend their property with a firearm. ``I think everybody ought to have one,'' she said. ``You can't always get the police when you need them.''

DOC.HEAD: Ratiu, Exiled For 50 Years, Wins Nomination For President
DOC.TEXT: A millionaire businessman who spent 50 years in exile was picked as an opposition party's presidential candidate Friday and is expected to present a tough challenge to the ruling National Salvation Front. Ion Ratiu, 72, was nominated as the candidate of the National Peasants' Party. It is one of two leading pre-World War II parties that have re-emerged since the December revolt toppled Nicolae Ceaucescu and ended 45 years of Communist rule. Interim President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist and member of the National Salvation Front, is expected to declare his candidacy this weekend. Ratiu was one of four candidates for the nomination. He won on the first round of voting during a meeting of party's 64-member ruling body, said party official Victor Isac. Isac said he believed Ratiu was helped to victory by party elders' belief that his international connections will serve the Peasants' Party well in the May 20 elections. For years, Ratiu campaigned against the Communists from exile. He returned to Romania soon after the revolution. Ratiu said he would import a printing press next week to publish an opposition newspaper open to all political parties. The opposition parties have frequently charged the National Salvation Front unfairly dominates radio, television and the press. Isac said Ratiu also was helped by being the nephew of his namesake Ion Ratiu, who led the influential Romanian National Party in Transylvania at the turn of the century. No accurate opinion polls have been published in Romania since the revolution, making it hard to gauge the relative strength of the parties contesting the elections. Opinion samples and conversations with Romanians suggest, however, that the National Salvation Front, which took over after Ceausescu was ousted, will face its strongest challenge from the Peasants' Party and the National Liberal Party. The National Liberals, also a strong pre-World War II party, are led by Radu Campeanu, who last Saturday declared he would run for the presidency. Campeanu also said the National Liberals, the Peasants and the Social Democrats, another group powerful before World War II, were forming an alliance for the May elections. He said the three traditional parties would cooperate in order to win a majority in the parliamentary elections, with a possible view to creating a coalition government. However, Amalia Radut, a National Liberal Party official, said in an interview Friday that the agreement holds only for the parliamentary, not the presidential race. Ratiu became a millionaire in shipbuilding and other enterprises in Britain. He described the three-party cooperation as a kind of ``non-aggression pact'' but stressed, ``We are not a coalition.'' Ratiu's wife, Elisabeth, from Liverpool, said she would have ``to collect my breath'' to get used to the idea of campaigning as the potential first lady of Romania. Married to Ratiu for 45 years, she said she had visited Romania frequently in the late 1960s and 1970s to see her husband's relatives. ``He's wanted to come back to Romania all his life,'' she said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Ole Miss Tradition of Elected Newspaper Editors Ends
DOC.TEXT: For 50 years, University of Mississippi students who wanted to be editor of the campus newspaper had to be elected, a procedure critics said picked the best politician, not the best journalist. Following a spring protest that included publishing blank pages in the newspaper, the process has been changed. The next editor of The Daily Mississippian will be chosen by a selection committee instead of elected by the entire student body, ending a campaign process in which candidates often spent hundreds of dollars on posters and fliers. Last month, the student government voted 29-21 after much debate to do away with elections and empower an 11-member selection committee of faculty and students. Critics said fraternities and sororities controlled the annual elections, and the votes were little more than popularity contests. ``Our image is that we are the Greek white supremacists who don't want the state to be a good place to live for anyone but ourselves,'' said Journalism Dean Will Norton, who came to Ole Miss 16 years ago. ``Ole Miss is a school of deep tradition, but I think this way they will pick the best candidate,'' said Lee Eric Smith, a junior from Holly Springs who could be the school's first black editor. The deadline for applying for the post is Thursday. Norton said he knew of four students who were likely candidates. About 10,000 students are enrolled at the antebellum campus, the site of race riots in 1962 after a court ordered that a black student be admitted. About 20 students work on the editorial side of the 10,000-circulation paper. Before the student government vote last month, the staff put out two protest editions _ one had several blank pages and the other contained the U.S. Constitution published three times in place of the usual news and sports _ to object to the election process. ``We used that as a last resort to get the student's attention to show them how seriously the student journalists feel about this,'' said the current editor, Bill Dabney. Some students upset by the protest responded by scrawling obscenities on copies and scattering hundreds of issues across campus. Samir Husni, chairman of the selections board, said candidates will be given editing, writing and spelling tests before being interviewed. He said an exact timetable was still being worked out but that the new editor should be in place by the end of the month. ``Since its the first time ever, we want to do it as perfect as possible, so we'll set the stage for the future,'' said Husni. ``When you're hiring someone after a big controversy, it's even more difficult.'' Norton said Ole Miss was one of the few remaining U.S. schools that chose their editor by election. ``What's encouraging about it is that the students brought the change,'' said Norton.

DOC.HEAD: Record $7.3 Billion Spent For School Construction
DOC.TEXT: Government spent a record $7.3 billion for public school construction in 1987, the third consecutive year that construction spending increased by more than 19 percent, the Commerce Department said Friday. The department's Census Bureau said construction spending totaled nearly 4.5 percent of the $166 billion spent in 1987 for elementary and secondary education, their largest share of total spending since 1981. Long-term debt issued for elementary-secondary education is the traditional way most school construction is financed. In 1987, $6.6 billion in long-term debt was issued for school systems. The report, ``Finances of Public School Systems,'' is a compilation of all pertinent finance data for all elementary and secondary public school systems and local higher education systems with more than 5,000 enrollment for fiscal years that ended June 30, 1987, with a few exceptions. Total expenditures for all education _ elementary, secondary and higher education _ was more than $246 billion in 1987, the latest year for which figures are available. The federal government spent more than $32 billion, or 13 percent of the total, to fund programs such as school lunch and milk, impact aid, education for the handicapped and Head Start. Federal spending also included education research projects of the National Institutes of Health, the Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation. States funded almost $140 billion, or 56 percent, of the total spent for education, including more than $80 billion for elementary and secondary schools and nearly $60 billion for higher education. Local school systems supplied an additional $75 billion, or 31 percent, for local public education. According to the report, six states _ Alabama, Hawaii, Louisiana, Mississippi, New Mexico and South Dakota _ received more than 10 percent of their elementary-secondary funding from the federal government. Local government shares of funding for elementary and secondary education ranged from 91 percent in New Hampshire to 13 percent in New Mexico. New Mexico and Washington had the greatest proportion of funding for schools, with the exception of Hawaii's state-operated system, the report said. The report said the nation spent an average of $2,269 per student for instruction in 1987. Alaska had the highest spending for instruction per pupil at $3,721, followed by New York at $3,597 and New Jersey at $3,531. Mississippi had the lowest at $1,378, while Louisiana was at $1,407 and Utah at $1,487.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Killed in Clashes in Western India
DOC.TEXT: Factional violence erupted into riots on Friday, leaving 11 people stabbed to death and three killed by police who opened fire in an attempt to stop the fighting, United News of India said. In keeping with Indian news media's policy of not publicizing religious and ethnic differences, the agency said the trouble grew out differences between ``two communities.'' The term is often used to describe trouble between Hindus and Moslems. United News said ``anti-India, pro-Pakistani'' slogans had been painted recently on walls in Ahmedabad, where the fighting occurred. It is 470 miles southwest of New Delhi in Gujarat state, which is adjacent to Islamic Pakistan. Police reinforcements and paramilitary troops were rushed to Ahmedabad to try to halt what the news agency called the city's ``worst ever communal riot.'' It said police fired about 100 bullets and 150 tear gas shells to break up the disturbance. Thirty-one people have been killed in the past four days in violence in Ahmedabad, United News said. It had no additional details on the 14 deaths Friday. Ahmedabad, an industrial city of 1.7 million people noted for its blend of Hindu and Islamic architecture, served as a base for independence leader Mohandas G. Gandhi. Gandhi advocated nonviolence in India's struggle for freedom from British rule. When India became independent in 1947, it was partitioned along religious lines into two nations: predominantly Hindu India and overwhelmingly Moslem Pakistan. Today 82 percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus, while 12 percent are Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's Elections: Political Unknown Surges in Polls
DOC.TEXT: A presidential candidate once considered a dark horse has made serious inroads into the lead held by celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa and may force a runoff, pollsters said Friday. They said Alberto Fujimori, a political independent like Vargas Llosa, has a strong chance of capturing second place in Sunday's election with enough of a margin to force another round of balloting. Nine candidates are competing in the elections, and a majority is required to prevent a runoff. Fujimori, 51, is the son of Japanese immigrants and commanded less than 1 percent of voter support in February surveys. The APOYO polling agency and the Peruvian Company for Market Research said surveys taken over the last week indicate a sudden decline in support for Vargas Llosa. His support level has dropped from around 45 percent in mid-March to 35 percent to 37 percent. Their surveys showed Fujimori surging into second place with 21 to 24 percent. ``We have been observing a tendency, first in Lima and then in the provinces, that is so strong that it has disconcerted pollsters,'' said Manuel Saavedra, director of the Peruvian Company for Market Research. ``It's a totally atypical phenomenon.'' The pollsters attributed Fujimori's rapid rise to Peruvians' distrust of established politicians. Representatives of APOYO, the Peruvian Company for Market Research and Datum, three of Peru's leading public opinion survey firms, met Friday with foreign correspondents to release results of surveys taken in recent days. The poll results are barred from publication in Peru within 15 days of the election. The last survey results released in late March, before the ban, showed Vargas Llosa of the center-right Democratic Front coalition with 45 percent of the vote and Fujimori with almost 12 percent. More recent polls show Fujimori nearly doubling his popularity. ``I don't want to talk about the polls, but apparently they give us an overwhelming force,'' Fujimori said in a Friday news conference. The pollsters said Vargas Llosa stood a strong chance of being defeated by what they called the ``Fujimori phenomenon'' in a second round of balloting. The polling firms said Peruvians, facing the worst economic crisis ever to hit their nation, support Fujimori because they see him as a political newcomer. They said Vargas Llosa, who has been campaigning two years, has acquired the image of a professional politician. Manuel Torrado, president of Datum, said surveys also indicate Peru's poor are not confident that Vargas Llosa can keep his campaign pledge to lower inflation from current levels of 2,000 percent a year to 10 percent. The pollsters all agreed that Vargas Llosa's detailed plan for economic sacrifice has cost him dearly in the polls. ``People have begun to fear Vargas Llosa's program,'' said Alfredo Torres, media director for APOYO. Fujimori's campaign has emphasized general themes. He has said no drastic economic measures are necessary. ``Peruvians are looking for a savior,'' Torrado said.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Between Black Groups Kills 10
DOC.TEXT: New black feuding reportedly killed at least 10 people Friday, the day after President F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela agreed to open black-white talks that were delayed by the violence. Pro-apartheid critics attacked the government for the accord. Andries Treurnicht, leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, called for unity in ``the white nation.'' On the other side of the political spectrum, a black group lambasted Mandela for agreeing to negotiate with the white government. De Klerk and Mandela, vice president of the anti-apartheid African National Congress or ANC, agreed in Cape Town on Thursday to go ahead with the talks. They are aimed at removing obstacles to formal constitutional negotiations between the government and leaders of the disenfranchised black majority. The two leaders hailed their Thursday night agreement as a breakthrough. The Citizen newspaper in Johannesburg said the talks will be April 25, though no date was official announced. Mandela and de Klerk also called for an end to violence that has left hundreds dead in recent weeks and prompted the ANC to postpone the opening of talks with the government. Police said Friday that rival Zulu war bands armed with guns, knives and sticks clashed around the Natal province capital of Pietermaritzburg. They set fire to homes and fought on the hillsides around black townships of the southeastern province. The bands also clashed with police, who fired on crowds with rifles, pistols and shotguns. At least one black man was killed when police opened fire on a large crowd near Ladysmith, according to the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp. The police also said their patrols had been shot at when they tried to separate the fighting groups, and one police officer was killed and three injured in various incidents. Crowds attacked funeral processions, firing on the mourners and breaking open coffins in two incidents, police said. The fighting erupted after two days of relative quiet in the region hit by vicious fighting between rival Zulu factions supporting the conservative Inkatha movement and the United Democratic Front, an ANC affiliate. Both groups oppose apartheid, but they differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. At least 67 people have been killed in the area since last week. More than 12,000 refugees, mostly women and children, have fled their homes to escape the fighting. In Pretoria, Treurnicht, the pro-apartheid Conservative leader, lashed into the government for what he called an alliance with the ANC and the Communist Party. At his speech commemorating the day Dutch settlers arrived in South Africa in 1652, Treurnicht appealed for support from all whites ``so that on the day the state president dares to hold a referendum on his new constitution, this white community can stand shoulder to shoulder and simply reject any dispensation that denies white freedom.'' De Klerk says he wants to negotiate a new constitution that will bring blacks into the national government but allow whites to maintain veto power over major policy decisions. He opposes a one-person, one-vote system that the ANC and other leading anti-apartheid groups demand. Leaders of the Pan-Africanist Congress on Friday accused Mandela and the ANC of selling out by negotiating with the government. Barney Desai, the Pan-Africanist Congress' regional coordinator, criticized the idea of negotiating with the white government. ``What you have won in battle, you will never gain on the negotiating table,'' he said. The ANC and other anti-apartheid groups were legalized in February, when Mandela was released from prison. He was serving a life term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white government.

DOC.HEAD: FDA to Issue Aspirin Warnings for Pregnant Women
DOC.TEXT: New warnings will be required on over-the-counter aspirin products advising women in the last three months of pregnancy not to use the products unless directed by a physician, the Food and Drug Administration said Friday. Aspirin late in pregnancy can affect fetal circulation and uterine contractions and cause excessive bleeding during elivery, an FDA spokeswoman said. A third-trimester pregnancy warning is already required on non-prescription ibuprofen products. Acting FDA Commissioner James Benson detailed the agency's plans in a March 29 letter to Thomas Warriner, under secretary of the California Health and Welfare Agency. Benson said he was aware of the state's interest in preparing a similar warning under Proposition 65, California's anti-toxics law, and wanted officials there to know FDA's plans. Benson said the wording of the warning had not been determined, but would likely be similar to the ibuprofen warning. That warning says: ``It is especially important not to use ibuprofen during the last three months of pregnancy unless specifically directed to do so by your doctor because it may cause problems in the unborn child or complications during delivery.'' The agency plans to publish a rule on the warning in the next several months, Benson said. It would go into effect immediately and companies would have one year to make the label changes, he said. Aspirin labels already advise pregnant women and nursing mothers to get the advice of a health professional before using the product.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st and 3rd grafs of 1st item to CORRECT spelling to `decibel' sted `decible'
DOC.TEXT: County commissioners meeting to discuss a noise ordinance found that they themselves violated the proposed decibel levels while they chatted during a recess. ``Outside in the hall, it was 75 or 77 decibels while y'all were on your break,'' said Sgt. Joe Westbrook of Glynn County Police, who brought a sound meter to the courthouse. The ordinance would limit noise to 60 decibels in residential areas. County Police Chief Carl Alexander said the proposal is unreasonable, and he suggested Thursday that commissioners raise the limit in a residential area to about 70. Interest in a noise ordinance apparently grew out of complaints last year from Beverly Shores subdivision residents who were bothered by music coming from a skating rink north of Brunswick. Skateland owner Bob Hurst said he thinks he can operate within the proposal's restrictions. He said he already has a sound meter inside the rink and keeps the music at no more than 80 decibels. At that level, the music cannot be heard by his nearest neighbor, Hurst said.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Ask Democratic Congressman To Sign Up
DOC.TEXT: The Republican National Committee sent a membership card to the wrong guy, Rep. Frank Annunzio said Friday. The Illinois Democrat said he had received a letter from President Bush on behalf of the committee asking for a contribution that would make him a sustaining member of the Republican Party. Ironically, Annunzio, who has represented a Chicago district for 26 years, faces a tough challenge this fall from a Republican state senator, Walter Dudycz. ``I have learned that the Republican National Committee has targeted me for defeat and has pledged to give my opponent $400,000,'' Annunzio said in a reply letter. ``Since the Republicans have that kind of money to spend, why do you need a contribution from me?'' Annuzio inquired in the letter. Mistakes like the Annuzio solicitation ``happen all the time,'' said RNC spokeswoman Leslie Goodman. We've had more than 200 elected officials switch parties,'' she added. ``If Democrats don't want to switch, maybe they'd be willing to contribute.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sen. D'Amato,Blocked at Border, Criticizes Gorbachev
With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet border guards Friday barred Sen. Alfonse D'Amato from entering Lithuania, and D'Amato later accused Moscow of trying to strangle the Baltic republic's ``cry for freedom.'' D'Amato, a New York Republican, had printed in his U.S. diplomatic passport a stamp that read, ``Lithuanian Republic, Visa No. 3'' and had been invited to visit Vilnius by the president of the breakaway republic, Vytautus Landsbergis. The senator said the purpose of his trip was to show congressional support of Lithuania's drive for independence from Moscow. But at the small country border crossing at Ogrodniki in northeast Poland a Soviet major politely told him to go to a consulate and apply for a regular Soviet visa. The refusal came as little surprise. The crossing is normally closed to all but Polish and Soviet citizens. Since the confrontation between the Kremlin and Lithuania began this month, the Soviets have limited even that traffic. D'Amato used the occasion to highlight what he called the Soviet Union's ``psychological warfare'' on Lithuania, whose parliament declared independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. ``It's nothing more than a stranglehold being placed on the cry for freedom by the Lithuanian people,'' D'Amato said. ``I think the Soviets are making a mistake: those artificial barriers will not keep the Lithuanian people away from freedom.'' He told reporters the United States should be more skeptical of the intentions of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``The sooner the United States wakes up to what is taking place and becomes realistic, the better,'' he said. ``Mr. Gorbachev says one thing and does another. He talks about freedom and yet denies access to a free country.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said regarding D'Amato's trip: ``We're always concerned about members of Congress and others getting too involved in foreign policy. But on the other hand, he is a senator who has an important message to deliver. He represents a broad constituency and has every right to make that trip and deliver his message.'' D'Amato is on the Senate Appropriations Subcomittee on foreign operations, but is not viewed as a major Senate spokesman on foreign relations. He flew to Poland Thursday planning to challenge the Soviet land blockade of Lithuania. The Soviet Union rejected any claim of Lithuanian sovereignty, and U.S. diplomats and Western journalists were ordered out of Vilnius. Accompanied by Lithuania's Foreign Minister Algrinas Saudragis, D'Amato and a half-dozen aides traveled by chartered bus the 200 miles from Warsaw to Ogrodniki, Lithuania's only direct border opening to the outside world. In sunny weather, they arrived at the crossing at about 2 p.m. Polish soldiers let them pass the first barrier on the Polish side. But 100 yards down the road they came to a red-and-white barrier marking the Lithuanian frontier and guarded by Soviet KGB troops. Through an interpreter speaking Lithuanian, D'Amato asked Soviet Maj. Vitas Buchis for permission to pass into the country. Buchis, a native Lithuanian serving in the Soviet border force, told D'Amato he would check by telephone with Moscow. After returning from a phone call that he said was to Moscow, Buchis told D'Amato passage was forbidden. ``I am sorry but rules are rules. I am just following orders,'' he said. Saudragis, who was met on the Lithuanian side by two subordinates, then crossed into Lithuania by himself. Extending his arm to D'Amato's across the frontier, Saudragis said: ``We shake hands over this border that divides us. But your support is strengthening our spirit.'' Saudragis also thanked the United States for never recognizing the forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union in 1940. ``We are optimistic that the borders now being guarded by the brutal military force will be replaced by bridges of good will, and that we will be able to visit each other without any obstacles,'' he said. D'Amato spent about one hour at the border before turning back. The Soviet government has closed the Ogrodniki crossing for most traffic since Tuesday. It is permitting only Polish and Soviet citizens to use it to return home to their respective countries. Ogrodniki is Lithuania's only direct border crossing to a non-Soviet country. The main international crossing between Poland and the Soviet Union is about 95 miles to the south, at Brest in the Soviet Byelorussian Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Official Questioned by Marcos Lawyer About Immunity
DOC.TEXT: The former bank manager who told of huge cash withdrawals for Imelda Marcos' visits to New York was grilled Friday by her attorney about the immunity given him by the U.S. and Philippine governments. Oscar ``Oca'' Carino, who managed the Philippine National Bank's New York branch from 1973 to 1984, also was questioned about his evasion of U.S. taxes on interest he skimmed, with the approval of Mrs. Marcos' personal secretary, from two accounts set up for offshore investments. ``Isn't it true that you did some dishonest things while you were at that bank?'' asked Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerald Spence. ``I did some wrongdoings there but they were pursuant to instructions to me,'' Carino said. On Thursday, Carino testified that Mrs. Marcos visited New York two to three times annually during the years he ran the PNB office, each time drawing an average of $100,000 from his bank's operating accounts for her personal use. Mrs. Marcos is accused of using more than $160 million stolen from the national treasury, and millions more from defrauding several banks, to finance a lavish lifestyle and the purchase of four New York buildings. Her husband, former Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos, was charged in the 1988 indictment but died in exile in Hawaii last September. A co-defendant, Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction for allegedly backdating documents to help the Marcoses conceal their ownership of the Manhattan properties. Spence probed into Carino's agreements with the two governments that granted him immunity from prosecution in exchange for truthful information about his dealings with the Marcoses. Carino many times said he could not remember details of the agreements when pressed by Spence. One exchange _ about whether Carino knew he wouldn't be arrested before he came to speak to U.S. prosecutors in 1987 _ went on for about 20 minutes. Spence, however, could not shake Carino's answer that he spoke to prosecutors on the advice of his lawyer and had no assurances from the U.S. government that he would not be charged. ``I took the risk,'' he said. Carino said he set up two special accounts ``with the clear understanding'' of Mrs. Marcos' confidential secretary, Fe Roa Jimenez. One, called Oemcee, lasted from 1976 to 1981 when it was replaced by the second one, called Oscarman Holdings Ltd., which was closed when he left the bank in 1984. The accounts were designed for offshore investments that would not be noticed by PNB staffers or state bank examiners, he said, but the interest was credited to him and went undeclared on his U.S. taxes. The witness said he couldn't recall how much interest he took from the two accounts over the eight years. His agreement with the U.S. government includes a provision that he repay $123,000 in back taxes and interest, but Carino said he had not yet made the payment to the Internal Revenue Service. ``You can remember a conversation with the first lady at the airport nine years ago but you can't remember the amount of money that you took from these accounts?'' Spence asked with an edge of sarcasm. ``I never paid much attention, I was not keeping track. But on those instructions from the first lady ... if I don't remember them and execute them, I'll be done,'' Carino said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Salutes `Towering, Passionate' LBJ
DOC.TEXT: President Bush praised former President Lyndon B. Johnson on Friday as ``a towering and passionate figure.'' ``The Johnsons were close to both the land and the people,'' Bush said at a White House ceremony honoring the nation's 36th president. He paid special tribute to Johnson's widow, Lady Bird Johnson. ``She brought to the White House dignity, warmth and grace,'' Bush told an East Room audience that included Mrs. Johnson and several hundred people who served with Johnson. Bush also called Mrs. Johnson's highway and park beautification program, along the Potomac River in Washington and alongside Texas highways, ``a very important legacy.'' The best thing his predecessor ever did, Bush said, was to ``marry Lady Bird.'' Mrs. Johnson, 78, thanked Bush and his wife Barbara for tribute. ``What a beautiful big wonderful thing you've done for this big family of ours,'' she said. ``We had the added privilege of going upstairs, and remembering where this picture hung and where that one came from. ... I am very grateful,'' she said. Of LBJ, Bush said: ``He was a towering and passionate figure, endlessly in motion.'' Among the guests were former House Speaker Jim Wright, former Defense Secretary Clark Clifford, former Health, Education and Welfare Secretary Joseph Califano and former White House aide Jack Valenti. Bush also joked that members of his administration in a quarter century ``might be invited to your own reunion, perhaps even hosted by President Robb _ Jennifer Robb.'' It was a reference to the Johnson's granddaughter, who is the daughter of Sen. Chuck Robb, D-Va., and Lynda Bird Johnson Robb. Johnson, who became president after John F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1963, won election on his own in 1964 and was inaugurated the following January, 25 years ago this year.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiations Bog Down on Disbanding Contras, Security Zone Sizes
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations have stalled for disbanding the U.S.-backed Contra rebels because of disagreement over the size of security zones in Nicaragua and over a verifiable cease-fire, rebel leaders say. One leader, Oscar Sovalbarro, known as Commander Ruben, said in an interview Thursday night it was impossible for his guerrillas to disarm before the leftist Sandinista government leaves office on April 25. A delegation from the United National Opposition, the pro-American, 14-party coalition newly elected to power in Nicaragua, is expected in Tegucigalpa on Saturday to try to break the deadlock. Contras and Sandinistas have exchanged several proposals without results. Members of a U.N. mission for Central America will monitor the talks. The Contras accused the Nicaraguan military and Interior Ministry security troops of bombing peasant communities and intimidating residents, killing UNO activists and ordering soldiers to shoot at helicopters from a U.N. mission that is supervising the demobilization plan. The Sandinistas charged the Contras with staging attacks against military installations and against pro-Sandinista civilians to intimidate them. Honduran military authorities have barred journalists from visiting Contra jungle camps at Yamales, near the Nicaraguan border. But journalists who went there before the clampdown said most Contras have slipped into Nicaragua. A Western diplomatic source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said only 2,000 to 3,000 combatants remain at Contra camps of the 12,000 fighters based there before the Sandinistas lost in the elections on Feb. 25. The number of Contras in Nicaraguan territory ``is easily 9,000,'' the source said. Sovalbarro, the Contra chief of psychological operations and its negotiator on disarmament, claimed 12,000 rebels are now inside Nicaragua. An accord signed by the Contras and UNO in Tegucigalpa on March 23 calls for the rebels to start disarming no later than April 20, five days before President Daniel Ortega hands over power to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, but sets no deadline for completing the process. ``Nobody is saying that those inside (Nicaragua) have to disarm before April 25,'' said Sovalbarro. ``For there to be confidence among the fighters and a national reconciliation there must be a total demilitarization.'' Sovalbarro said the Contras and Sandinistas agreed on the sites, but not on the size of five security zones inside Nicaragua where the rebels are to concentrate and surrender their weapons to international observers. The Sandinistas want a total area of less than 400 square miles; the Contras want 1,200 square miles, he said. Sovalbarro said the Contras also want the Nicaraguan army and security forces purged of Sandinista officers, saying ``the entire Sandinista structure must disappear.'' An agreement signed by UNO and the Sandinistas on March 25 stipulates that the government of Mrs. Chamorro will ``respect the professionalism'' of army and security forces but forbids officers from holding leadership posts in any party. ``If she agrees that elements that are in high leadership levels of the Sandinista party remain in place, that would create much unhappiness among all the fighters, and even the voters,'' Sovalbarro said. Some Contra fighters interviewed inside Nicaragua said they will not surrender their weapons while the Sandinistas maintain control of the army. ``But they know they must obey a top command,'' said chief Contra spokesman Alejandro Acevedo. ``As people, anybody has the right to express themselves. But they are very disciplined elements. And we keep in constant touch with them.'' Acevedo said negotiations were hindered by what he said were Sandinista violations of a cease-fire. ``As long as our people are persecuted and harassed, they will keep thinking that way. We must have a true cease-fire. It's a very important step,'' he said. Contras remaining at camps in Honduras are to surrender their weapons April 16. But military sources said ``only a bunch of old FAL'' Belgian-made automatic rifles remain there because the Contras took all their newer weapons with them to Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Club Fire Survivor, Haunted, Hanging on
LaserPhoto NY46
DOC.TEXT: Nightmares jolt Ruben Valladarez awake in his hospital bed, tormenting him with thoughts of friends who died in a place called Happy Land. ``I feel better,'' he said Friday. ``Only I got a little bad dreams.'' Valladarez, the disc jockey at the illegal Bronx social club, is one of a few survivors of the arson fire that killed 87 people March 25. He was critically injured, with burns over 40 percent of his body. In his first interview, Valladarez described the ordeal haltingly, with tears. He lost friends, and at least three cousins, he said, naming them with a tortured face. He cannot explain why he was the one who lived. He was spinning records in the back, on the second floor, about 4 a.m. ``Somebody screamed _ `Fire!''' Valladarez recalled. ``I put the lights on. I said into the microphone, ``Everybody get out! I've got a fire!'' There was no emergency exit at the crowded club, no emergency lights, no sprinkler system, not even a window to jump from. Valladarez was one of only two people to escape from the second floor. Four or more escaped from the first floor. First he crossed to the front of the second-floor dance area, looking for a friend. ``I said, `We have to get out, man.''' He descended a narrow front stairway to the first floor bar. It was already filled with flames. ``Downstairs is fire. I run downstairs,'' said Valladarez, 26, a native of Trujillo, Honduras, for whom English is a second language. People there were running about in panic. ``They scream. Everybody going to the door, pushing the door. It's locked.'' Valladarez thought of his wife, Frances, and their 2-year-old daughter, Nadine. He ran into the flames, searching for the sole open door; there was no other choice. ``I had to go,'' he said. When Valladarez reached the street his clothes were on fire. People threw water on him. He suffered third-degree burns on his forearms and hands, second-degree burns on his legs and face. When his wife saw him at Bronx Municipal Hospital she could not recognize him. Twelve days and three operations later, Valladarez remains in critical condition in the burn ward. He may need more surgery, and two to three months of hospitalization, and nine to 18 months of rehabilitation.
