The burn ward chief, Dr. Steven Blau, said it is too soon to say whether Valladarez will regain the use of his hands. ``His attitude is very good. He's a fighter,'' Blau said. ``And his attitude is very important, because everything he has to do in terms of recovery will hurt him.'' Valladarez's face is raw, blistered under the eyebrows and on his lips, coated with salve. A tube feeds oxygen into his nose. Two needles provide intravenous fluid. His arms are heavily bandaged, one suspended from a stand to keep swelling down. He is hooked up to a heart monitor. He said he feels anguish for loved ones who died and anger at Julio Gonzalez, the man accused of setting the fire to punish an ex-girlfriend who worked there. ``He has to go to jail. Fifty years _ or 200,'' Valladarez said. ``In my country, this man is die.'' Valladarez, who worked at the Happy Land for two years, said he never had considered the danger of fire there. His advice now: Stay away. ``Don't go no more. Because every social club in New York is bad.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA on Target for Shuttle, Telescope Launch
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Friday cleaned Discovery's engines and replaced a TV camera lens from the shuttle in preparation for next week's mission to launch the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. The camera was removed from the shuttle's robot arm after technicians found the spot on the lens, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. ``It's not going to impact the schedule at all,'' he said. Mission specialist Steven A. Hawley will use the 50-foot-long arm to deploy the telescope during the five-day mission. A spot on the television camera lens might have hampered his view. The launch countdown was to begin soon after Hawley and the four other crew members arrived on Saturday afternoon. The shuttle is scheduled to blast off at 8:47 a.m. Tuesday. ``Things are coming on us in a rush right now,'' said Bill Taylor, the telescope's chief engineer. ``It's almost unbelievable to think that in a couple of days we'll be closing the payload doors and it will be the last time we'll see it until it's in orbit.'' Tuesday's launch date was jeopardized earlier this week when a power outage interrupted testing of the telescope and orbiter. The tests were completed Thursday, eliminating the last major prelaunch hurdle. Technicians on Friday continued cleaning the shuttle's rear engine compartment, removing protective covers for flight and installing essential last-minute items. ``Everything's pretty well on target,'' said George Diller, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Diller said the only operation left that might pose a slight problem was disconnecting the telescope's nickel-hydrogen battery chargers and removing the instrument's dust and moisture protection. The operation, which NASA calls a ``payload closeout,'' was expected to the completed by Sunday. ``Once they get in to disconnecting the umbilicals, that's when you get into the real serious Hubble Space Telescope closeout,'' Diller said. The telescope is the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built by NASA. Hawley said he has practiced deploying the telescope dozens of times and is prepared for just about anything that might go wrong. ``I'm confident we can do it under almost any circumstance,'' he said. ``NASA's real good at what-ifs, and we've done a lot what-ifs. What if this part doesn't work? What if the arm fails completely?'' Once deployed, the telescope is to orbit 380 miles high for 15 years, enabling astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. It will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Design Flaws Responsible For 15 Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Flaws in the design of the Army's CH-47D helicopter have caused two accidents that killed 15 servicemen and injured six others, a House subcommittee contends. The House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations found that in at least 25 instances potential disasters were avoided by the work of the aviator, constraints on the aircraft or luck. ``The report is nothing less than an indictment of the CH-47D Chinook helicopter as well as the failure of the Army Aviation Systems Command to seriously and effectively resolve safety of flight problems,'' Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the subcommittee, said in an April 4 letter. Dingell, in the letter to Army Secretary Michael P.W. Stone, questioned why the service continues to procure the helicopter despite the mechanical problems. He also asked if the Army would suspend its plans to buy 144 helicopters at a cost of $900 million over three years until the problems are fixed. The report said the CH-47D, a twin-engine, transport helicopter made by Boeing Helicopters of Philadelphia, has suffered numerous mechanical problems that have grounded the aircraft nine times, including five last year. In addition, the Army Aviation Systems Command has issued ``no less than 84 flight safety directives to correct safety problems on the aircraft.'' A 1988 accident in Texas killed 10 soldiers and was blamed on design defects, the report said. Fire triggered by flying metal fragments was the cause of another 1988 crash in Honduras that killed five servicemen. The Army said it had not received a copy of the report but said its Aviation Systems Command has taken steps to resolve the problems when identified in the CH-47D. ``Soldiers' safety is the Army's primary concern and the Army would not allow the CH-47D to continue flight operations if it were not a safe aircraft,'' Army Maj. Nancy Burt said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: More Snow And Low Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell Friday from Texas across the southern and central Appalachians to the East Coast, and temperatures fell into the single digits around the northern Plains and Great Lakes. An inch of snow fell at Syracuse, N.Y., during the morning and raised the city's total snowfall since last fall to 161.3 inches, almost 14 feet. Rain was scattered over south-central Texas, the central Texas Gulf Coast, central Louisiana and southern Mississippi, and from northeastern Mississippi across northern Alabama, northwestern Georgia, much of Tennessee, western North Carolina, western and northern Virginia, eastern Kentucky, West Virginia, Maryland, Delaware and southern New Jersey. The rain changed to snow at higher elevations of West Virginia and Kentucky. Snow showers continued along the shores of Lake Michigan, eastern Upper Michigan, east-central and northwestern New York state, and north-central Pennsylvania. Two inches of snow covered the ground Thursday morning at Wausau, Wis., and up to 3 inches of snow fell between Pulaski, Wis., and Algoma, Wis. Snow showers also fell over north-central and northeastern New Mexico with light snow in parts of the Texas Panhandle. Huron, S.D., chilled to a record low of 8 and Marquette, Mich., had a record low of just 4. In a milder region, Melbourne, Fla., had a record low of 48. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was the record 4 at Marquette.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Editors Elect Six Directors
DOC.TEXT: The American Society of Newspaper Editors has elected three new directors and re-elected three incumbents, the society reported Friday. New directors, elected for three-year terms, are Jane Healy of the Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel, John Driscoll of the Boston Globe and Robert Giles of the Detroit News. Re-elected to three-year terms were Jean Otto of the Rocky Mountain News in Denver and Larry Allison of the Long Beach (Calif.) Press-Telegram. Arnold Rosenfeld of Cox Newspapers was re-elected to a one-year term. The elections took place during the ASNE's annual convention, which concluded Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Study of Eighth Graders Shows Promise, Problems
DOC.TEXT: The typical eighth grader is happy at home and doing well in school, but an Education Department official said Friday about 20 percent of middle-school students are at risk of failure. Emerson Elliott, acting commissioner of the department's National Center for Education Statistics, released the first results of a study that will follow today's eighth graders as they move through high school and beyond. ``We've already identified a large number of students who are at risk of either school failure or dropping out before high school graduation,'' Elliott told an Education Writers Association conference in Chicago, where the report was released. ``We will continue to collect data on these same students for another dozen years whether they stay in school or drop out,'' he added. To examine factors that contribute to school success, the National Education Longitudinal Study of 1988 collected information on six commonly used indicators of ``at risk'' status. Overall, 53 percent of the 24,600 eighth graders in 1,000 public and private schools nationwide in the spring of 1988 had none of the risk factors, but 20 percent had two or more, the study showed. Twenty-two percent were in single-parent families, 21 percent lived in families with income of less than $15,000, 14 percent were home alone more than three hours a day, 11 percent had parents with no high school diplomas, 10 percent had siblings who dropped out and 2 percent had limited English proficiency. The study found that students with several risk factors tended to have more educational problems, including low grades and high absenteeism. Students with two or more risk factors were six times as likely as those with none to report that they did not expect to graduate from high school and were twice as likely to score in the lowest 25 percent on achievement tests and to receive the lowest 25 percent of grades, said the study. Twenty percent of all eighth graders were not proficient in the basic math skills _ addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division _ considered necessary to perform everyday tasks. Thirty percent of Hispanics, blacks, and American Indians were not proficient at the basic level. Fourteen percent of eighth graders were unable to perform basic reading tasks, such as finding information in a text or identifying the author's main thought. About 30 percent of students who usually speak a language other than English failed to show basic reading skills. The report, ``A Profile of the American Eighth Grader,'' was conducted under an Education Department contract by the National Opinion Research Center, a not-for-profit research center affiliated with the University of Chicago. Other key findings were: _41 percent of females and 28 percent of males aspired to professional or managerial careers, or careers in business, science or engineering fields. _10 percent of students reported that someone has offered to sell them drugs at school, with 16 percent of American Indian, 14 percent of Hispanics, 10 percent of whites, 8 percent of blacks and 5 percent of Asians reporting that experience. _Blacks and American Indians were nearly twice as likely as whites to report they did not feel safe at school, 18 percent versus 9.9 percent. _The typical eighth grader spent almost four times more hours per week watching television, 21.2 hours, than doing homework, 5.5 hours.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Nations to Participate in Naval Exercise
DOC.TEXT: The United States and four other Pacific nations will take part in a maritime exercise from April 9 to May 20, the Pentagon said Friday. The exercise, which will include naval forces from Australia, Canada, Japan and South Korea, will take place in the waters off the coast of southern California to the Hawaiian Islands, the Pentagon said. Some 55 ships, approximately 200 aircraft and more than 50,000 sailors, marines, airmen and soldiers from the five nations are scheduled to take part in the event, dubbed RIMPAC 90. It is the 12th in a series of exercises conducted since 1971, the Pentagon statement said. ``The exercise is designed solely to enhance the tactical capabilities of participating units in most major aspects of conventional maritime warfare,'' the Pentagon statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Measuring 5.8 Strikes Area Northeast of Guam
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake, the second in less than 24 hours, struck northeast of Guam early Saturday, according to the Hong Kong Observatory and U.S. Geological Survey. There were no reports of injury or damage. An Observatory statement said the quake registered 5.8 on the Richter scale and was centered off the east coast of the Marianas Islands 434 miles northeast of Guam. The observatory gave no further details of the quake, which occurred at 1:04 a.m. (11:04 a.m. EDT Friday). Dan Finley of the U.S. Geological Service in Reston, Va., confirmed the quake. ``They did have an aftershock of 5.8 in the same location,'' he said. ``This is normal after a big earthquake like this to have aftershocks.'' Earlier Friday, a quake registering 7.4 shook a section of the Marianas Islands at 7:15 a.m. (5:15 p.m. EDT Thursday). There also were no reports of injury or damage. The epicenter was 138 miles northeast of Saipan near the island of Anatahan in the western Pacific. On Tuesday, all 21 residents of Anatahan, closest to the epicenter, abandoned the island after a volcano there showed signs of erupting. A Navy crew from Guam was checking the volcano Friday, but geologists said the earlier quake and volcanic activity apparently were unrelated. Anatahan and Saipan are part of the Northern Marianas chain just north of Guam, about 1,500 miles east of the Philippines. An earthquake of 6 on the Richter scale can cause severe damage in the local area. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Three Dead, 21 Injured in Miami Beach Hotel Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with authorities changing estimates of number of missing to nine sted 12 and saying number of dead could rise, revising estimate of total number of residents to 100 sted 100 to 150; other details. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `Tenants reported...' Branaird is cq 2nd graf and Olimpia is cq in 15th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MH2,4,6,7, LaserColor MH3, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Frantic tenants jumped from their windows or groped through smoky hallways as a pre-dawn fire destroyed a three-story residential hotel Friday, killing at least three people and injuring 21. At least 9 residents were unaccounted for hours after the three-alarm blaze broke out at the Fontana Hotel on Collins Avenue north of Miami Beach's trendy art deco district, Fire Chief Branaird Dorris said. But officials had no evidence they were trapped inside. Many of the estimated 100 residents were retirees, some of whom had to flee without their medications or hearing aids. ``It's a terrible fire. I don't know how to describe this when you have multiple deaths and you have total destruction of a building,'' said Assistant Fire Chief John Reed. ``I can't even think of the proper word to describe it.'' Alfonso Teixeira, a 27-year-old Brazilian, was awakened in his room by a frightened resident. ``I saw this guy running in the hall, shouting `Fire! Fire! Big! Big!''' Teixeira said. The hotel had smoke alarms but no sprinklers, authorities said. Two women and a man were killed, and fire officials presumed they were on a list of 12 people still missing by late afternoon. Twenty-one people were treated for smoke inhalation at various hospitals. Some were hospitalized and others were released. The dead weren't identified Friday. ``There's reason to believe that the number of dead may grow'' because many of the missing lived in the most heavily damaged front section of the hotel, said Assistant Fire Chief John Reed. After rescue efforts ended Friday, police and fire officials, state fire marshals and a special federal fire investigation team planned to meet Saturday to determine how to pursue the hotel search. Mayor Alex Daoud, who opened his house to survivors, said the intensity of the 3 a.m. fire led investigators to suspect arson, but Detective Jim Hyde said no evidence of arson had been found in the early stages of the investigation. Tenants reported a water leak, raising the possibility of an electrical short, Dorris said. Dorris said crews had entered the building six or eight times by early afternoon but about 30 percent of the building had collapsed and those areas hadn't been searched for the missing residents. He said it might be Saturday or later before the worst sections are examined. Residents said the fire started near an elevator shaft at the front of the 102-room hotel, and Hyde said two of the bodies were found in the lobby area. ``I felt I was choking,'' said Rose Waller, an elderly woman who made her way out with three neighors but lost her daily medication. ``I couldn't see because already the smoke came into my room. I really couldn't see anything. It was blurred.'' Residents fled in nightclothes, robes or whatever they could grab while members of a Romanian immigrant family who have owned the white stucco hotel since May knocked on doors to alert everyone. ``I ran upstairs and got people out. I broke down a door with my shoulder to get somebody out,'' said Olimpia Mihai, a member of the family. ``It happened so quick _ half a minute and I couldn't see anything. I'm still in shock.'' Her brother-in-law Cosmin said: ``I woke up in the nick of time when the high-frequency alarms went off. I was screaming down the halls, `Move it! Move it! Move it!' I stayed up in the halls no more than 10-20 seconds before the smoke got too bad and I had to run.'' Ann Karmiller, 87, said she walked down from the third floor by hanging onto the bannister, fleeing so quickly that she left with nothing but her nightgown, forgetting her dentures, hearing aid and cane. ``She grabbed my hand and helped me out,'' said Jewel Mirsky, 76, who escaped with Ms. Karmiller. ``It was all black. We felt the steps very haltingly. I heard the noise and the siren went off like mad. The smoke was very bitter.'' Second-floor resident Joe Marcello, 32, who has limped since breaking his back two years ago, tried to go down the hall but choked on the smoke. ``I started to fear for my life. I got scared,'' he said. ``I thought: `I'm going to die in here. How am I going to get out?' I'm already crippled. I just busted out the window and I hung from the second floor and I dropped down about 15 feet.'' He said another second-floor resident broke her window, dropped her baby to a man on the ground and jumped out herself. The Fontana was built in 1951 and complied with a 3-year-old ordinance requiring electric smoke alarms in each room, said Reed, the assistant fire chief. The only major violation in the most recent city fire inspection last September was battery-powered alarms, which were replaced, officials said. The hotel was not equipped with sprinklers, which won't be required by state law until October 1991. The American Red Cross checked in 121 people from the Fontana and the adjacent Prince Michael Hotel at a shelter set up at a community center. Hotel Capri owner Barry Appel opened about 30 rooms for elderly Fontana residents and said 25 rooms were available to younger residents at a nearby apartment building. The staff of Fedco Pharmacy called hotel residents' doctors to get a list of their medication and fill prescriptions. ``Unlike other fires, lots of these people need medical supplies right away,'' said Red Cross spokesman Chris Chidley.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Warmly Greeted; Jackson Blasts Bush
LaserPhoto NU3
DOC.TEXT: If the administration's test battle in the war on drugs has failed in the nation's capital, it's because federal authorities neglected to work with local officials, Washington Mayor Marion Barry said Friday. Barry, facing drug and perjury charges in the District of Columbia, was in New Orleans for the National Conference of Black Mayors. He briefly stole the show from Jesse Jackson when he walked into an anti-drug meeting during a Jackson speech and was given a standing ovation. Later, in an impromptu news conference, he discussed a story in Thursday's New York Times that said the Bush administration would soon issue a report indicating its year-old pilot program in Washington hasn't worked. ``I have not seen the report,'' said Barry. ``I think they're going to release it next week. But as Jesse Jackson indicated, the initial approach was wrong. It was like an exclusionary situation where you come down and you propose things for us without talking to us.'' Barry said he saw no irony in his attending an anti-drug meeting at the mayors' conference while facing cocaine charges. He scoffed at a suggestion that the proliferation of drugs in Washington could be related to his own admitted substance abuse problems. ``It's a red herring,'' he said, later adding, ``America has a critical need to solve its problem. I'm not going to be the focus of it.'' Barry has admitted dependency on alcohol and tranquilizers but has skirted the issue of cocaine abuse. He was arrested Jan. 18 during an FBI sting operation and faces trial on five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and three counts of lying to a grand jury about his drug involvement. He has pleaded innocent to the charges. ``It would be nice if they would spend as much money for drug treatment and other kinds of facilities as they did in investigating my administration for the last 10 years,'' Barry said. Barry had slipped into the room during Jackson's speech and was walking up an aisle when Jackson stopped and said, ``Come on up, Mr. Mayor.'' The 400 or so people in the audience stood and applauded as Barry walked to the dais and sat next to the former Democratic presidential candidate. Jackson had been delivering a scathing indictment of President Bush's handling of the drug war. He described William Bennett, Bush's national drug policy adviser, as ``a general without portfolio.'' President Bush, Jackson told the mayors, will ``declare a war with the resources and have you fight the war without resources _ voodoo politics.'' Jackson also reiterated his call for state, national and local officials to develop a plan to make public and private pension funds available for investment in low-income housing and other programs aimed at eliminating poverty.

DOC.HEAD: 23 Polynesians Convicted in Religious Witch-Hunt Murders
DOC.TEXT: A jury convicted 23 residents of a South Pacific atoll who claimed they were swept up by demons or religious frenzy when they tortured to death six people during a witch hunt. The seven-man, two-woman jury at the Tribunal of Papeete handed down penalties late Thursday that ranged from three to 14 years imprisonment for those who participated in the 1987 slayings. ``I find these penalties very heavy,'' said Roman Catholic Archbishop Michel Coppenrath, the highest-ranking church official in French Polynesia. ``The repentance of the accused is sincere.'' The defendants, mostly fishermen and farmers from the atoll of Faaite, showed no reaction when the sentences were read. Another suspect, a minor, will be judged in a separate proceeding. The 14-year sentence went to farmer Francois Mauti, 25, on convictions of murder, complicity in murder and inflicting mortal blows. He led a band of disciples that organized the violence in Sept. 2-4, 1987. ``I had a spirit under the spell of the devil,'' Mauti told Judge Marcel Bihl. ``I lost my head, but I believed I was on the holy path, shunning the evil fighting within me.'' During the nine-day trial, the court heard defendants speak of being swept away by evil spirits or religious enthusiasm as they hunted down and killed neighbors they thought were possessed. The terror had roots in August 1987 visit by three women who arrived from Tahiti, 300 miles to the west. The women claimed to represent the Roman Catholic-affiliated movement Christian Renewal, a group founded in the United States. Church authorities deny they had any official role in the movement. The group already had a strong following on Faaite, a sandy atoll where about 180 people live. The women, regarded as ``priestesses'' by the islanders, took over the community's whitewashed church and replaced the lay preacher as the religious authority. The trio's leader, Alexandra Silvia, conducted services in a trance and told frightened islanders of her visions that God would abandon Faaite, the defendants said. Miss Silvia suggested demons were in their midst, defendants said, and the population began viewing with suspicion fellow islanders who failed to attend her daily services. ``My words were misinterpreted,'' testified Silvia, a 55-year-old dental secretary who was not charged. ``I only gave prayers that cured those who were sick.'' But the defendants said the mood of the once-placid atoll swung between ecstasy and dread inspired by Silvia and her assistants. The trio left Faaite in late August and anointed seven disciples to continue their work. A few days later, a 14-year-old boy reported a vision that the devil had possessed his aunt. The islanders gathered in nightlong prayer and finally pronounced the demon exorcised. They repeated the ritual with two other people. But Ioane Harris, the assistant mayor, publicly denounced the women on Sept. 2. Maddened villagers twisted a cord around his neck, beat and drowned him, and threw his body on a bonfire built before the church. ``It was necessary to purify him,'' one defendant said. ``It was necessary to purify the village.'' Five more people were killed over the next two days. Most islanders took no part in the carnage, but it was Sept. 4 before anyone established contact with Papeete, the capital of French Polynesia, and reported trouble on the atoll. The mayor, who had been on vacation, and a Roman Catholic priest arrived the next day with police. Psychiatric experts testified the emotional charismatic Christianity, mixed with ancient Polynesian beliefs in the supernatural, produced a dangerous mass hysteria on an isolated island lacking institutional authority. The three visitors were not put on trial because they left Faaite before the murders.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Employee Buyout Plan Riddled With Doubt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 5th & 6th grafs, ``Lenders also,'' with 3 grafs to update with unions saying Wolf may not be ousted, closing stock price, and Inserts 2 grafs after the 20th, ``Wolf would,'' to add detail on change in stance on Wolfe. Longer version moved on financial wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: UAL's directors agreed Friday to a $4.38 billion buyout by employees that would make United Airlines' parent company the world's largest worker-owned corporation. But some analysts doubted whether the deal would fly. Union leaders said the agreement calls for the 71,000 employees to give up $2 billion in concessions over five years, including $300 million in the first year and $500 million in the fifth year. The three union groups that negotiated the $201-a-share deal have not yet secured financing for the buyout, according to a source involved in the talks. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. Analysts said that weakness could prove fatal. Lenders also may frown on the possibility the unions will dump UAL Corp. Chairman Stephen Wolf, who is perceived as a highly capable airline manager despite his difficult relations with the unions, analysts said. One union leader said Wolf would be out but a spokesman for the union group said later that the issue had not been settled. The stock market apparently reflected investor skepticism that the deal will be completed. After a strong opening, UAL closed $2 a share lower at $163.50 Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. ``The capitulation of the board has been significantly overshadowed by the continuing financing risks,'' said airline analyst Samuel Buttrick of Kidder Peabody & Co. Those risks, he said, ``make it a very uphill battle from the financing side.'' UAL's board announced the tentative agreement after meeting all night at company headquarters near Chicago. The leaders of unions representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants gave some additional details at a news conference in New York. Under the agreement, shareholders would receive $155 in cash, $35 in UAL notes and an estimated $11 worth of securities in UAL subsidiary Covia Corp. for each UAL share. UAL would spin off to shareholders its 50 percent stake in Covia, which is co-owned by a consortium of five other airlines and operates an automated reservation system. UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, immediately called off its threatened proxy fight to oust the board at the April 26 annual shareholders meeting. Coniston has an 11.8 percent stake in UAL and was pressuring the board to sell to the UAL employees. The company formed by the unions for the takeover is called United Employee Acquisition Corp. In terms of the number of workers, the largest employee-owned company currently is Publix Inc., a supermarket chain based in Lakeland, Fla., with 50,000 employees, said Corey Rosen, executive director of the National Center for Employee Ownership in Oakland, Calif. UAL said it expected to conclude a final agreement promptly. But the deal depends on the unions securing financing, and Machinists union Vice President John Peterpaul said the group had several months to put financing together. ``We're very optimistic about the financing,'' he said. Under the plan, the unions would sign five-year contracts with no-strike clauses. Other concessions include wage cuts of up to 7.69 percent for flight attendants and Machinists and as much as 11 percent for pilots. UAL's 25,700 non-union employees would negotiate their work conditions with the union group, said their lawyer, Stephen Fraidin. The pilots would own 37.9 percent; Machinists 35.7 percent, non-union employees about 14.3 percent and the Association of Flight Attendants about 12 percent, the union leaders said. Wolf would be replaced, said Frederick Dubinsky, head of the Air Line Pilots Association union. But later in the day, union group spokesman Hank Krakowski said the unions had made no such decision. ``Our position is we're not including or precluding anyone from any management team at this point,'' he said. One candidate previously contacted by the union group as the possible successor to Wolf is Richard Ravitch, onetime head of New York's public transit system. Ravitch did not immediately return calls to his New York office Friday and the union leaders would not comment on whether he would take over. ``The question is, who is going to manage this thing and take it to the banks?'' said analyst Jack Hunter of Howe Barnes Investments Inc. in Chicago. Hunter said he believed the deal would ultimately go through. Doubts about the deal stem from the failure last October of a $6.8 billion employee buyout of UAL attempted by the pilots, Wolf and British Airways PLC. That deal collapsed on Oct. 13, sparking a 190-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average, after banks refused to finance it due in part to opposition by the Machinists. Peterpaul said this deal would be more attractive to lenders because it involves about $2 billion less debt and has the participation of all three unions, which represent about two-thirds of UAL employees. UAL is the second-largest U.S. carrier, after American Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: A Cry From The Hallway: `Fire. Fire. Big. Big.'
With AM-Hotel Fire Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bewildered survivors of a pre-dawn fire at the residential Fontana Hotel sat quietly in an emergency shelter Friday, staring dazedly at a crowd of social service workers and Red Cross volunteers. Most of the hotel residents, many of them elderly, lost everything they owned in the blaze that claimed at least three lives. ``I just sold my business last Sunday and moved all my things into that room,'' said Enid Davis, a Jamaican-born beautician. ``I lost ... I just don't want to think about it.'' ``I don't have a place to go. I don't even have a dime.'' Ms. Davis said her children and grandchildren live ``down south'' in Florida. But she couldn't remember where. She moved into the Fontana only three weeks ago. Willy James Williams, 42, remembered coming home from a bar shortly before the fire broke out. In his room, he was startled by the smell of smoke that wasn't coming from his cigarette. ``When I went for the hall, the smoke through the (door) frame caught me full in the face,'' he said, a Red Cross toiletries kit in a plastic bag on his lap. ``I lost everything I had.'' Williams, who had been at the Fontana for a week, said his mother lives in Miami, ``but I don't want to live with her.'' Red Cross volunteers gently questioned those left homeless by the fire. Paramedics, social workers, police officers, social center staff members and reporters filled the makeshift shelter in the auditorium of the South Shore Community Center. But most of the roughly 200 residents who escaped the Fontana blaze _ or were evacuated from the neighboring Prince Michael Hotel _ rarely left their seats for the boxes of doughnuts, cans of fruit or cocoa on tables set up in front of the auditorium stage. Most were still in their pajamas and bathrobes while a pile of donated clothing and shoes grew hourly on the stage. ``What we have on is what we now own,'' said Alfonso Teixeira, 27, tugging at his trousers and T-shirt. The Brazilian-born security supervisor and his 29-year-old fiancee, Ester Cubinhese, had been saving money to get married. ``It's all gone: the clothes, the stereo, the television, everything,'' said Teixeira. ``Thank God he was at home last night,'' Cubinhese said quietly in Portuguese. ``I'd have panicked certainly if I'd been alone.'' Teixeira said someone banging on their door woke them up. ``I saw this guy running in the hall, shouting `Fire. Fire. Big. Big.' He didn't speak much English. Luckily, our door was right next to the fire exit.'' Cubinhese and Teixeira said they had been impressed by the hotel maintenance during their six months there. ``If you had any problem, like a broken light, anything, they came and fixed it right away,'' Teixeira said. But the hotel didn't have a sprinkler system. Sprinklers aren't required by law until 1991. Teixeira's mother also lives in Miami Beach. ``We'll probably work something out,'' he said. At least three hotels offered rooms or efficiency apartments to those in need. A supermarket offered food and a neighborhood drug store sent a pharmacist to fill prescriptions for medications left behind at the Fontana.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Blasts Bush Administration on Civil Rights
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward M. Kennedy attacked the Bush administration Thursday for giving mere ``lip service to the fight to end bigotry'' while the White House renewed both support for civil rights and its threat to veto a bill the Massachusetts Democrat is sponsoring. ``The administration's veto threat underscores the sharp contrast between its words and its deeds on civil rights,'' said Kennedy, whose bill to combat job bias is a major goal of civil rights forces in Congress this year. Kennedy's comments came after presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters at the White House that the administration is ``for civil rights legislation'' but ``we are simply not for that bill.'' The Kennedy bill is aimed at restoring legal tools that civil rights forces say were taken away by six Supreme Court decisions last year. Provisions range from a ban on harassment of employees to expanding workers' rights to challenge seniority systems based on discrimination. The heart of the bill, based on a case at a salmon cannery in Alaska, would force employers accused of discrimination to change their hiring practices or prove that the practices were based on business necessity. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in his letter to Kennedy on Tuesday that this provision, aimed at overturning the Supreme Court's ``Wards Cove'' decision last year, would in effect result in racial hiring quotas. Kennedy said in his statement that while ``giving lip service to the fight to end bigotry, the administration is clinging to its do-as-little-as-possible response to the Supreme Court's recent decisions, which dramatically cut back on long-accepted protections for working men and women against discrimination on the job.'' ``The administration is digging in its heels at a time when a bipartisan majority in the Congress and the country want to see those decisions overturned and the gaps in our civil rights laws filled,'' Kennedy said. The Bush administration is calling for approval of a more modest job-discrimination bill, which would address two of last year's rulings. ``We are interested in correcting problems which arose from last year's Supreme Court cases,'' Fitzwater said. Kennedy's Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee on Wednesday approved his measure, 11-5, with support from Sens. David Durenberger, R-Minn., and James Jeffords, R-Vt. Durenberger told the panel that the administration would not act on civil rights without pressure from the committee. The measure now has 40 Senate co-sponsors and civil rights forces say they have enough votes for passage. But conservative critics led by Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, say they hope to ease some of its provisions in floor action. Hatch told the committee that the measure would create a ``bonanza for lawyers'' while Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., declared that it would ``add litigation.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Fire on Afghan Surrender Ceremony, Say They Tricked Gov't
With AM-Afghanistan-Khost, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new casualty figures, rebel claim that surrender was a trick. No pickup. Najib is single name
DOC.TEXT: Moslem guerrillas fired on a surrender ceremony in Afghanistan Friday in which 10,000 rebels were giving up to the Soviet-backed government and more than 12 people were killed, Kabul radio said. The major rebel organization Jamait-i-Islami said the surrender was a trick, planned five months ago to trap government forces. Two Afghan generals, one of them a deputy security minister; nine guerrillas and several civilians died in the close-range battle that broke out during the ceremony in northwestern Herat province, the official Afghan broadcast said. Jamiat-i-islami (Islamic Society) is considered the most militarily efficient of the seven Pakistan-based resistance groups and the dominant one in the Herat area. Numerous diplomats based in the Afghan capital of Kabul and foreign journalists were flown especially to Herat for the ceremony and witnessed the attack, the radio said. Western diplomats in Pakistan, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they had reports that up to five Afghan generals were killed or wounded in the 15-minute gunbattle and in hand-to-hand combat with knives and pistols. Kabul radio made no mention of five generals. The radio, monitored in Islamabad, reported, ``A small group of extremists attacked the welcome ceremony with heavy fire. In the resulting battle between Afghan troops and extremists, numerous people were martyred.'' The broadcast said guerrillas shot and killed Lt. Gen. Jalal Razaminda, who was also a deputy security minister, and wounded Herat provincial Gov. Fazle Haq Khaliq Yaar as they embraced guerrilla leaders who vowed to give up their weapons and join President Najib's national reconcilation policy. A second general died later on a military plane to Kabul, it said. His identity was not immediately released. National reconcilation is a term used by the government in which local guerrilla groups agree to switch sides and either stop fighting or help the government fight. The government says tens of thousands of rebels joined national reconcilation the past year. But mujahedeen sources in Quetta, southeast Pakistan, said Friday's attack was first planned five months ago and was apparently aimed to avenge a similar attack by government troops 11 years ago. According to the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, the guerrillas slowly began infiltrating the area in November and then sent word recently that they wanted to surrender. The guerrillas, known as mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors, have been fighting to overthrow the government that seized power in a 1978 coup and installed a Marxist regime. The mujahedeen are backed by the United States and Saudi Arabia, and are based in neighboring Pakistan. According to Radio Kabul, 2,200 armed guerrillas and 8,000 unarmed rebels gathered on the plains about 25 miles from Herat city for the surrender ceremony. But instead of surrendering their weapons, the guerrilla fighters turned them on government officials and army troops, the mujahedeen sources said. The guerrillas reportedly were armed with weapons ranging from side arms to recoilless cannons, missiles and rocket launchers. They fired the first shot as the governor embraced an unidentified rebel commander dressed in a white robe and turban, according to Western diplomats and mujahedeen leaders in Pakistan. The governor's guards immediately fired back and the plain erupted in great volleys of gunfire from both sides, they said. Several civilians, including children, were killed in the crossfire that was cut short when two Afghan army tanks moved into the area and broke up the crowd with bursts of fire, the diplomats said. A photographer from Afghan national television was reportedly shot in the head and seriously wounded. Herat district was the first region in Afghanistan to rise against the Soviet Union in early 1979 before the Red Army intervened to prop up the Marxist government. That uprising cost at least 2,000 Afghan lives when government troops pretended to join the rebellion against widening Soviet influence in the country. The Kremlin pulled out its troops in February 1989 but continues to pour an estimated $300 million a month in supplies and weapons into Kabul. The leading rebel commander in the district is Jamiat-i-islami's Ismail Khan, a former government officer. Herat has been fought over, conquered and destroyed since it was founded by the Persians more than 2,500 years ago. It was captured and destroyed by Alexander the Great in 330 B.C., by Genghis Khan in 1221 and by Tamerlane a century later. Once famed as Afghanistan's most beautiful city, much of it is deserted and in ruins. Lack of law and order has earned it the nickname of ``Afghanistan's Wild West.''

DOC.HEAD: Coupon Cutter Sentenced
DOC.TEXT: ``Coupon Connie'' was sentenced Friday to 27 months in prison for her role in a $2 million scheme to swap and redeem hundreds of thousands of bogus coupons. ``I can say a lot of nasty things, but I won't,'' a teary-eyed Connie Arvidson said after the sentence. She intends to appeal. Mrs. Arvidson, 34, of Boca Raton, Fla., was convicted in federal court of two counts of mail fraud and one of conspiracy. Also known as the ``Dumpster Lady,'' Mrs. Arvidson was one of 10 people indicted in a scheme that saw more than 600,000 illegal copies of coupons distributed nationwide from Texas. The coupons, for products from 47 companies, were printed in San Antonio. Prosecutors said Mrs. Arvidson purchased the bogus coupons from San Antonio counterfeiter David Rackmill, who pleaded guilty to mail fraud and conspiracy then acted as an informant in the case. In the trial, which began Jan. 8, federal prosecutors contended Mrs. Arvidson's claims that she dug through the trash to find coupons to sell were false. ``You know what trash looks like,'' prosecutor Paulina Jacobo told jurors. ``It doesn't come in nice bundles and get shipped by UPS. Mrs. Arvidson knew what she was doing.'' Prosecutors said she made as much as $40,000 in one year. But Mrs. Arvidson estimated the most she ever made was $200 a week from collecting and trading coupons. In addition to the 27-month prison term, she was sentenced to three years of supervised release, the maximum penalty under the sentencing formula the judge used. The formula takes into account her lack of a criminal record. Before sentencing, Mrs. Arvidson told U.S. District Judge Sidney Fitzwater, ``I would never do anything to break the law in any way. I would never hurt anyone.'' Mrs. Arvidson called coupon clipping ``my American dream,'' adding that, ``When I saw so many coupons, I guess I just let greed take over.'' Fitzwater said Mrs. Arvidson was unrepentant and tried to cover up when she realized postal inspectors were investigating her, and that she lied on the witness stand. Earlier Friday, Fitzwater sentenced fellow coupon conspirator David Reese of Center Point to 24 months in prison and two years supervised release. A third defendant, printer James Floyd Richards of San Antonio, was cleared of all three counts against him. The seven others indicted in the case agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in exchange for leniency, and several of them them testified against Mrs. Arvidson.

Wrapping up a week of designer fashion shows in New York Friday, Geoffrey Beene presented sleek, uniform-inspired clothes and anchored his ensembles with insets in the shape of triangles. ``I always try to keep the collection as contemporary as possible,'' said Beene, who has opted for stark, dramatic looks that establish his niche as an American designer. Control, discipline, fullness and sensuous severity are Beene's own words for characterizing the collection, which includes functional, ankle-length jersey tent dresses in dark tones such as black or gray, with leather insets. Somber shades of loden, taupe, wine and chocolate contribute to the sense of austerity. Strap-on accessories, such as a strip of leather, sweep over the shoulder, military-style. When you think of Beene, think of triangles, which apper throughout the collection, at the hipbone, above the bust, along the neck and within a fluttering hemline. A black evening column dress showed off a gold triangle quilted onto the bodice, and a black suit had triangles of red satin at the shoulder blade. It's all part of Beene's love affair with geometric shapes. Beene continued his tradition of shunning traditional lines; he'll take a curve whenever he can. He showed a wool fleece and quilted satin bolero with seams streaming from the bust down both sleeves. And Beene uses curved hems, ``which move fashion from an applied art to a fine art,'' says fashion arbiter Eleanor Lambert, creator of the 50-year-old International Best-Dressed List. Beene also showed jumpsuits, another longtime favorite, which he considers ``the most functional piece of clothing in the collection.'' Another trademark look is the short, buoyant full evening skirt of silk combined with a fitted bodice, sometimes with point d'esprit. ``He's the quintessential American designer, superb, tops,'' says Ellin Saltzman, senior vice president and fashion director of R.H. Macy & Co., Inc. Meanwhile, Donna Karan introduced a collection dedicated to ``pure comfort, luxury, and sensuality.'' Chock full of shades of brown, grays, beiges and taupes, in fabrics such as cashmere, ``furry'' alpaca fleece, wool crepe jersey, lacquer sequins and velvet, the collection exudes a sense of softness and ease. Monochromatic ensembles predominate, with matching opaque hose and shoes. Emphasis is on the unconstructed jacket, in an updated longer length, worn over a narrow unitard for a neat, linear look. The unitard is often paired with a short circular skirt with lots of swing, fairly buoyant with movement. Also capturing the wave of motion are circular coats over unitards. For evening, Karan creates dramatic contrast by teaming black velvet with white lacquer sequins. A black velvet circular wrap-around coat with a matching stretch velvet dress was set off by an oyster lacquer sequin scarf, creating a striking play of tone. Karan counts as one of the many American designers, such as Blass and dell'Olio for Anne Klein, who are knocking down distinctions between day and nighttime looks. Like Blass, who is showing strapless gray cashmere for evening, Karan offers an oversize gray cashmere off-the-shoulder cowl sweater teamed with a platinum sequin draped skirt. Karan's favorite after-five look is a sequins-on-cashmere kimono top with a short stretch skirt, her version of a combination of sweatshirt comfort and drop-dead sexiness.

DOC.HEAD: Complaints Spur Request For Probe of INS Detention Center
DOC.TEXT: Authorities are investigating complaints that guards at a federal holding center for illegal aliens are physically and psychologically abusing inmates, in some instances locking them in portable bathrooms. U.S. Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., and a panel of Dade County officials said they have received complaints that guards at the Krome Detention Center conducted routine strip searches and beat inmates, taunting them with comments like ``go back home because you have no right to be here.'' Other complaints included locking the inmates in portable bathrooms and forcing them to kneel and raise their hands while being ridiculed. Fascell said he has asked Attorney General Richard Thornburgh to investigate. Richard Smith, the INS district director in Miami, said he sent documents alleging abuse to the U.S. Justice Department three weeks ago and supports an investigation. George Waldroup, a spokesman for INS in Miami, refused to comment on the investigation Friday. The Krome detention center is a converted Nike missile base on the edge of the Everglades, south of Miami, that serves as a holding area for illegal aliens, mostly Haitians. It was built in the early 1980s at the height of the Mariel boatlift to house the flood of exiles from Cuba. The facility generally houses about 450, but that number can double at times. The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service says it is required by law to hold illegal aliens there pending expulsion proceedings. ``We Haitians are especially mad because we always get the worst treatment here,'' said one Haitian quoted in an affidavit. He, like other detainees quoted in the documents, wasn't named for fear of reprisal. Cheryl Little, an attorney for the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami, said there are ``alleged acts of physical abuse, mental abuse, lack of proper medical care, improper access to baths and showers, not enough time to finish meals, lack of access to telephones.'' ``We were told that one Haitian had his head smashed on a metal banister, and he was carried away on a stretcher,'' she said. Little said she has more than 100 affidavits that allege incidents and name guards involved. She said many of the same names keep arising in the affidavits. ``I'm not suggesting that everyone there is abusive,'' she said. ``There are employees there who may not have engaged in abuse, but who condoned it. The U.S. attorney's office in Miami refused to discuss the investigation, saying through a spokeswoman, ``We do not have any charges filed against Krome Detention Center at this time, but the U.S. Attorney's office would be interested in violation of federal law at Krome or any other federal facility.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Ease on German Unification; Treaty at Summit in Doubt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 4, `Baker will ...' and inserts one graf after graf 8, `Separately, Shevardnadze ...' to UPDATE with Baker comments on arms control, Lithuania; subs grafs 24-25, bgng `He did ...' to include Baker and Shevardnadze comments on possibility of German membership in both NATO and Warsaw Pact.
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Soviet Union scaled back expectations Friday for reaching a major missile-reduction agreement at next month's superpower summit but narrowed differences over German unification and the flight of Soviet Jews to Israel. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Moscow had dropped its insistence that a reunified Germany be neutral. ``There was a recognition that perhaps neutrality is perhaps not the best route to go,'' he said. Baker also said the two sides had failed to resolve differences over air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles, two obstacles for agreement on a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START). ``That is a disappointment,'' Baker said. Baker will go to the Soviet Union to hold another round of talks May 16-19 on the weapons issues. ``It's still our hope that major issues will be resolved by the summit, but that's got to take a lot of work,'' he said at a news conference. In the windup of three days of high-level U.S.-Soviet talks, President Bush cautioned Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze that a crackdown against the breakaway republic of Lithuania would be a setback to superpower relations. ``I don't think we are telling them what to do. We're telling them what not to do _ and that is, don't use force,'' Bush said later. ``We have an awful lot at stake in the U.S.-Soviet relationship, an enormous amount at stake,'' Bush said at an appearance before the convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. ``It gets into arms control, it gets into human rights, the exit of Soviet Jews, it gets into regional questions.'' Separately, Shevardnadze told reporters ``we have a clear conscience'' on Lithuania. Renewing a pledge to work out a peaceful settlement, Shevardnadze said, ``I don't think there is a basis for a deterioration in U.S.-Soviet relations.'' (And Baker, at the end of three days of talks with the Soviet diplomat, credited Moscow with trying to resolve the situation peaceably. ``Of course,'' he added, ``I would be disturbed if I thought conflict might erupt,'' he said. The president and the foreign minister met at the White House for 2 hours and 20 minutes _ more than twice as long as scheduled _ in preliminary discussions for Bush's five-day summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev beginning May 30. ``This summit will certainly become a major event in world affairs,'' Shevardnadze said afterward, standing under an umbrella in a cold rain outside the White House. Similarly, Bush said later, ``this is an important time for discussion and dialogue.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush viewed Friday's meeting as ``extensive, cordial and productive.'' ``I don't think there have been any breakthroughs,'' Fitzwater said, adding that much of the meeting had been focused on setting the agenda for the summit. Both the United States and Soviet Union expressed reservations about being able to resolve the major issues for a new treaty to reduce long-range nuclear weapons before the summit, a goal they set for themselves when Bush met Gorbachev last year in Malta. Shevardnadze said ``I would not hide from you the fact that ... we have encountered certain difficulties, certain problems'' in Washington for a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. ``This is a time of hard choices, the hard choices that one has to make in the concluding stages of the talks,'' the foreign minister said. He said the problem was compounded by the need to write a treaty that would be approved by a newly independent Soviet parliament. Nevertheless, he predicted, ``in the end there will be real certainty that we will have a solid agreement, a durable agreement.'' Fitzwater said both sides still hope for agreement on major provisions of the treaty by the summit. However, he said, ``the nature of some of these issues is difficult enough that there's certainly no guarantee at this time that we'll have a final treaty ready to sign.'' He said, ``That is our hope and that is our goal, but I'm not sure at this point in time we can say that we can expect it.'' Shevardnadze gave Bush a letter from Gorbachev on the subject of arms control, but both sides declined to disclose its contents. Shevardnadze said that at the summit Bush and Gorbachev would be able to sign a draft agreement on trade, cooperation in science and technology, arms control and bilateral relations. The foreign minister took a conciliatory stance on the unification of East Germany, a Soviet ally, with West Germany, the linchpin of NATO. ``We have to look for a solution, a solution that would be acceptable'' to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, Shevardnadze said. He did not offer any specifics beyond a suggestion that perhaps the merged country could be part both of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, and said: It is possible that we will be able to find a mutually acceptable way, a way that will make sure that a unified Germany is a factor for stability in Europe and that it never threatens anyone.'' Baker said that while the Soviets had eased their demand that a unified Germany be neutral, they continued to object to its membership in NATO. He said the idea of Germany being in both alliances was not ``attractive.'' ``We were equally firm in our view that the unified Germany must remain a member of NATO,'' Baker said. In another area, Shevardnadze said the Soviets were willing to implement an agreement for direct flights of Jewish refugees to Israel provided Israel gave assurances they would not be settled ``in the occupied territories.'' He said he included East Jerusalem as part of the occupied territories, as well as the West Bank and Gaza. Shevardnadze also held out the prospect of resuming normal diplomatic ties with Israel after a 23-year lapse _ depending on ``the overall Middle East situation.'' On the thorny issue of Lithuania, there was little indication of any movement. ``It was primarily (for) both sides to repeat their positions,'' he said. Bush said he told Gorbachev the United States supports the right of Lithuania to self-determination and never recognized its incorporation into the Soviet Union. ``And I told Minister Shevardnadze that this is an issue that could adversely affect the prospects for progress in these important U.S.-Soviet relations,'' Bush told the newspaper editors. ``And I urged the Soviet Union to begin a good faith dialogue with Lithuania. We want and we believe the Soviets want to make further progress in U.S.-Soviet relations.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced to Jail After Neighbor Takes Pictures of Dog Beating
Laserphoto LOW1
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager was sentenced to six months in jail as a result of a neighbor taking photographs of him beating his family dog, authorities said. Animal rights advocates said it was the first time in at least 20 years that anyone in Massachusetts had been imprisoned for abusing an animal. ``This shows that something can be done in cases like these, and it certainly sends a message to people that animal cruelty will not be tolerated,'' said Allan Davidson, director of the Lowell Humane Society, where Champ is in protective custody. Kevin Deschene, 19, of Lowell, was sentenced Thursday on a conviction for a misdemeanor complaint of cruelty to animals. Deschene's neighbor, Jim Molloy, said he had seen Deschene on several occasions beating and kicking the German shepherd while it was chained to a post. Molloy took pictures of Deschene kicking and beating Deschene's family's dog, named Champ, with a plank last fall. ``I had no idea that beating the dog was a crime when I took the pictures,'' said Molloy. ``I just hoped they would take the dog away and save the poor thing.'' Deschene and his family have contended the teen-ager was disciplining the dog for tearing up garbage. Deschene's attorney argued in court that, as in domestic disputes involving people, there should be no conviction because the victim was not seriously injured. Judge James Killam said Champ was helpless and was without the option of leaving or obtaining a restraining order, as do people in abusive situations. In addition to the jail term, Killam fined Deschene $500 and ordered him to perform one day of community service per month for two years. Champ's fate will be decided at a custody hearing May 3, when Duschene's family will attempt to retrieve the dog from the custody of the Humane Society.

DOC.HEAD: Benefit Concert Returns after 2{-Year Hiatus
DOC.TEXT: More than 60 singers and bands, including Willie Nelson, Jackson Browne and Bonnie Raitt, take the stage Saturday in a nationally televised concert to raise money for the American farmer. The Farm Aid concert, which has been dormant for the last two years, was organized by Nelson, John Mellencamp and Neil Young and will feature three winners from the recent Grammy Awards: Raitt, Don Henley and Lyle Lovett. A sellout crowd of 45,000 also will hear Dwight Yoakum, K.T. Oslin, Lou Reed, Guns N' Roses, Richard Marx, Jackson Browne, John Denver, and a Soviet band called Gorky Park. The Nashville Network, a cable channel, will telecast the full 12 hours live. Hosts include Dick Clark, heavyweight boxing champion James ``Buster'' Douglas, comedian Fred Travelena and actors Dennis Weaver and Michele Green. The Rev. Jesse Jackson and Texas Agriculture Commissioner James Hightower are scheduled to speak. This Farm Aid concert, the fourth, is the first to be staged in 2{ years, but the organization has been an ongoing enterprise, said Janet Corpus, its program officer. Farm Aid has raised some $12 million since its first concert in September 1985 at Champaign, Ill. Of that, $9 million has been distributed to more than 100 farm organizations, hotlines, service agencies and churches in 41 states. A quarter of the money has gone to fill the emergency needs of financially strapped farmers, while 22 percent has been earmarked for education. Previous concerts were held in held in Austin, Texas, in 1986, and in Lincoln, Neb., the next year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises to Issue Executive Order for Chinese Students
DOC.NOTE: EDS: recasts graf 5 bgng, He told, to CORRECT characterization of protection, inserts new graf 6-7 with explanation of status of students who have arrived since June 5 crackdown.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he would issue the executive order he promised last fall to guarantee that Chinese students who fear for their safety if they return home may remain in the United States. ``I did say I was going to have an executive order. What we had was an executive directive from the president,'' Bush said. In a written statement later, the president said he had recognized that his directive had not addressed two important issues: extending deportation action against Chinese nationals until Jan. 1, 1994, and taking steps to alleviate concerns about China revoking passports. The comments came in the wake of news stories that Bush failed to issue the executive order to assure no Chinese students would be returned to their homeland against their will. He told newspaper editors that the executive order will protect students from deportation beyond the current deferral of enforced departure that is scheduled to expire June 5. Bush's previous directive said students in this country as of June 5 last year would be protected from deportation. Students who arrived after that date, which is when Beijing began its violent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, are not specifically covered in Bush's executive order. But an administration official who spoke on condition of anonmyity said the later arrivals ``will be given the same consideration'' on visa waivers as those here as of June 5, 1989, who are specifically written into the order. Answering questions at a gathering of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, Bush also said he soon will announce an offshore oil drilling policy that will include banning drilling in some environmentally sensitive areas and will redfine sea lanes for tankers in other regions. Bush last year ordered a task force to study offshore drilling with an eye to environmental protection. He has yet to announce the findings of the study or any policy moves. Bush, a former Texas oil man, said there should not be a permanent ban on offshore drilling, ``because then I would be compelled to ask the question, `Where do we get the energy to keep this country going?' I don't think there should be a ban.'' However, he added, ``there will definitely be bans on certain environmentally sensitive areas.'' He said he would push for tanker sea lanes to be rerouted in the Florida Everglades, hinting at the same prospect for California's coast. On the China matter, Bush said he would issue an executive order incorporating all the provisions in his November presidential directive telling the Justice Department how to deal with Chinese students in the United States. ``We don't want to take a chance on people being mistreated, brutalized,'' Bush said. The promise came a day after his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters that an executive order was ``not the right tool'' to accomplish what the president had done by directive. However, Bush was criticized by congressional sponsors of legislation he vetoed Nov. 30 that would have put into law assurances the Chinese nationals could remain here when their visas expire. On other matters, Bush told the editors: _Former President Carter was ``not acting with the blessing of nor disapproval of or anything else of the administration'' during his trip this week to the Middle East, where he met with Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat. ``He was acting in this meeting on his own. I knew nothing about that. And certainly a former president should be free to do his thing.'' _He is not linking aid to Israel to U.S. hopes that Israel works out a negotiating format for peace with Palestinians. _He hoped a compromise budget plan to reduce the huge federal deficit could be forced, but he noted that one congressional deadline had already been missed and another was fast approaching.

DOC.HEAD: Abu Nidal Group Says Freedom Near for Three European Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian extremists led by terrorist Abu Nidal said Friday that preparations were under way to release at least three French and Belgian hostages they hold in response to an appeal from Moammar Gadhafi. Walid Khaled, Beirut spokesman for Fatah-Revolutionary Council, said in a statement issued in Beirut and delivered to the offices of a Western news agency, ``I am pleased to announce the acceptance of our movement in response to (Gadhafi's) appeal. ``I am also pleased to declare that the contacts and arrangements under way now include Mrs. Jacqueline Valente, her boyfriend Fernand Houtekins, and their baby Sony Houtekins.'' The statement said the radical Palestinian group ``hopes that this will draw the attention of the Belgian government that it should fulfill its pledges ... and curb Zionist activities against the revolution of our people.'' Fatah-Revolutionary Council has said previously that it holds Ms. Valente, a 32-year-old Frenchwoman; her two daughters born in captivity; and five Belgians. The names of the two girls were previously reported as Liberte and Palestine. The name used Friday, Sony, was new. Two other daughters of Ms. Valente were freed after Libyan intervention on Dec. 29, 1988. Daughter Marie-Laure was 6 at the time, and Virginie, 5. They were returned to their father, Pascal Betille, who had divorced Ms. Valente. Ms. Valente has been living with Fernand Houtekins, one of the five Belgian captives. Gadhafi, the Libyan leader, on Wednesday asked that Ms. Valente be freed as a compassionate measure on the occasion of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan, which ends in late April. Gadhafi's call was carried by the official Libyan news agency JANA. Abu Nidal _ whose real name is Sabri al-Banna _ is backed by Libya and believed to be living in Tripoli, the Libyan capital. Fatah-Revolutionary Council said on Nov. 8, 1987, that it seized the hostages aboard the French yacht Silco off the Gaza Strip and said they were collaborating with Israel's Mossad secret service. Friends denied it, saying the hostages were on a holiday cruise. These hostages are believed to be in Libya and so are not listed among the 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon, including eight Americans. The Belgians are Emmanuel Houtekins, in his 40s; his wife, Godlieve Kets; his son, Laurent, in his late teens; his daughter, Valerie, a teen-ager; and his brother Fernand, in his 40s. Meanwhile in Geneva, the International Committee of the Red Cross on Friday expressed doubt about the authenticity of a renewed threat to kill one of two Red Cross relief workers taken hostage in Lebanon exactly six months ago. Work at the humanitarian agency's Geneva headquarters came to a halt as staff protested the ``odious act'' and the ``prolonged anxiety caused by the kidnappers' continuing silence,'' an ICRC statement said. The statement said the ICRC was analyzing a telephone message received by a Western news agency in Nicosia, Cyprus, late Thursday from a man claiming to speak for the Action Group for the Release of Hariri. The caller demanded the release of Mohammed Hariri, jailed for life in Switzerland for a 1987 air hijacking, and Anis Naccache, jailed for life in France for trying to assassinate an Iranian emgire leader in Paris. He said if the demands were not met, one of the Swiss hostages would be executed after Ramadan. The ICRC ``has not found any proof that the caller is linked in any way with the kidnappers of Elio Erriquez and Emanuel Christen, nor has any tangible evidence ... been provided to corroborate the authenticity of the caller's claims,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Most Murder Defendants Younger Than 30
DOC.TEXT: Most of the murder defendants in the nation's largest counties are younger than 30, and a third overall are under age 21, according to a Justice Department study released Friday. In fact, two-thirds of all the felony defendants in those counties during February 1988, when the study was begun, were under age 30, says the study by the Bureau of Justice Statistics. The average age was 28. While a third of the murder defendants were younger than 21, the study also found that another third were between the ages of 21 and 29. The report studied about 11,000 felony cases in 39 jurisdictions, and said that sample represented more than 47,000 cases filed in February 1988 in the 75 most populous counties. The report gave percentages only and did not include the raw figures on which they were based. The most serious arrest charge at the time of arrest was a property offense for 36 percent and a drug offense for 35 percent. A violent offense was the most serious charge for 21 percent, with murder the most serious offense charged against 1.4 percent. Approximately six of every seven defendants were male, and 95 percent of those arrested on a murder charge were male. Two-thirds of those arrested were known to have been arrested previously, and about half were known to have at least one prior conviction. For 65 percent of those with a prior conviction, it was on a felony count. Approximately one-fifth of all defendants had more than one prior felony conviction. The defendants' progress through the system was monitored through January 1989. About 4 percent of all defendants were held without bail, including 26 percent of murder defendants. For murder defendants overall, 61 percent remained incarcerated, 26 percent without bail and 35 percent with bail, which averaged $75,000 for those who remained in jail. Thirty-nine percent of murder defendants were released before the case was disposed of, with 7 percent freed on their own recognizance and 32 percent on a financial basis such as posting bond. Bail for those murder defendants who got out averaged $10,000. Meanwhile, felony defendants with no prior convictions were released in 77 percent of the cases, compared with 46 percent of those with a prior conviction for a violent felony. The study found that two-thirds of all felony defendants were released from custody before their case was disposed of, 53 percent on nonfinancial terms and the rest on bail. While about three-fourths of the released defendants made all scheduled court appearances, a third of those who did not remained fugitives at the end of the study period. For murder charges, 78 percent of those released made all court appearances. Most of those who missed a court appearance eventually returned to court, but 4 percent of all murder defendants remained fugitives after one year. As for convictions, 70 percent of those arrested on all felonies were convicted, 54 percent for a felony and 16 percent for a misdemeanor. For those arrested on a murder charge, 66 percent were convicted of a crime. Of those convicted, three-quarters were convicted of murder. Counties participating in the study were Arizona: Maricopa; California: Los Angeles, Orange, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Diego, and Santa Clara; District of Columbia; Florida: Broward, Dade, Duval, Hillsborough, Palm Beach and Pinellas; Georgia: Fulton; Hawaii: Honolulu; Illinois: Cook; Massachusetts: Suffolk; Michigan: Wayne; Missouri: St. Louis; New Jersey: Essex; New York: Bronx, Erie, Kings, Monroe, New York, Queens; Ohio: Hamilton; Pennsylvania: Allegheny, Montgomery, Philadelphia; Tennessee: Shelby; Texas: Dallas, Harris, Tarrant; Utah: Salt Lake; Virginia: Fairfax; Washington: King; Wisconsin: Milwaukee.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Said to Be Preparing New Peace Offer
DOC.TEXT: A kidnapped senator released by the Medellin cocaine cartel said Friday the group is preparing a new peace proposal in its war with the government. The announcement came two days after President Virgilio Barco indicated the government might be easing off its policy of extraditing drug suspects to the United States. Also Friday, a presidential candidate called for legalizing drugs in Colombia, saying the government has lost its war against the drug traffickers. Authorities meanwhile announced traffickers were responsible for placing a huge truck bomb Thursday morning in a wealthy Bogota neighborhood. They said it was safely deactivated. The truck, loaded with 1,650 pounds of dynamite, was capable of killing 5,000 people had it exploded in the suburb where it was placed, secret police chief Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez said at a news conference Friday. Maza's own apartment is just off the avenue where the truck was abandoned. Sen. Federico Estrada was kidnapped by the cartel in Medellin on Tuesday and released Thursday. Drug traffickers told him that they were readying a new peace plan to present to the government, Estrada said at a news conference Friday. However, he said he did not know the details of the proposal. On Jan. 17, the cartel's leaders offered to surrender themselves and their illicit business in exchange for an end to extradition of suspects to the United States. The government said the extradiction of suspects was not negotiable. However, that position seemed to change Wednesday, when Barco said Medellin cartel leader Pablo Escobar would be tried in Colombia if he turned himself in. The president made the statement while on a state visit to France. A cartel communique last week pledged new terrorist attacks in retaliation for the government's refusal to end its policy of extraditing traffickers. Barco's government has sent 15 trafficking suspects to the United States for trial since intensifying its crackdown in August, when traffickers killed a leading presidential candidate. Since then, more than 200 people have been killed by terrorist attacks blamed on traffickers. The cartel had threatened to bomb a Bogota neighborhood and to kill police as part of the renewed offensive. Gunmen working for the traffickers shot 16 police officers and a soldier this week in the northwestern city of Medellin, authorities said. At his news conference, Estrada indicated that Barco's latest statement may have dissuaded the traffickers from carrying out more attacks. In a television broadcast Friday night on ``Programa'', conservative presidential candidate Alvaro Gomez Hurdado, a 70-year-old lawyer and journalist conducting his third race for the presidency, said the government had lost its war with the traffickers. ``This war is not being won,'' he said. ``We must look for a new approach that quickly leads to solutions that are not as evil as some have said, proposals made by respectable people who have won Nobel prizes.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Formally Filing Complaint Against Stangeland
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota Democrats are formally asking the House to investigate allegations that Rep. Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn., improperly charged Congress for hundreds of phone calls to and from the home of a woman lobbyist. The complaint being filed with the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct also accuses Stangeland of exchanging favors with a former congressman who now works as a lobbyist. The allegations were made public in newspaper articles last January. Stangeland, who is seeking re-election, has denied any impropriety. ``I don't think the questions have been answered,'' Ruth Stanoch, chairwoman of the Minnesota Democratic Party, said Friday. ``They're still lingering right now.'' Stangeland has said he welcomed the ethics investigation even though he believed it was unnecessary. Stangeland says that his relationship with Eve Jarvis, who now works for the House of Representatives, was professional, although he acknowledged making 341 calls to or from her home during five months in 1986 and 1987. Stangeland said initially that some of the phone calls might have been personal but has since insisted that they were all made for business purposes. Ms. Jarvis has refused to talk to reporters. Stangeland also denied he did anything wrong in using a car owned by former Rep. Gene Snyder, R-Ky., and in letting the lobbyist use his Capitol parking space. Ms. Stanoch said the complaint was filed with the committee but returned to the state party for Democratic leaders to verify that they could not get a member of Congress to request the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Israel General Warns that Combined Arab Attack Lies Ahead
DOC.TEXT: The army's deputy chief of staff said Friday that a combined Syrian, Jordanian and Iraqi force could threaten Israel's borders in the years ahead, but played down Iraq's present capability to destroy Israel. The comments over Israel television by Gen. Enud Barak came in reponse to threats this week by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who said his country had chemical weapons and would destroy ``half of Israel'' if attacked. ``I think (Saddam) will weigh a decision more than twice before he even thinks about attacking Israel with chemical weapons,'' Barak said in the interview, a rare TV appearance by a high-ranking military officer. Barak said in talking of a possible combined Arab push against Israel, ``We must prepare ourselves for it as if it will come to pass. However, we should not see in these preparations a certainty that this will happen.'' Barak called Saddam a sane and experienced leader who knew how to size up the Jewish state's military capabilities with those of Iraq better than any Israeli citizen. However, Barak emphasized the need to stop Iraq's attempts to build nuclear capability before it was too late. He praised a joint U.S.-British operation that resulted in five arrests in a purported plot to smuggle detonators for nuclear weapons to Baghdad. ``There is no doubt that Iraq has not ceased its attempt to reach nuclear capability. Actions like that of the Americans and British are important and proper,'' the general said. On Tuesday, government officials called for a special program to distribute gas masks to every Israeli citizen in preparation for a surprise attack. The Friday newscast repeated instructions on use of gas masks after Barak's interview.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Moves To Shed Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted Friday to eliminate the dreaded SB secret police; the old, uniformed Interior Ministry and the Citizens' Militia in a dramatic assertion of civilian control by the Solidarity-led government.
