The Interior Ministry is to become a smaller, civilian-run office. It had been staffed by uniformed functionaries along military lines and was considered part of the national defense system. The new ministry will oversee the newly created police and Office of State Protection; firefighters, and a border guard that will be separated from the army. Members of the Citizens' Militia the paramilitary force previously charged with fighting crime and enforcing the law, can automatically become police officers similar to those in Western countries. Secret police officers hired before August 1989, when Poland got its first non-communist prime minister in four decades, will be dismissed. Only those officers who pass a review process proving they are innocent of past abuses will be rehired into the new, smaller Office of State Protection. The SB monitored and harassed dissidents and even ordinary citizens to maintain the Communist Party's grip on power in Poland. The Office of State Protection is to limit its activities to fighting espionage and authentic threats to national security. The changes were adopted in three separate bills. SB officers murdered the pro-Solidarity priest the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko in 1984 and were suspected in scores of political killings. A parliamentary commission is working to uncover past SB abuses. As a safeguard, the new Interior Ministry is to include a civilian advisory commission. Local governments for the first time will be permitted to establish their own police force. The secret police force was pared from 24,000 officers last June to 3,100 this year, the government has said. Some reportedly took early retirement and some were permitted to transfer to the Citizens Militia after retraining. The Citizen's Militia has an estimated 80,000 officers nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Shoot American in Liberia, Correspondent Reported Missing
DOC.TEXT: Troops at a roadblock near the presidential mansion opened fire Friday on an American, who died while undergoing surgery for his wounds, the U.S. Embassy said. Also Friday, the government said rebels in an eastern war zone ambushed a freight train and three people aboard were reported kidnapped, including the West Africa correspondent for the U.S. news agency United Press International. The developments occur at a time when relations between the United States and this West African nation founded by freed American slaves are at their lowest level since President Samuel Doe seized power in a bloody April 1980 coup. The U.S. statement said soldiers manning a roadblock near Doe's residence in Monrovia, the capital, opened fire after midnight on a vehicle driven by Martin Joseph Millay, wounding him in the leg. Millay suffered a heart attack and died during surgery for his wounds, the statement said. A U.S. Embassy official, reached by telephone from Abidjan, Ivory Coast, said he did not know Millay's age or hometown, only that he worked for a small charter airline, Gibacol Air Services. Last week, an elderly American missionary and his British wife were killed in a shootout between Liberian troops and rebels in eastern Nimba county. It was not known who killed the Rev. Tom Jackson and his wife, June. They were Protestant missionaries who had worked in Liberia for 40 years. In addition, two U.S. Embassy warehouses in Monrovia were gutted in a March fire that destroyed $3 million worth of goods. Embassy officials suspect arson. Acting Information Minister Moses Washington told reporters Friday that rebels ambushed a train carrying empty iron ore carts from the port of Buchanan to a state-owned mine in Yekepa, Nimba county. The rebels demanded food from the conductors and three passengers, including Mark Huband, a Briton who was UPI's West African correspondent and also worked for the London Financial Times. One of the conductors escaped, but the whereabouts of the other people on the train was unknown, the minister said. Huband, 26, had been on assignment from Abidjan, where he is based, a UPI spokesman said Friday night from Washington. Rebels fighting since December to overthrow Doe had threatened to blow up the train for the Yekepa mine, a well-guarded complex in the north of Nimba County managed by foreigners, including Britons and Americans. The United States, which in the past has been a major supporter of Doe, cut aid to Liberia this year, citing human rights violations and failure to repay debts.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Remain Loose in British Prison for Sixth Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with two more prisoners surrendering; pickup 3rd pvs `The jail...'
DOC.TEXT: A small group of inmates remained loose in riot-torn Strangeways Prison on Friday, shouting from the rooftop while authorities tried to drown them out with rock music and a helicopter siren. During the day, up to 18 prisoners appeared on the roof, which was torn up by prisoners during the earlier rioting. They mostly milled Friday in the bright sunshine on the sixth day of the uprising. The Home Office, which runs prisons, reported that two more prisoners surrendered Friday. For the second day, it said ``fewer than 40'' remained loose. The jail, built for 970 inmates, housed 1,648 when the rioting began. Ivor Serle, chairman of the local chapter of the Prison Officers Association, said authorities had identified at least 18 prisoners still inside. ``We are staying patient. We are not going to take anyone by force because we don't want anyone injured,'' Serle said. On Thursday, prisoner Paul Taylor, 28, a self-professed leader of the uprising, shouted through a makeshift bullhorn that he had not meant to start a riot. Taylor said he grabbed the minister's microphone during a church service Sunday as a prelude to a planned sit-in to protest prison conditions. Taylor tried to speak again Friday, but authorities turned on rock music and a helicopter siren to drown him out. Police also turned away friends and relatives who have been waving and shouting words of encouragement to the prisoners. ``The vast majority in there, I have no doubt, want to come out,'' said Barry Cuttle, an attorney who has been involved in the negotiations. ``It's a very minute minority ruling the majority.'' Cuttle said the demands of most of the remaining inmates were no more extreme than those made by men who had surrendered. They are requesting such things as a bath, a good meal and permission to contact their families. The negotiations were calm, he said, with individual prisoners coming to talk to staff on the ground floor and then returning to report to the others. At least one prisoner was killed in the uprising. But a lawyer for some of the inmates who surrendered said they reported other killings. Attorney Frank Sinclair said two inmates told him they saw two men hanged and three thrown off balconies. Enraged prisoners then hurled cell doors and beds down on the men, he quoted the inmates as saying. ``I can't believe they could all make up stories about people being hung and killed,'' said Sinclair. Prisoner Derek White, 46, died in North Manchester Hospital on Tuesday of injuries he received at the hands of other inmates when the riot began. He was in the prison awaiting trial on charges of assaulting three children.

DOC.HEAD: Educator, Businessman Kidnapped in Kashmir, Six Militants Killed
DOC.TEXT: Moslem extremists abducted a leading businessman and an educator Friday and threatened to kill them, a day after authorities killed six militants crossing into Pakistan for arms and training, police said. Roads were blocked around Srinagar, where the hostages were seized, and soldiers tightened security around the Kashmir Valley, where the government launched a crackdown Jan. 20 on the Moslem separatist movement. A telephone caller told a local reporter the abductors were also holding a third hostage and all three men would be killed within 24 hours of a Monday afternoon deadline for releasing three jailed militants. The caller claimed to speak for the Students Liberation Front, a branch of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front fighting for autonomy in the predominantly Moslem state. India itself is overwhelmingly Hindu. Police sources, who demanded anonymity, and the telephone caller both identified the new kidnap victims as Vice Chancellor Mushir ul-Haq of Kashmir University and L.M. Khela, general manager of Hindustan Machine Tools Co. The caller said ul-Haq's private secretary also was being held hostage, but that could not be confirmed. Moslem separatists had warned Indian government officials to leave Jammu-Kashmir state before April or ``face the consequences.'' Police said the border violence took place in Kupwara district, where at least 20 separatists tried to sneak into neighboring Pakistan to receive military training and buy weapons. No details were available. India says Pakistan trains and arms the militants in Kashmir, at the far northern tip of India. Pakistan denies it. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the region since 1947, when both nations won independence from Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Young Girl Dies When Outhouse Collapses
DOC.TEXT: A young woman suffocated when an outhouse collapsed on her in eastern Nigeria, a news report said Friday. Friends got worried when the victim, 22-year-old Monica Ofor, didn't return from the outhouse after 30 minutes last weekend in the Emelili township of Anambra state, according to the News Agency of Nigeria. The outhouse had collapsed, the news agency reported, quoting police. By the time rescuers dug up the woman, she had suffocated, the report said. Much of West Africa lacks modern plumbing.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Army Truck Crash Hurts 21
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one soldiers were injured Friday, four critically, when their canvas-topped military truck skidded on an icy highway and landed upside down in a small stream, authorities reported. All were from a Royal Canadian Horse Artillery regiment based at Petawawa, Ontario, and were on assignment to train servicemen at the artillery school in Gagetown, a military base south of Fredericton. They were en route to a firing range when the accident occurred at Geary, about nine miles from Fredericton. The truck's cab was crushed in the accident and the rear, where most of the soldiers were sitting, was flattened, investigators said. All the passengers and the driver were thrown clear, said Maj. Dave Krauter. Four soldiers were in critical condition with spinal injuries and were taken to larger hospitals outside the immediate area for possible neurosurgery, said Jackie Steward, spokesman for Dr. Everett Chalmers Hospital in Saint John.

DOC.HEAD: Two Women Plead Guilty in Ax Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents in 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: Two of three women accused of attacking a man with an ax in a ritual honoring Jack the Ripper pleaded guilty Friday and agreed to testify against the third. Catherine Lipsham, 22, and Ramona Barry, 27, both of Milwaukee, pleaded guilty in Circuit Court to attempted first-degree intentional homicide in the May 29 attack on the 26-year-old man whose name was being withheld. Assistant District Attorney Mark Williams agreed to seek seek at most eight years in prison for each of the two women in exchange for their testimony against Deborah Kazuck, 26. Ms. Kazuck's trial is set to begin Monday with jury selection in Madison. Sentencing for Ms. Lipsham and Ms. Barry is set for May 25. According to the criminal complaint, the three woman told police they planned to dismember the victim's body, drain his blood and eat his kidneys in a ritual they believed would bring Jack the Ripper back to life. The women called the attack a ``kacking'' a combination of ``killing'' and ``Jack,'' the complaint said. Police said Ms. Kazuck told officers she wanted to commit the attack to prove her love for Jack the Ripper, the famous 19th century British serial killer, whom she said she believed was her son in a previous life. The complaint said Ms. Barry lured the man to an apartment she shared with Ms. Lipsham on the city's south side, saying she was alone and frightened by a storm. The man told police that he heard something move in the shower while he was in the bathroom. He said he pushed the curtain and found the other two women. Ms. Kazuck allegedly held an hatchet with a two-handed grip, raised it above her head, began chanting ``redrum'' and struck the man on his forehead just above his left eye, police said. ``Redrum'' _ murder spelled backward _ is an term taken from ``The Shining,'' Steven King's novel about supernatural violence, the complaint said. The man told police he ran into the street and flagged down an ambulance, which took him to a hospital. The gash required 50 stitches. All three defendants originally pleaded innocent by reason of insanity and were evaluated for competence by two psychiatrists. Each was found competent to stand trial.

DOC.HEAD: Abu Nidal's Ex-Commander Says Terrorist Leader is a Psychopath
With AM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: A former commander in Abu Nidal's organization says the terrorist is a psychopathic killer, according to a report broadcast Friday. CBS Evening News reported that Abu Nidal has $200 million in Swiss francs and is preparing another terrorist attack. ``He is a person with a sick mind,'' the former commander, Atef Abu Bakr told CBS. ``He's like a snake that bites and disappears, a schizophrenic that would kill comrades, put them in the hole and put flowers on top.'' Abu Bakr said he split with Abu Nidal in December because the leader was killing members of his own group and their families. He said reports that Abu Nidal is under arrest in Libya are false and that the terrorist could be anywhere because he has numerous false passports. ``It's easy for him to move around, his face is not known,'' he said. Abu Nidal is leader of the Fatah Revolutionary Council, a group that has been in turmoil since he ordered dozens of his followers killed during the last two years. Some terrorist experts say that some Abu Nidal operatives have joined the Syrian-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, led by Ahmed Jebril. FBI and intelligence officials believe the General Command carried out the December 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Scotland that killed 270 people.

DOC.HEAD: Contractor's Report of Stolen House was a Mistake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with police saying reported theft was mistaken. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A police househunt was called off after a contractor discovered that the cottage he had reported stolen had been moved to another lot through a misunderstanding. Gulfport Police Chief George Payne said Friday the contractors appeared to have settled their differences and he considered the matter closed. The misunderstanding began Thursday when Larry LaFontaine, acting on behalf of his hospitalized brother-in-law, Murray Ladner of Young's House Movers in Pass Christian, filed a complaint that a cottage Ladner had purchased had been stolen. Ladner said Thursday the cottage had been jacked up in preparation to be moved, but was stolen before his house-moving equipment could get there. ``Apparently, it was a case of missed contacts between Ladner and some other people,'' Payne said. ``The people who took the house said they had tried several times to contact him when it was removed.'' Calls to Ladner's hospital room went unanswered Friday. Payne declined to release the name of the other house mover.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Intervene in Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with preview opening to overflow crowd; Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Arts center ...' SUBS 14th graf to delete first reference to Helms.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS2
DOC.TEXT: A preview exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photographs opened Friday night, just hours after a judge's ruling gave prosecutors a free hand to act against the show. The photos, once denounced by U.S. Sen. Jesse Helms and the target of a large local protest, drew an overflow crowd for a preview open only to members of the Contemporary Arts Center. It was to open to the public Saturday. An hour after the show opened, a museum attendant estimated 1,000 people had already seen the photos and a block-long line formed outside. There was no protest at the preview began, though several hundred demonstrators showed up earlier Friday for a court hearing. More than 3,000 tickets were sold. At the hearing, Hamilton County Municipal Judge Edward Donnellon dismissed a lawsuit by the arts center seeking a ruling on whether the show was obscene. The suit was seen as an attempt to pre-empt any effort by local authorities to close the show. Donnellon dismissed the suit for lack of legal standing. After the ruling, prosecutors declined to say whether they would press obscenity charges. ``We can do a lot of things. I'm not going to tell you what we're going to do,'' Hamilton County Prosecutor Arthur Ney Jr. said. ``I can't discuss anything that I may, could, should or might do.'' Arts center lawyer Marc Mezibov said the exhibit will open to the public as scheduled. ``The show will go on,'' Mezibov said. ``I would assume as public officials if they intend to bring criminal charges they would have brought that to the attention of the court.'' However, another lawyer representing the arts center said he feared authorities will move against the exhibit. ``In this county you always live with a certain degree of fear,'' said the lawyer, H. Louis Sirkin. Hamilton County is a hub for anti-pornography activities. A citizens group has dubbed nine of Mapplethorpe's works obscene and demanded that they be banned from the 175-photograph exhibit. Last month, Sheriff Simon Leis Jr. declared that the photographs were criminally obscene. That was one reason the art center went to court, expecting charges. In June, the Mapplethorpe exhibit was canceled at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. The exhibit of the work by Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in March 1989, prompted Congress to limit funding to the arts after Helms, R-N.C., declared the photographs obscene. It has been shown in Philadelphia, Chicago, Hartford, Conn., Berkeley, Calif., and Boston. The exhibit includes photographs of homosexual and sadomasochistic sex acts. Several hundred supporters and opponents of the Mapplethorpe exhibit gathered in front of the courthouse Friday afternoon during the hearing. Police kept the two sides separate. Supporters carried banners that said, ``If you give artists freedom of expression, soon every American will want it.'' Opponents' signs said, ``We want decency in Cincinnati,'' and ``God is against pornography. So are we.'' The show is scheduled to run through May 26. Warning signs about the photos' content are posted at the center door, and no one under age 18 will be admitted. During the hearing, Assistant City Solicitor Karl Kadon accused the arts center of making the photographic exhibit a public issue. He said he also objected to the top law enforcement officials of the city and county being ``painted as Neanderthal barbarians of some sort.'' Assistant Prosecuting Attorney Robert Taylor, representing the county, also took umbrage at the art center's lawsuit. ``We're not going to let the CAC or anybody from New York come into Hamilton County and dictate to our elected officials what we will and will not do,'' Taylor said.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Released From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Singer Eddy Arnold was released Friday from St. Thomas Hospital, where he had double bypass heart surgery March 28. ``He's feeling great and his recovery is ahead of schedule,'' said Gerard Purcell, Arnold's personal manager. ``The doctors are very pleased with his speedy recovery and attribute it to his overall good health and his healthy lifestyle.'' Arnold, 71, is known for such songs as ``Make the World Go Away,'' ``Bouquet of Roses'' and ``Anytime.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders News Organizations to Turn Over Film of Tax Riot
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday ordered 25 newspapers and television stations to give police all film and photographs of last weekend's anti-tax riot in London. A dozen organizations immediately opposed the order, two said they were willing to hand over what they published and the remaining 11 neither opposed nor consented. Judge Neil Denison issued the order after a day of legal argument, ruling the film would help police and that it was in ``the overriding public interest.'' However, he said in other cases the public interest may be better served by allowing the news media to report events freely and each case should be decided on its merits. ``It is right, as has been argued, that the court should not automatically or routinely grant such orders,'' Denison said. ``It should not be seen to be rubber-stamping such applications.'' The new organizations reacted angrily. ``If we are seen to be a potential arm of the state, journalists are going to be targets of the rioters,'' said TV-am news director Jeff Berliner. Geoffrey Shaw, lawyer for the BBC and TV-am, argued there had been 2,750 police officers at the poll tax demonstration. ``They should not require the media to be their eyes and ears. If they want film, it is reasonable to expect them to take it themselves,'' Shaw said. Shaw said the news media would face increased dangers if all reporting material could eventually become available to police. The riot broke out last Saturday after 40,000 had gathered for a peaceful demonstration to protest the new poll tax by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government. Police were attacked, automobiles burned and overturned, shop windows smashed and shops looted. Police said 339 of the 3,000 people who took part in the six-hour street battles were arrested. Police also said 374 officers and 86 civilians were injured. Scotland Yard Detective Chief Superintendent Roy Ramm, who is in charge investigating the riot, testified that access to all published and unpublished film and photographs would help him get a clearer picture of the event. Ramm said the photographs taken by police and videotape taken from traffic cameras and a helicopter were insufficient. He said the investigation needed as much material as possible to identify people and to follow from pictures their activities during the demonstration. People pictured in a nonviolent photograph might be identified committing acts of violence or damage in another, Ramm said. The newspapers and television companies ordered to submit film include all the major British daily and Sunday newspapers and the major television companies. Editors have seven days to comply with the orders, expected to be signed by Denison on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Commends UNLV Basketball Champs
DOC.TEXT: Majority Leader George Mitchell played the sports diplomat Thursday when the Senate commended the University of Nevada Las Vegas for its 103-73 men's basketball championship victory over Duke. The resolution, which passed by a voice vote, would have been routine except that Sen. Terry Sanford, D-N.C., was presiding over the Senate at the time. Sanford was president of Duke from 1969 to 1985. Sanford had to listen to a description of the bill praising the Runnin' Rebels for their NCAA championship, then decree that the resolution was passed. ``If there is no objection, the preamble and the resolution are agreed too,'' he said. Mitchell then got up and said: ``Although there is no resolution to that effect, in view of the resolution just adopted and the presiding officer's former role as president of Duke University, I think we ought to also take a moment to commend the Blue Devils of Duke for a great season and a valiant effort in getting to the final four although they lost to the University of Nevada at Los Vegas. And I know my distinguished colleagues will join me in paying tribute to them.''

DOC.HEAD: Hijacking Suspect Uses Insanity Defense
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of trying to hijack an America West airliner to Cuba pleaded innocent Friday, and his attorneys said they would argue temporary insanity. Jose Manuel Gonzalez-Gonzalez, 39, of New Orleans, said he was under the influence of drugs and temporarily insane on Jan. 16 when he grabbed a flight attendant, announced he had a bomb and demanded that the Houston-to-Las Vegas flight go to Cuba instead. Gonzalez-Gonzalez was thwarted when the pilot landed the Boeing 737 at Austin's Robert Mueller Municipal Airport and a police officer climbed up an emergency chute and overpowered him. No bomb was discovered, but a device made of a toothpaste container and a ``flashlight-type article'' was found on the airliner, authorities said. He is charged with air piracy and assault. ``It's his position at this point that he will proceed that he was not sane at the time of the event and therefore that will be his defense,'' said Gonzalez-Gonzalez's attorney, Benny Ray. Prosecutor Kelly Loving said, ``I don't think it's appropriate for me to comment on the evidence itself until we go to trial. Anyone could deduce that if you're competent now it sheds some question on the person being insane at the time of the offense.'' If convicted of air piracy, he faces 20 years to life in prison. The assault charge carries a maximum 10-year sentence.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Space Shuttle
Networks Plan Shuttle Coverage
DOC.TEXT: ABC, CBS, NBC and the Cable News Network plan to air the scheduled launch of the shuttle Discovery live Tuesday morning. The space shuttle is scheduled to lift off at 8:47 a.m. from the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral, Fla. During the five-day voyage, five astronauts will put into orbit the Hubble Space Telescope, which will give scientists the most detailed look yet at the universe. CNN coverage will begin Tuesday at 5:30 a.m. The three broadcast newtorks will begin coverage during their morning news programs.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MEXICO CITY
200 Arrested to Break Up Opposition Protests in Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with report of up to 200 arrests, details; no pickup. CHANGES byline
DOC.TEXT: At least 200 opposition politicians were arrested at city halls across western Michoacan state to end sit-ins protesting purported election fraud by the governing party, officials said Friday. A government official called the opposition leaders, arrested Thursday and Friday at 17 city halls, ``a group of thugs.'' Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, founder and leader of the Revolutionary Democratic Party (PRD), said in a statement Friday that his party is ``in full rebellion.'' His party claimed soldiers and police arrested and beat at least 100 supporters in evictions Thursday at occupied town seats. Party leaders claim the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has been in power in Mexico for 61 years, cheated them out of victory in the Dec. 3 elections in both Michoacan and neighboring Guerrero state. Soldiers in riot gear patrolled the streets of Ciudad Hidalgo, 120 miles northwest of Mexico City, in army trucks Friday afternoon, while police reopened city hall and ushered the mayor inside. Eight PRD leaders were arrested in Ciudad Hidalgo during ``Operation Supreme Government,'' a Federal Judicial Police commander said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said similar arrests took place in all the towns where police removed protesters from city halls Thursday. Participating federal agents arrested five of the opposition leaders at the central square in Ciudad Hidalgo after one of them, Arnulfo Medina, told The Associated Press the party planned to retake the city halls. The arrest toll climbed to at least 200 on Friday, District Attorney Carlos Pratts told the Excelsior news service. State Attorney General Color Romero denied charges that violence occurred in the arrests. A federal government spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Cardenas' remarks prove his party ``is not a political party, but rather a group of thugs, with its only law being the law of the jungle and savagery.'' Police installed mayors Friday in all the cleared city halls, a police officer in Ciudad Hidalgo said. PRD spokesman Gustavo Tena said party members had organized a demonstration for Friday night in Morelia, the state capital. They were demanding authorities pull the army from Michoacan, end repression and free purported political prisoners. Cardenas said Friday that supporters in Guerrero will also redouble their efforts to organize ``when the time is right.'' His party has called for the impeachment of Guerrero Gov. Francisco Ruiz Massieu and a ``return to order'' in that state after at least seven people died in February and March police actions to still protests. Opposition activists stayed put at four city halls Friday, including Uruapan, where elections are scheduled to be repeated June 8, a state government spokesman said. He said protesters abandoned one city hall without police intervention.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Who Presided Over Vietnam Protest Trial Dies
DOC.TEXT: R. Dixon Herman, the federal judge who oversaw the Vietnam-era trial of seven people accused of plotting to kidnap Henry Kissinger, has died of a heart attack. He was 78. Herman, of the U.S. District Court in Pennsylvania, died Thursday at Harrisburg Hospital. He was admitted March 30 after suffering a heart attack, said his law clerk, Bill Kellett. Herman was appointed to the federal bench by President Richard Nixon in 1969, and became a senior judge on Sept. 25, 1981. He presided over the three-month trial in 1972 of the so-called ``Harrisburg Seven'' group of Vietnam War protesters, which included the Rev. Phillip Berringan, and several other priests and nuns. They were charged with conspiring to blow up underground steam tunnels in Washington and kidnap Henry Kissinger, then Nixon's national security advisor, in an attempt to bring about the end of the war. The seven also faced charges of interfering with the draft board, unlawfully mailing threats to Kissinger and smuggling letters into the federal prison at Lewisburg, Pa. A jury acquitted the seven of all charges except smuggling. Herman also ruled in a 1979 case that damage claims against Piper Aircraft Co. resulting from a plane crash in Scotland had to be tried there. His ruling was upheld in 1981 by the U.S. Supreme Court, which determined that people filing damage claims from accidents overseas are not automatically entitled to a trial in this country. That ruling played a role in determining that the multibillion-dollar damage suits against the chemical manufacturer Union Carbide should be heard in India, where a gas leak in 1984 killed 3,500 people in Bhopal, India. Herman was a graduate of Bucknell University and the Cornell Law School. He served in the Navy in the South Pacific during World War II. He served an assistant district attorney, a state representative and county solicitor before being appointed to the bench in Dauphin County in 1957.

DOC.HEAD: `Jake's Women,' New Neil Simon Comedy, Closing Out-of-Town
DOC.TEXT: ``Jake's Women,'' a new Neil Simon comedy starring Peter Coyote and Stockard Channing, will fold April 15 at San Diego's Old Globe Theater, and will not open in New York, a spokesman said Thursday. It is the first time a Simon play scheduled for Broadway production has closed out-of-town, said spokesman Bill Evans. ``The show may very well arrive to New York in another version, but this production won't,'' Evans said. The comedy, which Simon has called semi-autobiographical, concerns a writer who is still coming to terms with the death of his first wife while his second marriage falls apart. The California reviews for the play were negative. Variety's asked the question ``Is it funny?'' then answered, ``Not very. ... `Jake's Women' will require major surgery.'' The play's director, Ron Link, was fired before the San Diego opening and was replaced by Jack O'Brien, artistic director of the Old Globe. ``Jake's Women'' was to have opened at the Neil Simon Theater in New York on April 30. Simon, whose Broadway hits include ``Barefoot in the Park,'' ``The Odd Couple'' and ``Biloxi Blues,'' has had his share of flops on the Great White Way, including ``Fools,'' ``God's Favorite'' and the revival of ``Little Me.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed One Wounded in Attack at Suspected Crack House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Two unidentified ...,' to UPDATE with identities.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT3
DOC.TEXT: A storm of gunfire at a suspected crack house left five people dead and a sixth critically wounded in the city's worst multiple slaying in nearly 19 years, police said Thursday. ``It's a drug deal gone bad,'' said neighbor Alonzo Johnson. ``They are dealing drugs on every other house on every other street in this neighborhood. It's bad.'' No arrests had been made in the Wednesday night attack, said police Sgt. Christopher Buck, who declined to discuss a possible motive. Calls to the department's homicide, narcotics and special crimes units were not returned or drew no response. The attack was the worst multiple slaying in Detroit since June 1971, when seven members of a heroin ring were found shot to death, said Deputy Police Chief James Younger. Four of the dead, including two teen-agers, were found dead on the second floor of the bungalow. Each had been shot in the head, Buck said. Two of the victims were shot while trying to run downstairs and were found in the basement. Buck said Levon Robinson, 18, died shortly after arriving at Detroit Receiving Hospital, where Rodney Lewis, whose age was not available, was listd in critical condition. The dead found upstairs were Steven Owens, 32; Carl D. Williams, 20; Bobby Lee Frazier, 16; and Robert Lee Hill, 15, all of Detroit, said Buck. Police would not say if the attack was committed by gunmen high on crack or seeking revenge for a crack deal gone bad. But City Councilman Gilbert Hill, former head of the police department's homicide division, said he saw little difference. ``Most of the time it's not a turf battle, just thugs robbing each other,'' Hill said. ``Some of these guys walking around with Uzis and .44 magnums, they have the brain of an ant. I don't think it's part of any organized conspiracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Rebels Claim Government Air Raids
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian Air Force jets killed 46 and wounded 82 in raids on the Red Sea port of Massawa and the northern town of Afabet, Eritrean rebels said Thursday. In separate reports, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front said planes dropped cluster bombs on both towns in raids Tuesday and Wednesday. Israel has been accused of supplying cluster bombs to Ethiopia, a charge denied by both governments. Cluster bombs typically explode above ground level, hurling shards of metal over a wide area. They are particularly effective against massed troop formations. The report of the air raid could not be independently confirmed and the government made no mention of it. However, a handful of reporters allowed into Eritrea in recent weeks have confirmed past air raids on the port. The United Nations had hoped to use Massawa as the port of entry for some 1 million tons of emergency food needed to relieve an estimated 4 to 5 million famine victims in northern Ethiopia this year. In a radio broadcast monitored in Nairobi, the rebels said 30 people were killed and 58 injured in Wednesday's raid on Massawa. The broadcast said most of the victims were women and children. In a later report telexed to The Associated Press in Nairobi from their London office, the rebels said 16 were killed and 24 injured on Tuesday in Afabet, 60 miles northwest of Massawa. The rebels said the Afabet strike was carried out by two Soviet-built MiG fighters and was concentrated on the center of the town, near its main mosque. The rebels captured Massawa, one of only two Ethiopian ports on the Red Sea, on Feb. 11, three days after launching a massive new offensive in the country's northernmost province. The rebels have been fighting for autonomy for Ethiopia's northern province since 1962.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Claims 730 Rebels Killed in Counterattacks
DOC.TEXT: Chadian soldiers killed 730 rebels and took another 315 prisoner in counterattacks on guerrillas who struck two military garrisons last week, the Armed Forces High Command announced Thursday. The attacks ``completely destroyed'' rebel elements of the Libyan-backed Islamic Legion operating from Sudan, the High Command communique said. Government troops reportedly seized 67 vehicles equipped with machine guns. The High Command announced the attacks Wednesday night after retaking the outposts of Tine and Bahai. No casualty figures have been given for the government. The Islamic Legion infiltrates into Chad from Sudan's Darfur province, an area over which the Sudanese government has virtually no control. Radio Chad on Wednesday stressed Libya's role in backing the Islamic Legion, reportedly headed by Idress Deby, a former commander-in-chief of the government forces. Libya denies backing the Islamic Legion. The government of President Hissene Habre reported attacks on Bahai and Tine last week, the latest in sporadic Islamic Legion assaults since Chad and Libya announced a cease-fire. Libya, which once occupied most of northern Chad, was chased out three years ago in a series of defeats. Tripoli still claims as its own a strip of land on Chad's northern border, the Aouzou Strip. In a peace agreement signed last September, Libya and Chad reconfirmed their cease-fire, agreed to the exchange of prisoners of war and to submitting their territorial dispute to international arbitration.

DOC.HEAD: Finland Grants Visas to Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: The Finnish consulate in Leningrad has issued visas to about 100 Soviet Jews, the Foreign Ministry reported, opening a new transit route from the Soviet Union to Israel. The visas allow the emigrants to stay in Finland for up to five days. They may also apply for asylum in Finland, the ministry said. Jaakko Blomberg, chief of the Foreign Ministry's political department, said in a statement the decision was in line with the human right of free travel. But in apparent response to protests by the Palestine Liberation Organization, Blomberg said Finland asked Israel not to move the immigrants into the occupied territories. Israel says only a small fraction of newly arrived Soviet immigrants settle in the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip. Some Palestinians want the occupied lands to become a separate Palestinian state.

DOC.HEAD: With Gospel Awards
Gospel Music Dove Award Winners

DOC.TEXT: A far-reaching clean air bill goes to the House floor after clearing a committee by a 42-1 vote, moving Congress a step closer to enacting tougher air pollution controls. The Energy and Commerce Committee approved the complex and costly clean air package late Thursday after resolving the thorny issue of helping Midwest utilities cope with tougher acid rain controls. The acid rain compromise, approved 39-4, aims to help Midwest states pay for cleaning up pollution caused by utility plants by providing a ``pollution allowance'' system and a one-year extension for initial compliance in some cases. Critics of the measure have said it would cause electric rates to jump. Legislation passed by the Senate earlier this week includes a similar provision.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Following item EMBARGOED for release 10 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional auditors warned today that last year's savings and loan bailout plan will fall a staggering $68 billion short and called on the Bush administration to come up with a plan to raise the money. The General Accounting Office, in its highest-yet estimate, said it will cost the government $325 billion to close or sell failed thrift institutions. That's greater than the annual budget of the Defense Department. The new projection is up a sharp 26 percent from a $257 billion estimate the GAO offered only five months ago. And it is based on admittedly optimistic assumptions about interest rates, rescue costs and the number of S&L failures, Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who heads the GAO, told the Senate Banking Committee. In his prepared testimony, Bowsher called on Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman, who is administering the bailout, to ``develop proposals to provide the additional funds.''

President F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela have agreed to set a new date for talks on power sharing between the white-led government and the nation's disenfranchised black majority of 28 million. After a three-hour meeting Thursday, De Klerk and Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, said the time and place for talks to replace a canceled April 11 meeting would be announced later. De Klerk also said both sides agreed there had to be an end to black factional fighting that has left hundreds dead in recent months. Meanwhile Thursday, the military of the nominally independent homeland of Venda overthrew the government and said the area should be reincorporated into South Africa, radio reports said. There were no immediate reports of fighting or casualties.

The new Parliament has asked the man likely to lead East Germany into unification with West Germany to form a democratic government for the nation raised on Communism. Christian Democrat leader Lothar de Maiziere, whose party holds the most seats in Parliament, will attempt to resolve differences over reunification in the coming days, and build a broad coalition from the 11 parties represented. His success would speed merger of the German states, the principal issue in the country's first free elections on March 18. Unification was a prominent theme of Thursday's inaugural session of the 400-member Parliament, and the lawmakers formally dismantled the Communist system that ruled for four decades.

Labor's traditional allies in Congress are steering clear of the Greyhound strike because bus passengers don't carry political clout and lawmakers are skittish about taking sides in the violent dispute, legislators and others say. ``Members of Congress fly in airplanes _ they don't ride buses. These passengers tend to be poor folks who are not active politically,'' said Rep. Tom Downey, D-N.Y. Democrats who sometimes take the lead on labor issues also said President Bush's hands-off approach to such disputes _ he vetoed a union-backed plan to help settle the Eastern Airlines strike _ has inhibited lawmakers from jumping into the fray. Congress historically has sat on the sidelines for months before injecting itself in labor-management disputes, and neither Greyhound nor striking drivers who walked out five weeks ago has asked Congress to intervene.

The Pennsylvania governor's race is tipping conventional political wisdom on its ear when it comes to the issue of abortion. Democratic Gov. Robert P. Casey is an unyielding foe of abortion, contrary to his national party platform. Casey's chief Republican challenger, state Auditor General Barbara Hafer, is firmly pro-choice, a position that puts her at odds with the GOP national platform. While leaders of both parties say they can accommodate people on both sides of the issue, a Casey-Hafer contest could test the loyalties of many rank-and-file members in both parties. Casey's and Hafer's views on abortion also have attracted two more candidates to the gubernatorial race, an anti-abortion Republican and a pro-choice Democrat campaigning almost exclusively on the abortion issue.

DOC.BYLINE: ABC's ``Capital News'' Has Good Cast, Hot News, Cliches ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper life has fallen on hard times. No smoking in the city room. Computers instead of typewriters. Phones that chirp. Reporters who go straight home after work. Columnists who regularly appear on ... TV. ABC's ``Capital News,'' about the inmates of the mythical, powerful Washington Capital of Washington, D.C., faithfully reproduces all these modern ills. It has a first-rate cast. There even are some funny lines. Alas, its script also has more familiar feats of Fourth Estate than you can shake an editor at. Why, the troops even expose a rotten slumlord in only a few hours. And some of the cityroom dialogue has to be heard to be disbelieved. It includes: ``I want to document what crack's doing to that neighborhood.'' And: ``I'm way behind on a front-page story.'' And: ``This paper does not conduct vendettas.'' Even reporters will long remember the angry warning of the paper's handsome young metropolitan editor to a management colleague, an oily national editor who is trying to steal one of the metro section's best scribes: ``Let's get something straight, Edison. Metro's not your farm club. My people go into the real world, and it stinks sometimes.'' In short, ``News,'' bowing tonight with a bloated two-hour edition, may make one think its authors saw a ``Lou Grant'' rerun, then leaped up and said, ``Hey, kids, let's put on a newspaper!'' Funny thing, though. There are bits and pieces of good in this show. It actually has promise, even though the first round basically seems a series of variations on cliches. It has two major things going for it: _ A excellent cast, the best-known of them Lloyd Bridges, who plays the paper's avuncular, tough-when-he-needs-to-be veteran editor. The actors often make the spoken cliches tolerable. Major credit is due Michael Woods, who as the handsome young metro editor has to deliver most of them. _ Characters that stick in your mind, like the smarmy, snippy, syndicated gossip columnist with his own TV show (Kurt Fuller, who is very funny); Mark Blum's nasty national editor, and the streetwise fire and police reporter (Jenny Wright). Wright, who seems to get the best one-liners, has a well-honed sense of timing. She's fun to watch, even in a quick bit when she asks a tight-mouthed fire department official about a nursing home fire: ``I just need a hint of the approximate cause of the fire. Was it a meteor from outer space or was one it of the older men smoking in bed?'' One nice aspect of the show is that its make-believe scribes aren't terminally earnest, as often is the case in newspaper shows. On the glum side, the dramatic Old Reliables of TV newspaperdom are lurking here. There's the eager, lovely young newcomer (Helen Slater) who, teaming up on an unusual bank robbery story with a rumpled hotshot (William Russ), proves incredibly good. On her first day, she gets a front-page byline. There's the elegant, fast-fading old foreign correspondent _ beautifully played by Lee Richardson _ resting on his reputation and hip flask. Bridges wants him to retire. Unbeknownst to him, the old-timer takes one last shot on a local story about a drug-ridden housing project. And there's the old problem of a reporter's sex life, specifically that of its basic beautiful ace investigative reporter (Kathryn Harrold). She has written an explosive expose about a defective missile system. But with deadline approaching, she's under pressure to print the name of her source (you only need one in TV) for the story. This is because word gets out she's been sleeping with a handsome Senate aide, and he is suspected of being her source. He's not the source, she tells editor Bridges: ``The agreement was we don't talk about our work if there might be a conflict.'' The editor's snappy comeback: ``What'd that leave you, the weather?'' Later, shifting to a fatherly role as a man of Washington wisdom, he urges her, if she really loves the guy, to go public with it: ``In this town, nobody minds you having a private life as long as they know all about it.'' That intelligence comes near the finale as the show shifts to post-deadline glimpses of the scribes' private lives, including the fact that three of the staff share an old house in Washington and invite the rookie to join them. The post-deadline puttering around seems tacked on, and only gives the impression that false endings are now in vogue. All this doesn't make for the best possible premiere for a TV newspaper series, even when the creator is David Milch, who had a hand in a pretty good cop show called ``Hill Street Blues.'' But, as we say, the acting is fine and many of the characters well-sketched. If the writers of future ``Capital News'' episodes have paid more attention to journalistic detail and less to cliche, the series may have a chance. If not, everyone should write ABC and demand that it revive ``Kolchak: The Night Stalker.'' Now that was a nifty newshawk series, even if it was set in only a wire service.

Elsewhere in television ... SURFER GIRL, THE SEQUEL: ABC on April 29 will air ``The Story of The Beach Boys: Summer Dreams,'' a dramatization of the unhappy side of the guys who sang of little deuce coupes and things. It's based on Steven Gaines' ``Heroes and Villains, the True Story of The Beach Boys,'' a book described by ABC as an ``unauthorized biography.'' ABC says its film will note that ``dialogue and scenes interpretive of this material have been created for dramatic purposes'' and that _ uh oh, surf's down _ ``the music in the film is not performed by The Beach Boys.''

DOC.HEAD: The Strike, Once Labor's Big Weapon, is Now More of a Gamble
DOC.TEXT: Union leaders who've watched the strike lose part of its firepower as a bargaining weapon in recent years are turning to new strategies for winning better wages and benefits. ``The notion that the first thing you do is go stage a strike, that cry, that slogan, is dead in the labor movement,'' says Bob Harman of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. ``The strike used to be almost automatic, just part of the industrial landscape,'' says John Duray of the United Mine Workers. ``Now you have unions picking their targets much more carefully, exhausting all their options first.'' The strike has become more of a gamble over the past decade as the hiring of permanent replacement workers _ a practice once considered taboo _ becomes more widespread. In the ongoing Eastern Air Lines strike, for instance, the company has replaced most of the machinists who walked out more than a year ago. Flight attendants and pilots who conducted temporary sympathy strikes also have permanently lost their jobs. Greyhound drivers now face the same prospect in their month-long strike because the company has pledged to give permanent jobs to the drivers who join up as replacements. Many labor leaders blame the trend toward replacement hiring on former President Reagan, who fired striking air traffic controllers in 1981. The practice has forced unions to look increasingly at ``inside strategies,'' or tactics that workers can use on the job to exert economic pressure on employers to win a new contract, yet also avoid a strike. Tactics include ``work-to-rule,'' where employees strictly follow work manuals rather than taking their normal shortcuts that speed up productivity; ``rolling'' strikes where workers hold spot, one-day no-shows; boycotts of a company's products; newspaper and billboard advertisements to win the public's support; and personal approaches to a company's board of directors and shareholders. ``All these things can have a tremendous impact on mobilizing workers and help increase a union's presence on the shop floor,'' says Jim Green, a labor historian at the University of Massachusetts. Energizing workers keeps them from crossing picket lines once a strike starts and can dissaude people from taking replacement jobs, Green says. That's what unions did in two of the most recent strike success stories, pulled off by Appalachian coal miners and NYNEX telephone workers in the Northeast. ``That shows you what it takes to win a strike under current circumstances. But to say that this is going to be the norm is probably expecting too much of the unions,'' Green says. Many unions are also devoting more energy to negotiations before a contract expires in an effort to head off a strike. St. Paul, Minn., county workers, for instance, called in a mediator to help them bargain and as a result were on strike only six days, Harman says. The Communications Workers of America is drafting a manual that will list 40 tactics organized labor can use to build worker and community support and avoid a strike. In the 1970s, nearly 300 strikes involving 1,000 or more workers occurred each year. That average dropped to about 50 per year over the past five years, federal figures show. Companies have had the legal right to hire replacement workers for decades, but it was rarely used, largely because employers feared a public backlash. Reagan's firing of air traffic controllers ``put starch in the spine of employers,'' says AFL-CIO spokesman Rex Hardesty. TWA, Boise Cascade, International Paper, Colt Firearms and the Chicago Tribune lined up replacement workers before a strike occurred, Hardesty says. ``I think it represents the atmosphere that Reagan set. ... Employers are saying, `Well, the name of the game is greed and we've got the green light.' It's get as much as you can, get it as fast you can, and no matter if it hurts a lot of people,'' says AFSCME President Gerald McEntee. Duray says the new age of replacement hiring is ``disturbing from the point of view of what it says about a company's concern for long-term productivity and its commitment to its workers.'' Legislation is pending in Congress to ban companies from hiring permanent replacement workers in labor disputes. Union officials acknowledge that employers feel more comfortable hiring replacement workers because organized labor lost clout in the 1980s with a decline in membership. ``We've probably been victims of our own success. Our workers may have reached the point where they were making pretty good wages, had two cars in the garage, and they lost that knot in the belly, a desire to stick together,'' McEntee says. Green says Americans also have shifted their thinking on the ethics of being a strikebreaker. ``It used to be that the worst thing somebody could possibly call you, in blue-collar neighborhoods, was a scab. Now a lot of people think it's alright to take someone else's job.''

DOC.HEAD: The Mystery of Corporate Dividends
DOC.TEXT: There is a recession in corporate profits, but you would hardly know it from the rate at which companies are paying dividends. Compared with other periods, it's sky high. Good reasons for the situation are hard to find, but no harder than several other mysteries about the profits recession. Many stock prices seem to have ignored the evidence, for instance, and a lot of forecasters too. A good many of the published economic forecasts tend to make little of the decline, choosing to stress instead what they see as an improving situation as the year goes on. A plausible explanation is offered by economist Edward Yardeni when he suggests that if profits fall but the economy continues to grow ``then company managers presumably have a good chance of reviving profits.'' In contrast, says Yardeni, who does his analyses for Prudential-Bache Securities, ``if the economy is in a recession, the situation is out of their control.'' But what about now? The decline in profits already is greater than that which occurred in the deep recessions of a decade ago, and officially, at least, there isn't even a recession under way now. Throughout the decline, which has lasted four straight quarters, or since the end of 1988, very few companies have tampered with their dividend payout and some of have raised it. As a result, dividends as a percentage of after-tax profits _ following a 16 percent profits decline last year _ are about 80 percent, whereas a more normal figure would be around 50 percent. The current percentage, says economist H. Erich Heinemann, is near a record high in the postwar period, surpassed only by the second quarter of 1986, when the economy skirted the edge of recession. In times gone by, the ratio of dividends to after-tax profits usually peaked at the end of a recession, then fell as profits improved. But, if you can believe Uncle Sam, there is no general recession now, and none since 1982. But there is that profits recession, and there is no denying that a logical tie exists between profits and dividends. Simply stated, if you don't make the profits you can't pay the dividends. However, based on experience of the past year, that logic seems suspended. During the 1989 final quarter pretax operating profits were running at an annual rate of $285.7 billion, compared with a rate of $340.2 billion one year before. ``Could it be that big, bad, ugly bear markets in stocks only happen if the economy and corporate profits are in a recession?'' asks Yardeni, who believes the economy will continue to grow all year long. In that outlook, he has plenty of company among his fellow forecasters, many of whom see a bigger and better economic picture, including corporate profits, as the year wears on. It seems, therefore, that faith in higher future profits is having more of an impact on dividends than the current low-profit profits. What if profits don't rise? Well, it seems that logic eventually must prevail _ that if the money isn't coming in, it can't be paid out as dividends. Should the profits fail to recover, can dividends not fall?
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday April 9

DOC.HEAD: Health vs. Wealth: Will Clean Air Create a Crisis in Coal Country?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Commonwealth Edison ...,' to UPDATE with House version of bill approved in committee; PICKS UP 11th graf, `Edison can ...'
With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: When Gary Hart descends deep into the darkness of the coal-rich soil each day, he fears the future. As a miner, he could lose his job. As mayor, he could lose his town. The double threat comes from hundreds of miles away, where Congress is rewriting the nation's clean air laws, setting new pollution standards that could crush this tiny town that lives and thrives on coal. To combat acid rain, the local mine's neighbor and only customer _ one of the nation's dirtiest coal-fired power plants _ will likely have to reduce the sulfur dioxide spewing from its stacks. How it does that has put Kincaid on edge, hoping for a reprieve, but leery of a death sentence. ``If they shut down completely, I'm not going to have a community to lead,'' Hart said. ``It'll sit there and die. People will have to move to get jobs. It's just a sad thing. People want to work, they want their jobs, but how do they keep them?'' Across the Midwest and northern Appalachia, high-sulfur coal country, Kincaid and other mining towns are in a quandary, wondering whether new clean air laws will pit health against wealth, reducing prosperity with pollution. ``There is a need for clean air,'' Hart said. ``But completely wiping out an industry is not the solution to the problem. It just creates a bigger problem.'' In Ohio, one congressman recently said acid rain controls could cost the state up to $2 billion a year and raise some commercial electric rates as much as 40 percent. In Kentucky, officials say half the coal mining jobs in the western part of the state could be lost. And in Illinois, which already lost 30 percent of its coal mining jobs in the 1980s, a worst-case scenario estimates up to 4,500 more could vanish. The government says up to 5,000 high-sulfur coal jobs likely will be lost nationally by 1995. But the United Mine Workers predicts that will grow to about 20,000 by the end of the decade, inflicting more pain on an industry that has shrunk by 44 percent in the last decade and crushed Main Streets dependent on miners' dollars. Commonwealth Edison, the utility that owns the plant, won't decide how it will reduce sulfur fumes in Kincaid until the clean air measure becomes law. On Tuesday, the Senate passed its bill, which Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., one of 11 opponents, said would ``decimate'' his state. A House version was approved Thursday in committee. Edison can install ``scrubbers,'' which would cost about $350 million and cut emissions by about 90 percent, or take two other devastating steps: switch to cleaner, low-sulfur coal from the West or shut down, which would almost certainly trigger the mine closing. ``We're doing everything possible to try avoid closing the plant,'' said John Maxson, Edison's governmental affairs director. The stakes are enormous. The plant and Peabody Coal Co.'s mine No. 10, across-the-road neighbors, have nearly 900 workers and an annual payroll of about $25 million, Maxson said. Meanwhile, in this town of 1,500 where mining is a tradition, with sons and fathers working side-by-side, the uncertainty has folks fretting. ``You're hanging by a thread,'' said miner Butch Spinner. ``Are you going to fall on the good side of the lake or on the side with the alligators?'' ``We're pawns in a big political game,'' said Ron Phares, 33, a husky 12-year mine veteran. ``You feel powerless, pushed aside, neglected. ... I'd hate to be 55, 56, 57 looking this in the eye. Where are you going to go?'' Miners also say that while they're all for reducing pollution, having fought for cleaner air underground, this isn't a simple case of good vs. evil. ``I hope environmentalists have some sympathy with me,'' said Tim Drea, a second-generation miner. ``Many of my co-workers' fathers were miners, they went to high school, got a job, married their prom dates. Now their kids are 10, 11, 12. All they know is coal mining. ``If the mines close because of emotional legislation, these people are left with nothing. I can't agree with that any more than I can agree with dirty air.'' In fact, many environmentalists support subsidies to cut cleanup costs and protect jobs, but others say utilities and miners adopted a head-in-the-sand policy too long. ``They played this denial game for 10 years,'' said Clark Bullard, an environmentalist and University of Illinois mechanical engineering professor. ``They denied acid rain was a serious problem. ... Now they're looking for sympathy and bailouts.'' Bullard said there was little support several years ago for a proposed national utility surcharge to help pay for scrubbers. ``The time for getting a good deal has passed,'' he said. ``The deal we're going to get is going to hurt the Midwest.'' Too much so, say miners and utilities, who argue that experts don't have conclusive proof heavy damage is caused by acid rain, created when sulfur and nitrogen oxides mix with water in the atmosphere. It is blamed for damaging forests and killing fish in the Northeast and Canada. The Senate bill calls for a 10 million ton reduction in annual emissions of sulfur dioxide by the year 2000. Miners say if that takes jobs away, the government should help. ``If (President) Bush can bail out the savings and loans, he can help the coal miners,'' said Paul Wagahoft, a Kincaid miner. Last week, however, Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W Va., lost his bid to amend the clean air bill to provide $500 million in aid to miners who would lose their jobs. ``Coal miners can't walk across the street and find another job,'' said Gerald Hawkins, legislative director of Illinois District 12 of the UMW. ``There is none.'' It's a bitter reality in Kincaid and neighboring central Illinois towns. ``What are they going to retrain you for around here?'' Phares asked. ``This is a farming area. There's not much industry to go into. ... I'd have to relocate. You're not going to make $15 an hour and have good insurance.'' ``You're not going to step out tomorrow and find a $30,000-a-year job,'' Wagahoft said. ``You're going to have to start over.'' Hart also worries about the impact on Kincaid, which he says supplies about 25 percent of the work force at the mine and plant. ``You take 100 miners in the community _ they get paid $1,000 every two weeks,'' he said. ``That would be lost.'' Some miners are bracing for the worst, taking accounting classes, attending truck driving school, putting off home repairs and purchases. Whatever happens, they'll adjust. ``It's something I feel I can't change,'' Phares said. ``I can't tell George Bush I've got three kids, I've got a house payment, I've got a truck payment. ... Whatever comes, I've just got to accept it. I've just got to live with the consequences.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Cohen is the AP's Midwest regional reporter, based in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Index Warrants Booming
DOC.TEXT: The action may be dull and dispirited most places on Wall Street right now, but there is a hot new game in progress at the American Stock Exchange. The excitement centers on a new breed of security, scarcely three months old, that provides investors with a way to play the ups and downs of foreign markets, most notably the one in Tokyo. These vehicles take the form of warrants, which give their holders the right to buy or sell another security or group of securities at a stated price within a specified period of time. Through their long history in this country warrants have been best known as an adjunct to individual common stocks, with issuers ranging from legions of small companies to such blue-chip names as American Telephone & Telegraph. Starting in January of this year, the idea was adapted to embrace a stock index in a foreign market _ specifically, Japan's Nikkei Stock Average _ as the underlying ``security.'' By the end of March, Amex trading had begun in four different ``put warrants'' on the Nikkei index. These warrants, which constitute rights to sell a cash equivalent of a basket of Japanese stocks at a set price, naturally tend to increase in value whenever the going prices of those stocks fall. They have been hailed by some observers as a valuable tool for managing and hedging risks that come with the increasingly international approach many investors have taken in recent years. Some skeptics, by contrast, call them a gimmick. Whether for good or ill, they appeared on the scene at an opportune time, as the lofty Japanese market ran into a turbulent period of selling that drove the Nikkei index down more than 25 percent. Before long, the Nikkei warrants, and a couple of similar ones based on the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index in Britain, seized a prominent place on the daily lists of the most active Amex issues. Last week the Wall Street firm of Salomon Brothers stirred the pot anew with the first of an expected series of ``call warrants'' on the Nikkei, for buyers seeking a way to profit from RISING stock prices in Japan. Thanks to that, and to rumors of further volatile times ahead in Tokyo, nearly 9 million of the various foreign-index warrants were traded on the Amex last Wednesday _ accounting for 43 percent of the exchange's overall stock volume for the day. So far this year, the warrants have been responsible for nearly 15 percent of what the Amex counts as ``equity volume.'' The speculative allure of this product isn't hard to see. The first of the Nikkei put warrants, for instance, tripled in price as the Japanese market tumbled. Among the many risks that also come with these investments, some are more obvious than others. For any speculators venturing into this game, it is plain that wrong guesses are very likely to mean large losses. In addition, it takes market savvy to gauge when a warrant is trading at an advantageous price in relation to its underlying index. On top of that, commissions and other trading costs may stack the odds heavily against the small investor. Drawbacks like those haven't stopped the foreign index warrants from attracting a substantial following to date. Whether they will keep growing as rapidly in the future depends partly on what happens in the Japanese and other overseas stock markets. Should they continue to flourish, all sorts of possibilities arise. For instance, could an index warrant, or something closely resembling it, some day provide the springboard to large-scale ``index arbitrage'' and other computer-program trading on an international scale? If such activity ever came to stir up problems and controversy, who or what would regulate it?

DOC.HEAD: Cyrano Is Season's Brightest Star
DOC.TEXT: Without a doubt, Cyrano de Bergerac is France's most famous fictional character, with his long nose and gift of poetic gab. Painfully shy and downright ugly, Cyrano was a master swordsman with verve and panache who breathed his poetry and passion into the tongue-tied head of a handsome soldier to win the lovely Roxanne. He's so popular this season that he's currently being portrayed on the stage and in movie houses by France's top two leading actors. Nearly 100 years after he was created for theater, Cyrano is once again tugging at the heart. Jean-Paul Belmondo is dazzling audiences at the sold-out Marigny Theater, while Gerard Depardieu is inducing tears _ and laughs _ in France's most expensive cinematic production ever. ``Cyrano de Bergerac,'' produced at a cost of $17 million, opened March 28 to critical praise. The classic tale of unrequited love got a modern face lift in 1987 in the movie ``Roxanne,'' starring Steve Martin and Darryl Hannah. Martin played a long-nosed fire chief in a contemporary American small town. The newest versions are faithful to Edmond Rostand's play set in 17th-century France against a background of war between kings, a war fought by such swashbuckling Gascons as D'Artagnan of the Three Musketeers. Both Depardieu and Belmondo have received rave reviews from critics in their portrayals of Cyrano, considered one of the most difficult roles ever written. For Depardieu, 41, France's biggest box-office attraction with 60 films under his belt, ``Cyrano'' is his most brilliant performance ever. He gives an eloquent delivery and sublime dramatic portrayal of Cyrano. He is comic and poignant at the same time, and with magnificent period costumes and sets, the film is 215 minutes of sheer poetry and pleasure. Belmondo portrays Cyrano in an athletic, swashbuckling way. There tends to be a bit more shouting by Belmondo in the play. Depardieu, on the other hand, literally whispers into the camera. The movie, which will open in the United States in December, was filmed on location in Hungary with 2,000 actors and extras in period costumes, 40 studio sets and 1,000 pikes and muskets. An entire forest was cleared to film the siege of Arras, a town in northern France where the French succeeded in ousting the Spaniards in the mid-1600s. Studio Magazine, France's leading film monthly, devoted 20 pages to the film and described Depardieu as ``an actor in a state of grace.'' ``Everything in Cyrano's character fits him like a glove,'' Marc Esposito wrote. ``The power, the sensitivity, the arrogance, the complexes, the fragility we sense under his imposing physique, belongs as much to Cyrano as to Depardieu.'' Jacques Weber, who triumphed in his portrayal of De Guiche, the haughty count also enamored of Roxanne, called Depardieu ``a bomb fallen from the moon.'' Written by Rostand in 1897, ``Cyrano'' is as French as the national anthem. Children study it in school and audiences know the ``nose'' and ``no thank you'' tirades by heart. Yet, it has defied filmmakers until now because of its alexandrines _ iambic lines with six feet that rhyme. Rappeneau and veteran screenwriter Jean-Claude Carriere streamlined the original text, but critics say they sacrificed neither the poetry nor its romantic soul. ``Cyrano'' has also endured because its story is timeless. Who has never felt despair looking in the mirror or pain upon discovering that the one you love loves another? ``A little Cyrano sleeps in the heart of all of us,'' Depardieu says. For Belmondo, 56, best-known for his tough-guy roles in fast-paced thrillers, Cyrano marks a long-awaited return to his roots as a dramatic actor and only his second stage appearance in 25 years. Director Robert Hossein said playing Cyrano had long been a secret goal of Belmondo because the actor's father, Paul, used to say the role was the ultimate test for an actor. ``When will you go back to your real profession? I will die without seeing you as Cyrano,'' Belmondo senior would say as his son posted one box-office smash after another, Hossein recalled. Paul Belmondo died several years ago. ``Belmondo is paying off a personal debt (to his father),'' wrote Jean-Pierre Thibaudat in Liberation. ``If the movies hadn't been invented, he would have been the Coquelin of our times. And Coquelin invented Cyrano.''

For Release Sunday, April 8, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Bicycling and Recycling, City Seeks to Protect Environment
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Another in a series marking the 20th anniversary of Earth Day.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos FX1-5 of April 5
DOC.TEXT: On a tree-shaded street of $500,000 homes, burlap sacks bulging with empty cans and neatly tied stacks of newspapers lie waiting for the weekly recycling truck in front of environmentally landscaped yards. Recycling has been going strong here for almost 20 years, but xeriscaping _ using drought-tolerant plants so yards need less watering _ is all the rage these dry days. In Palo Alto, birthplace of the Silicon Valley's computer industry and home of Earth Day headquarters, the fascination with high tech is matched by a commitment to high quality of life and devotion to the environment. Businessmen and women pedal to work on a 30-mile network of bike lanes, cruising past houses topped by solar energy panels. Snowy egrets and great blue herons soar above marshes, and ducks splash in a pond in the city's cherished baylands. Hundreds of deer graze the hillside meadows of the city's 1,500-acre private Foothills Park. Mountain lions, bobcats and 11 species of snakes roam freely in the hills, and 150 kinds of birds delight hikers and picnickers. Frank Zinn takes a break every day around noon to feed bread to ground squirrels in the baylands. The normally skittish creatures, who live in 8-foot deep burrows, let Zinn pet them. ``They're kind of like my family,'' Zinn said. ``I was a still photographer in Hollywood and when I came back to this area I was worried that this whole place would be condominiums. I sure am glad they preserved all this.'' While 75 percent of the wetlands around San Francisco Bay have been filled in over the years, Palo Altans have worked to preserve their edge of the bay since the 1920s and have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to maintain its natural beauty. ``Wetlands are one of the most productive land forms in terms of wildlife,'' said Emily Renzel, a City Council member who has led protection efforts. ``Many animal species depend on them. To the extent that we are crowding out major segments of the animal population, we're just setting ourselves up for disaster someday. ``Slowly but surely we're creating a world in which we may be the only ones existing, and it may not be a very pretty world. I don't think we want to be in a world without birds singing.'' Palo Alto is not without problems, of course. High-tech companies sometimes leak toxic chemicals, and older buildings waste too much energy. But it is a small city with a big reputation, a pioneer in recycling since 1971, a center for solar energy research and a model of environmental responsibility for cities of any size. It has won national awards for its bicycling and recycling programs, waste water treatment and hazardous waste disposal. Halfway between the gray fog of San Francisco and the brown smog of San Jose, Palo Alto is seen in aerial photographs as a patch of green. A thick canopy of trees enriches the air with oxygen. The redwood El Palo Alto _ ``the tall tree'' used as a landmark by Spanish explorers in 1769 _ still stands nobly, though thin on top and slightly stooped. The city of 56,000 that grew up around that tree and bucolic Stanford University has developed a passion for trees, especially after watching apricot and cherry orchards give way to aerospace, communications and electronic companies in the 1940s and '50s. According to the city's computerized tree inventory, 32,089 city-owned trees _ the most popular are magnolias with big white blossoms _ line the streets. Perhaps 10 to 15 times as many are privately owned, including birches, eucalyptuses and orange, lemon, plum, pear and almond trees that flourish in the Mediterranean climate of mild, moist winters and warm, dry summers. In the Magic Forest, a small stand of redwoods in one of the city's more than 50 parks, the air is as cool and refreshing as in the wilds of Yosemite. For many Palo Altans, though, their view of the environment extends beyond the beauty of the land and the quality of the air and water, said Denis Hayes, Earth Day founder and a resident of Palo Alto, off and on, for more than 20 years. ``When a bunch of us were involved in trying to build a new environmental movement in the late '60s and early '70s,'' he said, ``the search was really for an all-encompassing set of values, a new ideology relevant to the 20th century.'' A top priority, he said, was a desire to stop deterioration of the planet and encourage peace, justice and education. In that broad context, he said, ``Palo Alto is in many ways an idyllic kind of community. It aspires to become a new Athens. It really does promote that vision in the sense of having large democratic involvements in (national and international) statecraft and doing what it can to encourage art and athletics.'' No environmental danger escapes notice and no waste is tolerated in this city, where more than 70 percent of residents and 24 of the 30 leading generators of commercial waste participate regularly in recycling. Newspapers, glass, aluminum cans, plastic bottles, corrugated cardboard, used motor oil, scrap metal, high-grade paper, mattresses, yard debris and used car batteries are collected either curbside or at drop-off centers. This month, the City Council is expected to pass the nation's first toxic gas ordinance _ drafted by the Santa Clara County fire departments with help from Silicon Valley computer chip companies, environmentalists and lawmakers. It is designed to control releases of poisonous gases and add enough safeguards to prevent a ``Bhopal, India, type of disaster,'' said Fire Marshal Phil Constantino. The model ordinance, under study by dozens of other cities, is a follow-up to a hazardous materials storage law, also the first in the nation, adopted by Palo Alto and neighboring cities in 1982. Last year, the council prohibited all places that serve food from using containers made with ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs. Downtown coffee shops offer coffee at 20 cents off for patrons who bring their own mugs instead of using styrofoam cups. Another ordinance, banning all non-recyclable, disposable polystyrene and rigid plastic food service items, is to go into effect July 1. By the same date, auto service shops will be required to have equipment to capture the CFC-laden Freon that escapes during air conditioning repairs. On January 1, retail stores were required to offer a choice of paper or plastic bags. Houses are expensive in Palo Alto _ three-bedroom homes range from $300,000 to $1 million _ but gas and electricity rates are generally at least 30 percent lower than the rest of the Bay area, thanks to a city-owned utilities system. Palo Alto Utilities, the only municipal agency in the state that provides gas, electricity and water, offers customers free analyses of energy and water use, as well as low-interest loans to install solar systems.
