DOC.TEXT: According to the 1980 Census, 14 percent of Palo Altans working there rode bicycles to their jobs. The current Census is expected to show a big increase. ``The more bicyclists you have, the fewer cars you have,'' said Ellen Fletcher, a former council member and longtime bicycling advocate. ``That reduces the pollutants in the air, the traffic and the need for more parking lots.'' Fletcher helped push through laws requiring companies with more than 50 employees to provide showers and bicycle parking spaces. She is now urging the city to create a network of bicycle boulevards to make it easier to ride around town. ``It's still a tough competition with the automobile,'' she said. ``The ultimate goal should be to make it as convenient to bicycle as it is to drive, and we haven't quite gotten to that stage.'' One progressive Palo Alto drug research company, Alza Corp., pays employees up to $60 a month for using public transportation or $1 a day if they bike, jog, walk, or ride in carpools to work. ``Our primary concern as a company is an environmental one,'' said Alza executive Peter Carpenter. ``Paying people not to drive and providing them with bike lockers and showers is also cheaper than building more parking spaces for cars. ``Instead of subsidizing cars, we're subsidizing alternatives. It's the free market approach. We're giving people an incentive to leave their cars home.'' Yet Carpenter admits, somewhat sheepishly, ``I still drive 90 percent of the time myself, which is horrible. ... That's the acid test, when you can get people like me to stop talking about getting out of their cars and start doing it.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Baron's Hometown: Utopia by Day, Slaughterhouse by Night
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS to ``grew up here'' in 1st graf
DOC.TEXT: Pablo Escobar, leader of the Medellin drug cartel, grew up here. Residents say his money turned Envigado into a utopia by day, but made the city police a squad of butchers by night. A former police official put it this way to a local newspaper: ``If Envigado is Colombia's first city in quality of life, it is also the first in the quality of death.'' On March 28, President Virgilio Barco's government ordered the civilian police force disbanded. The army has detained 19 of the 27 former city officers. Ten are charged with torturing and murdering people for the Medellin cartel. One of those under arrest is Marlon Perez, who is accused of organizing death squads for the drug gang. Envigado, population 80,000, is is northwestern Colombia, four miles south of Medellin, the city from which the largest cocaine gang takes its name. Escobar's hometown is under martial law and the army colonel in charge is empowered to arrest any official who tries to impede investigations of the local police force, known as the Department of Security and Control. After the army took over, people started making their way to brigade headquarters to report the killings of family members. Lately, police had begun killing wealthy townspeople who somehow angered the drug traffickers, residents said. In the beginning, the Department of Security and Control had concentrated on ``cleaning'' Envigado's streets of beggars, thieves and people who smoked basuko, a cocaine base. ``They focused on murdering and torturing street people,'' Miguel Moreno, unemployed, told The Associated Press two days after the police force was disbanded. ``They took me into the headquarters and beat me up many times just because my clothes were dirty.'' During the interview, Moreno waved cars into parking spaces next to Envigado's main plaza and tried to hustle the drivers for change. Army motorcycle patrols rumbled past the white church that towers over the plaza. ``I would rather have a million soldiers in this town than those damn security agents,'' said Leo Gomez, also unemployed. Sergio Jesus Jimenez, 23, sat in his wheelchair at a sidewalk cafe and told how the police shot him in the back eight months earlier, crippling him for life. Jimenez said he and some friends were watching a soccer game on a store-window television when a police patrol, four men and a woman, came around the corner. ``When we saw them, we began to run,'' he said. ``That's when they shot me. They put me in the hospital for six days, and then threw me in jail even though I couldn't walk.'' He said police released him when they found he had no record. Jimenez, an orphan who lives with his four brothers in the poor Sebastiana neighborhood, admitted to smoking basuko ``from time to time.'' The same traffickers who export tons of cocaine to the United States and other countries ``don't want to see a poor person even thinking about smoking basuko on the street'' in Envigado, he said. Envigado appears to have fewer homeless people than other Colombian towns. Although residents call it the nation's Monaco, however, the business district remains a typical crowded jumble of shops and restaurants. Most of the money Escobar put into his birthplace seems to have financed condominium construction in wealthy neighborhoods. ``It is said the drug traffickers have invested in Envigado and made life better for the people here, but at the same time they send the police out to kill the poorest,'' Jimenez said. ``I was in the army, and even in the army we didn't shoot people for no reason.'' ``Octavio, Arturo, Gonzalito, William, Jairo,'' the young man said, reciting a litany of names of friends he said were victims of the police. Edwin Arredondo Galvis, a 15-year-old half brother, said bodies would show up under a bridge leading to their neighborhood. ``I would see six or seven at a time,'' he said. Mayor-elect Jose Mario Rodriguez said the army had overreacted. ``We cannot see the justification of the military presence, but we will cooperate with the officials,'' he said. Rodriguez takes office Aug. 1, but will have no power if martial law still is in effect. The mayor-elect said he was certain the army would realize Envigado was a peaceful place and leave soon. ``We continue in peace as we always have,'' he said. ``We invite people to come and see how tranquil life here really is.'' Jimenez, in his wheelchair, said silence does not necessarily mean peace. He said families of victims had been afraid to speak up about police links to the drug cartel, but ``now that the killers are in jail, people are getting up the courage to talk.'' He would go to army headquarters himself to report his injury if he had the money for a taxi, but ``how am I suppose to get to the brigade in this?'' Jimenez said, pointing to his wheelchair. A former city policeman, who would identify himself only as Freddy, said Envigado had no problems except crimes committed by people, like Jimenez, who smoked basuko. ``The department has done a good job here,'' said the officer, who was playing cards with several men in a cafe. ``In 1989, we detained 900 people. The national police didn't take in 5 percent of that figure.'' Freddy weighs about 120 pounds, has a thin face and shows rotting teeth when he smiles. His friends called him Freddy the Mouse. Rodriguez, the mayor-elect, said Envigado's problems had been blown out of proportion. ``I think people are exaggerating because they envy Envigado's wealth and its excellent administration,'' he said, and declared his municipality to be the only one in Colombia with unemployment benefits. A high tax base and such thriving industries as textiles and chemicals paid for that, not money from cocaine traffickers, he said. ``People associate the town with Pablo Escobar because he was born here, but I for one have never met the man,'' Rodriguez said. Freddy the Mouse predicted the Department of Security and Control would be back in business soon. ``The government needs us,'' he said. ``They just don't realize how badly.''

DOC.HEAD: `A Lot of Hopes' Riding with Hubble Space Telescope
DOC.TEXT: After seven years of frustrating delay, the Hubble Space Telescope is finally tucked away aboard the shuttle Discovery, ready to embark on its mission to scour the outermost depths of space. The $1.5 billion observatory represents an astronomical advance of astronomical proportions _ the greatest, in fact, since the first use of a telescope by Galileo in 1609. ``We know a lot now, we think. Perhaps we don't know anything. Perhaps we'll learn that,'' said astronaut-astronomer Steven A. Hawley, part of the five-member crew that is set to launch Discovery on Tuesday. Among the mysteries that Hubble might help explain are quasars, pulsars and black holes, as well as the precise origin of the universe and the possible existence of other solar systems and life forms. But the telescope's most extraordinary find during its 15-year odyssey likely will be one not yet envisioned, said Eric Chaisson, senior scientist at the Space Telescope Science Institute at Johns Hopkins University. ``The history of science has shown the greatest discoveries are those the human imagination has not even conceived,'' he said. ``We are going to demand that the Hubble look into regions of total darkness, to look where nobody has ever looked, hoping by design to discover the unexpected.'' From its perch 380 miles high, the Hubble will be free of atmospheric distortion and therefore able to detect light of all wavelengths, including ultraviolet. The telescope will be capable of discerning objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best observatory on Earth. Astronomers expect to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years. The universe is believed to have been created 15 billion or so years ago by a terrific explosion known as the Big Bang. That theory is based on the discovery by the late American astronomer Edwin P. Hubble that the universe constantly is expanding. The shuttle mission that will put the observatory named for that pioneer into orbit has been eagerly awaited by NASA and scientists around the world for more than a decade. The Hubble Space Telescope originally was scheduled for launch in 1983, five years after receiving government funding. Technical problems postponed liftoff for several years, and the mission was delayed to 1989 by the Challenger explosion on Jan. 28, 1986. Concern over Discovery's solid rocket boosters pushed the mission back yet again to mid-April so the booster's lower right segment could be replaced. Minor problems continued to crop up, such as the discovery that several dozen midges, tiny mosquito-like insects, had invaded a payload preparation room at the launch pad. Engineers feared the bugs might damage the 24,250-pound, 43-foot-long telescope, and installation was postponed while the midges were rounded up. Later, a broken pipe sprayed water on electrical equipment and knocked out air conditioning. Some heat-sensitive computers were shut down, temporarily interrupting testing of the telescope's scientific instruments. ``Every new problem makes you a little uptight. But we've survived,'' said Bill Taylor, the telescope's chief engineer. Until the telescope arrived at Kennedy Space Center last October, engineers had taken advantage of the numerous delays to upgrade the instrument and make it easier to care for in space. The telescope, at $1.5 billion, is the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built by NASA. An additional $500 million has been spent to stockpile spare parts, train astronauts and develop computer software to operate the instrument. The European Space Agency is paying 15 percent of the costs. Discovery's five astronauts say they won't breathe easy until the Hubble is safe in space. For scientists, the nerve-racking wait will be longer. ``Their hearts are going to be beating, they're going to have butterflies and they're not going to be happy until several weeks after we release it and they start getting data,'' said Marine Col. Charles F. Bolden Jr., Discovery's pilot. Hawley will use the shuttle's 50-foot-long robot arm to remove the Hubble from Discovery on the second day of the five-day mission. NASA wants to deploy the telescope as soon as possible into the flight to minimize the risk of contaminating its 8-foot primary optical mirror. ``We're taking every possible precaution to be able to back up any potential problem that we have in deploying the telescope,'' said William Reeves, NASA's lead flight director for the mission. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan, veteran spacewalkers, will go out to help extricate, adjust or repair the telescope, if necessary. The cabin's pressure will be lowered three hours into the flight and remain low for several days to shorten the four-hour response time normally required for a spacewalk. It is estimated the Hubble will cost $200 million a year to operate and maintain in orbit. Within a month or two, data for test images will be sent via satellite to the Space Telescope Operations Control Center at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., and the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore. Six scientific committees chose 160 proposals from the world's astronomers, including five amateurs, for the instrument's first year of observation starting in December. Ten times more observing time was requested than the institute was able to grant. Every year, new proposals will be accepted. In 1993, a shuttle is scheduled to go up to service the telescope and, since its orbit inevitably will decay over time, boost it back up to a proper altitude. Further maintenance missions will be scheduled every three years. Any emergency work would have to be squeezed into the shuttle's already crowded flight agenda, said Discovery's commander, Air Force Col. Loren J. Shriver. ``More than likely, you would have to dedicate a mission because the altitudes are so high,'' Shriver said. Discovery's ascent to 380 miles will be the highest a shuttle has ever gone. The astronauts will bring the telescope back if it cannot be deployed safely. But that would be a last resort, Hawley said. ``We're going to do anything we can do to leave the telescope in orbit so that it has a chance for a mission,'' Hawley said.

DOC.TEXT: Shopping for spring apparel and other seasonal items plus a temporary spell of warm weather boosted retail business in March. But some of the country's big store chains reported little or no sales growth for the month due largely to a later Easter. Executives of several major general merchandise and department store chains said Thursday they were satisfied with their results. In a few cases, March sales surpassed the weak levels retailers had projected privately in advance.

West Germany said it was moving ahead with plans to replace the nearly worthless East German currency with the mighty Western mark by summer, amid uproar over the proposed exchange rate. Finance Minister Theo Waigel on Thursday confirmed newspaper reports that under the proposed currency union, East Germany would relinquish control of monetary policy to the West German central bank, the Bundesbank.

Phillips Petroleum Co. became the latest oil company to introduce a reformulated gasoline designed to be less harmful to the environment than existing grades. Phillips said Thursday its reformulated fuel _ blended to reduce certain hydrocarbon emissions _ will be tested in St. Louis, one of more than 100 cities that fall below the Environmental Protection Agency's minimum standards for air quality.

Eastman Kodak Co. was fined $2.15 million in criminal and civil penalties for violating New York's environmental laws. The photographic giant pleaded guilty Thursday in Rochester City Court to two misdemeanor violations for illegally disposing of hazardous waste and failing to report the spill of a toxic solvent until five days after it was discovered.

A jury rejected a delicatessen owner's claims that he was promised a slice of Paul Newman's food companies, ending a closely watched trial where profits were the issue but Newman was the star. The Superior Court jury deliberated just five hours over two days before deciding Thursday that Newman never promised Julius Gold 8 percent stock in the companies, Newman's Own Inc. and Salad King Inc. The Academy Award-winning actor was applauded as he left the courthouse.

Americans took out $3.4 billion more in consumer credit than they repaid in February, but the pace slowed because of slackening demand for car loans, the government said. The Federal Reserve said Thursday that consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.7 percent, down from January's revised 6.4 percent pace. The January rate was reported last month to have been 5.9 percent.

U.S. and Japanese negotiators put the finishing touches on an unprecedented agreement seeking to make broad-based reforms in the economies of both nations. The talks, which had been scheduled for two days, took up four days and ended Thursday as negotiators haggled over details of the complex proposals aimed at reducing the United States' huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan.

States in the industrial Midwest, seemingly on their last legs as the 1980s began, are now flexing their economic muscles, while Plains and Rocky Mountain states show little sign of recovering from the last recession, a private research group reported. The study by the Corporation for Enterprise Development, a research and consulting organization, released Thursday, said states on both coasts generally are in good economic health, and those in the South are improving but still have a long way to go.

U.S. companies plan to boost their overseas capital spending by 13 percent this year, up substantially from a 2 percent increase projected six months ago, the government said. The Commerce Department said Thursday that a survey conducted in December showed that majority-owned foreign affiliates of U.S. companies plan to spend $54.9 billion after increases of 14 percent in 1989 and 24 percent in 1988.

Stock prices drifted through a mixed session Thursday after a rumored financial storm in Tokyo failed to materialize. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been down 17.34 points Wednesday, rose 1.80 to 2,721.17. Bond prices slipped in light trading. The dollar finished mixed in dull trading. Petroleum futures prices fell sharply; soybeans surged while grains were mixed; copper futures fell; precious metals retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Momentum Building
With PM-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Retailers reported encouraging results for March despite a later Easter shopping season and appear set to record strong sales growth this month as the important promotional period gets into full swing. Thomas H. Tashjian, an analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities Inc., said April could be a robust month, particularly for retailers specializing in apparel. He said the investment firm might raise its financial forecasts for the first-quarter performances of several shopping-mall-based clothing chains. Reports from some of the country's big store chains released Thursday showed little or no sales growth in March, largely because Easter falls in April this year, three weeks later than in 1989. Nevertheless, demand for spring fashions and a temporary spell of warm weather boosted business at apparel-oriented retailers. Executives of a few major general merchandise and department store chains said they were satisfied with their results. In a small number of cases, March sales surpassed the weak levels retailers had projected privately in advance. ``On balance, they are slightly better than expected,'' said Wayne Hood, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``We can look forward to a continuing good trend in April.'' The results overall were decent given that holiday promotions timed to capitalize on the Easter season had not begun. Sales of Easter baskets, candy and decorations _ items important especially to discounters _ normally begin in earnest 10 days before the holiday. Last month's tallies were measured against a year earlier, when retailers benefited from a traditional pickup in shopping ahead of Palm and Easter Sundays, a time that brings extra customers into stores hunting for new outfits. Apparel sales outpaced other types of merchandise in March, continuing a pattern that has prevailed for more than a year. Sales of hard goods, such as expensive household appliances, were softer. Mediocre economic growth has kept consumers cautious about spending heavily or going deeper into debt to finance costly purchases. Car buying, for instance, has been very sluggish. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. stood out from the rest of the pack. The Bentonville, Ark.-based discounter posted a 27 percent March sales spurt over a year earlier. Sales excluding the take t stores opened within the year rose 12 percent. Results at stores open a year or longer, called same- or comparable-store sales, give the best indication of a retailer's performance. J.C. Penney Co., based in Dallas, said its store and catalog sales rose 9.7 percent in the five weeks ended March 31. On a comparable store basis, sales gained 8.7 percent. Much of Penney's business is in apparel. Two big mass merchandisers, Sears, Roebuck and Co. and Montgomery Ward & Co., posted sales growth of under 2 percent. Analysts said the two Chicago-based chains did reasonably well _ possibly better than their executives thought they would _ considering the tough comparison against last March. Sears, the nation's biggest retailer, said March sales rose 1.3 percent and were up 1.6 percent on a same-store basis. Montgomery Ward's sales grew 1.8 percent. It did not report results for comparable stores. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Bernard F. Brennan said the performance ``indicates a continuing growth trend'' when viewed against an 8.5 percent jump in March 1989 sales. A retailer that apparently didn't fare as poorly as it expected was Woolworth Corp., the New York-based parent of numerous specialty stores, including Foot Locker athletic shoe shops. Domestic sales edged down 1 percent in the five weeks ended March 31 from March 1989. Same-store sales were off a steeper 3.7 percent. Including foreign sales, Woolworth had a 2.5 percent increase in total March sales. Harold E. Sells, Woolworth's chairman and chief executive officer, said the domestic results ``exceeded our plan, and while total sales for the period showed only a small gain over the prior-year period, they were satisfactory considering the fact that last year's March results included the important Easter selling season.'' By contrast, Ames Department Stores Inc. said its March sales slumped 12 percent from a year earlier while its same-store sales were off 13.5 percent. The Rocky Hill, Conn.-based discounter blamed the later Easter season. Additional reports from retailers are due next week. K mart Corp., Dayton Hudson Corp., The Limited Inc. and others will issue their March results on April 12.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Pros Insulted by `Wall Street' Lotto Game
DOC.TEXT: A new Washington state lottery named ``Wall Street'' has irked the securities industry by implying that stockpicking is more risky than a crap shoot, but gaming experts say it's a clever idea. ``Players can experience the exciting world of `Wall Street' investing without the risks,'' says a press release by the Washington State Lottery, which starts the game Monday. Prizes for a $1 ticket range as high as $10,000 and buyers have better than a 1-in-5 chance of winning something, it said. ``The `Wall Street' game offers advantages not found in trading on that New York City street,'' the lottery's director Evelyn Sun said in the press release. ```Wall Street' is just the ticket for the player who wants to experience the thrill of high-stakes investing. And `Wall Street' players cannot lose more than they invested.'' On the real-life Wall Street, professional strategists were insulted when told about the game Thursday. Some said it was unfair to equate serious investing with gambling. Others said the Washington game would only reinforce a prejudice that the stock market is no better than a casino. ``It's only people who speculate and don't know what they're doing who get killed or get sucked in by the market,'' said Yale Hirsch, a prominent investment adviser who publishes the Stock Trader's Almanac. ``The Washington game should be called Atlantic City or Las Vegas. It's really a punch in the nose to Wall Street.'' Edward I. O'Brien, chairman of the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's national trade group, said he wished Washington would find another name for the game. ``Of all the states that have lotteries, this is the state that gave us WPPSS,'' O'Brien said, referring to the Washington Public Power Supply System, biggest municipal bond defaulter in history. ``Whoops, there they go again.'' Washington is one of 32 states that run officially sanctioned gaming operations. Its lottery is about 7 years old. The Wall Street game works much like lottery scratch games in other states. Players scratch across rows of boxes to reveal amounts under ``Buy,'' ``Sell'' and ``Profit.'' If a sell number is higher than a buy number in the same row, the player wins the price revealed in the profit box on the right. Richard Paulson, a spokesman for the Washington State Lottery, said the Wall Street theme was devised about six months ago, the 50th scratch game offered by the state's lottery since it began. Paulson said he saw no reason for the securities industry to be insulted. ``Obviously, we're trying to build a sense of excitement into our game,'' he said. ``We think this is an innovative name. It certainly conjures up the idea of riches and money, except it's fun.'' Saul F. Leonard, national partner and head of the gaming industries division of Laventhol & Horwath, an accounting and lottery consulting firm in Los Angeles, said he thought the real Wall Street had little to gripe about. ``They're part of the public domain,'' he said. ``I think they should be flattered the name Wall Street would attract people to play.'' Most state lotteries that sell scratch games concoct new themes every few months to stimulate sales. But most focus on other games, such as cards, horse racing, baseball and bowling. Some professional stock pickers found the Wall Street theme amusing. ``I'm ready to play,'' said Stan Weinstein, a widely followed strategist who publishes the newsletter Professional Tape Reader. ``I think we all take ourselves too seriously. It's a cute concept. But obviously I think real life investing is a bit less risky.'' William Knowlton, a spokesman for the lottery in New York, Wall Street's own home state, also called Washington state's idea a creative innovation. He said many real-life Wall Streeters are lottery fans themselves. ``We always have good lines down there when our jackpot gets big,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: CFTC Puts Broker Association Rule Out for Comment
DOC.TEXT: The agency that regulates the futures markets is moving closer to correcting problems uncovered in the scandals on the Chicago exchanges. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission voted unanimously Thursday to submit for public comment a proposed rule that would provide a legal definition of broker associations and require them to register with the exchange at which they do business. Broker associations have been loosely defined as formal or informal groups of futures traders formed to provide more capital to finance trades and more people to handle them. But the CFTC's Division of Trading and Markets concluded in a study reported on last January that broker associations ``may increase the potential for certain types of trading abuses.'' The study was an outgrowth of last year's undercover investigation of trading at the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange _ the nation's two largest futures exchanges _ which resulted in the indictment of more than 40 traders. Only five of the 13 futures exchanges have rules defining broker associations. Of those only the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, New York's Commodity Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange require broker associations to register. CFTC staffers believe that keeping tabs on broker associations will help deter abuses in the trading pits. Commission members agreed by a 5-0 vote. ``I believe very strongly that we identify and register these groups and I also agree that it gives a big assist and augmentation to our surveillance program to have this information,'' said Commissioner Kalo A. Hineman. As defined in the CFTC's proposed rules, ``broker association'' refers to two or more exchange members who share responsibility for executing customer orders, profits or losses from trading activities, or access to each other's unfilled customer orders. The rule would bar participation in the trading activities of a broker association unless the association is registered with the market or exchange. Interested parties have 60 days to comment on the proposed rule before the CFTC takes a final vote on it.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Firm Expects First-Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Salomon Brothers Inc. had a strong first quarter despite the continued slump across much of Wall Street, the securities firm's parent company said. Salomon Inc. said Thursday it would post a first-quarter profit because a strong performance by its securities unit offset a slump at its oil trading subsidiary. Chairman John H. Gutfreund said the company will show ``good quarterly earnings'' when results are announced April 24. In the first quarter of 1989, the company lost $28 million, or 35 cents a share. Gutfreund said profits at the brokerage arm were broadly based in the latest quarter. Salomon recently has been driven by its Phibro Energy oil refining and trading unit. Phibro was largely responsible for the firm's $470 million 1989 profit that confounded a major Wall Street slump. But Gutfreund said Phibro was expected to post only a modest profit in the January-March quarter, while the company's Philipp Brothers commodities trading unit would continue to be a drag on the firm. The two together would show a small loss, analysts said. Lawrence Eckenfelder, an industry analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said Salomon's securities arm ``made a ton of money'' in March following a slow period in the first two months of the year. ``It indicates while it's generally been a bleak quarter there have been a few lines of business that have done OK,'' Eckenfelder said, citing corporate and government securities trading as two improving areas. Salomon officials also indicated that unspecified trading strategies implemented in recent months had paid off. Analysts said the weaker quarter at Phibro was due to eroding oil prices and narrowing refining margins. Analysts remain hesitant to project higher earnings in coming quarters because Salomon relies heavily on the up-and-down nature of trading. ``Their earnings are very volatile,'' Eckenfelder said. ``They're very trading dependent and they have relatively high fixed costs right now.'' In light of Gutfreund's announcement, Eckenfelder said he would raise his quarterly per-share earnings estimate for Salomon to 85 cents from 30 cents. For the full year, the analyst said he would increase the estimate to $3.20 from $2.65. Phibro claims to be the world's largest trader of oil and the fourth-largest independent refiner in the United States. It made $367 million before taxes last year, while Salomon Brothers, which is supposed to be the company's main business, made $490 million.

DOC.HEAD: Modest Sales Increase a Glimmer of Hope?
DOC.TEXT: A modest sales upturn in late March has boosted prospects that the slump in the U.S. auto industry is ending, but the rebound isn't being shared by everyone. Chrysler Corp. was the most notable exception as its car sales fell behind those of Japanese rivals Honda and Toyota last month. ``We think the industry bottomed in sales in November of 1989 and that production bottomed in January of '90,'' analyst Doug Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. of New York said Thursday. Laughlin said sales bottomed out in November and have improved since then, with a few minor setbacks. In sales figures reported Wednesday, domestic automakers said they sold 2.9 percent more cars and trucks in late March than in the corresponding period last year. Analysts and others are quick to point out that drawing a conclusion from a 10-day reporting period can be dangerous because it is such a tiny sample of a huge industry. However, Laughlin and others say they are beginning to wonder if the industry is rebounding, especially with other economic factors figured in. ``The strong income growth and job creation and a stable prime rate has created a nice underpinning for sales,'' said Scott Merlis of Morgan Stanley & Co. of New York. But that underlying demand apparently hasn't reached Chrysler's cars, partly because of Honda's and Toyota's U.S. assembly plants. With imports counted in, Chrysler dealers sold 70,849 cars last month, just less than the 71,086 sold by Honda. Toyota sold 79,320 cars, or about nine for every eight sold by Chrysler. ``They have conceded some market share in cars,'' Laughlin said of the nation's No. 3 auto maker. ``They are the most truck-oriented company in the business.'' Chrysler sold 73,665 trucks last month, 4 percent more than its cars. ``I don't see much reason for that to change in the next few months,'' said auto analyst David Healy of the brokerage Barclays-BZW in New York. ``Chrysler has been slipping in retail passenger car market share recently.'' For all of March, Chrysler held 7.6 percent of the market for North American built cars, down from 9.4 percent during March 1989. General Motors Corp. held 33.2 percent of the market last month and Ford Motor Co. had 20.4 percent, each down 0.3 percentage points. Chrysler and Ford reported declines in their late March car sales of 23.7 percent and 8.1 percent respectively, while GM posted a 3.9 percent increase. Sales have been slumping since last October, and executives of the Big Three have forecast that the first half of this year would remain soft before sales pick up in the second half. In January, assembly lines nationwide ground to a halt temporarily as automakers took drastic steps to shrink new-car inventories, estimated to be more than 90 selling days, by shutting off the flow of vehicles at the source. The strategy appears to have worked. At the end of February, according to the weekly industry journal Ward's Automotive Reports, new-car inventories stood at 66 days, considered good for early spring. That level, when combined with what some analysts say is a strengthening demand and a stable economy, could indicate a rebound is on the way. ``I think fingers are crossed that the worst is behind us,'' Laughlin said. Other analysts, including Healy, were more cautious. ``I think the best way to look at it is the (sales) numbers for the full month,'' he said. ``If you do that, not a great deal is happening.''

DOC.HEAD: Phillips Petroleum Introduces Its Version Of Cleaner Gasoline
DOC.TEXT: Phillips Petroleum Co. has joined the growing number of oil companies to introduce a reformulated gasoline designed to be less harmful to the environment than existing grades. Phillips' reformulated fuel _ blended to reduce certain hydrocarbon emissions _ will be tested in St. Louis, one of more than 100 cities that fall below the Environmental Protection Agency's minimum standards for air quality, the company said Thursday. The rush by America's oil companies to make gasoline less toxic comes in response to stepped up government efforts to reduce air emissions from the tailpipes of cars and trucks. George Gaspar, a stock analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co. in Milwaukee, said oil companies are trying to protect their markets by developing ``cleaner'' gasoline that will help auto companies meet tougher air emission standards. ``If the auto companies don't get any help they may have to take some major actions that could hurt the petroleum industry,'' said Gaspar. ``We're going to hear a lot about how great reformulated gasoline is.'' Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., sells gasoline in the Midwest. It selected St. Louis for the test because of the company's strong selling base in the area. The reformulated gasoline is blended to reduce the amounts of certain hydrocarbons, such as aromatics, benzene and olefins, that react with the atmosphere and produce ozone, a main component of smog. Charles Bowerman, a Phillips senior vice president, said the mid-grade gasoline, SuperClean Unleaded Plus, contains 20 to 30 percent less olefins and aromatics and 35 percent less benzene than the average gasoline sold in the St. Louis area. The company did not make a comparison with the average gasoline sold nationally. The new gasoline is made by removing the more toxic compounds and replacing them with methyl-tertiary-butyl-ether, a blending component with a high oxygen content. Other oil companies that have introduced reformulated gasolines include Arco, Marathon, Exxon, Amoco, Mobil, Citgo and Sun Oil. While the new gasolines are slightly better for the environment, they're only a small step in attempts to end smog and other pollution in America's cities, said Scott Denman, director of the Safe Energy Communication Council. ``They're missing the forest for the trees,'' said Denman. ``These new gasolines are a little more benign on the environment, but they are not the best way for us to reduce pollution.'' The Safe Energy Communication Council, based in Washington, is a national coalition of environmental groups working to promote alternate energy sources and better use of current ones. Denman said that while Phillips and other of the nation's oil companies tout their efforts to devise ``environmentally improved'' gasoline, they're also ``fighting tooth and nail'' against establishing higher fuel efficiency standards. Making cars more fuel efficient and reducing the amount of gasoline burned in engines is the best way to clean up the environment, Denman said. Auto companies could use more efficient fuel-injection systems, build lighter motors, design more aerodynamic bodies, use lighter materials and equip cars with ``fuel-smart'' tires that deflate and inflate to improve gas mileage, he said. ``I'm not saying we shouldn't improve the gasoline, but I think we should recognize it for what it is, a small step, and ask why we're not taking some of the much bigger steps,'' Denman said.

DOC.HEAD: Steel's Pact With Disney Announced
DOC.TEXT: Dawn Steel, the tough former Columbia Pictures movie chief, has agreed to produce movies and TV exclusively for Walt Disney Co. Ms. Steel's move to Disney as an independent producer had been rumored since Sony Corp. bought Columbia for $3.4 billion last September. Sony immediately brought in superproducers Peter Guber and Jon Peters (``Batman,'' ``Rain Man'') to head Columbia, and Ms. Steel quit in January. ``There just wasn't room for all three big egos over there,'' said Alex Ben Block, the editor of the Hollywood newsletter Show Biz News. Ms. Steel is known as an aggressive fighter for her projects. She also is known as difficult to work for, so tough that California magazine ran her picture on the cover when it did a story on the state's worst bosses, calling her ``the queen of mean'' and ``hell on heels.'' But as rough as she may be on secretaries, she is praised widely for her knack of luring top filmmakers and actors into movies that suit their talents. ``I have known Dawn for over 12 years and, based on our close working relationship, I have only the greatest respect for her abilities and accomplishments,'' Disney Chairman Michael Eisner said Thursday as the deal was announced. She was out of town and unavailable for interviews Thursday, the studio said. Before joining Columbia, Ms. Steel was president of production for Paramount Pictures, where she was involved with hits such as ``Flashdance,'' ``Top Gun,'' ``Beverly Hills Cop II,'' ``The Accused'' and ``Fatal Attraction.'' In November 1987, she was hired as Columbia's president, the highest position ever held by a woman in Hollywood. She replaced David Puttnam, a British filmmaker who alienated many powerful people in Hollywood with his attempts to buck the star system of inflated egos and salaries. Ms. Steel is generally regarded as having stayed at Columbia for too short a time to prove herself as a studio chief. ``I don't think anyone gets a fair chance to do anything in a studio unless they are there 2{ to three years,'' said David Hoberman, the president of Disney's Touchstone Pictures. Hoberman said Ms. Steel will develop family-oriented movies to be released by the Disney studio as well as pictures for Touchstone aimed at adult audiences. She will not produce any movies for Disney's recently launched third studio, Hollywood Pictures, he said. A Disney statement said that in addition to movies and TV, Ms. Steel will ``develop other projects for the company'', but provided no details. Terms of her contract were not revealed, but Hoberman said, ``I think it is about as strong a producing deal as is out there, with one or two exceptions.'' The comment referred to deals such as the one Paramount has made with star producers Jerry Bruckheimer and Don Simpson, allowing them to make movies without approval from the studio's head of production. Ms. Steel apparently will have to get such approval. During Ms. Steel's tenure, Columbia released ``Casualties of War,'' a Sean Penn-Michael J. Fox movie that died at the box office, and ``Ghostbusters II,'' which made money but failed to become the hoped-for blockbuster. Other successful releases were ``When Harry Met Sally ...,'' and ``Look Who's Talking,'' but those films were already under way when she was hired. Yet-unreleased films she initiated include ``Postcards from the Edge,'' directed by Mike Nichols and starring Meryl Streep, Shirley MacLaine, Dennis Quaid, Gene Hackman and Richard Dreyfuss; ``Awakenings,'' directed by Penny Marshall with Robert DeNiro and Robin Williams; and ``Flatliners,'' produced by Michael Douglas and starring Kiefer Sutherland and Julia Roberts.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Posts Third-Largest Gain Ever
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange jumped sharply higher today with the market's key index posting its third-largest gain ever. The dollar fell slightly against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed the week at 29,278.78 points, up 1,029.72 points, or 3.65 percent. It was the index's third-largest single-day advance since it posted a 2,037.32-point gain on Oct. 21, 1987, and a 1,215.22-point gain on Jan. 6, 1988. The dollar closed at 157.47 yen, down 0.43 yen from Thursday's close of 157.90 yen. After opening at 156.90 yen, the currency ranged between 156.55 yen and 157.65 yen. The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond slipped to 86.36 points, as of 3 p.m., compared to Thursday's close of 86.55. The yield rose to 7.280 percent from the previous day's 7.240 percent. ``The market is almost dominated by buying orders,'' said Akiya Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities. ``The yen's advance against the dollar is an encouraging factor.'' ``Many investors, including institutional investors, have begun to think that the index has reached its bottom level,'' Shimoda said. He said the general mood of the market had begun to revive during Thursday's afternoon session as major institutional investors started active buying to support the falling market. On Thursday, the index lost more than 1,000 points at one point before closing with a 193.88-point loss. The market on Friday received buy orders for 160 million shares at the market's opening, compared to sell orders of 46 million shares, according to Daiwa Securities Co. In currency dealings, the dollar was making position adjustments prior to a weekend meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Paris. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said some market participants expect that ``there will be some policy initiative to defend the yen'' against the dollar in Saturday's meeting of monetary authorities from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. The dollar ``will remain in a relatively narrow range by the end of the G-7 meeting, though a demand for dollars by institutional investors remains strong,'' said another dealer with Fuji Bank who spoke anonymously. Bank of Tokyo's Kagawa said there was ``no significant effect'' on the exchange market from Thursday's agreement between the United States and Japan pledging to reduce trade frictions by making broad-based reforms in the economies of both countries. The agreement, reached after several months of discussions between U.S. and Japanese negotiators under the Structural Impediments Initiative, set forth a set of proposals aimed at reducing a $49 billion U.S. deficit with Japan by easing barriers to trade and investment.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against other major currencies in quiet trading in Europe this morning. Gold prices advanced. Traders said they did not expect much movement in the dollar as investors waited for the release of U.S. unemployment figures later today, and with the Group of Seven industrial nations meeting in Paris over the weekend. ``I'd say the mood is still positive on the dollar, neutral on the (West German) mark and negative on the yen,'' one Milan trader said. ``But everyone is watching to see if the G-7 meeting produces a renewed initiative for the yen.'' Traders said they doubted the G-7 finance ministers would be able to create new support for the weak yen, given Japan's reluctance to raise interest rates further and the ineffectiveness of central bank intervention to shore up the Japanese currency. The Group of Seven countries are the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.43 yen to close at 157.47 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 157.35 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6965 West German marks, down from 1.6997; 1.4995 Swiss francs, down from 1.5010; 5.7035 French francs, down from 5.7155; 1.9067 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9123; 1,247.50 Italian lire, down from 1,250.50; and 1.1665 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1685. In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6392, compared with $1.6427 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $375.25 a troy ounce, down from $377 bid late Thursday. But at midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a higher recommended price of $380.35. In Zurich, the bid price was $379, up from $376.50 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid $379.43, up $4.09 from Wednesday's close. The market was closed Thursday for a holiday. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.15 a troy ounce from Thursday $5.18.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
CHICAGO: reservation system.
DOC.TEXT: UAL's stock closed at $165.50 Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. UAL has more than 21.8 million shares outstanding. In a statement today, the board said it had agreed in principle with United Employee Acquisition Corp., the company representing the unions, to the sale. The board said both sides ``expect to conclude a final agreement promptly.'' The directors had negotiated with the unions, which represent United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants, in the two weeks since the board rejected a $185-a-share, or $4 billion, offer. The employee bid was supported by UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, which holds an 11.8 percent stake. Coniston has said it would wage a proxy fight to oust UAL's board at the company's April 26 shareholders meeting if a deal wasn't reached. The earlier bid was reportedly opposed strongly by UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf. A proposed $6.75 billion employee-led buyout of UAL collapsed last October after the would-be purchasers were unable to line up enough financing. The failure of that deal contributed to a 190-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average on Oct. 13.

The stock market advanced slightly today in a muted response to the latest status report on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.35 to 2,722.52 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 506 up, 389 down and 527 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 18.67 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The Labor Department issued its monthly report on employment, showing a drop in the civilian unemployment rate to 5.2 percent in March from 5.3 percent in February. In a separate statistical measure that commands especially close attention among stock and bond traders, the department said nonfarm payroll employment increased by 26,000 last month _ well below advance estimates and the smallest gain in more than 3{ years. That latter figure prompted a rise in Treasury bond prices of nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to the 8.47 percent-8.53 percent range. But if stock investors were encouraged by the drop in interest rates, the data also raised questions about whether the corporate earnings outlook would improve any time soon. Tandem Computers was actively traded, up { at 23[. The stock tumbled 4} points Thursday, when the company said revenues for the fiscal quarter that ended last weekend fell short of its target. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .18 to 187.33. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .31 at 360.92. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.80 to 2,721.17. Declining issues slightly outnumbered advances on the NYSE, with 716 up, 726 down and 537 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 144.17 million shares, against 159.54 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, Fiat Discussing Collaboration
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Friday it is holding talks on possibly selling its farm equipment operations to Italy's Fiat Group. Separately, the two automakers are discussing altering their current heavy truck agreement, which covers the making and marketing of trucks in Europe. It is not clear whether the discussions involve just a sale or swapping the farm machinery business for the truck operations. Ford, which sold its Rouge Steel operation late last year and has its Ford Aerospace Corp. subsidiary up for sale, apparently is interested in divesting all or part of Ford New Holland Inc., its farm implement making subsidiary. Ford officials have said recently that the company is interested in focusing on its auto- and truck-related businesses. In a joint statement, the automakers said any worldwide agreements would preserve their respective brands and markets. Ford and Fiat officials said there would be no further comment until a definitive agreement is reached. In 1985, Ford and Fiat held discussions about a wide range of worldwide associations. A year later, the two companies' heavy truck operations joined forces in Europe through Iveco-Ford. Ford and Fiat each owns 48 percent of Iveco-Ford; the rest is held by a French-U.S. investment banking concern. Ford spokesman Bert Serre declined to give earnings figures for the European truck operations but said Ford was pleased with its performance. Ford bought the New Holland, Pa.-based farm machinery builder in 1986 for $330 million from Sperry Corp. Ford does not report financial data on New Holland, but the subsidiary is estimated to have annual sales of about $3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Browning-Ferris Pulls Out of Hazardous Waste Business
DOC.TEXT: Browning-Ferris Industries Inc., a waste disposal giant, announced it is getting out of the hazardous waste business and taking a $295 million charge against earnings in the second quarter. Hazardous waste business added 2 percent to the Houston-based company's business, but reduced earnings by 10 percent and accounted for ``75 percent of our headaches,'' John Stanton, Browning-Ferris' chief financial officer said Thursday. The hazardous waste collection, treatment and disposal businesses, which the company operated under its BFI Environmental Systems Inc. and CECOS International Inc. subsidiaries, have lost money for a year and a half. BFI Environmental and CECOS lost $26.6 million last year and $5.2 million in the first quarter of the fiscal year ended Dec. 31. Total Revenue last year was $60 million. ``It's a significant event,'' said Jerald Cobbs, analyst for Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc. of Houston. ``It says how difficult a business it is to operate in.'' Stanton said regulatory problems at two of its four waste facilities figured heavily into BFI's decision. CECOS has agreed to plead guilty to one violation of Ohio environmental law in connection with activities at its Williamsburg facility and to pay a $25,000 fine. Separately, under a consent decree, CECOS has agreed to pay the state of Ohio a civil penalty of $1.5 million, establish a $1 million environmental trust fund for the state and pay $1 million to Clermont County. CECOS also will be required to close the facility. The company also was turned down for a permit to continue adding waste to its Niagara Falls, N.Y., facility, although it is being used as a non-hazardous industrial waste. Other CECOS land disposal sites are in Louisiana and Colorado. BFI said it will operate the hazardous waste business until it is sold or converted to non-hazardous uses, or until the hazardous waste assets are otherwise disposed of. That could take about two and a half years. About 800 employees will be affected, many of whom BFI expects to stay with operations as they are sold.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rate Dropped to 5.2 Percent Last Month
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate edged down to 5.2 percent last month despite the smallest increase in new jobs in four years, the government said today. The jobless rate had held steady at 5.3 percent for the previous nine months. The nation's manufacturing slump continued, with a loss of 30,000 factory jobs in March, the Labor Department said in releasing the unemployment report, the first comprehensive look at economic activity for the month. That brought manufacturing job losses to 100,000 since November and 250,000 over the past year, the department said. The jobless rate dropped even though only 26,000 new jobs were created in March. Most analysts had been predicting that the economy would produce around 170,000 new jobs last month. The 26,000 new jobs was the fewest produced since June 1986 when 110,000 jobs were lost, the government said. More than 350,000 new jobs were produced in both January and February. The government's household survey said total employment rose slightly in March to 118.3 million and that the labor force edged up to about 124.8 million. The Labor Department surveys businesses for statistics on job gains and losses. The losses were offset by gains in the services industries, which added 125,000 jobs, and the federal government, which added 75,000 Census Bureau workers and other employees. Since November, the number of jobs in the services sector of the economy has grown by more than 400,000. The government said that for the first quarter, there were about 750,000 so-called discouraged workers, or people who have given up looking for jobs. That was the lowest level since the first quarter of 1979. Michael Evans, who heads an economics firm in Washington, said unemployment fell despite the weaker-than-expected increase in jobs because the government's figures typically lag and reflect a previous month's activity. That means the fewer jobless Americans in March benefited from the healthy gains earlier in the year. ``I don't think it's a negative report, even though job gains were kind of puny,'' Evans said. He noted that for the January-to-March period, jobs gained an average of 250,000 a month. The average manufacturing work week held steady in March at 40.7 percent while overtime increased from 3.6 hours to 3.7 hours. Average hourly earnings increased from $9.88 to $9.92 for a 0.4 percent change, the government said. Over the past year, many economists have predicted a slight rise in unemployment this year. Federal Reserve policymakers have forecast a rate between 5.5 percent and 5.75 percent. The unemployment rates among major demographic groups last month were: _Adult white men, 4.0 percent, up from 4.1 percent in February. _Adult white women, 3.9 percent, down from 4.1 percent. _White teen-agers, 12.7 percent, down from 13.2 percent. _All blacks, 10.6 percent, up from 10.5 percent. _Adult black men, 9.6 percent, up from 9.2 percent. _Adult black women, 9.0 percent, down from 9.4 percent. _Black teen-agers, 26.2 percent, down from 27.5 percent. _Hispanics, 7.7 percent, down from 7.8 percent. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the March jobless rate was 5.1 percent, down from February's 5.2 percent.

The stock market pulled back today in a wary response to the latest status report on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.84 to 2,708.33 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 485 up, 676 down and 562 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 44.57 million shares at midmorning. The Labor Department issued its monthly report on employment, showing a drop in the civilian unemployment rate to 5.2 percent in March from 5.3 percent in February. In a separate statistical measure that commands especially close attention among stock and bond traders, the department said nonfarm payroll employment increased by 26,000 last month _ well below advance estimates and the smallest gain in more than 3{ years. That latter figure prompted a rise in Treasury bond prices of nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to the 8.47 percent-8.53 percent range. But if stock investors were briefly encouraged by the drop in interest rates, the data also raised questions about whether the corporate earnings outlook would improve any time soon. Losers among the blue chips included Aluminum Co. of America, down 1~ at 61{; Hewlett-Packard, down { at 44]; General Motors, down \ at 45}, and International Business Machines, down | at 105{. Tandem Computers was actively traded, up ] at 23. The stock tumbled 4} points Thursday, when the company said revenues for the fiscal quarter that ended last weekend fell short of its target. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .40 to 186.75. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .41 at 360.82.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Lower After Mixed Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices turned lower after a mixed opening today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The corn and soybean markets opened with solid gains, supported by indications the Soviet Union bought as much a million metric tons of U.S. corn. But the Soviets also were said to have purchased large amounts of corn and other grains from Argentina, which dampened buying enthusiasm. ``I think when everybody figured it all out, it looks like the Argentinians are going to get all the business,'' said John Frazier, director of agricultural futures trading for Gerald Inc. in Chicago. ``I think we're going to have a big washout,'' he said. Analysts also attributed some early selling to pre-weekend profit-taking after three strong days, especially in the soybean market. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 to 2 cents lower with May at $3.68 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1} cents lower with May at $2.70\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent lower with May at $1.52\ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2 cents lower with May at $5.96{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .20 cent to .35 cent higher with April at 79.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .40 cent higher with April at 83.20 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent lower to .35 cent higher with April at 54.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .28 cent to .90 cent higher with May at 56.17 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on Thursday.

EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The world's two most powerful economies have become inextricably wedded. But too often the relationship between the United States and Japan seems like a bad marriage characterized by frequent spats. What do the two have in common apart from money?

Never mind trade tensions. At Sam Kusumoto's company, a recent office party was enough to put a crimp in U.S.-Japan relations. There wasn't an argument or even a minor contretemps at the affair. Many of the American employees just didn't show up. It seems they didn't know about it in time, explains Kusumoto, president of Minolta USA in suburban Ramsey, N.J. ``At Japanese companies, we have very nice horizontal communication,'' he says. ``Everybody listens to what the other guy is talking about over the phone. After office hours we associate.'' So plans for just about everything spread chattily through the ranks _ in Japanese, of course. Formal notice, American-style, is almost an afterthought. ``The Americans didn't hear about the party,'' Kusumoto says. ``And when they discovered the date was decided months ago they got upset.'' A simple miscue, but behind it lay a gulf of misunderstanding that somehow has defied nearly 50 years of U.S.-Japan amity and more than a century of cultural exchange since 19th century Japan, under American prodding, cast off its feudal kosode (robes). Today more than ever, the world's two most powerful economies have become inextricably wedded. But too often the relationship seems like a bad marriage characterized by frequent squabbles and little in common apart from money. The tensions have appeared in numerous forms, despite the best efforts of both sides to avoid them: in charges of discrimination by American employees of Japanese companies, in a hardhearted new appraisal by Washington of its one-time protege, and vice versa. And not least, in an undercurrent of racism. The racism often surfaces subtly. When Japanese companies purchased such American corporate icons as Columbia Pictures and New York's Rockefeller Center last year, the headlines often read ``The Japanese Buy ...,'' as if the entire nation were bent, samurai-like, on the takeover. In contrast, other major foreign purchasers _ British, Canadian, Dutch _have been described more accurately as individual companies. Part of it is the sheer cultural impact of Japan's new wealth, an economic sea change that made Japan the world's largest creditor by the end of the 1980s, and its former patron, the United States, the largest debtor. ``It's the Japanese rate of buying that's frightening,'' says Marlene Rossman, a New York-based consultant to New York companies. Japan is now second only to Great Britain in U.S. investments. From May 1987 to last May, the number of U.S. factories with at least partial Japanese ownership nearly doubled from 550 to 1,043, according to the Japan External Trade Organization. Japan's total investment in U.S. real estate, corporations and subsidiaries soared from $4.7 billion in 1980 to $53.4 billion in 1988, according to the most recent Commerce Department figures. Japanese companies now hold about 50 percent of the commercial real estate in downtown Los Angeles, more than 20 prime properties in Manhattan, including Tiffany's, and substantial holdings in Washington. It is not over the issue of Washington real estate, however, but closer to the heart of the nation's capital that U.S.-Japanese tensions have perhaps cut deepest. Particularly irksome were the 1989 trade figures released in February. The United States enjoyed a $1.5 billion surplus with the 12-nation European Community, a sharp turnaround from a $9.2 billion deficit in 1988. But with Japan, despite a sharp decline in the dollar engineered to help U.S. exports, the deficit was a stubborn $49 billion. That was no appreciable improvement from the previous year's $51.8 billion deficit with Japan, even with an 18 percent increase in U.S. export sales, says J. Michael Farren, undersecretary for international trade in the Commerce Department. The trade frictions are aggravated by what many in Congress and the Bush administration see as the Japanese government's xenophobic resistance to open markets and cultural disposition to treat trade as economic warfare. ``The fallacy in asking the Japanese to open their markets is they haven't got the foggiest idea what an open market is,'' says Clyde Prestowitz, a former Commerce Department negotiator whose influential 1988 book, ``Trading Places,'' portrayed Japan as having carefully planned its export-fueled ascendancy. In Tokyo, Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said U.S. analysts were wrong in arguing that Japan's culture was an unchangeable barrier to concepts like an open market. Last week, under growing threat of trade sanctions from the Bush administration, Japanese and U.S. negotiators put the finishing touches on an unprecedented agreement to liberalize Japan's market, including its tightly controlled goods distribution system. In addition, experts point out, Japan has been gradually moving from an export-based to a domestic market-based economy. Japan has a long history of adapting foreign ideas, Watanabe said, ``and there is no reason why we cannot continue to do so.'' One reason, however, is that the Japanese are not as keen on foreign ideas these days, an attitude born of Japan's pride in its postwar ``miracle'' and a growing contempt for the United States' persistent problems.

DOC.HEAD: Undercover Police End Sting Against Upscale Prostitution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `By Thursday...', to give background on charges. SUBS 21st graf, `In Ohio..', to CORRECT spelling of Columbus.
DOC.TEXT: Investigators are poring through records seized from escort services they say catered to businessmen, athletes, entertainers and politicians who paid up to $1,000 a night for a prostitute and charged it. ``This hits the highest-priced call girls in prostitution,'' said Maury Dettmer, chief of criminal investigations for the Internal Revenue Service. ``These are not street-level hookers. The average receipts were for $800 to $1,000 an evening.'' By Thursday, six people _ three in California and one each in Fort Lauderdale, Dallas and Atlanta _ were in custody, charged with prostitution, weapons or drug offenses uncovered during the investigation. Other arrests on money laundering, tax evasion, racketeering and organized crime charges are planned, Dettmer said. Undercover agents, working out of a storefront in Tampa, posed as launderers able to disguise charge card payments, so customers could bill the services on company cards, officials said. During a two-year sting, Tampa-based agents said they laundered $2.5 million in charge payments from escort services in major cities. Since business executives don't want a charge from an escort service on their card, escort services would pay to hide the charge, showing it for something such as a copying service, said an agent who worked undercover on the operation in Savannah. Authorities called a news conference at the Tampa storefront Thursday to announce raids on more than 40 escort services overnight Wednesday and early Thursday. ``We processed $2.5 million in credit-card receipts, or about 20 percent of their total gross receipts, which we estimate to be about $12 million annually,'' Dettmer said. ``We targeted escort services who advertised in the Yellow Pages that accept credit cards,'' he said, adding: ``The reason they take credit cards is because businessmen traveling have company credit cards. Companies then deduct it as a business expense. ``So not only do we have unreported income from the escort services, but we have false tax deductions by the businesses who used credit cards.'' The sting began small in Tampa, said Steve Cole, spokesman for the Tampa Police Department. But as word spread among escort services, business boomed. More than 25,000 credit-card receipts for escort services from 23 cities in 15 states were processed, officials said. ``It just kept getting bigger and bigger,'' Cole said. Local police contacted the IRS after they were bombarded with laundering requests from as many as 100 companies. Agents sent out letters soliciting business, Cole said. They charged a fee of 13 percent to 18 percent. The money they collected paid for rent, telephones and other related charges. Officials said it worked this way: An escort service sent charge slips to the Tampa office; agents made up other slips in the name of Sunset Enterprises and sent them to the bank; then the bank sent the money to Sunset and the agents, in turn, paid the escort services with checks that looked like tax-free loans. Typically, Cole said, a prostitute probably would collect $500, the escort service $300 and the cops $200. In one instance, a madam in the business for more than 25 years said she ran a house in North Carolina strictly for politicians and could tell what day it was just by who was coming to the door, investigators said. In another, a co-owner of an escort service bragged of paying off local politicians to warn her if she was being investigated. In Mobile, Ala., about 20 agents searched two locations of Candy's Movie Mates and the residence of the manager Wednesday night. But Tim Lee, an IRS criminal investigator, said there were no arrests. Evidence seized in the raids was turned over to the U.S. Attorney's office. In Ohio, IRS agents seized records from escort services in Columbus, Cleveland and the Dayton area. Records were taken from Dulcet International escort service in the Columbus suburb of Whitehall, the Kitty Kats Touching Place Adult Studio in Vandalia, near Dayton, and an several escort services which operate out of the Crile House, a historic building in Cleveland's Ohio City neighborhood. Seized in the raids were telephone records, telephone numbers, license plate numbers and other documents. In Florida, law officers served search warrants on businesses in Cape Coral, near Fort Myers, and in Fort Lauderdale and Plantation in Broward County.

DOC.HEAD: Accord Reached on Landmark Agreement
LaserPhotos WX8, WX9
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new with administration comment. picks up 3rd graf pvs, In Tokyo today.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today hailed the U.S.-Japan trade agreement as marking a new era in relations but cautioned that the accord must be followed by concrete action on the part of Japan. ``We think we have a good blueprint for action and we got a good downpayment,'' said U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. ``Obviously, we want results and if they don't occur we would be disappointed.'' Hills' remarks to reporters at a briefing session was in response to skeptical comments which greeted the document in Congress. Many members said Japan had made broad promises before to open its markets to foreign products but had failed to live up to the agreements. Hills said the administration would be pushing for significant follow-up to Thursday's accord, in which Japan promised to take a series of measures to make it easier for foreigners to invest and do business in Japan. She said both nations still had to come to terms on a final report due in July and that even after that document was finished she would consult frequently with the Japanese to monitor their progress in implementing the commitments. In Tokyo today, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu warned his nation that the coming economic changes could ``in some cases be painful,'' but he promised they would lead to an improved quality of life for the Japanese people. ``I ask for the understanding and cooperation of the people of my country,'' Kaifu said in a televised appearance. The unprecedented agreement followed four days of marathon bargaining in Washington. The talks, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, were devised by the administration last July as a way to attack the underlying cultural reasons for America's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. For the first time, representatives of sovereign states set about reviewing each other's economic failings and making suggestions for changes. From the lengthy lists supplied, bot governments drafted a set of commitments that they would be willing to make. The Japanese proposals, if implemented, would be much more far-reaching in their impact than the U.S. proposals, which essentially recycled past administrative initiatives, including the Bush plan to cut the capital gains tax as a way of boosting investment. But members of Congress said they remained to be convinced that the Japanese were serious about making the changes needed to open their markets to more foreign goods. ``Put me down as a skeptic who has seen too many (Japanese) agreements in which the results didn't match the rhetoric,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. ``In any commercial agreement with Japan, seeing is believing,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo. In its 22-page list of promises, the administration said it would work to balance the federal budget, improve the U.S. educational system and boost incentives for personal savings _ all in the name of bolstering America's international competitiveness. Tokyo's 32-page list of promises, which turned out to be more comprehensive than many critics had expected, pledged to alter the closed-door policies Japanese businesses have long employed to keep out foreign competition. Kaifu's government promised to: _Stiffen penalties for antitrust violations by Japanese companies, including higher jail terms for bid-rigging and other collusive practices which hamper the ability of foreign companies to compete in Japan's market. _Reregulate Japan's complex distribution system, which makes it difficult for foreigners to get products into the country. As part of that process, the government promised to step up spending for construction and expansion of airports and harbors where foreign goods arrive. It also said it would shorten from as much as 10 years down to 1.5 years the time needed to get approval to open large retail stores _ restrictions that have blocked American and other foreign companies from setting up shop in Japanese markets. _Pass new legislation designed to alter tax laws in an effort to expand the amount of land available for residential construction and to boost government spending for housing and related areas such as sewer systems. _Promote reducing the work week for Japanese government and private-sector workers to 40 hours and five days and examine ways to expand consumer credit. In many ways, the Japanese list of proposals sounds like a blueprint for transforming a work-obsessed, thrifty country into a nation more like America _ with more leisure time, expanded options to buy consumer goods at lower prices and more access to charge cards. Administration officials said that while Americans have developed an inferiority complex over Japan's economic prowess, they too often forget the high price Japanese consumers have had to pay for their nation's trade superiority. ``It has resulted in a standard of living that the American people wouldn't trade for,'' said Undersecretary of State Richard McCormack, the head of the U.S. delegation. ``We live far better, we have far better houses, we have far better access to products that are much cheaper.'' The agreement on reducing structural barriers was the latest in a string of trade concessions the Japanese government has made since Kaifu and Bush met in California in early March. In the past two weeks, negotiators have reached agreements to expand markets for American-made telecommunications equipment, satellites and supercomputers. The flurry of agreements was seen by some as a last-minute effort by the Japanese to avoid being targeted again this year as unfair traders. That designation means the administration could retaliate by doubling the tariffs on selected Japanese goods sold in the United States. The administration must decide by April 30 on its new unfair-trade list.
