DOC.HEAD: House Leader Seeks SEC Probe of Analyst's Firing
DOC.TEXT: Congressional staffers say they are getting several letters a day supporting calls for a federal probe of the firing of a securities analyst who questioned the prospects for a Donald Trump casino. ``We are getting a fair amount of mail, about five to 10 letters a day,'' said Dennis Fitzgibbons, an aide to Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Fitzgibbons said Thursday that the mail was from executives and citizens ``from around the country'' applauding Dingell's call for a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the firing of gaming industry analyst Marvin Roffman. Roffman was fired by his firm, Philadelphia-based Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., on March 23 after he made negative comments published in the Wall Street Journal about the long-term prospects for Trump's new Atlantic City, N.J., casino, the Taj Mahal. Trump threatened to sue the firm and Roffman was fired after he rescinded his initial written apology to the real estate developer. Janney Montgomery said it did not fire Roffman for his negative analysis, but for violating firm policies about dealing with the news media. Last week, Dingell wrote SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden asking the agency, which Dingell's committee oversees, to look into firing. ``This scenario raises serious questions about the honesty and integrity of Wall Street research as well as conflict of interest problems between firms and analysts and their clients,'' Dingell's letter said in part. Dingell also stated that ``if self-regulation cannot effectively deal with these matters, we need to be looking at legislative remedies.'' Dingell also asked Janney President Norman T. Wilde Jr. to provide the House panel ``with complete reports on this matter.''

DOC.HEAD: Junk Defaults Rise, But Fitch Sees a New Market There
DOC.TEXT: The bad news keeps coming in the junk bond market, but that isn't stopping new players from seeking a piece of the action. Swelled by the bankruptcy woes of Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retailing arms, the amount of corporate bonds defaulting in the first quarter of this year quadrupled, the Bond Investors Association says. Thirteen companies defaulted on 38 bond issues totaling $5.69 billion in the period, compared with nine companies and $1.33 billion a year earlier, the Miami-based non-profit group reported. The quarter's toll surpassed the total for all of 1988, when $4.97 billion in defaults were recorded. The burgeoning growth of defaults is the inevitable consequence of the explosive growth of junk bond borrowings in the mid 1980s, says C. Richard Lehmann, president of the association. ``We're getting that higher fallout because there's more debt eligible for fallout,'' Lehmann says. Defaults tend to occur four or five years after bonds are issued as borrowers' problems come home to roost, he says. Those problems are plentiful, he adds, because credit quality deteriorated in the '80s as companies replaced equity with junk debt via leveraged buyouts and recapitalizations. Campeau is a prime example, having issued billions in junk bonds to acquire Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. Those subsidiaries filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January and accounted for $3.5 billion of the first quarter's defaults. But even without Campeau, defaults rose 64 percent in the period. Lehmann says he conservatively estimates defaults will hit a record $15 billion this year, exceeding last year's $11.7 billion. Over the next three years he forecasts a staggering $40 billion in defaults. Those numbers may mean bad news for some investors, but they spell opportunity for Fitch Investors Service Inc. The rating agency has been moving aggressively to compete with its bigger rivals, Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, and it hopes to make a mark with a new service that evaluates so-called distressed credits. ``We believe the market's ripe for it,'' says B. Daniel Evans, chief operating officer at Fitch. In contrast to the traditional rating game, which ranks borrowers according to their perceived ability to repay, Fitch's recovery analysis aims to tell bondholders how much they are likely to get back on investments in companies that are in bankruptcy or facing severe distress. First, the service tries to determine the value of a borrower's assets. Then it examines the covenants of the company's bond issues to determine what leverage bondholders might have over management. Simple stuff for a rating agency, but it gets more problematic. Next Fitch estimates how long it will take to work out the company's problems and realize values for bondholders. Then it tries to determine how proceeds will be allocated among individual bond issues, and discounts those proceeds back to the present. With Federated, for example, Fitch estimates holders of the retailer's senior classes of bonds can expect to receive 78 cents on the dollar in about three years' time. Assuming that holds true, an investor who pays 42 cents for the bonds now would get an effective return of 25 percent a year. Fitch is selling its service to institutional investors as part of a broad package of high-yield research for $10,000 a year. It could be a fertile market, judging by the growing number of investors poking around the wreckage of the junk market, Evans says. Oppenheimer High Yield Fund, for example, now has 5 percent to 6 percent of its assets invested in distressed credits compared with perhaps 2 percent six months ago, portfolio manager Ralph Stellmacher says. ``We have gravitated toward that sector because that is where we're finding the most values,'' he says. The boom in defaults has been good business for R.D. Smith & Co. The New York broker specializes in distressed credits and workout situations, and its staff has grown to nearly 100 from only 30 three years ago, President Mike Singer says. It takes a lot of legal expertise to assess the value of a bankrupt company's securities because ``there are no strict rules as to how an estate gets allocated,'' Singer cautions. But for those who can do the job, there's no end of work in sight. ``The supply of distressed securities still far outpaces the new funds coming into the market,'' Singer says.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Buoyant, Defense Attorneys Shocked by Lemons' Sentence
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th and last graf to CORRECT to one official convicted, sted pleaded guilty; SUBS 20th graf to CORRECT that Dixon owned, sted chairman, at Vernon
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DN3 of April 5
DOC.TEXT: A record 30-year sentence given to a former savings and loan executive convicted of fraud won applause from regulators, who said it showed authorities were dead serious about cracking down on thrift fraud. The sentence for Woody F. Lemons, former chairman of Vernon Savings & Loan, was the stiffest ever given to a thrift executive in a fraud case, regulators said. U.S. District Judge Robert B. Maloney said it was well deserved. Lemons was ``a thief in every sense of the word,'' the judge said. The sentence was praised by L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp., which is overseeing the thrift industry bailout. ``I think it says these kinds of crimes are very serious,'' Seidman said. ``They are very harmful to the people of the United States and they are going to be punished severely.'' Lemons was convicted in December on 13 charges _ including misapplication of funds, conspiracy and bank fraud _ for soliciting a $9,000 kickback from a loan broker in January 1986 and receiving $212,000 from the broker in April 1986. Seidman had written Maloney urging him to ``send a message to the banking and thrift community and to other who would commit such egregious acts as did Mr. Lemons.'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburg called the sentence ``fair and just punishment for one whose criminal misconduct resulted in a multimillion dollar fraud in the Texas savings and loan industry.'' Vernon S&L was shut down in 1987 as part of a then-record $1.3 billion federal bailout, and has been cited as an example of some of the worst abuses in the savings and loan industry. Six other Vernon officials, a consultant and two borrowers have been convicted or pleaded guilty to various crimes. When regulators seized Vernon, they found it owned 17th century castle doors and expensive art objects, including a Baccarat eagle and a silver-studded saddle. The thrift also owned a yacht in Washington, D.C. Prosecutors said Lemon spent some of his money on a West Coast home and on travel. Maloney levied no fine against Lemons, but he still faces an April 19 hearing on restitution. The government is seeking as much as $18 million in repayment. The judge said he had received more than 100 letters on Lemons' behalf praising his church and community activities, but he wasn't persuaded. ``Your friends are wrong,'' Maloney said. ``You are not a religious man. ... Even though you are present (in church), you are not listening.'' ``You have no real moral values,'' the judge said. ``If you had the opportunity, you would (steal) again. You are a thief in every sense of the word.'' Elated government attorneys would say little about the sentence, but were heard shouting ``hot dog'' as they disappeared into their offices. ``They hit a home run,'' said defense attorney Michael Gibson, who promised to appeal the sentence. Gibson accused the government of having ``another agenda'' in prosecuting Lemons. ``He's going to be the trophy that the federal agencies bag,'' Gibson told Maloney. Later the attorney predicted, ``You will see Mr. Lemons and the sentence used to enhance (the agencies') position'' in Congress. The sentencing of Lemons sets the stage for an expected indictment of another former Vernon chairman, Don R. Dixon, who is painted by government officials as the main culprit behind the abuses at the thrift. Dixon has been notified he is the target of a federal investigation, according to his attorney. He also is the lead defendant in a $540 million federal fraud lawsuit filed in 1987. Gibson would not say if prosecutors had sought Lemons' cooperation against Dixon, but Dixon's attorney, William M. Ravkind, said, ``Anybody facing 30 years would turn in their mother.'' Five other Vernon officials and two Vernon borrowers and a consultant also have pleaded guilty in thrift-connected cases. In addition, former President Patrick G. King was convicted of fraud and sentenced by Maloney to five years in jail and fined $55,000.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
London Stocks Finish Sharply Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with close.
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell sharply on London's Stock Exchange Friday, on nervousness before this weekend's Group of Seven meeting in Paris. Traders also said concern about British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's unpopularity upset the market. In a Gallup poll published Friday, the Labor Party had support of 52.5 percent support of those polled. It now holds a record 24.5-point lead over the Conservative Party. A late afternoon tumble in the pound also undermined the market, dealers said. Market watchers said the G-7 meeting was not expected to focus on the pound, so there were perceptions that sterling would be neglected afterward. The G-7 countries are the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was down 18.4 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,221.1, just a shade better than its 2,221.0 minimum. The index hit an early morning peak of 2,243.2 and proceeded to move lower throughout the rest of the session. Volume amounted to a moderately active 578.6 million shares, compared with 499.5 million shares Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Board Agrees to Buyout
DOC.NOTE: EDS: NEW grafs 3-15 to UPDATE with source saying no firm financing; details from unions' news conference in New York; picks up 12th graf pvs bg'ng, ``There's not ...
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. directors announced today they have agreed to sell the parent of United Airlines to its employees for $201 a share, or $4.38 billion. The move heads off a threatened proxy fight with the company's largest shareholder but puts UAL back in a familiar position _ floating a deal with uncertain financing. Under the agreement, employees will exchange $155 in cash, $35 in UAL notes and an estimated $11 worth of securities in UAL subsidiary Covia Corp. for each UAL share. There was no immediate word on how the deal was to be financed. But a source close to the negotiations told The Associated Press the parties had no firm financing for the deal. UAL, parent of United Airlines, said it expects to conclude a final agreement promptly with United Employee Acquisition Corp., a new company organized by United's pilots, flight attendants and Machinists. At a news conference today in New York, representatives of the unions said the agreement calls for employees to give up $2 billion in concessions over five years, including $300 million in the first year and $500 million in the fifth year. The breakdown of ownership in the new company would be as follows: pilots owning about 37.9 percent; Machinists owning about 35.7 percent, non-union employees about 14.3 percent and flight attendants about 12 percent, the unions said. Machinists' union Vice President John Peterpaul predicted banks would look favorably on the deal. ``We're very optimistic about the financing,'' he said. UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, immediately called off its threatened proxy fight to oust the company's board at the April 26 annual shareholder meeting. Coniston holds an 11.8 percent stake. ``We think it's a fair deal,'' said Coniston general partner Paul Tierney, adding that employees and stockholders alike will gain from the agreement. The announcement met with a lukewarm reaction, however, from some analysts, who questioned how the deal would be financed and whether banks would be willing to back the bid without a strong management group behind it. The fate of UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf has been in doubt because of union indications made before today that they would dump Wolf in the event of an employee buyout. Pilots union head Frederick Dubinsky said in New York today that Wolf would be replaced. ``It's our intention to put together a top-notch senior management team ... and that will include a new (chief executive officer),'' he said. ``There's not a financed bid, and there's a lot of skepticism,'' said Edward Starkman, an airline analyst for PaineWebber Inc. in New York. UAL's stock opened up $3.50 a share at $169 on the New York Stock Exchange but by midday had slid back to $165.50, unchanged from Thursday. The agreement marks another chapter in a takeover saga that began in August when Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis made a $5.4 billion offer for the company. Davis said earlier this week he would not make another bid. But his initial offer sent United's pilots and management scrambling to come up with their own bid. In September, UAL directors accepted a $6.75 billion offer from the pilots, management and British Airways PLC that also included labor and wage concessions. The proposal was killed after the would-be purchasers were unable to line up enough financing. Failure of that deal contributed to a 190-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average on Oct. 13 and was seen as the end of the takeover boom of the 1980s. The stakes were raised again in November when Coniston announced it had amassed a large block of UAL stock and wanted to reduce the number of directors on the company's board. After UAL directors told financial advisers to consider a recapitalization plan in January, United's three labor unions proposed buying 75 percent of the stock. That proposal resulted in a $185-a-share, $3.8 billion buyout offer from the unions that the UAL board rejected two weeks ago. The bid was reportedly opposed strongly by UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf. Earlier this week, the board met at least twice by telephone, presumably on the buyout scenario. United is the nation's largest carrier behind American Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Miller Expands Production of New Non-Alcohol Brand
DOC.TEXT: Miller Brewing Co. said Friday that the company has expanded production of Sharp's, its new non-alcoholic brew, because demand in some areas has left it short of supply. Milwaukee-based Miller introduced the alcohol-free beer in December, producing it at its breweries in Albany, Ga., and Eden. N.C. But first-quarter sales in 1990 were so strong, Miller is expanding production to a third brewery in Fulton, N.Y., said Tony Sciolla, new products manager. The company declined to release the exact sales figures. ``We didn't expect it to do as well as it has,'' Miller spokesman Ron Richards said. ``We hope the expansion that we've done will solve the spot shortages.'' The immediate success of Sharp's did not surprise some beer industry analysts, who predicted it could soon bump G. Heileman Brewing Co.'s Kingsberry label as the top selling non-alcoholic beer. Frank Walters, vice president of research for Impact, a bimonthly newsletter for the alcoholic beverage industry, said he expects growth in the non-alcoholic segment of the market to continue. In 1989, sales of non-alcoholic drinks was up 14 percent, he said. It was one of the faster-growing segments of the beverage market, behind imported vodkas, up 24 percent and California varietal wines, up 16 percent. Walters said he expects sales of Sharp's and O'Doul's, the non-alcoholic brand Anhueser-Busch introduced this year, to grow fastest and ``put a lot of pressure'' on La Crosse, Wis.-based Heileman's Kingsberry brand. ``I think they'll do very well because of the clout that both companies have,'' he said. Richards said the ``overwhelming consumer response'' to Sharp's was due in part to a brewing process that allows Miller to brew at lower temperatures, minimizing alcohol production. The process produces a non-alcohol beer that tastes the same as regular beer, he said. Most other brewers that have non-alcohol or low-alcohol beer first brew regular beer and then remove the alcohol _ along with the real beer flavor, he said. Richards also cited a trend toward drinking moderation. He said the product was selling best in the Northeast, the Midwest and the West. The trend toward tougher enforcement of drunken driving laws is also a factor, Walters added. ``Police aren't playing around,'' he said. ``I would suspect that on-premise is a big share of the business. Someone who wants to go out and visit a bar _ they can have two or three and not have any problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Mesa Pulls Hugoton Holdings Off Market
DOC.TEXT: Mesa Limited Partnership on Friday pulled its Hugoton Royalty Trust holdings off the market, saying prices were too low to sell the prime properties in the nation's largest natural gas field. Mesa, T. Boone Pickens Jr.'s energy company, said in December it would package its Hugoton holdings into a separate trust and sell shares to raise money to help pay down some of the partnership's $1.5 billion in long-term debt, much of it left over from the $715 million purchase of natural gas properties from Tenneco Inc. in 1988. ``At the right price, the Hugoton offering made sense for Mesa unitholders,'' Pickens said. ``We're simply not going to sell a portion of our premier properties at an inferior price.'' The decision was based on ``unusual delays experienced in bringing the transaction to market and pricing indications which did not ... reflect the value of (Mesa's) Hugoton reserves,'' the company said. W. Mark Womble, Mesa's vice president of finance, said the partnership had hoped to raise about $400 million through the sale, but indications were the offering would only bring in about $320 million. Plans were to sell about 16 million units at about $25 per unit; Womble said indications were the units would bring no more than $20 each. ``It's just not something we had to do,'' Womble said. ``We're not to the point that we have to sell anything to pay debt.'' Mesa had about $350 million in cash investments at the end of 1989, Womble said, adding that the properties may never be sold. ``We have not said that we would ever come back to the market with this particular deal,'' he said. ``The field has been producing a long time, and will produce a long time into the future and it's not going anywhere,'' he said by telephone from Mesa's offices in Amarillo. Between 12 percent and 15 percent of Mesa's natural gas holdings are in the Hugoton field in Kansas, Womble said.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Ministers Gather for Key Exchange Rate Talks
DOC.TEXT: Financial market turmoil stemming from the Japanese yen's sharp decline provided the backdrop for key talks by U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and the economics chiefs of other major industrial nations who gathered Friday. The ministers from the so-called Group of Seven nations, holding their first formal discussions of 1990, also were expected on Saturday to examine West Germany's plans to forge a monetary union with East Germany as well as the political upheavals in other East European countries. In advance of the meeting at the French Finance Ministry, analysts were doubtful the Group of Seven _ Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States _ would change course dramatically. The nations generally work together to achieve broad economic goals, often through currency exchange rates, and rely at times on coordinated market intervention as a tool. ``I don't expect any major policy conclusions,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist at the consulting firm of DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass. French Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy and his German counterpart, Theo Waigel, held bilateral talks Friday but said their discussions did not extend to the international financial scene. The Japanese, worried about the weakness of their currency against the dollar over recent months, were expected to appeal to their economic partners for help in boosting the yen's value. The yen's slump has rattled the Tokyo stock market because of speculation about its negative implications for the Japanese economy, and stocks have tumbled by more than 25 percent so far in 1990. Earlier in the week, the dollar skyrocketed to a three-year high of more than 160 yen before retreating a bit. The yen closed at about 157.5 yen to the dollar Friday in Tokyo, reflecting uncertainty in the currency markets about the outcome of the Group of Seven meeting. A stronger dollar also is worrisome for the United States because it threatens to aggravate the already large American trade deficit with Japan. It makes Japanese imports less expensive for U.S. consumers and American goods costlier for foreign buyers. Many analysts predicted the United States would be wary of promising to do much to prop up the yen. Some said American officials may agree to intervene more in the currency markets by selling dollars to try to strengthen the Japanese currency. The Japanese would like to see the Americans lower their interest rates, which would in turn help lift the yen. But the U.S. Federal Reserve has been hesitant to knock down those rates for fear of igniting domestic inflationary pressures at home. While the financial markets were most interested in the outcome of the yen talks, the officials could spend more time considering the events unfolding in East Germany and its East-bloc neighbors. It will be the first time the finance ministers and the central bank presidents have met since the political shakeups in the East at the end of last year. Waigel and Karl Otto Poehl, the president of the West German Bundesbank, the central bank, were expected to give details on their plans for creating an economic and monetary union this summer with East Germany. The Bonn government has become embroiled in a controversy over the conversion rate for exchange of the East German currency to the West German mark. The Bundesbank has recommended a rate of one West German mark for each East German mark, with a higher rate for small savings accounts. East Germans have complained that the proposed rate would effectively cut in half their wages, pensions and other savings. No final decision has been announced on the conversion rate. The finance chiefs' agenda also included plans for the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, designed to funnel aid into Eastern Europe, and proposals for increased lending by the International Monetary Fund to poor nations.

DOC.HEAD: Profit-Taking Sends Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures closed lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as profit-taking set in following a strong opening on rumors of a major grain purchase by the Soviet Union. The rumors of a Soviet grain purchase were never confirmed during the day and traders took the opportunity to cash in on the surge in the market. ``Corn and wheat had been rallying for past two weeks on expectations of a major purchase by the Soviets,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. ``But they sold off with no word of a purchase.'' Wheat prices was getting support from expectations of a weekend freeze in winter wheat crop areas. However, that concern was eased as forecasts indicated the drop in temperatures would not be so severe. Slack export demand for soybeans also weighed on futures. However, concern over the availability of soybeans and soymeal out of Brazil provided some support to prices, Karlin said. At the close; wheat was 2{ cents to 4} cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.65\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 2\ cents lower with May at $2.69{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents lower with May at $1.51} a bushel; soybeans were a \ cent to 3{ cents lower with May at $5.95 cents a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Ronald Davis: Handling Perrier's Crisis
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Importer Ronald V. Davis has adopted the market revival of Perrier sparkling water as a personal mission. ``I feel like my family has been attacked,'' said the 43-year-old father of two teen-agers in describing his emotional reaction to the worst problem he's faced in two decades in the beverage business. Davis, president and chief executive of Perrier Group of America Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., felt a misstep in handling Perrier's contamination crisis could damage the French brand's image for decades. But he relied on instinct and the advice of longtime colleagues in ordering the recall Feb. 9 of every Perrier bottle in the United States. The government had alerted the company that several bottles of Perrier in North Carolina were found to have trace amounts of benzene, a dangerous chemical. ``You can't be trained for an event like this,'' he said. When specially marked Perrier is returned to American stores, bars and restaurants in a few weeks, Davis hopes customers will respond by restoring Perrier to its former stature as the nation's best-selling imported water. ``The big red flag that seemed about to go up and wave and kill the cachet of the brand never went up, and Davis is responsible for that,'' said Tom Pirko, president of the beverage consultant BevMark Inc. of Los Angeles. Pirko initially expected Perrier's share of the $2.2 billion U.S. bottled water market would drop 10 to 15 percent in the aftermath of the contamination and recall. But he says now ``the damage is going to be very minor'' and pent-up demand could make the brand stronger than ever. Critics said Davis was not quick enough in explaining to consumers directly through advertising rather than through news media briefings how the Perrier bottles became contaminated. A half-dozen lawsuits have been filed against the company alleging that the product has been misrepresented as pure. Davis said the company acted responsibly in reaction to the crisis and that the lawsuits are groundless. He said he ordered the recall voluntarily after independent laboratory analyses indicated the contamination was not confined to a single batch of Perrier or a single part of the country. Source Perrier SA, the French bottler which owns 53 percent of privately held Perrier Group, initially blamed a worker's improper use of a cleaning solvent containing benzene for the contamination. But the contamination was later traced to the gas reservoir that lies beneath the spring from which Perrier is drawn in Vergezes. While the water was pure, Source Perrier discovered benzene occurs in small amounts in the gas and a filter failed to screen it out before bottling. The company said it took steps to monitor and replace filters more often so the contamination will not happen again. In a recent interview, Davis was unable to cite anything in his professional career that includes nearly 10 years in General Foods' beverage division that compared with the stresses of the contamination incident. Davis lives with his wife, son and daughter in Greenwich, an affluent New York suburb. He was born Jan. 26, 1947 and grew up near Los Angeles where a dispenser of Arrowhead bottled water _ now one of Perrier Group's brands _ was a fixture in his house. After college, Davis joined General Foods and worked on the Country Time lemonade brand. He moved to Perrier Group in 1979, intent on expanding its business which amounted to $20 million in annual sales and one brand, Perrier. Davis became president and chief executive the next year, and the company has grown to $640 million in annual sales and nine brands. A marathon runner and an avid golfer who regularly shoots in the 70s, Davis is described as competitive. ``He hates to lose whether we are playing gin rummy or are on the golf course even if its only $1 at stake,'' said Louis A. Matagrano, head of a beverage distributorship that has handled Perrier for 10 years in San Mateo County south of San Francisco. Davis said he became aware of reports from North Carolina that a private laboratory had discovered bottles of Perrier were contaminated on Feb. 6. The company gets calls ``15 to 18 times a year from someone saying they have found something'' that usually prove groundless, he said. But over the next three days, both the federal government and the company's independent tests disclosed trace amounts of benzene in Perrier bottles selected randomly in various regions. Davis said he was assured the benzene levels posed no safety or health hazard, and the government was not demanding any action. But he said it was clear on Friday, Feb. 9, what should be done. After all, the product's ad theme was ``It's perfect. It's Perrier.'' Kim Jeffery, the former Pepsi-Cola Co. executive who is Davis' top marketing ally, suggested the recall in a conference call that Friday as he and Davis talked to Frederik Zimmer, managing director of Source Perrier, in France. Davis said they instantly agreed. ``We could have sat there and agonized but that didn't happen. It was like all three of us were together,'' he said. He said expense was not an issue. Reclaiming the 70 million bottles cost about $30 million alone. ``When a product's whole reason for being is quality and purity, the costs of not doing what we did would have been borne for the next 100 years,'' Davis said. The recall was announced Friday afternoon. Perrier's 178 distributors were told by telephone and fax they were not to load the trucks on Monday. On Saturday, packages were sent to distributors by courier telling them to collect all the bottles and outlining reimbursement procedures. Davis held a news conference. A toll-free telephone line for consumers was activated Sunday. On Monday, Davis went to France where it took three days to pinpoint the cause. He talked by phone with James Burke, who guided Johnson & Johnson through two Tylenol poisonings in the 1980s. Burke's advice: ``Be straight.'' The next week, Perrier hired Burson-Marsteller, the communications company they worked on the Tylenol case. By March 6, the recall was virtually complete and Davis announced plans to relaunch ther brand by summer. It ran a full-page ad in 22 major newspapers admitting a ``mistake'' that it said was ``identified and corrected.'' BevMark's Pirko said Perrier evidently will not suffer from the disclosure that benzene is present in the gas reservoir used to make the water fizzy. ``The harpoon that could have stuck went whizzing by,'' he said. Industry executives applaud Davis. ``I have enormous respect for what he did considering what little he knew about it when he made his decision,'' said Jack West, owner of Puro Corp., a water company serving offices in metropolitan New York.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed-Rate Home Mortgages Averaging 10.26 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are currently averaging 10.26 percent, up from 10.22 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, unchanged from the week before.

DOC.HEAD: Fisher-Price Offers Modifications For 20,000 Defective Child Seats
DOC.TEXT: Fisher-Price on Friday announced that 20,000 of its child car seats made since Feb. 1 could break during a crash and offered free repair kits so consumers can fix the problem. A faulty die that weakened a metal part was discovered during tests, said company spokeswoman Carol Blackley. The repair kit includes a new part and tools with which to install it. The problem affects, at most, one-fifth of the child seats made between Feb. 1 and April 1, Blackley said. She said consumers should call Fisher-Price to inquire whether their seat is one of the defective ones and to order a repair kit if so. Seats should not be returned to the store, Blackley said. The seat can be used before the repair kit arrives if it is used in the ``rear-facing position,'' for infants weighing less than 20 pounds, but should not be used for larger children until it is fixed, she said. Blackley refused to say how much the repair kits would cost Fisher-Price, but said it would have a minimal financial effect on the company. Last year, Fisher-Price sent out repair kits for 1.5 million of the child safety seats because they did not meet federal flammability standards.

DOC.HEAD: Champion Consolidating Plants
DOC.TEXT: Champion Spark Plug Co. said Friday it would consolidate its U.S. operations by closing two plants because of less demand for spark plugs. The move will affect 675 salaried and hourly workers _ 245 in Detroit and 430 in Toledo. The two plants will be phased out over the next two years. Production will be integrated into the company's Burlington, Iowa, and Cambridge, Ohio, operations. Champion employs 10,000 people worldwide. ``Judging from the factors that exist today, it's not only inevitable, it's the right thing to do,'' William Basedow, director of employee relations, said at a news conference. Company officials and representatives of the United Auto Workers union are to meet regarding how the timing of the consolidation will affect production and maintenance employees. Company officials said new jobs in Burlington and Cambridge would be created. ``Champion has been struggling for several years with an overcapacity of production facilities, while at the same time selling a product _ spark plugs _ whose overall market has declined,'' said Jerry Godwin, Champion president. Champion plants in Toledo produce spark plug shells and assemble the final spark plugs. The Detroit plant manufactures ceramic insulation used in the plug. Champion is a division of Houston-based Cooper Industries Inc., which bought the company last year for $707 million. Basedow said Champion's plans have nothing to do with the sale, saying the company had to streamline to remain competitive. ``The prior management had a similar study and came to much the same conclusions that we have. ... Had these factors been in place in 1988, 1989, they would have done the same thing,'' he said. Basedow said the declining spark plug market was caused by a reduction in the number of cylinders in automobiles because of smaller engines; improvements in the ignition systems on most vehicles and in the spark plugs themselves, resulting in longer life; and unleaded fuel, which does not damage spark plugs as does leaded fuel. Foreign spark plugs entering the country as original equipment in imported cars also contributed to falling demand.

DOC.HEAD: Ford of Canada Shuts Plant for a Week
DOC.TEXT: Ford of Canada announced Friday it would shut its Oakville assembly plant west of Toronto next week, resulting in 2,200 layoffs. Spokesman Jim Hartford said inventories of the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz which the plant builds had grown too high. About 80 percent of the plant's cars are shipped to the United States. It is the second time the Oakville plant has shut down this year because of slumping sales. It closed for a week in early February. In the United States this week, Ford extended until Thursday the shutdown of its Dearborn, Mich., assembly plant, which stopped producing the Mustang April 9 because of slow dealer orders.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Bailout Costs Could Soar to Half a Trillion Dollars, GAO Says
DOC.TEXT: The price tag on the savings and loan bailout could hit a mind-boggling $500 billion if the economy falters, congressional auditors said Friday in their bleakest assessment of the thrift crisis yet. The General Accounting Office said it would cost the government at least $325 billion to close or sell failed savings institutions. That's greater than the Pentagon's annual budget. But even the new projection, a sharp 26 percent higher than the $257 billion estimate offered by the GAO only five months ago, is optimistic, said Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who heads the GAO. ``It could easily become a $400 billion problem and it might even hit as high as $500 billion, or half a trillion dollars, if you get the economy working against you,'' Bowsher told the Senate Banking Committee. His testimony at a sparsely attended hearing challenged the Bush administration's contention that regulators have enough money for now and a reassessment can wait until after this year's congressional elections. Bowsher called on Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman, who is administering the bailout, to ``develop proposals to provide the additional funds.'' Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., the committee chairman, said he would ask the administration to respond at a hearing next month. This ``devastating statement'' from the GAO ``should be a call to arms for all people involved, from the administration, to Congress to the industry,'' said Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla. In past appearances before congressional committees, Seidman has conceded that last year's bailout probably is underfunded. The administration, however, has suggested it could get by through early appropriation of about $30 billion intended for S&L failures after 1992. Michael Boskin, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, declined to comment on the report but promised, ``We'll analyze it in detail.'' The GAO's new estimate includes interest payments spread over 40 years, but the bulk of the $325 billion will be needed during the 1990s. Taxpayers will have to pick up most of the $68 billion increase, Bowsher said. That likely would push their share of the total above $200 billion, with the S&L industry paying the rest. ``We are looking here at a huge, huge number as far as what the American taxpayer is going to have to pay,'' he said. The administration had planned to spend $50 billion to cover losses in S&Ls that fail through 1992, but Bowsher said it would need at least $13 billion more. The GAO chief said the government also will have to spend $5 billion more than anticipated on interest to borrow the $50 billion; $10 billion more for administrative expenses at the bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp.; and $28 billion more for interest on money the RTC is borrowing temporarily until it can sell the assets from failed thrifts. Additionally, Bowsher said, the government will need $12 billion more than earlier projections to meet its obligations through 1999 under the more than 200 S&L rescue deals concluded in 1988. That will cost $68 billion rather than $56 billion, he said. Bowsher blamed the overall shortfall in part on the government's slow start in closing and selling failed S&Ls. Over the past 14 months, regulators have seized 403 institutions but disposed of only 52. Still-open failed S&Ls under government control or targeted for takeover are losing $29 million a day on their operations. ``It is imperative that RTC begin to quickly resolve troubled institutions to minimize the ultimate costs,'' Bowsher said. Seidman, who also serves as chairman of the RTC, has announced plans to sharply accelerate the bailout pace, closing or rescuing 140 institutions by the end of June. Riegle, Graham and Pressler were the only senators on the 21-member committee who showed up to hear the bad news. Many of the others had already left Washington to start the Easter recess in their home states. On another matter, GAO officials said it was too soon to say if the insurance fund backing commercial bank deposits was in trouble. But, Robert Gramling, GAO director of accounting and financial management, said auditors were very concerned about banks struggling with a real estate slowdown in the Northeast. ``I don't see the (FDIC) fund in a growth pattern,'' he said. A GAO audit of the fund, which has lost money in the last two years, will be issued in June.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 431.79 down 1.63 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arbitragers Convicted of Insider Trading In Yuppie Five-Related Case
DOC.NOTE: EDS: grafs 1-6 NEW to UPDATE with appeal planned, comment; uppicks 7th graf pvs: U.S. District ...
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Friday convicted two Wall Street arbitragers on insider trading, fraud and other and counts linked to the so-called ``Yuppie Five'' scandal, capping a 12-week trial. Victor Teicher and Ross Frankel both plan to appeal, a defense attorney said. Teicher, 38, who headed the arbitrage firm Teicher & Co., faces a maximum 60-year prison term and fines that could total $3 million. Teicher's firm faces a $500,000 fine, according to assistant U.S. attorney Carl H. Loewenson. Frankel, 33, former head of arbitrage research at now-defunct investment house Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. He could receive as much as 30 years in jail and a $1.5 million fine. The verdict ends five days of jury deliberations over a case stemming from the ``Yuppie Five'' insider trading case. Four young Wall Street professionals and a client pleaded guilty in 1986 to making illegal stock trades based on inside information about corporate takeovers that they had obtained through their jobs. Teicher and Frankel were convicted of trading the stocks of eight corporations based on stolen information. Loewenson said he did not have a figure for the total profits reaped from their trades. Attorney Robert Morvillo, whose firm represented the pair, said Teicher and Frankel would appeal after sentencing. ``We're disappointed,'' Morvillo said. Teicher and Frankel admitted to trading the stocks of the eight companies in question, but Morvillo said ``they did not trade based on receipt of non-public information.'' U.S. District Judge Charles Haight scheduled Frankel's sentencing for June 18 and Teicher's for June 19. Testifying for the prosecution were two key government witnesses who pled guilty to insider trading charges in 1986. Michael David worked as an attorney in the corporate department of the top New York law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, where he gathered information on clients and passed it along to the defendants. Also testifying against the pair was Robert Salsbury, who worked with Frankel in Drexel's arbitrage department. Teicher and Frankel were accused of executing illegal trades between July 1985 and March 1986 in the stocks of American Brands Inc., Allegheny International Inc., Avondale Mills, American Can Corp., Revco, Westchester Financial Services Corp., Republic Airlines Inc. and Warnaco Inc. Teicher and Frankel were indicted in 1988 along with the trading firm Marcus Schloss & Co. and D. Ronald Yagoda, who headed its arbitrage department. Last July, Schloss became the first specialist firm on the New York Stock Exchange to be found guilty of conspiracy and securities fraud. But the jury acquitted Yagoda of all nine charges against him. Teicher and Frankel have maintained their innocence since their indictment. The jury convicted Teicher of nine counts of securities fraud, two mail fraud charges and one count of conspiracy. Frankel was convicted of one securities fraud count, one conspiracy count, one mail fraud count, one count of perjury and two counts of obstruction of justice. Loewenson had no comment on the verdicts.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Testifies IRS `Destroying People's Lives'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf pvs bg'ng, `The IRS ...' to UPDATE with quote on insurance check. Picks up 10th graf pvs bg'ng, `Mrs. Council's ...'; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: The widow of a businessman who killed himself so his insurance money could finance a battle with the Internal Revenue Service pleaded with Congress Friday to ``control the IRS, to keep it from destroying people's lives.'' ``This kind of thing should never have happened to me and Alex,'' Kay M. Council of High Point, N.C., told the Senate Finance oversight subcommittee. ``We didn't do anything wrong. We just got caught up in the middle of a big IRS screw-up and we couldn't get out of it.'' IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr., who preceded Mrs. Council on the witness stand, was not asked about her case but said his agency in general is making a great deal of progress implementing the 1988 law known as the ``Taxpayer Bill of Rights.'' ``Citizens of this country have more rights today in proceeding against the IRS'' than against any other agency ``and I think that is good,'' Goldberg said. He said employees have been put on notice that ``we need to be attentive to attitudes.'' Nine years after the Councils got into trouble with the IRS by writing off a $70,000 tax-shelter loss, Mrs. Council returned home one night in June 1988 to find a note from her husband: ``My dearest Kay _ I have taken my life in order to provide capital for you. The IRS and its liens which have been taken against our property illegally by a runaway agency of our government have dried up all sources of credit for us. So I have made the only decision I can. It's purely a business decision .... You will find my body on the lot on the north side of the house.'' Mrs. Council, 48, eventually won a federal court ruling that she and her husband owed the IRS nothing, not the $300,000 in taxes, interest and penalties the IRS claimed. The court held the IRS deficiency notice was sent four months after the statute of limitations had expired. The IRS apparently had misaddressed an earlier notice. By the time the dispute was decided by the courts, Mrs. Council had sold her home and paid $70,000 in legal fees, her credit rating was ruined and, as she put it, ``I was cheated of growing old with the man I love.'' She said the poor have little chance of fighting the bureaucracy. ``I don't think I would have ever gotten into a courtroom if my attorneys hadn't known that I had $250,000 from Alex's life insurance,'' she said. Mrs. Council's story highlighted a hearing on how the IRS has responded to the 1988 law aimed at protecting rights of citizens involved in disputes with the tax agency. She has refused to waive her privacy rights, blocking the IRS from commenting on any part of her tax history. IRS Commissioner Goldberg said the tax agency is doing well in implementing the law that requires that taxpayers be notified of their rights; requires the agency to give earlier notice before imposing a lien on property, and demands that notices of additional taxes owed spell out such claims in clear language. ``What the American public resents is complexity, uncertainty ... hassles with the IRS that take month after month after month to resolve,'' Goldberg said. Goldberg adamantly denied that the IRS has a quota system for rewarding employees on the basis of how much they collect. He called reprehensible a ``snitch'' scheme reported to the subcommittee in which the IRS supposedly would reduce the taxes of any business that turned in competitors who were cheating. ``It shouldn't be happening,'' Goldberg said. ``If it is, we'd like to know about it and will put a stop to it today.'' David Keating, executive vice president of the National Taxpayers Union, said that in the fight for taxpayer rights, ``much progress has been made but more legal protections are necessary.'' He said that even if the new law had been in effect for the Councils to use, it probably would not have helped. The provision allows a taxpayer to sue for damages if the IRS has recklessly or intentionally disregarded any tax law. But Congress dropped from the original draft similar recourse in case of careless action by the IRS. Reckless and intentional treatment ``is a very difficult standard to prove,'' he said. Mrs. Council said she had thought that beating the IRS in court ``would give some meaning to Alex's death, but it hasn't. ... There has to be something done to control the IRS, to keep it from destroying people's lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Copper Surge As Peru Strike Continues
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures rallied sharply Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange on concerns over the continued strike at mines in Peru and declining supplies, but profit-taking trimmed prices near the close of trading. On other markets, precious metals were higher, grain and soybeans declined, livestock surged and pork prices declined, and oil prices were mixed. Copper settled 1.60 cents to 2.55 cents higher with the contract for delivery in April at $1.245 a pound. Copper prices surged 420 points in early trading on the Comex before gains were trimmed by half to settle 255 to 160 points higher. Analyst Jim Steel of Refco Inc. in New York said the rally stemmed from short covering _ the buying of contracts to fulfill obligations made by selling borrowed contracts earlier _ by traders following Thursday's selloff. He said the selloff was prompted by reports the strike was over, but the fresh indications that the mines were still shut alarmed the market. However, Steel said, belief the strike was winding down caused prices to retreat near the close of trading. Steel said the price surge also was helped by feelings that copper stocks in London Metal Exchange warehouses had declined. Precious metals futures rose in trading on the Comex. Gold prices surged following the release of employment figures by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics that showed a minor increase in the number of jobs created and a decline of jobs in the manufacturing sector. Steel called the employment figures disappointing and said they could result in lower interest rates and weakening of the dollar, which he says would be good for gold. Gold was $5.90 higher with April at $380.75 a troy ounce; silver was 2.1 cents to 2.1 cents higher with May at $5.19 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as profit-taking set in following a strong opening on rumors of a major grain purchase by the Soviet Union. The rumors of a Soviet grain purchase never were confirmed during the day and traders took the opportunity to cash in on the market's surge. After the close of trading, the U.S. Agriculture Department reported the sale of 750,000 metric tons of corn to the USSR Wheat prices was getting support from expectations of a weekend freeze in winter wheat crop areas. However, that concern was eased as forecasts indicated the drop in temperatures would not be as severe as previously expected. Slack export demand for soybeans also weighed on futures. However, concern over the availability of soybeans and soymeal out of Brazil provided some support to prices, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Wheat was 2{ cents to 4} cents lower with May at $3.65\ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2\ cents lower with May at $2.69\ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents lower with May at $1.51} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3{ cents lower with May at $5.95{ cents a bushel. Livestock futures were higher and pork futures lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Profit taking weighed heavily on pork, following a price rally during the week after a U.S. Agriculture Department report that hog production would decline this week. Livestock prices rose in expectation of higher prices and increased demand. Live cattle were .20 cent to .80 cent higher with April at 79.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .80 cent higher with April at 83.60 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .20 cent higher with April at 54.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .70 cent to 1.10 cents lower with May at 54.47 cents a pound. Energy prices were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with crude oil prices pushed lower by high stocks. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 28 cents lower to 3 cents higher with May at $19.15 a barrel; heating oil was .12 cents to 29 cents higher with May at 53.60 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent to 1.18 cents lower with May at 62.11 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower

DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended the week slightly lower in subdued dealings Friday as traders moved to the sidelines ahead of a weekend meeting of world finance ministers. Gold prices were sharply higher in the United States after posting modest gains overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $380.70 a troy ounce, up $5.90 from late Thursday. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $380.50 an ounce, up $5.50. Currency trading was uneventful. Dealers were reluctant to do much ahead of the Group of Seven finance ministers' meeting in Paris over the weekend. Officials from the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada will gather to discuss international exchange rates. ``We've had last-minute position-squaring before the G-7'' meeting, said David Ogg, a vice president at Credit Suisse in New York. Otherwise, ``volume was slower than it has been.'' The dollar moved in a narrow range. The U.S. currency edged lower in early domestic dealings following the goverment's release of a smaller-than-expected increase in non-farm payrolls. The dollar then rose briefly on a rumor of a nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union. The Soviets dismissed the talk as unfounded. The British pound fell on news that Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's popularity continues to slide. A Gallup poll published Friday showed that the Labor party had the support of 53 percent of those polled, leading the Conservative party by 25 points. In London, the pound dropped to $1.6385 from $1.6427 late Thursday. But in New York, one pound cost $1.6425, slightly more expensive than Thursday's $1.6420. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 157.47 Japanese yen from 157.90 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it slipped further to 157.45 yen. In New York, however, the dollar rose to 157.70 yen from 157.50 yen on Thursday. DOC.HEAD: For Drexel's First Junk Bond Client, Collapse, Survival, Charges
Graphic in AP Access under TEXASINTL
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In 1977, a second-tier Wall Street firm named Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. issued $30 million in curious IOUs called high-yield bonds to help finance the growth of an oil company, Texas International Co. The deal marked the start of the Drexel era _ a corporate cattle rush that raised billions of dollars for American businesses through risky paper that earned the nickname ``junk.'' Investigators say Drexel's brash behavior also helped spawn criminal dealings that sullied Wall Street in the 1980s. Thirteen years after the tiny junk-bond deal, Drexel is going out of business. Texas International emerges from bankruptcy court Monday after plunging to a disaster fueled by heavy debts and an oil bust. The relationship between the giant New York investment house and the Oklahoma City oil driller in many ways tells Drexel's story. Drexel provided the means to grow, temporarily saved the company when times soured and now is accused of ripping it off along the way. A report in federal bankruptcy court alleges that Drexel sapped Texas International by trading on inside information, secretly ``parking'' bonds with a scandalous thrift and charging $3 million to create a tax shelter for its own holdings. The 53-page report by a lawyer for Texas International's stockholders committee, unsealed following a request by The Associated Press, portrays Drexel as hellbent to make as much money as possible at its client's expense while serving as financial adviser from 1985 to 1987. While Drexel legitimately raised capital for scores of companies seeking to grow _ many of whom still sing Drexel's praises _ the Texas International report supports a darker view of the investment firm's legacy to the takeover-frenzied '80s. ``There will be the continuing perception that in the pursuit of a brilliant idea Drexel went too far,'' said Samuel L. Hayes III, an investment banking professor at Harvard Business School. ``They were street-smart people,'' he said. ``They smelled an opportunity and moved very aggressively to exploit it. ... They may have carried it to the nth degree, but that's certainly not out of character for an investment bank.'' Drexel last year admitted to running an illicit trading network prosecutors say was directed by junk-bond innovator Michael Milken. The firm pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million in fines and restitution. Milken, who says he's innocent, has been indicted but no trial date is set. Drexel was accused of lawbreaking in about 20 deals. Texas International was not one of them, and federal law enforcers decline to say whether they even investigated it. The report unsealed by the bankruptcy court nevertheless alleges a variety of improprieties and blames Drexel for making Texas International's problems worse. Seeking to invalidate Drexel's $14 million claim as a creditor, the shareholders committee says Drexel deliberately structured deals to fail so it could generate more business. From 1978 to 1983, Drexel issued about $150 million in high-yield bonds for Texas International, which used the money to expand operations by drilling for deep natural gas in Texas and Louisiana. In taking on the debt, which wasn't limited to financing by Drexel, the company counted on rising oil prices, but they collapsed in 1986. Texas International's stock fell from $27 to $1. On the brink of default, the company hired Drexel to restructure its debt by lowering payments, delaying due dates and substituting stock for some of its bonds. In three deals, Drexel refinanced $389 million of Texas International debt. The investment firm pioneered so-called debt exchange offers, and Texas International acknowledges the arrangements staved off a bankruptcy filing. But only temporarily. Crushed by the burden, Texas International in 1987 sold key oil fields in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahomafor $120 million to make interest payments, laying off hundreds of workers. Still failing, the company sought bankruptcy court protection from creditors in April 1988. The shareholders report was written by Benjamin Waisbren, a Milwaukee attorney, based on Drexel trading records and other company documents a federal judge ordered Drexel to surrender. Waisbren filed the report last November but asked the court not to make it public, apparently to try to pressure Drexel to drop its claim as a creditor. Drexel, whose parent sought bankruptcy court protection in February, did not contest unsealing the report, nor has it dropped its claim against Texas International. The report says that because Drexel bought so much of the company's stock and bonds, it blurred the line between paid adviser and interested party. The committee alleges possibly illegal ``parking'' with Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of California, a collapsed thrift now under federal investigation that bought hundreds of millions of Drexel-issued bonds. Parking refers to placing securities in another party's name to avoid disclosing ownership to the government. The report also claims Drexel used inside information about the debt exchanges to profit by trading Texas International stock; billed the company $3.2 million to set up a tax shelter for interest income from Drexel junk-bond holdings; and charged nearly $4 million for financial advice it never gave. Drexel denies the claims. ``On each occasion where we acted as financial adviser on exchange offers for Texas International, strong economic benefits were produced for the company,'' Drexel said in a statement. ``Based on everything we know, the allegations of the equity committee are groundless.'' The claims were not made by a federal law enforcement agency and carry no more weight than a civil lawsuit. But they mirror the kinds of allegations that have dogged Drexel for years. The common defense among former Drexel employees is that Wall Street resented the upstart investment house for creating a wildly successful product and siphoning business from established ``white-shoe'' firms. ``People that couldn't compete just couldn't take it,'' said a longtime executive in Drexel's junk-bond department, based in Beverly Hills, Calif. To be sure, Drexel's crimes and reputation don't tell the whole story. Drexel lent money to Chrysler Corp. when no one else would; helped Mattel Corp. avert bankruptcy; gave MCI Communications Corp. the power to become a telephone giant. ``The people we dealt with at Drexel were very creative, very bright, extremely diligent,'' said Robert Herndon, chief financial officer of Pier 1 Imports Inc., which hired Drexel for debt offerings in 1987 and 1988. ``I think the country has lost something,'' he said. ``Drexel had a great idea in assisting low investment-grade companies to have access to money that was otherwise not available.'' But the Texas International report details a different Drexel _ similar to the one depicted by federal prosecutors _ a firm that abused securities laws, arm-twisted clients and manipulated a network of junk-bond buyers. The government's investigation showed ``there wasn't anybody they wouldn't cheat if the occasion called for it,'' said Bruce Baird, who ran the U.S. Attorney's Office securities fraud division during the Drexel case and now is in private practice. ``It was sort of the excesses of the '80s personified,'' he said.
