DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Most energy futures weakened again Friday, finishing the week on a negative note amid concerns about abundant supplies. Gasoline futures posted the sharpest declines on the New York Mercantile Exchange as they did on Thursday. But wholesale home heating oil bucked the trend and regained some ground. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline settled 1.18 cents lower at 62.11 cents a gallon, after Thursday's drop of 1.57 cents. The June contract also shed more than a penny a gallon while more distant months ended with lesser losses. The May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, settled at $19.15 per 42-gallon barrel, down 28 cents. Later contracts finished with similar losses. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, May home heating oil added 0.40 cent to 53.71 cents a gallon, erasing a portion of Thursday's loss of 0.71 cent. Later contracts also settled higher. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.625 per million British thermal units, up from $1.615 on Thursday. Contracts for delivery further in the future were mixed. Natural gas futures made their Merc debut earlier this week. Analysts said a bearish attitude developed in the energy market late Tuesday after the American Petroleum Institute issued a weekly report showing large crude stocks. Madison Galbraith, an oil specialist at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, said the selling sparked by the API figures pushed prices below thresholds considered technically significant. ``The Tuesday night announcement by the API set a bearish tone that led to a technical breakdown,'' he said. The drop below $20 a barrel for the nearby crude contract earlier in the week helped cause the market's overall slump.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Announces Merger Agreement With Novell
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp. and Novell Inc. agreed to merge their computer software companies Friday, a move that could give Lotus a leading edge in the software industry. The companies signed a letter of intent under which Novell would become a subsidiary of Lotus after the stock-swap merger. No cash would change hands. ``The primary reason for the merger is we were two companies both leading in our prospective markets, and we figured we could do better things for our customers if we got together,'' said Jim Manzi, chairman, chief executive officer and president of Lotus. ``We're sort of perfectly complementary.'' The agreement is subject to the approval of the boards of directors and stockholders of both companies, in addition to standard regulatory approvals, the companies said. The merger is expected to be completed by July. Under the agreement, Lotus would swap 1.91931 shares of Lotus common stock for each share of Novell common stock. Lotus would issue about 41.6 million new shares to carry out the transaction. Novell was worth a total of about $1.3 billion at end of trading Friday, while Lotus was worth $1.5 billion, making the merger worth $2.8 billion, said David Bayer, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. Investors did not cheer the announcement. Lotus shares closed Friday at $34.25, down $2 a share, in national over-the-counter trading. Novell closed at $38.75, down $4.12{, on the same market. Both Lotus and Novell said the merger would provide benefits to both companies and their customers. ``The synergy from a customer standpoint, a sales and distribution standpoint and in terms of future product offerings in tremendous,'' said Novell Chairman, President and Chief Executive Ray Noorda in a statement. Manzi said in a telephone interview that the merger would give Lotus better positioning in the software market. ``I think we'll be a stronger competitor. Their leadership in network and our leadership in organization is a real strong combination,'' he said. Lotus had $556 million in revenue for fiscal year 1989, while Novell posted $422 million in revenue. Cambridge-based Lotus is a leading producer of business software, based primarily on its popular 1-2-3 spreadsheet program. It recently expanded 1-2-3 from its original version for International Business Machine Corp.'s personal computers to versions for computers made by other manufacturers. Lotus was ranked No. 3 in revenue of software companies last year, behind No. 2 Microsoft Corp. and Computer Associates International Inc., according to Software Magazine. Novell, based in Provo, Utah, makes software used to link computers in networks for business-related tasks. Noorda would keep his positions with Novell and also become the vice chairman of Lotus under the plan. ``We view this as a marriage or merger of equals,'' Manzi said. Nancy McSharry, an analyst who follows Lotus for International Data Corp., said the merger would shake up the industry power structure. ``Before, on the top was Microsoft, then there were others. Now, with the merger, it really puts Lotus and Microsoft on the first tier in the industry,'' she said. ``And the first tier is now a far more balanced tier.'' If the new association works, Lotus could assume the No. 1 spot in the industry, McSharry said. Novell stands to gain from access to Lotus' established worldwide market. ``We get about 45 percent of our business offshore, and last year (Novell) had 38 or 40 percent offshore. We're a little bit stronger offshore, particularly in Japan, and they're just getting started there,'' Manzi said. Manzi said customers also will benefit from the merger. ``Novell is most successful in their field, and we are leaders in ours. So if you can bring them together in the fold of things its better for the customers,'' Manzi said. McSharry agreed with Manzi. ``In the short-term, it won't change the service provided to the customers. But in the long-term, it significantly changes the offerings,'' McSharry said. ``You'll see more industrywide software. There'll be more emphasis on group (networked) software.''

DOC.HEAD: Gerber Resumes Production of Special Formula for One Boy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to ADD that Gerber providing food free of charge; picks up 3rd graf pvs bg'ng, ``People here ...; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY37
DOC.TEXT: A Gerber Products Co. research plant is retooling to resume production for a market of one: a profoundly allergic 15-year-old boy who cannot live without a special baby formula the company stopped making five years ago. For a few days this month, one quarter of the production space at the Gerber research center in Fremont, Mich., will be devoted to making MBF, a formula only Raymond Dunn Jr. wants or needs and which Gerber is providing free of charge. ``People here are working on this on their own time,'' George Purvis, Gerber research director, said Thursday. ``We all have our own jobs, and this is one we added on. ``I don't want to talk too much about it,'' he added. ``It's just something we can do, so we're doing it. It's a volunteer project. The Dunns have nowhere else to turn.'' Raymond, who lives with his parents in the Catskills town of Yankee Lake, weighs only 31 pounds. He was born with an abnormally small head and brain. He is severely physically and mentally retarded, and cannot speak or see. He cannot move his thin arms or tiny legs without help. His warped little spine has worn a dent in the pad of his wheelchair. And, since the age of 5, Raymond has been allergic to almost every form of nourishment. All that kept him alive was Gerber's MBF, an expensive, meat-based formula for allergic infants. But in 1985, faced with declining sales, Gerber stopped making the brown liquid formula. The Dunns tried dozens of alternatives, but they all made Raymond sick. Gerber agreed to reveal its formula and process for making MBF to any manufacturer who would supply Raymond, but none was willing or able. So, Purvis said, ``We scrounged around for every can of the stuff that was in existence,'' including many whose expiration date had passed. After obtaining a Food and Drug Administration waiver, Gerber began delivering them to the Dunns. The unsold backlog prolonged Raymond's life, but didn't make it easier. Asthma kept him inside the house almost all the time. His mother and her helpers had to brush his teeth, bathe and dress him. To maintain his sense of touch, they ran his fingers through dry rice and beans. He slept in a small bed in his parents' room, but rarely for more than a few hours at a time. ``The little guy's been a 24-hour-a-day thing for the past 16 years,'' said his father, Raymond Sr., a car salesman. The Dunns have no other children. It seemed life couldn't get any more difficult until the day in July 1988 when Dunn's wife, Carol, got a letter from Gerber. The company said its MBF was all gone, leaving Raymond with less than a two years' supply. His mother, whose life already was totally consumed by his care, sought help in dozens of letters to political and business leaders, including President Bush, Donald Trump and the Princess of Wales. But Gerber seemed her only hope. ``I believed they wouldn't let me down because there's human beings in that corporation,'' she said. ``I felt that, somehow, that Gerber would not let Raymond die.'' Apparently she was right. Gerber employees who had been working with Mrs. Dunn told their bosses they could assemble the equipment and special ingredients (including beef hearts) to make a limited amount of MBF. Soon the project will fill about 6,000 of the plant's 25,000 square feet of production space. Other projects will be delayed, and the production run will cost Gerber about $15,000. Due to a lack of storage space, Gerber plans to produce only a two years' supply. After that, said Purvis, ``if push comes to shove, we'll do it again.'' Mrs. Dunn, meanwhile, says she understands why Gerber responded to her appeal: ``I'm just a mother trying to feed her son.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Fines Bethlehem Steel $1 Million For Benzene Emissions
DOC.TEXT: The Bethlehem Steel Corp. has been fined $1 million for the continuing discharge of benzene from its coke oven operation near Buffalo, state officials said Thursday. State Environmental Conservation Commissioner Thomas Jorling said the penalty is the largest New York has ever levied for a violation of state air-pollution laws. ``The magnitude of the penalty is justified by the nature and duration of the violations,'' Jorling said. State officials said the Bethlehem process in Lackawanna represents the largest single industrial source of emissions of cancer-linked benzene in New York state. With Thursday's fine, the company has been assessed $1.33 million in civil penalties since a state crackdown on emissions there began in 1984. ``We believe that the company acted improperly in allowing such emissions to continue in spite of state laws designed to protect the air New Yorkers breathe,'' said Jorling. The company discharged 1.5 million pounds of benzene a year since the early 1970s, state officials said. But it was only when a team of Buffalo-based Department of Environmental Conservation investigators suspected the discharge and ran tests in 1987 that the state first uncovered the problem. Jorling said Bethlehem Steel ``knew that its processes emitted significant amounts of benzene,'' releases that were subjct to state air-pollution laws. After a long series of negotiations, Bethlehem Steel signed an order admitting the discharge this week and agreeing to the air pollution treatment terms, state officials said. Bethlehem Steel issued a statement from its headquarters in Bethlehem, Pa., in which it said it agreed to the settlement to avoid protracted litigation. ``It will accelerate further improvement sand result in completion of the environmental improvement program in Lackawanna,'' the statement said. The DEC order would require BethEnergy, the coke-making division of Bethlehem and one of the steel giant's two remaining operations in Lackawanna, to cut emissions by 95 percent. Company officials have said they already made some process changes that they estimte reduced benzene emissions by 30 percent to 50 percent. BethEnergy also was directed to install a closed loop cooling system designed to prevent the benzene emissions. State engineers said the toxic chemical was emitted when water used to cool high-temperature coke oven cases absorbed benzene and then was later released as the water cooled. Benzene is a flammable, poisonous liquid used in paints, dyes, plastics and insecticides. It has been linked to cancer in laboratory tests.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Extends Shutdown of Dearborn Plant for Four Days
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Thursday extended by four days the shutdown of its Dearborn assembly plant, where the company's Mustang cars are made. Ford cited weak dealer orders for the move. Production at the plant stopped last Monday. The shutdown originally was scheduled to last one week. Ford has extended that through April 12. There are about 2,100 hourly workers at the plant, working on two shifts. Production is about 3,700 Mustangs a week.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Unchanged To Slightly Higher in Volatile Session
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished unchanged to slightly higher Friday after a volatile session racked by worse-than-expected employment figures for March and concern over German currency-swap plans. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond closed unchanged from late Thursday at 99.25 while its yield remained at 8.51 percent. Bond prices shot up after the government reported that the growth in non-farm jobs last month was 26,000 _ far lower than estimates of about 175,000. The figures implied that ``the economy really isn't doing as well as we thought,'' said Mike Geraty, a bond trader with Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago. Signs of economic weakness usually boost bond prices since they imply the Federal Reserve may act to ease interest rates. Lower rates boost the value of existing bonds. But bond prices dropped as several news reports reached the market, said Wayne Lyski, portfolio manager for Alliance Capital Management. One report said two unidentified Federal Reserve governors believed economic growth was exceeding target figures, implying they did not believe there was a need to move interest rates lower, Lyski said. Then news reached the market that the West German central bank expressed concern that a proposed 1-for-1 exchange rate between the West German and East German marks would be inflationary and require higher interest rates. Higher interest rates in Germany would make investments there more attractive, making it likely that U.S. interest rates would have to follow suit. The bond market also was jittery over concern about the weekend meeting of leaders from the seven leading industrialized nations, traders said. Lyski said concern centered around whether the officials would move to increase the value of the Japanese yen against the dollar. A strengthened yen would make yen-denominated investments more attractive, putting upward pressure on U.S. interest rates. But after the morning turmoil, the market eased to a near standstill, traders said, and prices returned to levels near Thursday's close. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term government issues rose from 1-32 to 1-16 point, intermediate maturities rose 1-16 point, and long-term issues ranged from unchanged to up 1-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.21 to 1,153.54. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unchanged at 91 15-32. The average yield to maturity remained at 7.51 percent. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 8.01 percent as the discount rose 2 basis points to 7.76 percent. Yields on six-month bills were unchanged at 8.16 percent as the discount remained at 7.74 percent. Yields on one-year bills, which were issued yesterday, fell to 8.25 percent as the discount fell 5 basis points from the auction discount to 7.67 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16, down from 8\ percent late Thursday.

UAL Corp.'s directors agreed to a $4.38 billion buyout by the company's employees, but some analysts doubted the viability of the deal that would make the parent of United Airlines the world's largest worker-owned corporation. The three union groups which negotiated the $201-a-share deal have not yet secured financing for the buyout, a source who was involved in the talks said Friday. Analysts said that weakness could prove fatal. The stock market reflected investor skepticism that the deal will be completed. UAL fell $2 a share to $163.50 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The price tag on the savings and loan bailout could hit $500 billion if the economy falters, congressional auditors said in their bleakest assessment of the thrift crisis yet. The General Accounting Office said Friday it would cost the government at least $325 billion to close or sell failed savings institutions. That's greater than the Pentagon's annual budget. But even the new projection, a sharp 26 percent higher than the $257 billion estimate offered by the GAO only five months ago, is optimistic, said Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who heads the GAO.

Civilian unemployment dipped to 5.2 percent in March, down from 5.3 percent in February and the lowest rate in a year, the government said. But analysts attributed Friday's report more to a statistical quirk than to an economic upswing. Indeed, the Labor Department report said the number of new jobs last month hit a four-year low.

States are in worse financial condition than a year ago, and 21 governors want to remedy the problem with tax increases, a new report said. The report, released Friday by two organizations representing state governments, blamed the fiscal problems on increased spending for Medicaid, education, prisons and transportation. The report was issued by the National Governors' Association and the National Association of State Budget Officers. The groups survey state finances twice a year.

Mesa Limited Partnership pulled its Hugoton Royalty Trust holdings off the market, saying prices were too low to sell the prime properties in the nation's largest natural gas field. Mesa, T. Boone Pickens Jr.'s energy company, said in December it would package its Hugoton holdings into a separate trust and sell shares to raise money to help pay down some of the partnership's $1.5 billion in long-term debt. But it pulled the holdings off the market Friday.

A federal jury convicted two Wall Street arbitragers of insider trading, fraud and other and counts linked to the so-called ``Yuppie Five'' scandal, capping a 12-week trial. But a defense attorney said after Friday's verdict that Victor Teicher and Ross Frankel both plan to appeal. Teicher, 38, headed the arbitrage firm Teicher & Co. Frankel, 33, is former head of arbitrage research at now-defunct investment house Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

The chairman of the Pepper Commission defended its refusal to include recommendations on how to pay the estimated $23 billion cost to provide health insurance for all Americans. Sen. John D. Rockefeller IV told a hearing of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee on Friday that the commission had, in fact, accomplished a great deal by putting a total price tag on its proposals _ $66.6 billion.

The Bush administration said it intends to monitor closely Japan's efforts to implement a historic market-opening trade agreement. President Bush said the American public would be satisfied only with ``concrete results.'' With the ink barely dry on the pact, however, a major Japanese retailers' group vowed Friday to fight a key provision and doubts were voiced by U.S. trade experts over how effective the agreement would be in reducing America's huge $49 billion deficit with Japan.

Fisher-Price announced that 20,000 of its child car seats made since Feb. 1 could break during a crash and offered free repair kits so consumers can fix the problem. A faulty die that weakened a metal part was discovered during tests, company spokeswoman Carol Blackley said Friday. The repair kit includes a new part and tools with which to install it. The problem affects, at most, one-fifth of the child seats made between Feb. 1 and April 1, Blackley said.

Stock prices slipped in quiet trading Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 4.05 to 2,717.12, reducing its gain for the week to 9.91 points. Bond prices finished little changed. The dollar moved slightly lower in foreign exchange. Copper futures rallied sharply; precious metals and livestock rose; grain and pork prices declined and oil prices were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Exchanges' Plan Could Raise Price Tag for Data
DOC.TEXT: Small investors and the media could face higher costs for their daily diet of stock prices under a proposal by the nation's stock exchanges that could lead to new fees for market data. A group of news organizations, discount stock brokerages and database services is challenging the request for a contractual change that could open the door to charges on 15-minute-old stock quotes. Delayed last sale information, as it is called, is now free to vendors, except for transmission costs. The debate on Wall Street and in Washington centers on the ownership of data vital to the functioning of the nation's financial markets. It also raises a First Amendment question: Are stock prices news or just another commodity for sale? Under the present system, charges are applied only to ``real-time'' quotes, which are up-to-the-second prices. Individual investors pay about $13 a month for real-time quotations from the New York Stock Exchange. Institutions can pay up to $120 a month. The stock exchanges say they own the data, real or delayed, and need to recover the costs of compiling and distributing it. Opponents of the proposal by the NYSE and seven other exchanges, pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Friday that delayed-price fees would drive investors who can't afford to pay for real-time data from the markets. They said the 15-minute-old numbers are public property. ``It's like charging for the wrapper on the candy after it's been eaten,'' said Hugo Quackenbush, spokesman for discount broker Charles Schwab & Co. ``The exchanges are in the business of making the financial markets accessible to everybody,'' said John Foley, director of on-line stock trading for discount broker Quick & Reilly. ``Information dissemination is part of that.'' As opponents read it, the proposed contractual change would eliminate the distinction between real-time and delayed data, allowing the stock exchanges to charge for all numbers. But Thomas Haley, the NYSE's vice president for market data, said the exchanges already have the right to charge for delayed data and to alter the definition of delayed data. He called the dispute ``a tempest in a teapot.'' Haley, chairman of the Consolidated Tape Association, which made the proposal, said charging some users for stock-price quotations and giving it away free to others is unfair and should be reconsidered. ``The exchange and the CTA receives nothing, zero, from those organizations for the use of that data,'' he said. ``That operation is being subsidized by all the others who are paying.'' ``How long before you have the folks that are paying say, `I'm paying too much?''' he said. ``You're letting the other group off the hook. There has to be balance here.'' Haley indicated the NYSE and other exchanges would consider various billing schemes that could lead to charging for delayed data or encouraging all users to buy real-time data. Delayed stock prices reach the public in various ways. Individuals with personal computers pay database services for access to quotes. Newspaper stock tables and some television services such as Financial News Network run delayed prices. Discount brokers use 15-minute-old quotes to cut down costs of servicing individual investors. Brokers said they would be forced to pass on a charge for delayed quotes to customers. With the development of lightning-quick transmission capability and competing computer databases in the last decade, more and more businesses are using the stock exchange's free data to make a buck. ``If the NYSE continues to give away ... price dissemination they will at some point enable an electronic competitor to eat their lunch,'' said Eric K. Clemons, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. ``There's a very substantial cost in providing that service.'' Haley said the NYSE has 134 contracts to provide delayed data to vendors, who in turn make it available to an estimated 1.5 million personal users. He said about 200,000 display units have access to real-time data. The Associated Press is one of a dozen groups that have objected to the exchanges' proposal. In additiion to Schwab and Quick & Reilly, others include Financial News Network, Dow Jones & Co., Fidelity Investments and Instinet Corp. For the AP and other media, the debate raises the First Amendment question of whether stock quotations are news or products. ``It's always been our position that all stock information is news that under the First Amendment we have a right to report,'' AP Business News Editor James M. Kennedy said. ``We feel it's in the public domain,'' said Roger May, a spokesman for Dow Jones, which publishes The Wall Street Journal. ``It's in the national interest to put this out to increase the availability of stock-market information.''

DOC.HEAD: Analyst: AT&T To Acquire Stake in Memorex-Telex
DOC.TEXT: AT&T is expected to acquire a minority stake in Memorex-Telex NV, a Dutch-based computer company, and to transfer responsibility for some of its computer line to Memorex-Telex, an industry analyst said Friday. Robert Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research of Phoenix, Ariz., said the companies were expected to announce the deal Friday. However, neither American Telephone & Telgraph Co. nor Memorex-Telex made such an announcement, and neither would comment on the report. Under the reported plan, AT&T would acquire a stake in privately held Memorex-Telex of 5 percent to 10 percent, Djurdjevic said. In exchange, the phone company would receive a seat on Memorex-Telex's board of directors, he said. As part of the deal, AT&T would transfer its line of computers based on IBM's model 3270 machines to Memorex-Telex, Djurdjevic said. Memorex-Telex makes a similar line of computer terminals. Djurdjevic, whose company does research on the computer industry for clients, declined to reveal his sources. He said he could not place a dollar value on the transaction. Memorex-Telex, based in Amsterdam, resulted from the 1987 purchase of Tulsa, Okla.-based Telex Corp., a computer systems maker, by the former Memorex International NV. The company makes a variety of computers and computer products and operates in 27 countries. Memorex-Telex had 1989 sales of $2.24 billion, said Julia C. Gentz, a company spokeswoman in Tulsa. It has about 10,000 employees, including 6,500 in the United States, she said.

DOC.HEAD: GE Files $1.15 Billion Lawsuit Against Daimler-Benz On Jet Engine Contract
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. has filed a $1.15 billion lawsuit against Daimler-Benz of West Germany, claiming that Daimler's new alliance with United Technologies Corp. breached an agreement it already had with GE to develop jet engines. The suit was filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court in New York, just one week after Daimler-Benz announced it had signed a preliminary agreement with UTC to allow their jet engine divisions to operate as a single company on certain ventures. GE claims that Daimler-Benz _ because of its strengthened ties to UTC's Pratt & Whitney division _ could give away GE's jet engine trade secrets to UTC. Pratt & Whitney and GE are fierce competitors in the jet engine business. A UTC spokesman on Friday dismissed assertions that GE trade secrets were jeopardized by the collaboration between Daimler's jet engine division _ Motoren-und Turbinen-Union _ and Pratt & Whitney. ``Neither UTC nor Pratt & Whitney needs, wants or would accept confidential GE information,'' said UTC spokesman Dan Harrison. ``We have complete confidence in the integrity of Daimler-Benz, MTU and its people.'' Daimler-Benz, an aerospace, electronics and auto giant, said it was studying the suit, but at this time saw no grounds for the action. The lawsuit alleges that GE claims that Daimler-Benz and its jet engine division already had a series of binding agreements to work exclusively with GE in developing a new generation of high-thrust commercial jet engines. The suit seeks damages of $1.15 billion and court injunctions to bar Daimler-Benz from using trade secrets or working with any company _ including UTC and Pratt & Whitney _ to develop jet engines that compete directly with engines covered under GE-Daimler-Benz agreements. GE refused to comment on specifics in the lawsuit or on its longstanding business relationship with the Daimler-Benz jet engine division. ``We're letting the (lawsuit) filing stand on its own and speak for itself,'' GE spokesman George Jamison said Friday. Harrison defended the new agreement reached between Hartford-based UTC and Daimler-Benz, calling it a ``logical outgrowth'' of a 20-year association between the two companies. MTU is now participating in three jet engine programs with Pratt & Whitney, and plans additional partnerships under the new alliance. Although the strengthened relationship is not a merger, the agreement means the two companies will act as one in designing, engineering and marketing new engines. In its suit, GE says it has had contracts with MTU for more than 25 years, covering the sharing of confidential technological information, revenues and costs for the development and sale of commercial jet engines. The company estimates that the market for the classes of commercial jet engines named in the suit is between $50 billion and $100 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Penn's Wharton School Names Boston Entrepreneur As New Dean
DOC.TEXT: Thomas P. Gerrity, an information technology specialist and head of a Boston consulting firm, has been named as dean of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of business. Gerrity, 48, will assume the post on July 1, subject to his confirmation by the university's trustees April 20. Gerrity is president of CSC Consulting, which has five divisions, including one in Europe, and employs more than 2,500 people worldwide. He served for four years on the faculty of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, where he pioneered the use of information technology by senior executives, according to Wharton spokeswoman Margaret Barry. ``We are delighted to welcome Tom Gerrity to Penn,'' Penn president Sheldon Hackney said. ``His experience spans both the academic and business communities. As a corporate leader, successful entrepreneur and proven academic, he will provide strong vision and direction to Wharton.'' While at M.I.T., Gerrity founded Index Group, a consulting firm in information technology that is now part of CSC and its parent company, Computer Sciences Corp. Wharton has 177 faculty members, more than 5,000 students and more than 4,000 executives who enroll in the school's education programs each year. Gerrity succeeds Russell E. Palmer, who will step down in June.

DOC.HEAD: Two Big NY Ad Agencies to Open California Offices
DOC.TEXT: Two big New York advertising agencies are opening offices in Southern California, bucking a trend in which some Eastern agencies have pulled out. Lowe Marschalk, which just won a Prudential Insurance account estimated to be worth $60 million a year, plans to open an office in Costa Mesa this month. Young & Rubicam, which recently was awarded a $30 million 20th Century Fox Film Corp. account, will open an office near Fox's Los Angeles operations within a week. Y&R once had an office in Los Angeles but closed it in 1987 after it lost the business for Walt Disney Productions. ``It's bad news for agencies like us,'' said Greg Helm, president of the 18-month-old Los Angeles agency Stein Rorbaire Helm. ``It brings two more agencies into the fray.'' Another Eastern shop, William Esty, moved away in 1987 after losing the Nissan account to Chiat-Day-Mojo. In 1988, less than two years after it opened, Scali, McCabe, Sloves closed its Los Angeles office.

DOC.HEAD: USX Says It Won't Buy Icahn's Stake At Premium
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf `His plan ...' to fix typo in percent.
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. said it won't pay Carl Icahn a premium price for his 13.29 percent stake in an effort to stop his plan to break up the steel and energy company. ``We do not pay greenmail and we won't ever pay greenmail,'' USX Chairman Charles A. Corry said Thursday. ``We do occasionally buy stock back through third parties, although we don't always know who we are buying it from.'' USX would be willing to buy some or all of Icahn's 34 million shares ``at market value or below,'' spokesman William Keslar said. USX shares closed at $36.37{ Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange, down 12{ cents. Corry said Icahn purchased about 30 million of his shares for ``somewhere between $22 and $23'' starting in 1986. He bought about 4 million more shares last fall at ``about $36 a share,'' Corry said. Telephone calls to Icahn's Mount Kisco, N.Y., office were not answered late Thursday. In a letter to USX stockholders earlier this week, Icahn said his plan to break up USX would be worth $48 a share to stockholders. His plan calls for spinning off the company's U.S. Steel division, giving current USX holders 80 percent of the shares and selling the remaining 20 percent to new investors. USX would retain its energy assets, primarily Marathon Oil Co. Icahn estimated the value of Marathon at $39 a share and the value of the steel operations at $9 a share. Keslar said Icahn's estimate doesn't account for current cash flow or earnings potential. ``It's an arbitrary figure made up of two arbitrary figures,'' Keslar said. Corry said about 65 percent of USX's revenue comes from energy and 31 percent comes from steel. USX has opposed Icahn's proposal, saying it would cause tax difficulties and make the separate divisions more vulnerable to slumps in either the energy or steel markets. USX shareholders will vote on Icahn's propsal in a non-binding ballot May 7 at Marathon's headquarters in Findlay, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Windmere Wins $100 Million Judgment Against Philips
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Friday awarded about $100 million to Windmere Corp. in an antitrust suit charging that the Dutch company NV Philips had monopolized the rotary shaver market. The verdict came in a counterclaim by Windmere against Philips and its subsidiary North American Philips Co., makers of the Norelco shaver. Philips had initially filed suit in the case against Windmere, charging unfair competition. The jury cleared Windmere on that charge, accepting the Miami Lakes company's contention that Philips had attempted to monopolize the market through predatory pricing in violation of the Sherman Act. ``We're very pleased with the jury's verdict,'' said David Friedson, president and chief executive officer of Windmere. ``We're going to have a good party.'' . The jury awarded Windmere $29.8 million, which is trebled automatically under the Sherman Act to $89.6 million. The jury also awarded reasonable attorneys' fees, interests and costs, bringing the estimated total to more than $100 million, according to Windmere attorneys. ``The rotary shaver war was started by Philips in 1984 as part of an attempt to drive Windmere out of the rotary business,'' said Gary Hoffman, an attorney for Windmere. ``The $87 million verdict gives Windmere the funds that it needs to re-enter the markets and provide effective competition against the Philips companies.'' Hoffman said Philips controls about 95 percent of the $165 million rotary shaver market. Windmere attorney Gary Jones said the appeals process would likely hold up payment of the award until mid-1991, but he said the company is confident the jury's verdict would be upheld. The case was first filed in Washington, D.C., in 1984, and a jury found in favor of Windmere on the monopolization issue while a judge directed a guilty verdict against Windmere in the unfair competition provision. The verdicts were overturned on appeal, however, and retried in Miami. The decision Friday capped a four-week trial before U.S. District Judge Stanley Marcus. Hoffman, who also represents Sears, Roebuck & Co. in a similar suit filed by Philips, said he will ask for a summary judgment against Philips in that case, based on Friday's verdict. Windmere employs about 300 people in Miami Lakes and has 50 to 100 other employees around the country, said Friedson. The company's manufacturing plants are in China and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Scandal-Plagued Home Builder Files For Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp. filed for federal bankruptcy protection Friday, less than a week after revealing a severe cash shortage and agreeing to a $100 million repayment program for victims of a scheme to sell overpriced homes. But it was not immediately known how the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in Miami will affect the restitution plan. The plan is part of a plea agreement to settle a 16-count federal indictment alleging that nearly 10,000 home buyers were deceived into purchasing homes at inflated prices. The 35-year-old company will retain present management, but the bankruptcy court will have control over efforts to borrow money or sell assets. Earlier this week, Miami-based General Development said it was considering a bankruptcy filing after negotiations for $60 million in short-term credit fell apart. The company's financial problems have caused delays in paying up to $10 million in property taxes and have cut back improvements and development at its communities. On Tuesday, General Development closed 24 sales offices in the United States and broker bureaus overseas and laid off about 1,100 workers. ``While we ... deeply regret having to take the step of filing for bankruptcy relief, our board determined that this action was necessary in light of the company's inability to secure additional financing to meet its short-term cash needs,'' said General Development President Charles Simons. The bankruptcy filing does not affect General Development's Vistana Resort and Glen Ivy subsidiaries, which operate time-share resorts near Disney World and the West. A statement from General Development said the company may present a financial restructuring plan within several months. General Development stock closed 37{ cents a share lower at $2.50 Friday in New York Stock Exchange trading. A master was appointed by the court Tuesday to review the restitution program before final approval. The victims of the overpricing scheme _ most from the Midwest and Northeast _ were charged an average of 40 percent above market value for homes at General Development's nine Florida communities, said prosecutors. Thomas Wood, a mortgage banker and attorney assigned to review the plan, said he has asked General Development to provide financial data by April 16. ``The Bankruptcy Court has its jurisdiction and the U.S. District Court has its own jurisdiction,'' said Wood. ``Right now, we are proceeding ahead with looking at the plan.'' Earlier this month, the company pleaded guilty to one fraud count that could bring a maximum $500,000 fine. Also, General Development's former president Robert Ehrling and former chairman David Brown pleaded guilty to one fraud count. Each faces a maximum of five years in prison, a $250,000 fine and restitution payments. Sentencing is scheduled for May 22.
